div.head: CHIRURGICAL INSTITUTIONS As Touching WOUNDS.
div.p:
IF, according to the ancient Sentence of the Stoicks, Man was bred and born for the publick good of his Neighbour: what greater ervice may be allowed in reaon to be performed for a Commonweale, then to tudy the health of its People; and the preerving their parts in vigour, form and beauty? And as the Learned and prudent Plutarch declares, that man had life given him from his Maker for Knowledge ake, the which doth as well procure Renown to his Name, as produce his Vertues into Action: o daily Experience doth evince, that the Indutrious hands, and unwearied Labours of men of worth and Learning, have been of great effect, ue, and benefit to all ages. And may we not well grant the ame of Chirurgery? where we may with pleaure and admiration view and behold, how variouly man, being either wounded, incied, pricked, battered, contued, or the like, is brought into a good form and hape by this excellent Art. It is he alone that can check fear in the Patient, and banih danger by his Judgment; foretell Symptoms, and prevent accidents: he is as well the Comfort in the Field, as a Friend in the City. It is by his practice and Art that divided parts are united, it's his Skill that keeps them thus united. And as Homer aith, we tand as much
in need of his help as we do of Water or Fire, < in non-Latin alphabet > . And for this reaon was it, that the Ancients taught their Scholars this Art of Chirurgery in their Schools, from whence alo they learned their firt rudiments and Intitutions.

And ince my preent task wholly relates to Wounds, I hall divide them into general and particular Dicoures. To thee alo have I adjoyned Gun-hot Wounds, and a particular dicoure of all kinds of Wounds of the Head, thence accompanying this Treatie with Wounds in particular, (viz.) uch as in their order may be aid to fall from thence to the Foot. And as every of thee do carry with them many differences, forms, hapes, and habits, it hall be my preent endeavour to acquaint the Young Chirurgion, how to provide and arm himelf againt thee, and with what neceary Intruments he may perform this task, and to conquer and cure the direfull Symptoms which attend many Wounds, which may inflict or accompany ome parts of the Body. And that I may place him in his right Tract, which may conduct him to the true and well management of thee: thee four things will necearily fall under our Confideration, being very proper engins in their places to be ued in Wounds, and thee are Ligatures, Medicines, Bolters and Pledgets, of each of which a particular repect is to be had, for they all require a right Order in their applications, both as touching their long or hort continuance at the part, a light paing by of which, doth very often prove detrimentall.

Ligature and its two Species. And firt as touching Ligature, of this there are propoed two contrary Species, the one to be made more trict, whilt the other may be made more looe. And thee two have diverity of parts allowed them, ome parts being property aid to be thick, and others called thin or rare. That part is accounted thick which is covered both with Bolters and Roulers, thee appointed both for keeping the part warm, and alo for making it more firm: that called or aid to be rare or
looe, which onely bindeth, not covereth. And thee alo are to be conidered according to the Times of the year, in which they are ued or aid to be applyed. Thus Winter time does generally allow to make more ue of thee then the Summer. Three fingers breadth for them is a very good allowance. Thoe Ligatures are generally accounted bet which are made and applyed mot naturally, and thoe do for the mot part expres the greatet honour to the Chirurgeon which are mot exquiitely performed by him. This made Wie Hippocrates affirm, that good Ligature doth delight the eye, as well as give the Patient atisfaction.

The next two hall be Section or Inciion, and Cautery or Inciion and Cautery. Adution; thee alo in ome caes are very uefull and neceary, and being either made ooner or later do carry an equall praie and etimate: for in ome caes Inciion is peedily required, and in thee, delay may bring pain and other bad Symptoms, and thee fix or place a new fear on the Patients front: But where many Inciions are to be made, a more deliberate care is to be had and ued, granting and allowing the Patient ome Intervalls of ret: and thee are to be o performed, as that they bring no pain to the Patient. To the well doing of which, the prompting of convenient Intruments and Medicines do much conduce, every one of which is to be dipoed in its proper Orb and Sphere, not hindring or detarding one another. Then are thee to be applied in their right method and form. The length and hortnes hereof ought alo to be conidered; and what Intruments are mot proper for the performance hereof: for ome parts of the body are of a peedy flux, and upon the light touch of a thin and mall Intrument heweth it elf, as Veins and Arteries, the which are not readily obtructed or topped: thee parts require mall inciions, and for this ue the Lancet or Inciion Knife are the bet Intruments. In places which are not o perillous, where the veels lie deep, and the bloud not o apparently contained, we may venture on larger Intruments. But of thee afterwards.

Cupping glaes. And becaue Cupping-glaes are generally reckoned amongt the Chirurgeons Intruments, I hall dicoure of thee here alo. Thee although they operate not as other Intruments doe, yet in many caes they are of great ue. Thee are called Concave Intruments, generally ued for Revulion, to be applied with, or without flame, by the benefit of which Intruments, the humour is fetcht from many parts of the body, and drawn to the part to which they are applied, and o is drawn forth. Thee alo are ometimes applied with or without Scarification. When there is occaion to make ue of Scarification, begin your Inciions from the lower parts, and o pas upward, for thus the bloud of every Scarified part will be apparent; the which on the contrary being made firt in the upper part, the bloud thence iuing will choak and obcure the mall Inciions which are made downwards, towards the lower part of the circle. Here alo are we with Galen to conider the differences of Inciions, thus properly to be made, for they ought to be either thin, uperficiall and lender, or deep and large, or of a ize between both. Now uch as are made uperficiall cannot draw from the remote parts: thee are neither aid to revell nor derive, but do only extract that humour which is cutaneouly lodged within. Others that are made more long, do educe much humour, as Orobaius witneeth of himelf, who upon having his Thigh carified when he lay ick of the Pet, had drawn from thence by the benefit of the Cupping-glas near two pounds of bloud, for this fetcht it from the remotet parts of his body, and at length perfectly recovered him. Cupping-glaes very uefull in three Repects.And for thee three caues they are accounted very uefull Intruments, becaue they do both Derive, Revell and Expurge the redundancy of humours which are lodged in the body, and do dicharge the ame by the mall Inciions opened by the Circle of the Glas, the which doth both ditend them and force the bloud to run more freely.

And becaue Extraction of Weapons, Splinters, Arrowheads, Darts, Bullets, uperfluous Fleh, Rags and the like, are a
very neceary point and Intention in Chirurgery, epecially in curing large and Gun-hot Wounds, I hall in the next place give you the names of uch Intruments as are mot in ue with us for the ame purpoe, (viz.) Crows Bills, Cranes Bills, Ducks Bills, Terebellum, Forcipes, and the lile. But becaue thee will appear more properly in their places of Gunhot Wounds, where alo their figures are preented, I will peak no more of them, onely here alluding this Caution, That there be not ued too much violence in Extraction of Obervat.thee extraneous Bodies, and to give and grant a jut time for the execution of this Intention. Knowing that moderation is ometimes allowed as advantagious, as remines or inconideratenes granted inuccesfull: and in ome caes it is not requiite to extract thee bodies through the Wound, they being ometimes fixed in a bone, or between bones; ometimes nature will lend her aiting hand to your work, if you give her time; and this, various Hitory makes good, and both former ages and our latter times have experienced the ame. Albucais writes of a Woman who having an Arrow Hitory.hot near her Belly, and lodged in her body, he recovered of her Wound. Ofttimes, after they have been lodged for many years, they frame a way for themelves and there dicharge by making Abcees for their Exition: and this you may ee confirmed by thee following Hitories. Alaharavius, Theoric. Tract. 6. cap. 1. writes that he aw a Another.man who had an Arrow hot into his Back, the which after even years made its way out. Gilbertus Anglicus lib. 5. Compend. writes of a man who having an Arrow hot into his Guts, Another.had it drawn forth with the Excrement, and that the man ecaped: but of thee expect more plentifully, in Gunhot Wounds. Sometimes it is alo requiite that the Wound it elf be dilated, for the more ready making way for its Exition: and then if you perceive the Extraneous body which is to be Extracted to be perfectly looe, you may remove it the firt dreing. But if it be only looe at one end, and fixed at the other, trive not too much for its removall,
let hereby you purchae ome ill accidents you cannot readily overcome and abate; as uch a flux of bloud as is not peedily to be topt, and therefore in uch caes are we to wait Natures leiure. Having thus hown you what large Intruments are bet and mot in ue in Gun-hot Wounds, you will find it a great advantage to gain the igns of thee infixed Weapons; for thoe being once known, there can be no place left of doubt which may terrify the Patient, or quetion the Chirurgeon; for it is the true Knowledge of Signs which do haten and promote the cure. Here alo is to be conidered the frequent differences of Weapons, and thee are carefully to be oberved, and with thee the variety of the parts into which they are infixed, for on thee two does the difficulty of the cure and Extraction chiefly depend, as hall elewhere more at large appear. Now the Differences of Weapons.differences of Weapons are taken from their matter, being made either of Wood, Glas, Iron, Steel, Bras, or the like; from their Figure, being either Round, Triangular, Fourquare, having harp Points, Bearded; from their Magnitude, being either large, mall, or of middle ize; from their number, being either one or many, Simple or Compound; from their habit, ome of which being harp pointed with Iron heads, others Concave; ome firmly fixed to the Wood, others more looely et; and latly they differ much in their Quality and Vigour, ome being venomed, others not. As to the parts affected, thee are evident enough from the property of accidents, which they hew: and where all thee are found out, the Cure goes on with peed and ucces; for Galens Proverb is very true, Dimidium facti, qui bene coepit, habet. And he that thus oweth the eeds of his Art may well expect to reap a plentifull Crop of Honour and advantage to himelf, as well as Eae and Comfort to his Patient.

And as touching proper Medicines required in curing Wounds; the times of Purging and Dyet required therein; of the diverity of Wounds, and variety of Intruments,
and Medicines, as he ought alwaies to have about him, I hall in their proper order et down. The Young The Chirurgeons Box thus to be furnihed.Chirurgeon hould have his Box thus furnihed with Intruments: with Sizzers to cut, Forcipes to Extract, a Spatula to mix Unguents, and pread Emplaters. A Spatula Linguae for depreing the Tongue. Inciion Knife to make Fontinels, and dilate any part. Probes to earch the depth of Wounds. vula Spoon to melt any Balome, and alo ued in Relaxation of the vula, the which after its being retored, is to be kept up by Retringent Powders being blown through this thither. A Stitching Quill to keep his Needles. The upper part of his Box being alwaies furnihed with Lint for making Tents, Doils and Pledgets, and the lower part to be armed with convenient Emplaters. In his Salvitory he hould have thee Unguents in readines. nguent. Bailicon, In his Salvitory thee Unguents. or Aureum or Fucum to diget, nguentum Apotolorum to mundify, nguent. Dialthaeae to eae pain, Balam. Lucatelli, or Linimentum Arcei to fill up with fleh, nguent. Deiccativum Rubrum, Diapompholigos, or Album Camphoratum to skin, dry up, and eae pain. In his Lancet Cae Lancet Cae.he hould have everall Lancets, a Capital Raour, and an Inciion Knife; all thee he ought at all times to be ready furnihed with: beides thee he hould have alo a Sett of large Intruments, amongt which may be reckoned thee. Crows Bills, Cranes Bills, Terebellum, Large Forcipes, Cutting Large Intruments. Forcipes for Extraction, Inciion Sizzers, Probe Sizzers, Dimembring Knife, Catlins, Dimembring Saw, Capital Saw; Trafines with heads for Inciion and Amputation; Probes of all orts for Probation; Syringes for Injection; Catheters, Wax-Candles for Examination; Cauterizing Buttons for prevention of Haemorrhagy, and topping of Fluxes; Splints and Junks for Fractures; Tape, Tow and Sponges for their everall ues.

Having thus given you an account of his Intruments, next we will proceed to Emplaters: and there give you Of Emplaters.a recital of their Vertues. Thus Empl. Diapalma or
Diacalcitheos, hath a repelling faculty, is good againt Inflammations, Healeth, Dryeth, and procures a Cicatrice. Oxycroceum, Emolliates, Dicues, Warms and Strengthens. Diachylon magnum cum gummi, Emolliates, Concocts and Digets, Attracts and Diolves. Empl. de Mucilaginibus, this partly Mollifies, and partly Digets, and in ome meaure does Suppurate, and is generally reckoned amongt the Emollients and Suppuratives. Empl. de Betonica is generally ued in Wounds of the Head, it retoreth Fleh being lot, it Digeteth and Cicatrizeth. Empl. de minio doth the ame things as Diapalma. Empl. ad Herniam does both Strengthen and Contringe the looe parts, good in Obtructing of Fluxes, for Ruptures and the like, for which reaon it had given it the name of Rupture Playter. Empl. de Ranis cum , this is very reolving, being applied to venereal Buboes or Nodes, it acts its part very well in dicuing them. Empl. Stiptic. Paraceli an uuall Emplater, applied to Pains and Aches, Contuions and Colds: for it warms and comforts.

Having given you thus a brief account of Emplaters: we arrive now to the undertanding of the appropriation of Medicines, and thee for the mot part do fetch their names from the proper places to which they are to be applied, as thus for Example.
The appropriation of Medicines. Cephalicks, Being uch Medicines as are uually applied to the Head, o called from < in non-Latin alphabet > , Caput.
Pectorals, Such as are appropriated to the Breat or Lungs, and thee regard both the parts afflicted, and the matter afflicting.
Oreticks, Thee applied to the Stomach, the which having allowed a pleaant harpnes may contract it, and by their delicate Tat delight and pleae it.
Hepaticks, Ordered to the Liver for Strengthening it, correcting its Vices, Opening its Obtructions, and tempering its Inflammations.
Spleneticks, Properly precribed for the Spleen, in order to help its Infirmities and relieve its Oppreions.
Nephriticks, Such Medicines as are aigned to the Bladder and Kidnies.
Hytericks, Thee ordered and deigned for the Womb.

Arthriticks, Such as appertain to the Joynts. And having pat thee, I hall next et down the everall names of Medicines as they are entituled, and hew you the reaons of their being o called, from their everall Operations. Thus,
Emollients, From their oftning Quality which they have granted them.
Relaxers, Such o called, which are aid to looen any Part or Member.
Rarifyers, Being of thin and ubtile Parts, can make Tough and Flegmatick humours rare and thin by their proper Qualities.
Aperitives, So nominated from Opening the mouths of the Veels.
Attenuators, Such as by a gentle outting Quality, do looen the Bowels and open Obtructions.
Atringents, So called from their drying Quality, binding up the places where they are applied, and knitting the parts.
Attractives, Thee profeing the contrary Quality, do by their heat and thinnes draw humours to any part of the Body they are deigned for.
Dicuives, thee gently do dipere Matter, and inenibly diolve it.
Anodynes, By a gentle heat do eae Pain, and abate its fury.
Narcoticks, By their cold and tupifying Quality do eae pain alo.
Carminatives, Thee Expell Wind by their anodyne Quality.
Diaphoreticks, Thee provoke Sweat, and do work by inenible Tranpiration.
Pyroticks, By their heat and burning faculty do burn the Skin.
Suppuratives, By a Natural heat do bring Bloud, raw and indigeted Humours into Matter, and ripenes.
Incarnatives or Epouloticks, Do generate new Fleh by changing Bloud into Fleh.
Agglutinatives, By their agglutinating Quality do joyn the Lips of Wounds together.
Cicatrizers, by their drying and binding Quality do skin and cover the Fleh.
Inward Medicines are alo very various, and have therefore diverity of names given them according to the variety of their Operations, as for Example.
We call thoe Catharticks, which work downwards by Siege.
Emeticks, Thoe which contrariwie work upward by Vomit.
Diureticks, Thoe carrying on their deigns by Urine.
Sudorificks, Thoe throwing forth the Excrements by Sweat.
Ptermicks or Sternutatories, Purging the Brain by Sneezing.
Salivaticks, Thoe cleaning the paages of the Brain and its glandules by Spittle.

Having thus given you in this mall draught all the Utenils properly belonging to the Young Chirurgeon, with his Intruments and Medicines, and howing you their true appropriation; and the reaons of mot of their Names why they hould be o called:

I hall conclude thee my Chirurgical Intitutions with a brief and generall Diviion of Wounds according as they are offered by the bet of Chirurgeons: with their differences, and Names of Solution of Continuity as they are et down by Galen lib. 4. Method. and thus they appear.

row.cell: The generall Diviion of Wounds. A Solution made by a Wound in the Flehy parts.
A Convulion or Ditenion in a Nerve.

div.p: That is

or Inhumoratio, Which is made when the Bloud is poured forth under the Skin, and Coagulates, happening by Contuions and Ruptions.
[or Apertion of the Mouths of the Veels.
or Trancolation, or Exilition, The Coat of the Sanguinary Veels being made thin, the Bloud alo being attenuated.
or Eroion, The which is inwardly incident to Veins and Arteries: bred out of ome ill Juice which carrieth a mordent Quality in it.

lg.l: Excoriation and Scarification, in the Cutis.
A Wound or Cut, in the New and Cruent Fleh.

div.head: The General Differences of New or freh Wounds by Guido, and other Chirurgeons of our Age are taken from thee Three. (viz.)
div.p: 1. From the nature of the parts in which they conit.
2. From the eence of Solution of Continuity it elf.
3. From the proper Differences of the Solution it elf excited out of the Wound.

div.head: 1. Differences of Wounds are taken from the nature of parts.

q.l: And herein a Wound may be aid to be either in a Similar or Organick part.

div.p: A Wound in a Similar part may be either, oft, hard, or between both.
That is aid to be in a oft Similar part, when it happens in Fleh or Fat.
That in a hard Similar part, when it falls on a Bone or Juncture.
That between both, when it happens in a Nerve, Ligament, Tendon, Vein or Artery.
That Wound is aid to happen in an Organick part, when it toucheth the principal part: or uch a part, as is ubervient to it; or in a principall part not ubminitring to it.
That is called a Wound in a Principall part which happens in the Heart, Brain, or Liver.
That in a part ubervient to thee, when it happens in the Oeophagus, Windpipe, or Bladder.
That a Wound not ubervient to any Member in a Principall part, as a Wound in the Noe, Ears, Eyes, Hand, or Foot.

div.head: The Differences of Wounds are alo taken from the Eence of the Solution of Continuity it elf.

q.l: And here alo we may properly call them either Simple or Compound Wounds.

div.p: That is aid to be a Simple Wound, which hath no other affect complicated.
That a Compound Wound, being conitent with many other complicated affects.

div.head: The Differences of Wounds are taken from their proper differences of Solution of Continuity it elf.
div.p: And herein alo may a Wound be aid to be either Great or Small, Short or Long, Broad or Narrow, Superficiall or deep, equall or unequall, right or oblique, retort or crooked: according to the Space, Quantity, Figure or Magnitude of the Diviion.

div.head: There are other Differences of Wounds, but thee by Galen are taken for Outward Accidents.
div.p: As firt ariing from the reaon of their Generation.
Then from the ite or place of the affected part.

Such differences of Wounds as are allowed to arie in repect of their Generation, may be allowed to be Diruption, Inciion, partly one, and partly the other; as Puncture of a Nerve, Preciion of a Nerve, and Preciion of an Artery.
Such differences of Wounds as arie from the Site of the affected part, are either according to their Length, or Tranvernes, happening in the beginning, middle, or tail of a Mucle.
There may be other Differences allowed by ome, as uch as happen from the Complexion of the Wound, and the like; but thee are improperly o called.

Having thus far et the Young Chirurgeon onwards in his Journey and Progres towards our enuing Dicoure; (in which Tract I have hown him how he is to be armed, and furnihed with Intruments and Medicines:) we arrive now at the Dicoure it elf of Wounds both General and Particular, the which I have furnihed and embroidered with variety of Hitoricall Obervations and Notes worthy of his peruall. I hall not well with too large a Preface, let it appear o montrous as rather to affright than atisfy the Young Reader. Concluding thee Chirurgical Intitutions with that Vere of the Poet:

q.l: Si mea dipliceant, fac meliora precor.

div.head: A TREATISE OF Wounds in general.
CHAP. I.
Of the Definition of a Wound.
div.p: What a Wound is. IT is and hath been the current Opinion of all Ages, and amongt all Authours, that a Wound does take its Definition from olution of Continuity or divorce of Parts. And although by Quacks and ignorant men there is made no great difference between a Simple and a Compound Wound yet that there is a very vat difference, no man that ever practied his Art with Judgment can deny. The truth is, the Scale tands in this cae, as in others, with uch kind of luggih Droans and ignorant Pretenders, whoe Cures may more properly be called Corruptions, and whoe pretended Judgments may as conentaneouly be owned onely as Ignorance plumed out and et forth with the bet advantage of Impudence. But to leave thoe as Idle Companions, we fall to our preent Task.

The true Definition of a Wound. A wound is called a recent divorce, or olution of Unity; or a diviion of Parts formerly united, without
Matter. Tagaultius offereth it to be a new Cruent Solution without Matter or Putridnes, happening in the oft parts by ome outward caue. Haliabbas declares, that a Wound may be made by an animate or inanimate Body. Pareus writes, that it may happen from a blow or a fall. Aquapendens, by or from ome outward Intrument: this offering it elf with ome violence in the oft parts. But there are other Solutions in other parts as well as in thee oft parts, and every of thee have allowed them their proper Names; the which I have already et down in my general Dicoure of Wounds. And after thee be pleaed to take this as a true definition of a Wound, That it is a Solution of Continuity bloudy or cruent, and recent, made newly in the Fleh by uch an Intrument as hath a power to occaion a divorce of parts formerly united. There are everal differences of Wounds, and thee are either taken from their caues by which they are occaioned, or from their accidents wherein they are cituated. The Caues may be allowed to be with, or without life: with life, as occaioned by the biting of ome venomous Beat, or other uch like Creature; without life, happening by ome Sword, Stone, Blow, Arrow or the like. The Scituation doth afford and allow various Differences, as ome Wounds happening in the Simple parts, others in the Organick. Under the Simple parts may be reckoned both the Sanguine and Spermatick, and to thee do relate Mucles, Nerves, Veins and Arteries. Thoe we more properly call the Organick parts, which are nearer related to the whole bulk. Others thereof belonging more directly to ome particular Member thereof. Now Wounds of the whole Trunk are generally allowed thee, (viz.) as being of the Head, Neck, Breat and Belly. Wounds of the Articulations are thoe which are of the Joynts, or Shoulders, Arms, Thighs and Legs. But this you hall have more largely et down in this following Chapter.

div.head: CHAP. II.
Of the Differences of Wounds.
div.p: GAlen, Avicen, Guido, and others when they write of the Differences of Wounds, they either draw them from the Parts, and thee are either Similar or Organick; the Similar being either oft as Fleh and Glandules, or hard as Bones and Cartilages; or between both, as Nerves, Veins, Ligaments and Arteries: thoe called Organick, as being made in the Principall parts, as in the Head, Hand or o forth; and of thee ome are Simple, others Compound; the firt we have already hown, the lat may appear either mild or malign; the firt being cured with eae, as a mall Wound happening in the Flehy parts, the other being of greater danger, being complicated with malignity, as occaioned by a venenate Weapon, or poyonous Bite; and thee are perillous, conidering either their Impreion, Time, Figure, or Parts wherein they are made and fixed, as falling in ome noble part, being made either ooner or later; with, or without los of Subtance; in a large, middle or mall Figure and the like: thee alo are to be dicovered either by Sight or Probation.

The difference between a Wound and an Ulcer. And having proceeded thus far: we next come to view the difference between a Wound and an Ulcer. And that both Wounds and Ulcers may arie from Externall and Interiour Intruments, hall be made good in my following dicoure.

A Wound, as is already laid down, is a Recent and cruent Solution without Matter; an Ulcer hath Matter joyned to it: And as a Wound is occaioned by an outward
Intrument, having in it an Inciive power allowed to caue this breach: o alo is an Ulcer purchaed by an inward Eroion or eroive Humour. The Differences of Wounds, as Avicen offereth in ecund. Fenn. prim. Canon. are taken from their varieties of Solution.

The Dicriminances of Wounds are taken either from the repect of the Subject, as Galen writes 3 Art. parv. as ome Wounds happening in a Homogeneous, others in a Heterogeneous part; or from the Eence, in which repect it is called a Simple Wound; as he alo oberveth Tertio Method. to which neither Dieae nor any other Symptome is complicated. On the contrary he alloweth that to be a Compound, to which omewhat is connexed or adjoyned: as you may ee in 4 Method. Or they are taken from the quantity which is olved and divided: but of thee more at large in their proper places. Wounds alo may be made either by Puncture, Inciion, Ruption, or Contuion. Thoe called Punctures, which are made by Thruts with Swords, Pikes, Knifes, Daggers, and uch harp pointed Intruments. Thoe Inciions, which are made lengthwaies, either by Knifes or Backwords: (the Rapier being a very proper Intrument for making Punctures) or any other Intrument having a harp cutting Edge. Thoe do caue Ruption, which by an egregious and violent Motion, can divel and divide the parts. Thoe allowed to Contue, which are of a ponderous Exitence: as Wood, Stone, Lead, Iron, Steel, Bras, and the like.

The difference between a Wound and a Contuion. I'le conclude this dicoure with the difference between a Wound and a Contuion: and thus as the firt is occaioned by a harp pointed or edged Intrument, o the latter is framed by a blunt and obtue Intrument; having in it a violent Motion allowed it to eparate the parts.

div.head: CHAP. III.
Of Judgments and Preages of Wounds.
div.p: WE arrive now to the Healthfull or Lethall Symptoms of Wounds, wherein the Chirurgeon hould not only appear < in non-Latin alphabet > but < in non-Latin alphabet > . And as it is one of his fair Graces and Ornaments to know well and undertand what Wounds are incurable: o ought it alo to be his greatet reaon and prudence not to undertake uch, as he jutly mut acknowledge he hath no Authority or encouragement from Art to be concerned with: and were thee much practied, the Art of Chirurgery would not fall to that low degree as it appears now in.

To know the events of Wounds, and to preage the good or bad tidings of the Patient wounded, is a thing abolutely neceary for the Chirurgeon to undertand; for in this cae does the life of Man very oft conit and depend. The Prognotick igns of thee are taken either from the ubtance, ue, and action of any part; or from the proper eence of its dipoition or effect: thus Galen lib. 4 Therapeutic. does declare, that large and great Wounds bring ofttimes much danger with them.

General Preages of Wounds. Wounds made by three quared Weapons are alo dangerous, conidering either the Excellency of the part afflicted, or the greatnes of the affect, or the form and hape of the Intrument afflicting and cauing the Wound.
Of the Head and Thorax. Wounds received in the Head, or Thorax, or penetrating the Peritonaeum do bring danger with them, epecially if any of the inward parts be Wounded.

Of Nerves and Sinews. Such Chirurgeons who by Anatomy do well undertand the parts, may well conjecture, where Tendons or Nerves are pricked or cut, there follow Pains, Convulions, and fear of Delirium.
Of the Noble Parts. Hippocrates telleth us, when the Bladder, Brain, Heart, Diaphragma, mall Guts, Stomach or Liver are wounded, the Wound does generally prove Mortall.

In a bad Complexioned Member. Every Wound happening in a Member of the Body which is not well complexioned, and having a cacochymick habit, is not to be cured without difficulty; whereas on the contrary happening in a Body of good Contitution it peedily is cured.
Every Wound continuing its uperficiall march from one part to another, cannot be good, becaue in this cae, Nature may be aid not to have found a place to begin her work.
Not pat danger till the 7th Day be pat. Wounds are not pat danger untill the 7th Day be over, neither are they void of accidents untill the Matter be well digeted.

No Tumour in large Wounds appearing is a bad ign. Happening in the ends of Mucles wore then in their middle.Wounds in the ends of the Mucles are more dangerous then if they were in the middle: Nature having here planted Tendons and Nerves, the which do bring Motion and Sene to the body of the Mucle.
Never expect to cure Wounds of the Bones, Nerves, Tendons, Veins, Arteries, according to the firt intention.
Cloe not up large Wounds by Suture, which are alo deep, let by your inconideratenes, and unadviednes, you permit corrupt Matter, Excrements, or other filth to lodge in the bottome.

Small Wounds ometimes do prove dangerous. Superficiall Wounds in ome caes may prove dangerous; as Wounds happening in the Brain: whilt others being more deeply made, prove not o perilous happening in the flehy parts.
Contued Wounds are Oppoite to Healing, for before you begin your Art of Healing you mut produce the Contued part into Matter and Suppuration.
Wounds which are made round, or occaioned by a round Intrument, do require a longer time of healing, then thoe which are made by a treight Intrument.
Recent or new Wounds are ooner healed then uch which are of a longer continuance.
Convulion happening in Wounds is dangerous; for this declares the hurt of ome Nervous part.

A Tumour in large Wounds preages well, for this heweth that Nature is at her Expulive Work, throwing forth the Excrements which lodged and were contained in the parts, and dicharging them from the part affected.
Preages of Mortall Wounds. Organick parts once divided deny any other or further Union.
That we for the mot part, and mot generally do call a Mortall or Lethall Wound, the which within the pace of few hours doth caue Death, and is not to be retrieved by Art.

Wounds of the Heart. Wounds penetrating the ubtance of the Heart, mut of neceity be allowed Mortall: for this being toucht, the liveliet Coal of mankind is oon extinguihed; the whole Train of Bloud making its peedy addres hither, from the Veins and Arteries as mall Rivulets to the Ocean; this being its chief Engine of Life and Motion, and emptying themelves thus of their warmth and Spirits, every part doth take its hare of its ruine: and thus out of this large profuion of Bloud, there follows a reolution of Spirits, the which brings a Chillines upon all the Extreme parts, an extinction of Natures Heat, Syncope of Spirits, Banihment of Life, and a peedy yielding to Death; for as Avicen aith, The Heart can never uffer a long Solution of Continuity, neither endure an Apoteme with Life.

Wounds of the Brain. Thee Wounds are for the mot part accounted Mortall: but not every of thee. For daily Experience evinceth, that part of the Brain hath been taken out, and the Patient hath recovered: and this you may ee by Example in Wounds of the Head, though the undertanding of the Patient have been lot. Thoe therefore are generally accounted Mortall, when a Nerve is hurt, when Bloud, or other Humours do obtruct the Origination of the Nerves; when within a mall time the putrefied Bloud does produce a Fever and Delirium. The Membranes of the Brain being wounded do occaion Sneezing, and Vomiting, bleeding at the Noe, and the like; and if the ubtance of the Brain be wounded, there is perceived a Bilious Vomiting, and Fever; the Undertanding grows tupid, the Memory flags, Sene and Reaon bepeak new Quarters, and the whole Frame and Countenance do agree to alteration; this being the Well-pring of the Animall faculty. A Fever and Inflammation, two common Attendants on Wounds, happening in the bais of the Brain do make the Wound incurable.

Of Wounds of the Liver. Wounds of the Liver, if mall, although dangerous, yet they admit of Conolidation; the whole ubtance thereof being as it were made of grumous or coagulated Bloud: yet large Wounds happening here are very dangerous; becaue by reaon of the defect of its Nutrition, the Heart languiheth and flags: and in large and deep Wounds of the Liver the Vena Porta being cut, the Patient o wounded dies of a Flux of Bloud.

Wounds of the Vena Cava. Wounds received in the Vena Cava within the Abdomen or Thorax, are declared Mortall; for that Bloud which formerly ued to repenih and furnih the whole Body, is by reaon hereof run into a confued mas; and is pat the skill of a Chirurgeon to cure by any Topicall applications.

Wounds of the Diaphragma. Wounds received in the Flehy parts of the Midriff may be curable, but happening in the Nervous parts are generally
mortally, becaue a Delirium goes along with them, occaioned by Inflammations; and ometimes Convulion, becaue it is a nervous part, and without bloud, and in continuall motion. And for a generall Rule let it be taken, that nervous Bodies do never unite, being once divided; epecially here where they are in continuall motion.

Wounds of the Lungs. The Lungs being wounded, the Breathing is difficult, the Pipes and Organs are out of tune, and a troubleome and incongruous muick is made, with fale Repiration. They are generally mortall, if a large Veell belonging to them be divided. If any Wounds of the Lungs be cured, they commonly do prove o michievous as to turn into Fitula's, and o in length of time do pin a man's life out by Marame, and run him into a Conumption. And that which makes their healing o difficult is, becaue in their motion they are always moved, and in coughing they are lacerated.

Wounds of the Spleen. Wounds of the Spleen, becaue it acteth the part of a econd Liver, and hath a common benefit allowed it, the which it ditributeth to the whole Body, and therefore is a neceary Intrument, are dangerous: and yet not o perillous as the other Parts, which we have already dicoured of. And if thee Wounds have not a great Haemorrhagy joyned to them, they are not o deadly, but they may be cured.

Wounds of the Bladder of Gall. Wounds here happening, although not on a udden, yet in proces of time do auredly bring Death with them, and o are not to be cured. For it is an exanguous and nervous part, and o denieth Union; therefore can we no waies apply convenient medicines to it. Beides which alo, the Humours do corrupt the parts unto which they are ent.

Wounds of the Ventricle. The Stomack wounded brings much terrour. The Wounds here generally do prove mortall which do happen in its upper Orifice, or in the Nerves ditributed on the Stomack: for thee do afford it that exquiite ene which
it hath, and upon their inciion, Syncope and Convulions do frequently follow. If it be wounded in the upper part, it may be cured, becaue in that part it hath allowed it a mall part of Fleh.

Wounds of the Small guts. Wounds happening in the Small guts are eldome cured, they being of a membranous ubtance, and of an exquiite ene. Wounds of the Great guts admit of a more eay Cure, being both more large and more thick.
Wounds of the Kidneys. Thee are not mortall. If the Wound do penetrate into the Cavity it elf, for the mot part an Ulcer follows, which conumeth the whole Kidney.

Wounds of the Meentery. The Meentery being wounded, inevitable Death mut follow. For as there mut be a great Flux of bloud enue from the Veins inerted and planted therein; o alo mut there needs be a great los of Chyle, the milky Veells being either incied or lacerated.

Wounds of the Windpipe. The Apera Arteria being hurt may be cured. If the Cartilaginous Rings be hurt or wounded, expect no cure thereof: for thee little hard Cartilaginous bodies being without bloud, and always in motion, if they be wounded, the Breath which paeth through it is a great impediment to the Cure, and joyning the lips of the Wound together.
Wounds of the Spinall marrow. Wounds of the Spinall marrow are always mortall which do happen in the Neck, or near the Head: but thoe that happen under thee are of les danger.
Wounds of the Bladder. Thee are eldome perfectly cured, but there remains ome gleeting. But thoe that are made in the muculous part of the Bladder may be cured.

Wounds of the great Veins, Arteries and Nerves. Wounds of the great Veins and Arteries are generally mortall, and Wounds of the great Nerves are incurable. The Jugular Veins being wounded are eldome cured, by reaon of the great Flux of bloud hereupon made, drawing forth Man's vitall pirits, and no proper method being found out to hinder this Flux, without danger of uffocation.

Take care of cutting the Artery which paeth through
the fore-part of any Mucle, but hun it by Exploration of its Pule, and keep the Vein if poible inviolate. If the recurrent Nerves be divided or wounded, there follows los of Speech, Sene and Motion. Thus have I run through the Preages of Wounds curable and incurable; in which the young Chirurgeon may plentifully atisfy himelf.

div.head: CHAP. IV.
Of Curing Wounds in General.
div.p: GAlen, lib. Art. medic. cap. 90. aith, the common Intention required in the Cure of Wounds is the Union of the Parts diunited: and this is performed by Nature as the proper Agent, and the Caue effecting it, aited by its virtues, and a convenient Nutriment. And thus as Art does remove the Impediments, Nature her elf does ait towards the Cure of the Dieae, which of her elf he cannot readily perform, where her native Heat is weak, the Bloud vitiated, or the Flux large; every of which are to be corrected and amended. As the native Generall Rules.Heat is to be preerved by a good Diet, and well ordering the Body. Where the Bloud is vitiated, this is to be amended and corrected by Purging. Where it flows too much, this is to be repelled, revelled, or derived, and the like.

Hippocrates his difference between a Simple and a Compound wound. Hippocrates does propoe two orts of Wounds: the one he calls Simple, the other Compound. The Simple he calls Solution of Continuity, having no other Affect joyned to it, perplexed with no Fluxion, not abounding with any ill Juice, or undermined with any Intemperies, without any apparent Cavity or Los of fleh. A Compound Wound, on the contrary, hath the repute of Los of fleh,
an adjunct Caue, Affect, or Symptome. A Simple wound taken therefore in its prime ene does onely require Deiccation. A Compound, to which may be annexed Contuion, hath alo a mixture of Inflammation; and this hindreth Union and Agglutination. In this cae therefore the Chirurgeon is firt to cure the Inflammation, then to proceed to the Wound. Green wounds, and their neighbouring Parts, are but mally inflamed, if Matter may be procured: for Wounds do onely then inflame, when they do not uppurate. For they uppurate by a trange Bloud, and Heat, untill the putrefying Wound occaioneth another Matter. And if Exition be not made for this Matter, it being uppreed, it excites Inflammation about the wounded part, and breeds and begets an ill Habit therein, and rendreth both the Wound and its neighbouring parts ordid and corrupt.

The chief Intention in curing a Simple wound is Deiccation, this being mot proper for the purpoe: and whereas the whole Body does abound with moit Humours, thee alo in ome meaure are to be dried up by Abtinence, and a thin Diet. Where any part of the Cutis is incied, no Oleaginous medicine can take place: for this eaily penetrates and entereth the Pores of the skin, and does there create a Moiture, in tead of Deiccation or Drines; and may therefore be allowed rather to hinder then et forward the Cure. But this chiefly belongeth to a Simple wound, and uch as is uperficiall: but our Dicoure doth motly tend to other Wounds, where the chief Scope and Intention is to unite thoe Parts which are divided; which thing is performed by thee ix Intentions: (viz.) by Stopping the Flux of bloud, and hindring Inflammation thereby; Removing all trange and extraneous Bodies; Bringing the Lips of the Wound together; Maintaining their Union; Keeping their Subtance and Temper entire; and Preventing all future Accidents. Every of which expect to meet in their Order.

div.head: CHAP. V.
Of Stopping an immoderate Flux.
div.p: AS the Heart is the chief Watch of man's Life, whoe pulefying wheels do give motion, life and vigour to it, by having adjoyned and allowed it its main Spring of Bloud which is given it from the Arteries, which Spirits thence enuing do operate as the chief Workman therein, and without which Man would oon run into diolution; and as the Bloud is the Treaure of Nature, without which Life appears but as a dead clod: o ought we to tudy its continuance with us, and in large Fluxes occaioned either by Inciion, Ruption, or Diviion of any large Veell, with care and diligence to tudy its peedy reerve, by applying uch Medicines as may command a quick obtruction of this Haemorrhagy. The Wound which we intend to treat of in this place is not of the large Veells, being either incied or lacerated: but when the maller Veins are incied, this Flux is to be peedily topped, unles it pontaneouly and timely do retrain and check it elf.

To conider two things in topping of Fluxes. And in obtructing or calling back this Flux, we ought to conider thee two things: (viz.) How much the part may be uffered to bleed, before it be topped; and then, How this Obtructing operation is to be performed.

And as touching the Firt; The Temper, Contitution, Time, Complexion and Habit are to be conidered. For if the Patient be of a Sanguine Complexion, corpulent Habit, having large Veells, and it be Summer-time, here the Patient may be permitted to bleed plentifully, both for preventing Inflammation, and Fluxion, and Fever. And if you meet with a Patient of contrary Qualities, diverify
your Intentions, according to uch Rules as you have precribed, contrary to the former.
Eight methods in topping of a Flux. As touching the Second; There are offered Eight methods of topping this Flux of bloud precribed by Dr. Alexander Read, the which I hall here briefly et down.

1. The Firt is performed by Pledgets, Buttons, Doills, Tents, and the like, being armed with ome Retrictive, that is, moitned in the Whites of egges, Vinegar, and Water, &c. to which alo may be added a little Bolearmeniack: thee to be applied warm; for nothing doth greater injuries to Wounds then Cold.

2. The Second is Deligation of the Veell which endeth forth the bloud. But this ofttimes proves troubleome Note.and uncertain. And where you intend to ue this method, eparate the Nerve from the Vein; for they generally keep company together throughout the whole Body; let by unadvied neglect of this, you do deprive the Nerve both of its motion and ene, and hereby purchae great pain to your Patient. Take care alo that the Ligature be not made too trict; for this is a ready way to cut and divide the Veells aunder, and hereby create a new Flux.

3. A Third method is performed by Sarcoticks or Incarnative medicines, uch as are Myrrh, Aloes, Frankincene, Dragons bloud, Matick, Amber, Olibanum, Bolearmeniack, Powder of Hares hair, and the like, mixed with the White of an egge, Vinegar and Water, and thus made into a good Conitence, and o to be applied to the affected part. Before which application cleane the Wound from all grumous and clotted bloud, and every other excrementitious matter; and with a Sponge being dipt in ome Retringent Liquour moiten the parts: then may you apply your Retrictives. Over which apply convenient Boulters and Rowlers. Ever oberving to begin your Ligature or Ligation in the lower part, making it acend upwards, and o to pas above the Wound; both for topping the Flux of Humours coming to the Wound, and alo for
compreion of the Coagulated bloud to the Wound it elf, for its Exition.

4. A Fourth method is performed by Retrictive Injections: thee to be ued when the wounded Veells ly low or deep, o as we cannot reach them with our fingers. And for this ue thee are proper, Bolearmen. Plantane, Comfrey, Knot-gras, Yarrow, Shepheards-pouch, Red roes, Balautians, Pomegranate-rindes, Oaken leaves and cups, Myrtills, and the powder of a dried Toad burnt in an earthen veell, having allowed it a trong retringent quality. Thee and the like may be made into Decoctions, being boiled in ome retringent Wine, or ome convenient Liquour.

5. The Fifth is acted by a tranvere Inciion; for this procureth a gathering up or hrivelling of the Veells towards their Originations. This by Galen's advice is to be attached by the Hook, and then the Veell to be twited.

6. The Sixth is performed by Cautick, and this either actuall or potentiall. This for the mot part is requiite in Amputation, and not to be ued upon every triviall occaion: for as it brings fear to the Coward, o alo its effects are not alwaies certain. And before you ue thee, be ure to cleane the Veells from all grumous bloud, that you may perfectly ee to what parts you apply them. For by an unadvied mitake of putting this into memory, and o into action, you onely cauterize the coagulated bloud, the which falling off, there is made a fair way for a new Flux.
7. The Seventh is performed by Revulion, as by Frictions, Opening of a vein, Ligatures, and Cupping-glaes: thee being applied to the oppoite parts, if need require are to be repeated.
8. The Lat is to cool the whole Body, and hereby thicken the Bloud, and make it les apt to flow, by inward uing and taking of Rice, Lentills, Atringents, Atringent Fruits, and harp Wines.

div.head: CHAP. VI.
Of Removing extraneous Bodies.
div.p: THE next duty and Intention of a Chirurgeon is to remove all extraneous Bodies, which may be allowed to hinder Union and Conjunction of the parts dijoyned. And that every thing herein may be acted according to Reaon, Judgement and Art, we are firt to enquire into the Shape and form of the Intrument which is thus lodged: and this may be collected and gathered from the Contemplation of the nature and diverity both of the hurt Parts, and alo of the Matters therein fixed. And thee two being coniderately weighed and undertood, the third thing, which next doth offer it elf, is the true method of Extracting thee. And becaue the Matter and Subtances hereof may be various, as being made either of Wood, Iron, Glas, Bone, Bras, Lead, or the like; and their Figures as divere, being aid to be either Long, Round, Square, or Flat; and whereas their Number is different, being One or Many, Simple or Compound; and their Magnitude is various, being Greater or Smaller; beides thee, their Habits being as trange, ome Arrows made with harp Iron heads fixed to them, others concave Intruments, and thee alo differing in their vigour and faculty, ome being ent with, others without poion: Thee and every of thee ought to be well conidered. But expect more hereof in Gunhot-wounds.

Hippocrates lays this down as a Maxime, That he who would deal with Wounds aright, ought well to undertand the Diagnotick part of his Art, before he undertakes the Therapeutick; and alo to be well skilled in the nature of the Parts, before he precribes a Reaon for a Cure: it being one of his greatet Ornaments, to undertand
which Wounds are curable, which are incurable, and which are difficult to cure. I hall hew the Intruments, and farther dicoure of them, at the end of this Chapter; and proceed for the benefit of the young Chirurgeon.

He is to oberve and take notice, that in Extraction of extraneous Bodies, he well conider the Shape and figure of the Intrument or other Body which is to be extracted, and how deep it hath penetrated; and being well skilled in Anatomy, he may eaily undertand the frame of the Parts wherein the Weapon is infixed: that hereby he may with more pleaantnes, and les fear, wiely undertake the Patient, to his own credit, and the Patient's eae and comfort. And to every of thee he is to undertand that he hath thee four things adjoyned: as firt, to know when it is mot fit to extract thee Bodies; next, what way is the bet for their Extraction; then, what Figure is mot proper; and then, what Intruments mot requiite for the performing of thee. I hall enlarge a little upon each of thee, they being very materiall for the young Chirurgeon.

If the pain be intolerable, and the infixed Weapon may commodiouly and with afety be drawn forth, if it be o looely fixed as by a mall moving it will eparate from the Part, draw this forth at the firt, for hereby you will both eae pain, and procure ret to your Patient. If the Weapon be poioned, deferre not Extraction, for this bringeth the whole Bulk into diolution: and therefore though you are forced through Nerves, Veins, or Arteries, to cut your way, yet this is not to be delayed. And that the young Chirurgeon may not mitake herein, he may know the Fleh poioned by a Weapon thus; it is of a trange colour, it appears pale, ublivid, and as it were dead: in thee caes he ought to carify untill he meeteth with freh bloud; and this he is to do untill the Poion be removed. After which he is to apply a Cupping-glas, which is the bet Intrument for the calling of this forth. Beides the former token, you will find it attended and accompanied
with extraordinary Pains, with Inflammations and pungent Girdings, epecially about the wounded parts, with a Heavines and Torpor of the whole Body, and with Syncope and Alienation of mind. And beides thee, the Wound hath an odd Smell with it: and the Weapon that was infixed, (if poyoned) when drawn forth, and after cat into the fire, doth upon its burning turn black, and end forth a foetid Smell. And therefore in thee caes, where Danger of life is o much threatned, we ought to ue all our Experience and Reaon to torm the force of this Enemy, and batter down and overcome with convenient Medicines the vigour of its virulency. But of this expect more alo in Gunhot-Wounds. Beides this alo, in the cae of a large Flux of bloud, which may alo put the life of man into jeopardy, here are we to top our hands: if horrible Pain, Syncope or Convulion appear, delay your Extraction.
As touching the way and method how to doe and perform all thee; That in the eye of all men mut be allowed to be tranacted the bet, which is done with mot eae.
And as to the Figure; If poible, gain the true figure of its Entrance, for this does make the Extraction more eay.
Thee and uch other matters as may more advantageouly be here preented hall appear in Gunhot-Wounds.

And ince I have already declared to you how the Body of man may be variouly aaulted by diverity of Intruments, I have here alo expreed in this following Figure how his Parts may be contued, punged, incied and lacerated, by Clubs, Stones, Swords, Pikes, Faulchions, Arrows, Shot, and the like: againt which, on the contrary ide, I have alo delineated uch commodious Intruments, as are and have been allowed as mot proper for the Extraction and dicharging of the ame out of the wounded parts. And that every thing may be done and performed according to Reaon and Art, as touching the Extraction of Weapons or any other extraneous Bodies out of the Body; We are firt to enquire after the Intruments which are to execute
this: and thee ought to be accommodated to the Part, the which does require their aptnes for the occaion, both as touching their Figure and Shape. And becaue, as we have already noted, it is requiite for thee Intruments to be of various and undry Shapes, we ought to tudy a mot exact Form of them for compleating this Intention. And here amongt the ret I hall preent you with thee following, whereof in the next Leaf you have the true Shapes and Forms. And the firt which does offer it elf is Terebellum, this being an Intrument, as you may ee, let into another, the which having a thin and pointed Screw at its end, may take hold of a Bullet, Splinter of Wood, Bone, or the like; and having once entered it, it brings it away with it. This is marked at the Letter A. The econd is a Hook to draw forth any Matter or Bone which lies uperficially. This is marked at B. The third is a large pair of Forcipes with Teeth, hollowed in the middle, the more apt for catching hold of any Bullet, Shot, or any other uperfluous matter. This is marked with C. The other pair of Forcipes are made without Teeth, but hollow alo; and this is a very ready Intrument for laying hold of a Bullet, having both allowed them trong Shoulders, for the more prompt extraction of any Body. And this is marked with D. The lat is called a pair of dented Cranes-bills, being bent or bowed, accommodated chiefly for deep Wounds; and being more lender then the former, may with more eae enter into the Orifice of the Wound. And this is marked at the Letter E.
The Weapon being extracted, what your next Intention is, hall be more at large declared in my Dicoure of Gunhot-wounds, this being but as a part and abtract thereof.

And having thus hown you how to remove extraneous Bodies, my next Intention hall be, to declare how Parts which are thus eparated are to be joyned, and how the Divorce of Parts thus made is to be brought into a mutuall Contacture, according to Art.

div.head: CHAP. VII.
Of Joyning of Parts eparated.
div.p: OUR next Intention is, the Uniting and Joyning of the eparated and divorced Parts: and this is performed by bringing the Lips of the Wound together, which were formerly diunited. If it happens to be a imple Wound made in the fleh, with which neither Symptome or any other evill Accident or Affect is complicated, this may be united by Ligature, leaving the ret to Nature. But if the Wound be o large, as that it is not to be brought to Union by Ligature, here are required agglutinative Aitents, the which are to have in them a drying quality, hereby conuming and drying the moit Excrements and Humidities, and prohibiting their Influxions. And therefore in this cae give me leave to premie, that in large Wounds, Purgation is very proper, and that in thee three repects; both as touching the Excellency of the Part, the greatnes of the Affect, and the Malignity of the matter, as Hippocrates writes. Oyl here ought not to be applied to thee Wounds, for it does both humect and relax: Sarcoticks and Driers being mot proper Medicines here to be ued. Beides this, Oyl rendreth the Wound more ordid and putrid. After this, we are to tudy the naturall Temper of the Part; and where it is once etranged by Air, Meats, Drinks, Evacuation and Retention, Sleepings and Watchings, and the like, thee are to be corrected and amended. As for example, if a Wound do prove very moit and ordid, and endeth forth much Matter, here are we to tudy its Alteration, drying this up by a lender Diet, Purging, and the like.

To this alo belong the diverity of Excrements which do uually accompany Wounds; and thee are of three
R. White culp
orts, (viz.) Ichor, Pus, Sordes. Ichor is a thin indigeted Three orts of Excrements of Wounds. Lympha: and this iueth either from the Veins, or the wounded Part. If from the Veins, it is thin and waterih, and hath no bad Smell; and according to its Colour you may gues of what Humour it does proceed. If it arifeth from the wounded Part, its Smell is unpleaant, and this is called Sanies: and according to the degrees of its Corruption, it endeth forth a greater or leer quantity of its ill mell and avour. The econd is called Sordes, being a vicous Excrement firmly adhering to a Wound: and the caue of this thicknes is aigned to a dry Contitution of body; ometimes to the errour of the Chirurgeon; ometimes alo to the Air. The third is called Pus. This is generally mooth, white, equall, having no ill Smell, as Hippocrates decribeth it. The caues which generate thee three are held to be the naturall or unnaturall Heat; the firt being the caue of Digetion, whereby a laudable Matter is generated, the unnaturall heat working up moiture with it, o caueth Putrefaction, and that ill mell we generally do perceive.

And having thus decribed to you the unnaturall and unkind Subtances which do hinder Union, I next proceed to Pain and Fainting: the firt being purchaed in the mot lender Wound, the Skin being the Intrument of Touching: and as for Fainting, this is as common in compound Wounds, and frequent in imple Wounds. And that this is true, how oft have we een your delicate Ladies faint at the cut of a Finger or the like, and the turdy Plow-jogger to faint at Bleeding? But of thee in their proper places: and to our preent Task, as touching the Uniting of Wounds disjoyned.

As touching Ligature. This may be performed by Ligature, or Suture, or Dry titch. Ligature is mot proper in Wounds made lengthwaies, being uperficiall. And this ought not too trictly to be applied, nor yet too looely; making them of a convenient breadth to take in the whole Wound. Suture
As touching Suture. is performed by Needles, or a Dry titch: and the Stitching-needle is as convenient an Intrument as any the Chirurgeon does carry in his Plaiter-box: for with it he may eae Pains, free the Wound from Inflammation, and himelf from Inconveniencies. In the ue hereof, care is to be taken that the Lips of the Wound be brought to an equall ditance, not violently, but gently bringing them together, not extending one more then another, equally to anwer each other in its uperficies. The Dry titch is motly ued when exteriour Beauty does eem to be impaired; As touching the Dry titch three things to be oberved.as a Wound happening in the Face, &c. And herein are we advied, according to Ambroe Parrey, to oberve three things; as the Preparation of the Cloath, the Method which makes the Wound joyn, and then the Form. As to the firt, the pieces of Cloath mut be trong, anwering each other alike, hemmed about the Wound, and looe at the other ides. It is Emplaticks which makes them agglutinative. As for their Forms, they are to anwer the Shapes of the Wounds, mot fit for the bringing them cloe together. Now if the Wound be deep, you are to take up a pretty quantity of fleh with the Needle; and if in this cae you hould make a uperficiall apprehenion, and the Wound hereby be uperficially agglutinated, in the bottome of the Wound may be left remaining uch a Sanies or Collection of Matter, which may frame an Abces or hollow Ulcer.

Guido's three orts of Sutures. Guido propoeth three kinds of Suture. The firt he calls the Agglutinative Suture, commonly called the Incarnative Suture, the which does make bet for our preent purpoe. Suppreion of the bloud, which is done by the Needle drawn through either Lip in form of a Glover's Suture, is by ome called Sutura continuata: by this the Bloud is eaily depreed. This is generally ued in Wounds of the Guts, or when any large Veell is wounded. The third is called the Retentive Suture, the which is mot proper in lacerated Wounds in which the Fleh is lot.

Guido's five methods of Suture. Of the Incarnative Suture Guido propoeth 5 kinds. The Firt is done by the Needle being drawn through each Lip by the right hand, holding and placing the titching Quill with the left, hereby making the Lips of the Wound equall. The Second is performed by taking divers Stitches, ome ditance from each other, through the length of the Wound, bringing the Wound to a proportionate evennes: and in every of thee Stitches the ends of the Thread are to be cut off near to the Knots. The Third pecies is performed by drawing the Needles through each Lip, and then by the ame Orifice drawing them back again, and o by degrees bringing the Lips of the Wound cloer, by annexing them to ome mall ubtance, the which by twiting the Silk thereon may by degrees cloe up the Lips of the Wound. But this is the wort of the ret. And in all Sutures take this Obervation with you, that before you make any Suture, Obervar.you do deterge all the concreted Bloud in the Wound, both for preventing Inflammation, and furthering Agglutination. The time of leaving the Sutures off, is, when Union is perfected, or Agglutination made: the which do vary, according to the largenes of the Wound, and in repect of the Habit of the body. In great and tranvere Wounds they are generally kept for eight days; in mall Wounds, not above three in ome.

I will conclude this Chapter, with acquainting you of the three Ues of Suture. For it is ued either for Agglutination of Wounds; and this is called the Incarnative Suture: or to keep the uperficial parts of the Wounds in a reaonable ditance from each other; and this is called the Retentive Suture: or to top the Flux of bloud; and this is termed the Suppreive Suture. Thus have I enlarged upon the Joyning of the Parts eparated and divorced. We next proceed to the Eighth Chapter.

div.head: CHAP. VIII.
Of keeping the Parts joyned, and preerving their Subtance entire.
div.p: WE come now to the Fourth and Fifth Intentions: and becaue it oft falls out that ome Heterogene Subtance does happen within the Lips of the Wound, as Hair, Dirt, Oyl, and the like, the which do hinder Agglutination, this with care is to be prevented; and that we may truly tudy the defence of the wounded Part, and keep it from harms, there is required much care and indutry. For we may wih Union in Wounds, which is Nature's work; but may mis of our aim, if the Temper of the Part be not ound. The Body alo being weak, Nature does very readily throw down her Excrements to the wounded Part; whence doth arie a Dycray both of temper and humour. Beides which, the Part being it elf much weakned, there cannot in any reaon be expected a good Nutriment, and hence mut follow Excrements, the which not being well driven out from the affected Part, there mut conequently be created a moit Intempereity therein. And beides thee, by reaon of this Intempereity, expect no fair cloure of the Lips of the Wound, this Matter inwardly lodged creating a repletion of Sanies, which hath force and vigour enough to create a Dycray.

And that we may therefore be armed againt all thee troubles, thee Sarcotick and Incarnative Medicines hould be of a cold faculty, that they may repell the Matter which flows; alo drying, and that in the econd degree,
to uck up thee inward Humidities; and alo tiptick, for trengthening the weak parts. And here Guido, after his Sutures made, does prinkle this Powder on the wounded Part: Pulv. Thur. ij. Sangu. Dracon. j. Bol. armen. iij. Powder.mix them, and apply them either in powder, or made into a Cataplam, by mixing them with the White of an egge, a little Vinegar, and powder of Bean-meal. And this he orders to remain on for four days. We of late, according to a more modern practice, do ue this method after the Suture, firt prinkling on the retrictive Powders, then covering them with ome drying and agglutinative Empl. as Diapalma, De minio, and the like: upon which we apply convenient Boulters, and conclude the dreing with convenient Rowlers.

Now of this ort of Colletick Medicines we have very many, both imple and compound, et down for our advantage. Amongt the Simple may be reckoned thee, having in them a drying and binding quality, and void of all harpnes: (viz.) Bolearmen. Red roes, Matick, Olibanum, Sanicle, Plantane, Betony, Agrimony, Scabious, Veronica, Gum. Elemn. Sage, Lap. calaminar. Lap. Pompholyx. Amongt the Compound are Empl. Stipticum Paracel. Balam. Peruvian. nguent. Bailicon, Aureum, Fucum, Nicotian. De Panac. Colon. Linimentum Arcaei, Deiccativum rubrum, Diapompholygos: all thee generally allowed Sarcoticks. And how much their drying quality is required, is to be collected from the time of the year, and the trength and contitution of the Patient. Thus a Simple wound does onely require a uperficial Dreing; whereas a Compound and deep wound does as necearily requet the ue of Tents and Doils, to be armed with ome of the former Medicines.

Three things to be oberved in the ue of Tents and Doils. Three things are to be oberved in the ue of thee, as for Pledgets, they are to be applied larger then the Wound; thee to be armed with uch Medicines as have an agglutinative quality in them, which can top Pain,
awage Inflammation, and repell the Humours. Of A Digetive of the Authour's.which ort may be reckoned this; Terebinth. lot. in aqu. Plantag. js. Mel. opt. depurat. j. nguent. Bailic. ij. Vitell. ovor. no. ij. mice ad ignem, fine addendo Pulv. Myrrh. Another. Alo. an. j. Croc. j. mice pro Linimento, Or this; Ol. Hyperic. cum gum. Ol. catellor. an. ij. Gum. Elemn. s. Pulv. Veronic. Salv. Myrrh. an. j. Tereb. Venet. vel Cupre. js. mice. Neither are we to tudy the filling up with Fleh onely, but to prevent every Hyperarcois, by the application of ome Cathaeretical medicine, as dried Lint, burnt Allome, Verdegreece, Praecipitate, calcined Vitriol, or the like. Thee to be prinkled in Powder, or applied in form of an Unguent, by mixing therewith nguentum Roatum, Pomatum, or the like.

The Wound being digeted, mundified, and brought to a good pas by Sarcoticks; nothing now remains but to procure an even Cloure or Cover, which is to be done by Epuloticks. And here alo are we to conider what Cicatrice may herein be allowed as bet. Where we may affirm, that that Cicatrice is the bet and fairet, which does repreent the natural colour of the Cutis; where we may ee Nature at work to help forward in the progree by her effecting caue, which is reident in the true and ound Skin, expanding from thence a mall and thin veil here, as he doth in Fractures, allowing there a Callus to fall from the ends of each Bone for the Unition and compleat Conjunction. Now her adjutant caues which promote this work are Epulotick medicines: and thee alo are either imple, or compound. Amongt the Simple are reckoned Comfrey, Tormentill, Sanicle, Betony, St. Johns-wort, Golden Rod, Plantane, Shepherds-Pouch, Red roes, Balauftians, Bolearmeniack, Sanders, Dragons bloud, Matick, Olibanum, Amber, Lead, Litharge, Tutty, the Pompholyx Stone, and many others. Amongt the Compound are nguentum Tut. Album Camphorat. Roatum, Populeon, Deiccativum rubrum, Diapompholygos,
Diapalma, De minio, Sacchar. Saturni, with many others, variety of which are to be found in the Dipenatories.

div.head: CHAP. IX.
Of Removing of Symptoms and Accidents.
div.p: WE are now come to the lat Intention, which is the Correction of Accidents: and thee are very various, and do as diverly happen in large and deep Wounds, and do keep up Solution of Continuity. And thee are allowed to be nine in number: as Pain, Inflammation, Haemorrhagy, Delirium, Fainting, Fever, Crudity, Paley, and Convulion. And thee as they are Symptoms in repect of their greatnes and vehemency, o alo in many caes do they threaten Death. The Correction of thee Symptoms is to be as much regarded as the Cure of the Wound.

I. Pain. And Firt therefore, as touching Pain, this by Galen, 2. Aphor. 12. Meth. is allowed to be a ad and heavy ene of change, following a Dieae as a hadow doth a ubtance. This mot generally is the caue of Fluxion, overthrowing the Faculties, be the temper and habit of the Body formerly never o good: it being Pain's chief property, to attract Inflammation, by tirring the Humours into a Combution: and it falls here as in other caes, the weaket is een to go by the wall. For generally the wounded Part is forced to ee whatoever Pain puts to it. And therefore is it accounted a great Intention in the Chirurgeon, to allay the fury of this Enemy, and quell this troubleome authour of Fluxion. And here ought he alo to remove his Medicines very often, let by their too
long tay Pain be excited. Then is he to enquire into the caue and occaion of this Pain; and the Species and way of the Humour by which it paeth, and which way Nature intends it; and here with her to join his adjutant helps for its remove.

2. Inflammation. The Second enemy we meet with is Inflammation: and this ofttimes is occaioned by Pain, and ometimes by the Unadviednes, Neglect and Ignorance of the Chirurgeon, when by too trict Ligatures he maketh a great attraction of Pain, creating an interception of Spirits, and an extinction of native Heat, purchaing hereby a fair way for a Gangrene and Sphacelus. Inflammation alo is mostly to be feared in Wounds of the Nerves, Cartilages, and the like; or where but a mall Flux of bloud does follow the Wound. In which caes the Chirurgeon is to breath a Vein, and to take away a plentifull quantity of Bloud: for hereby he doth repres the Heat, and extinguih the Flame. If Cacochymy offend, correct and amend this by convenient Purgings, and lenifying Medicines, a good order of Diet, and uch as may temper the Bloud, ordering your Patient to hun all manner of Perturbations, which may create or tir up any Paions within him. If Inflammation happen by the puncture of a Nerve, or an inciion thereof, wholly divide it; for it is better that Part hould loe its motion, then that the whole Body hould be robbed of its life, as well as of its ene and motion.

3. Haemorrhagy. I have been very plentifull in the Third already, and hall therefore remit you thither for this. Save onely by the way, when you come to Wounds of the Veins and Arteries, I hall there enlarge omewhat more thereon.

4. Fainting. As touching Syncope or Lipothymia, Galen, 12. Meth. cap. 5. does thus define it; that it is a principal Lape of all the Spirits, happening by ome hurt of the Heart, or injury done to it, when it is quiet in its procreation and
ditribution of its vitall Spirits. For then, as Gordonius doth expres it, both ene and motion are taken from the whole Body, the Pule becomes flat and dull, and Death appears in the face. And in thee caes the Patients are een to fall down without either ene or motion. This Syncope which does mot commonly intervene in Wounds is for the mot part from an Haemorrhagiall caue, the which does make this diipation of Spirits; or Fear, the which does make a peedy revocation of the Spirits to the Heart, whence followeth that every Part is forced to leave work, whilt this Diturbance is thus in action. A Syncope does ofttimes happen, as Galen does oberve, from a venenate and putrid Vapour paing to the Heart through the Arteries, and to the Brain by its Nerves. And hence by mot Authours are granted thee three caues of Syncope. The firt is made by the diipation of the Spirits and native Heat, as in a large Haemorrhagy: then by oppreion or obtruction of thee Spirits, as in Fear; for thus the Spirits are called back from the Circumference to the Center: and thirdly by Corruption, as in Cacochymick bodies, and venenate Wounds. The firt of thee are cured, if convenient Medicines be peedily applied and adminitred; as by prinkling cold water on the face, laying him on his back, and topping his Flux. The econd by good Cordialls, by cherihing and reviving his Spirits, by clapping weet Smells to his notrills, frictions of his Temples. But if a venenate Quality does occaion this, cure this by Mithridate, Venice Treacle, Actuall Cauteries, application of live Pigeons cut in the middle, Cupping-glaes, for derivation and interception of this Matter which is to be fetched out.

5. Delirium. Neither is Delirium in Wounds les dangerous, which is a perillous Affect ariing from ome principall or noble Part, as the Nerves, Brain, Heart, Diaphragma, and the like, thee, or any of thee, being wounded. For this Delirium is nothing ele but a deprivation of Motion, and
an alienation of Sene, contained in the wounded Brain by eence or conent. Hence is it, that we o oft ee in uch as are bit by a mad Dog, that venomous Vapours do acend upwards into their Heads, and fill the poroities of the Brains, which makes them o frantick and idle. It does arie from a vehement Pain and Inflammation; and therefore uch Medicines as may cure Pain and Inflammation are very proper here. If it arieth from Poyon, Alexipharmicks are the bet engines to remove it. For derivation and interception of the matter which doth excite this Delirium, alterant and evacuating Clyters are here proper. Phlebotomy, Cupping-glaes, Actuall and Potentiall Cauteries are here mot requiite. Setons and Fontinells are fair Orifices for letting out its venome. Cordialls, Emulions and good Decoctions may defend it from the Heart. Hordeaceous and Papaverall Decoctions may banih it, by procuring Ret. And as it is a deprivation of the principall faculty of Motion, o are we to take care of it.

6. Fever. But becaue this more properly does belong to a Phyician to examine and advie about, I hall briefly hut up this Symptome, onely acquainting you, that Avicen, fen. 1. does call that a Fever, which is an extraneous, adventitious, accenive heat in our Heart, by which the Veins and Arteries therewith haring, it's carried through the circuit of our whole Body, and hurteth its actions. Neither is there any Fever allowed where the Heart is not affected, either primarily, or econdarily, being a Dieae in Intempereity.

But to come to that which more properly does relate to large Wounds: and here, as Hippocrates offereth, untill a good Digetion be procured, both Fever, Pain and Inflammation do attend the Part: for whilt the Matter is making, the Heat does increae. Sometimes a Fever does arie from the Bite of a venomous creature; and therefore as it does carry this poyonous quality to the Heart, there
endeavouring to infect its Spirits, it very readily runs into a Fever and Inflammation. Now where this happens, cool the body by Phlebotomy: if ill Humous do joyn in the combate, dipatch thee by convenient Catharticks. And in repect of the Poyon, you mut ue Alexipharmicks: for the Pain and Inflammation, prepare Anodynes; hunning all things which may procure a vehement motion, diturbance and perturbations of the mind; and ue your greatet indutry to bring every part to its due order, temper and habit.

7. Crudity. Crudity alo is a great enemy to the healing of Wounds; for it does afford no laudable Matter, without which expect no good new Fleh. And this by many Authours is allowed to happen by thee ix means: by a continuall Six things cauing Crudity.Flux of bloud, where no good Digetion is; by an Intrument contuing the Part, as happens in Gunhot-wounds; by the nature of the Part, uch as deep Wounds in the Joynts; by coldnes of the Air; by applying of unfit Medicines; and latly, by too trict Ligature. As for the firt, this you have already hown. The econd is to be digeted as contued Wounds. Atringent Medicines are to be applied to the Articulations, to preerve their Temper. The Air is to be corrected; the Part to be furnihed with convenient Medicines; and the trict Ligature to be relaxed. And thus may you cure thee ix Caues of Crudity. The other two remaining Symptoms I hall peak of a little more largely, they being of great conequence.

div.head: CHAP. X.
Of Paley.
div.p:
A Paley by the generall Conent of Authours is allowed to be a Reolution or Relaxation of the Nervous parts, with Deprivation both of Sene and Motion, on either ide, or both ides of the Body, or in ome part thereof. And this mot properly is called a Paley. Now the Nervous bodies are reolved, in that the animall Spirits do not act in them, neither are they filled or enlightned with vigour and brisknes. The caues whereof are referred to the Obtruction of the paages, the which does hinder their Tranpiration. In a Paley, Motion, or Sene, onely, or both may be hurt together. And this may be acted either by Completion, Compreion, or Solution of Continuity. For either their Ductures are filled up with ome extraordinary Matter impacted in them, or compreed by extravaed Bloud or ome Tumour, or Solution of Continuity made by ome Wound or Concuion: and every of thee may imprint their everall reaons and caues for a Paley. And as our Countryman Dr. Willis does oberve, as often as an univerall Paley or Hemiplexia does ucceed a Lethargy, a Caros, or Apoplexy, it's very eay to conceive that this change of the Dieae does happen from a Metatais or Tranpoition of the morbifick matter. And if it may be enquired why that Sene and Motion are not alwaies equally inhibited in a Paley, either of thee is perfected in their proper Nerves and Fibres, and either Faculty is as the averion of each other. Jut as the Light cateth its beams through a Glas, when the Wind is excluded: o ofttimes Motion is abolihed, the Sene remaining afe and ound. For Sene is as a Paion, a enible
impreion, the which by the continuity of the Nervous proces is carried from the Organ to the common Senory; without which the faculty of the Spirits is propagated by coure and trength. Now Motion is a laborious and difficult action, to the which is required the expanion or exploion of Spirits, not onely in the motionall Organs, but chiefly in the Parts where the beginning of Motion and its firt affection does draw its Origination. For from hence floweth its whole conduct of its exploive endeavours, the which it acteth through all its Nervous parts. In the Spinall marrow an Interception of the Spirits, or Cohibition thereof, making a Paley, very oft doth happen, by reaon of Compreion, or Solution of Continuity. The extravaed Bloud, or Matter paing forth from the dirupted Abces, does very oft hut up and obcure the paages of the Spirits. Hence Wounds of the Head, Concuions or Inciions do not onely frequently pervert or lacerate the Medullary tracts, but alo by their coldnes do contipate and bind up their pirituall paages.

The next thing we propoe is, whether this Dieae be accidentall, or habituall.
