The firt may be aid to come from an evident caue, as being procured by Wounds, Inciions, Concuions, Exces of cold or heat: beides which it hath no other then a Compreion and Solution of Continuity. An habituall Paley hath its dependence from a procatarctick caue, the which is an extraneous Matter, and as it were vitriolized, uffued into the Organs of Sene and Motion, profligating the Spirits by contaction. A Paley does much differ from a Convulion, in that in the The difference between a Paley and a Convulion Caues of a Paley.firt, Reolution and Relaxation is its proper quality; in the latter, Contention and Contraction.

We come now to the Caues of this Paley, which are generally allowed to be both inward and outward. The inward obtructing the Ventricles of the Brain, o as the animall Spirit, which hould be conveyed to the Nerves of
Sene and Motion, is wholly abolihed. The externall Caues being Wounds, Concuions, Percuions, Inciions, Compreions, or Contrictions, or violent Colds occluding the Spirits. From what Humour a Paley may be aid to proceed, is hard to tell. For Melancholy drying the Nerves cannot be the Humour. Choler, having allowed it a drying quality alo, and having an acrimony joyned to it, may rather be allowed to create Convulion, by contracting and convelling the Nerves. And therefore it mut either proceed from the Bloud, or Phlegm. It very rarely happens from Bloud alone, unles by accident. It's therefore granted by a generall conent, that it is bred from thick Phlegm, bordering upon the Nerves. But I rather preume that it happens from thin Phlegm, which flows from the Brain, and therein does create an Obtruction through its whole ubtance, making it more oft, out of which oftnes there follows an exploion of the Nerves. A ubtance very contrary to its naturall Contruction, the which does wholly abolih the motion of the Nerves where it is inerted. Thus if the whole pinall Marrow be affected, there does ucceed a Reolution of the whole from the Head; if onely one part, that part onely bears the los. Thus have we given a brief dicoure of the Paley, and its inward and outward caues: let us now come more cloely to that which chiefly does belong to our preent dicoure.

When therefore a Nerve is wounded or amputated, there mut necearily follow a Paley upon the part, becaue both Sene and Motion in the action are lot and banihed; and being thus divided, it's impoible to fetch them again: for being once cut, they do gather towards their Originalls. Therefore when any Nerve is either incied, cut or punctured, Pain being hereupon a very ready attendant, Anodynes are here mot proper, defending the Wound from cold and all harp things, and ue comfortable and trengthening Medicines. But of thee more afterwards.

Signs of a Paley, and Caues. Galen does give all good Chirurgeons this Caution, that he ought to undertand the primary Affect hereof and its place, and from whence this michief arieth, and its dipoition. And he who is ignorant of thee, may not be allowed skilfull enough to cure thoe Parts whoe Sene and Motion are vitiated. The firt we do fetch from Anatomy, which is an excellent Schoolmater, the which perfectly learneth us how to know the Nerves which are prinkled about the Face, ent thither from the Brain. If ome of thee with the whole Body be reolved, it cannot in reaon be allowed, that this dipoition of Reolution hould conit in the Brain it elf, whereas the parts belonging to the Face do remain unhurt and afe. If all the parts of the Head being ound, either of its ides be correpted with a Paralyis, the caue is in one of the ides of the pinall Marrow. If the Arms be onely paralytick, the caue is in the fifth, ixth, or eventh Vertebra of the Neck. If the Legs, draw the caue from the Os Sacrum, and its Vertebrae.

Preages. To preage and judge of a Paley, and every occaion which may caue and produce it, and every affect of the Nerves, as touching their icknees or cures, this mot properly does belong to the Prognotick part. And thus according to Hipp. we may preage that a Paley is hard to cure in old men, becaue their native Heat is almot extinguihed. And Galen does affirm, if Fever and Trembling have upervened a Paley, it's a good ign: for Fevers do partly diolve the uperfluous Humours which are in Reolution of the Nerves, and do partly diget their coldnes. A Solution of the Nerves, as Galen does worthily declare, is never perfectly cured. A Paley proceeding from an inward caue is not eaily found out, or eaily cured. A Paley following an Apoplexy is carce curable, the caue being vehement, and the Parts weak. Where Sene and Motion do appear to be both lot, this does prove very dangerous. If the Paralied
member do change its colour, expect no Cure, for the native Heat is extinguihed, and the animal Spirits abolihed. If it happen from an evident caue, as by a Blow, a Wound, or the like, if it do not quickly amend, or give way to Medicines, it does prove for the mot part incurable. Such as are once cured of a Paley ariing from an evident caue, are not readily troubled therewith a econd time. And to conclude the Preages, if Paleys happen in Aged people, or in Cacochymick or Scorbutick bodies, and in Intempereities, thee are very hard to remove.

Cure. And ince, as I have already propoed, we ee that a Paley does conit of manifold Types and divers Caues, its Cure is alo to be performed after a various manner, intituting a proper method to every pecies of the Dieae. And as there are generally allowed three kinds or orts hereof, o hould there be propoed three kinds of Cure. Firt, for Reolution, this being the main Agent, this is to be cured, Secondly, if it happen by Wound, Inciion, exceive Cold, or a Fall from a high place, this alo mut have allowed it its way of Cure. Thirdly, as it is a procatarctick and primary Dieae of it elf. I mut leave the firt and third, and onely take the econd for our preent dicoure.

And whereas we here do grant, that this Paley does happen by ome Accident, produced by ome vehement Hurt, there will not be required many Intentions for this, ave onely the Conformity of the hurt Part to be made into its pritine frame. And that no Affect, as Bloud or affluent Humours, may bring detriment to the affected Part, Phlebotomy in this cae is very peedily to be made ue of, if nothing hinders it; and the Body is to be kept open by lenifying Purgings, and a good order of Diet, keeping your Patient in a moderate Sweat in his bed, o as all Superfluities may be exhaled and called back from the hurt Part. And for this Ue Pulvis ad Caum is granted a good Medicine, to be given in White wine, to
the quantity of a Drachm or a Drachm and a half. A common Decoction of Guaiacum is alo much commended here, for this does both diget and dicus the Matter and Caue. To this may be added many other Cephalick herbs and flowers, to be bruied, and boiled in Beer, for the Patient to drink either at meals, or morning and evening. And thee are to have in them uch faculties as may trengthen the Nerves. Such as are Cowlip-flowers, Betony flowers, Roemary-flowers, Stoechades, Calamint, Mint, Lavender-flowers, Marjoram, Germander, Groundpine, Elecampane, Calamus Aromaticus, Cinnamon, Hyop Thyme, Cloves, Nutmegs. With thee or the like may be made excellent good Mead, by adding Honey thereto. His Diet hould be light of digetion; as, Rabbits, Chickens, Pheants, Partridge, Black-birds, and the like, Electuaries, and Conerves of Roemary-flowers, Betony, Sage, and the like. To which may be added ome Cordiall pecies made up with Syrup of Cowlips, of which the Patient may take everal times in a day.

Pills. Pills to help to evacuate and dicharge thee Humours may be uch as thee: Pil. foetid. ijs. Agaric. Troch. j. Troch. Alhandul. gr. ij. Cator. gr. iiij. cum Mel. cillit. q. . iant Pil. no. 10. deaurentur, quarum umat ij. omni mane. Or this Decoction; Raur. Guaiac. vj. Saraparil. Decoction. Saafr. an. iiij. Santal. omn. Raur. Ebor. Corn. C. an. s. infunde, & coque in aqu. fontan. lbxvj. ad medietatem, addendo ub finem Rad. Calam. aromatic. Galang. an. s. Irid. Florentin. j. Cardamom
vj. Sem. Ani. Coriand. Foenicul. an. s. Dactyl. no. 10. hujus umat pro potu ordinario. In this cae alo Elixar Proprietatis taken to the quantity of ten or twelve drops, in a glas of good old Canary, is very good. Coffee is alo allowed very good to dry up this moiture: or this Digetive; Oxymel. impl. Syr. de Digetive. Stoechad. an. j. Syr. de Betonic. vj. Aqu. Salv. Betonic. an. jv. Spir. vitriol. gutt. 6. cum Syrup. Cinnamom. q. . fiat Julapium, umat mane. Then order thee Pills: Pil. Pills.
Coch. ij. Sine quibus j. Pulv. Nuc. Mochat. gr. 5. Ol. Succin. gutt. iij. Diagrid. gr. ij. cum Oxymel. q. f. fiant Pilulae. Electuary.An Electuary to be taken in the morning may be this; Mithridat. Theriac. Andromach. an. iij. Cator. elect. s. Spir. vitriol. gutt. 6. Spir. Poeon. j. cum Syr. Stoechad. Pills. fiat mixtura. Pills for the ame: Pil. Foetid. ij. Coch. j. Pulv. nuc. mochat. gr. iiij. Ol. nuc. mochat. gr. ij. Cambog. A medicate Wine. gr. ij. cum aqu. Betonic. fiant Pil. This following Medicate Wine is much praied in the Paley: Herb. Chameder. Chamaepit. an. m. j. Fl. Primul. ver. m. s. Rorimarin. Salv. Fl. Anth. an. pug. ij. Rad. Imperator. Angelic. Irid. Florentin. Ellebor. nigr. Sem. Cartham. an. iij. Agaric. alb. iij. Cardomom. Cubeb. an. ij. Sal. Tartar. js. conci. & crae contu. inuantur acculo cum Vini albi lbvj. fiat Vinum medicatum, hujus umat iiij. quibus adde Spir. Sal. Armoniac. gutt. viij.

As touching the Cure of a Reolution of the Nerves happening by a Wound, or any other outward caue, the whole Body being well ordered, wecome next to Topicks. And as touching the locall parts of application, here are we firt to examine well the affected Part, the which is properly collected and known by the Hurt affecting the Part, and partly by the Members reolved. And if in this cae any Part be out of order, you are to reduce it into its pritine place by your care and skill. If Tumour, Contuion or Wound be here excited, thee are to be dreed, corrected and amended, by Balams, Liniments, Fomentations, Oyls, Cataplams, Emplaters, or the like; beginning and proceeding in your Operation with mildnes, maintaining and preerving the moderate Heat. Such Medicines as thee following are very excellent in the Paley, oberving a due order in their application. And here Oyls for this ue hould be hot and drying, and by their thin parts digeting.

In applying of Unguents we are to begin with weak Medicines: of which kind may be allowed thee. Ol.
Cham. ij. Lilior. alb. js. Laurin. vj. Pingued. Anat. Gallin. Unguent. an. ij. make it into an Unguent. nguentum Martiatum and Aregon will make it tronger, if it be deired. Another.Or for the ame take this: Ol. Petrol. Hyperic. cum gummi, an. j. Pulv. Euphorb. Cator. an. j. Cotin. js. Martiat. Aregon, an. s. fine addendo Aqu. vit. j. fiat nguentum. Or this: Ol. Vulpin. Lumbricor. Chamomel. Another. Rut. an. s. Cator. Spic. an. iij. Ol. Succin. Salv. an. j. mice. Leonellus Faventinus does much glory in this his Unguent: Ol. Laurin. Terebinth. an. js. Ol. Nardin. Petrol. an. s. Another. Vini Malvat. ij. Aqu. vit. j. Pyreth. Piper. Sinap. granor. Juniper. gum. Heder. Anacardin. Labdan. an. vj. terantur & miceantur omnia, cum oleis & vino coquantur ad vini conumption. in duplo vae, fact Ã¢ forti expreione, adde Galban. Bdell. Euphorb. Myrrh. Cator. Adip. rin. Anat. an. ij. fiat Linimentum, fine addendo parum cerae.

All naturall Baths are good here; or artificiall Fomentations: of which ort take this as an Example; Rad. Fomentation. Alth. m. ij. Sem. Lin. Foenugraec. an. m. ij. Salv. Lavendul. Majoran. Chamaepit. Ivae Arthritic. an. m. js. Herb. Betonic. Abinth. Roar. rub. Hyperic. Stoechad. an. m. js. Aneth. Menth. an. m. j. Chamomel. Melilot. Rut. an. m. j. coquantur omnia in aqua & vino imul mixt. & fiat Fomentum: with which let the Paralied parts be fomented by dipping Stupes therein, and o applying them warm to the affected Part. After which application you may embrocate the Parts with this following Mixture: Summit at. Mixtute. Rorimar. Salv. Lavendul. Rut. Chamaepit. Majoran. an. m. j. coquantur in. . q. vini albi, ad hujus colaturae iiij. adde Spir. Vini rectificat. iiij. Spirit. Juniper. j. Aqu. Salv. Rorimar. Lavendul. an. j. Ol. Salv. Succin. an. j. Styrac. liquid. j. Styrac. liquid. j. mice.

Hitory. I conclude this Chapter with this Hitory of a young Gentleman, who being of a anguine Contitution, after eating a large Supper, did drink very plentifully of Wine. As he at in his chair, he was uddenly urprized with a
Stupidity in his Right hand, o that the Glove which did cover his hand did involuntarily fall of. He endeavouring to arie thence and walk, did perceive a Reolution in his Thigh and Leg on the ame ide. A mall while after, falling into a Drowzines of mind, and a Sleepines, without an Apoplexy, being asked everall quetions, he very aptly anwered them, yet lowly, and as it were diturbed. A worthy Phyician being ent for, Phlebotomy, Purging and Vomiting being in their orders ued, and Cupping-glaes, Frictions, Scarifications and Liniments being with care adminitred, yet the Paly did creep o fat on that ide, that the Member had almot wholly lot its motion: with which he lot the ight of his Eye on that ide. And all proper Medicines taking no place, the animall Faculties daily decayed; o that about the eventh or eighth day falling into a Delirium, and afterwards into a Convulion, he was within a hort while forced to hut up his lat minute, his Spirits being diolved. The dead Corps being opened, the anteriour Cavity of the Brain was een filled partly with an Ichorous, partly with a concrete and grumous Bloud, accompanied with plenty of Serum. Hence (as Dr. Willis does conjecture, who was the Authour of this Hitory) in repect of this Illuvies compreing one Striated body, and contringing its pores and paages, it hindred the afflux of Spirits paing into the Nervous appendix of that ide; and hereby a Reolution being excited in the repective Members, and alo a Compreion, by reaon of the Thalamus Opticus to which the Striated body is inerted, the ight of the Eye on this ide was wholly divided.

div.head: CHAP. XI.
Of Convulion.
div.p: AMongt all the preternaturall Affects which are conitent in Solution of Continuity, and which do bring danger of Inflammations, Watchings, Delirium, and Convulion, Wounds of the Nerves and Nervous parts are mot dangerous: for thee eldome do goe without their Symptoms. This Convulion in Wounds is a direfull Symptome, for it is an involuntary Contraction of the Parts towards their Originall, proternating their Faculties by Pain, abolihing all voluntary Motion, without which Life is but a troubleome thing. And that it is a morbifick caue may from hence be collected, in that it does deprive the Parts of their proper Motion. For as when Deglutition is hindred, there does follow an Inanition in all parts, o conequently a Conumption. Even thus while the Urine or Excrements are detained, Dieaes are made in the Cavities: and alo in Intempereity, Magnitude, and Solution of Continuity.

What a Convulion is. The Nature therefore of a Convulion is diligently and carefully to be minded and conidered, and its Caues, that we may better find out the way of its thus happening in Wounds. We allow therefore that a Spam is a depraved Motion happening in the voluntary moving Faculty, and is a nervous Ditempereity, by which contraction of the Mucles they are altogether made incapable of extention; and it is a principall affection of the Nerves, which do obey a voluntary command. And that this decription may the better be undertood, we may much enlarge in our knowledge hereof by Anatomy. All Motions
being procurated and procured by the animall Faculty, which are exercied and performed by the Mucles and their Tendons, as by their proper Intruments; whilt thee Mucles do contract their Beginning and Radix towards their End, they alo do draw with them their annexed Members, as Nerves, Tendons, and Ligaments. For no proper animall Motion can be made in any living creature without Mucles, and thee do take their moving Faculty from the Brain. For although the Brain it elf be not fibrous, the body of its Nerves is fibrous: and thee are the meengers which do convey this Spirit into the Mucles, and through them, which do give them both their ene and motion. Now therefore, when by any preternaturall affect the Nerves or Tendons are pricked, inflamed, or otherwie hurt, they do recede from their pritine vigour, and do prove incapable Intruments: and hence follows Convulion, or that contractive motion we call a Spam. Gal. 6. Aphor. 39. writes, a Convulion to be a hurting of the voluntary Function, becaue herein the moving quality is as it were tied up from acting in its proper phere; and thus Motion is hindred, the Intrument thereof not being wanting, but hindred in its action by being girt up by the Ditempereity of the Intrument. And therefore Spam or Convulion by Johan. Andr. Ã Cruce is decribed as a Symptome of a Dieae, not of a Faculty.

The differences of Convulion. There are allowed generally to be three pecies of a Spam. If the Affect do arie in the Anteriour part, this Convulion by the Greeks is called Emprothotonos:
< in non-Latin alphabet > is all one with ante in Latine. By ome it is called Convulio dometicalis. This is made, when not onely the Neck but the other Parts of the body are drawn forwards. If it poes the Back-part, it is called Opithotonos, from the Greek word < in non-Latin alphabet > , which is the ame to retro in Latine. And this happens when the Mucles which do inflect the Body are hurt backwards. By ome this is called
Convulio Scapuloa. The third is Tetanos, or Totum extenum: and this Convulion is made, when all the fore and back Parts of the body are equally contracted, keeping them as it were at a tay, and making them very tiff. Celus does declare, that there is no Dieae more outrageous, cruell, and acute, then that which by a Rigor or Stiffnes of the Nerves and Sinews does annex the Head to the Scapula's, the Chin to the Breat, and maketh the Neck right and immovable. In which Dicoure he hath both briefly and elegantly et down the three differences of Spam, which we have been dicouring of. He hath alo a fourth Species there of a Spam, which he calls Spamus Cynicus; as when the Mouth is pulled awry, or one or both Hands be contracted.
All the chief caues which do produce thee Convulions are by him reckoned as three: (viz.) Plethory, Inanition, and Sympathy. Of thee in their Orders.

Plethory. I begin with Plethory, o called from its copiounes and plenitude of divers Humidities, the which do replete and poes the Intruments of voluntary Motion; as the Body being thick and flehy, the Veells full, the Pule trong, the Age ripe, the Complexion anguine, and the like. Thus by Plethory or Plenitude Convulion may be aid to be made, when the Nervous bodies and their Fibres are nourihed with thick and glutinous Matter, and are therewith alo repleted: by which Repletion they are ditended; and hence, as they fill out in bulk, they do horten in their length: hence do they become contracted and abbreviated, and o are they run into Convulion.

Inanition. The Second is Inanition: and this is made for want of naturall Moiture; the Nerves being hereof detitute, do oon grow dry and hort. For they mut needs grow horter, as does a Cord, when once being wet, and dried again, it hrinks and hrivells up: o alo do the Nerves being corrugated. The Dieae therefore which does follow
a Convulion is a pervere figure of the Mucles, in which they are made horter by Inanition as well as Repletion. Thus every humourall Matter which may be aid to fill the Fibres, may alo be allowed to create a Convulion. And this may be confirmed of Inanition, that every thing which hath power to make this, hath alo trength enough in it to frame a Spam. And hence ometimes immoderate Evacuations or Vomitings, which are allowed to dry very much, do o ofttimes bid fair to a Convulion.

Sympathy or Conent. A Third Caue is called Sympathy: and this is aid to happen by malign Vapours offending the Originations of the Nerves, as it is ofttimes een in poyoned Wounds. Another is aid to be made by Pain attracting the Nerves from their Originations. A third which may offer it elf is from immoderate Cold, cauing in them a great Stiffnes.

What remains in the Caues of Convulion is, to hew how this may be made in Wounds. And here may we ee how this may be made out of Plethory, the Nerves being filled with purulent Matter, or other Excrements, generated either in the wounded Part, or ent thither from other Parts, and o ucked up by the Nerves; as it oft happens when a Nerve is half divided or cut: or by reaon of Inflammation, the Part being filled with a large Flux of bloud, and o ditending the Nervous parts; epecially if this Diaffection be communicated to the Originall of them, or the Nerve it elf be primarily offended. And hereby the Mucles become horter, and o forced to contract towards their Originall, neither by Heat alone, but alo by immoderate Cold in Wounds of the Nerves and Nervous parts, hereby uffering Convulion, this prohibiting the Excretion of Excrements, and hutting up and condening the Porous bodies. Out of Inanition may alo be made Convulion, and this alo by Inflammation: and this mot generally happens in Wounds of the
Nervous parts. For thus the inflamed Part is convelled, and anwers directly to Convulion, and hence it communicates it elf to ome principall Part, the which being there received, does communicate of its Ditempereity through the whole Body. Convulion does ofttimes happen in Wounds of the Nervous parts, in repect of exolution of the wounded Part, which does end forth its ill habits to the Brain, the Origination of them, by which the Brain it elf is vellicated and irritated: and being thus concued, that it may clear it elf from the michief this portends it, and give a quietus to this unhappy companion, there mut necearily follow Convulion upon this combate in the ubject Parts. But uch motions as thee do prove generally univerall, even as the pirituous quality is carried to the Brain through the affected Nerve, being either prickt, cut, or hurt, containing a putrednes in it. So alo of Cold may follow Spam, being a great enemy to the Nerves.

Signs of Convulion. The Signs of a Convulion are readily to be dicerned, for the Part is drawn towards its Origination, and there it does create uch a Stiffnes, that it is not eaily to be extended. Galen, 1. Proret. cap. 2. Tract. 20. aith that it is an Affect full of Pain. The greater is the Pain when made by Repletion: and this Affect hereby is oon procured, when it is communicated to a principall Part. This you may collect from thee Signs: in that the Throat is narrowed, the Teeth contringed, the Mouth is not to be opened, the Lips contracted, the Neck and Back pained, the Eyes and whole Face perverted; and after thee the Patient does breath with difficulty, and his Breath being intercepted, he parts peedily from his Life. If by reaon of a Wound Tetanos or Ditention does happen, the Patient's Mandibles are conglutinated, he cannot open his Mouth, his Eyes are filled with tears and contracted, his poteriour Parts are convelled, and his Body is bent backwards. Hence do arie vehement Pains, and ometimes
the Patient cannot either contract his Thighs, or extend his Hands. In Emprothotonos the Body bendeth altogether forwards, and the Parts are contrarily dipoed to the former. And this is to be undertood of thoe Parts which could bend either way. The Leg cannot be bent forwards, or the Thigh backwards.

p.U: aith that Convulion happening upon a Wound is mortall. A Spam alo happening upon a large Flux is ill. Aphorim. 3. Such as are taken with a Tetanos do commonly die within four daies; and if they ecape thee, they are pat the wort of danger. Aph. 6. Such as die of a Convulion do continue their Heat a long while, they dying uffocated, the Mucles of Repiration being convelled, and thoe of the Neck ditended. Such as have Convulions, a Fever happening, are freed hereby from their Convulions. Every Convulion may be aid to come from Repletion, becaue it is cured by Evacuation. A Convulion bred out of Inanition is both harp and cruell. If it do communicate its hurt to the Mucles moving the Thorax, it does threaten Death. That Convulion is much to be dreaded which cloeth the Lips, and lets fall the Mandible.

div.p:
Cure of a Convulion caued by Plenitude. As other Paions, Accidents, or Symptoms, which are wont to arie from a copiounes or plenitude of Humours, are to be cured by opportune Evacuations; thus alo is a humid Convulion to be treated, by ordering a good Diet, and application of convenient Topicks, the which hould not onely contain in them a drying and dicuing faculty, but alo eradicate and extirpate the whole Affect. The wounded Patient is therefore to be placed in a Room where the Air is hot and dry, or o made by Art. Frictions of the extreme Parts are beneficiall. Let his Diet be thin, for Inanition in this cae is an excellent Remedy, for it dries the Body. Let his Bread be well baked, and his Diet be of a light Digetion. Breath a Vein where bloud is much abounding, or Inflammation offers
it elf; for this is a ready remedy to prevent Convulion. Both Galen and Celus do declare, that in a Cynick Convulion to breath a Vein is very proper. And this is to be ordered and precribed according to the trength and Contitution of the Patient. Purge frequently with Hier. picr. Pil. Coch. Pil. Aggregativ. De Agaric. Extr. Rud. cum Merc. dulci, &c.

Outward Medicines for the wounded Part may be thus ordered. If the whole Nerve be incied, there is carce any Motion left perceivable. If the head of the Mucle be pricked, occaioning Convulion, and cannot be remitted by any force of Medicine, by cutting the whole Mucles tranverely you cure the Convulion. But you mut hereby expect to loe part of its Motion. The Ancients concluded this Operation with an actuall Cautery, after which was applied this Medicine; Ol. Hyperic. Matich. an. js. Terebinth. Oleum. Venet. Rein. Pin. an. iij. Sulphur. viv. j. Croc. s. mice, parum bulliant: over which to apply this Cataplam; Pulv. Catapl. Fl. Cham. Melilot. Fol. Betonic. Laur. Bacc. an. j. Farin. Hord. Fabar. an. ij. Ol. Lilior. albor. Sem. Lin. an. js. fiat Cataplama: or this; Spir. Lavendul. ij. Spir. vini jv. Another mixture. Ol. Succin. j. Ol. Hyperic. Magitral. js. Terebinth. Spic. an. ij. mice; and with this anoint the convelled Parts: or this; Axung. Human. Aner. rin. Ol. Vulpin. an. j. nguent. Another. Dialth. Martiat. Aregon. an. j. Ol. Hyperic. cum gummi ij. Ol. Lilior. Cator. an. js. mice, fiat Linimentum. Another for the ame ue may be this; Ol. Spic. Terebinth. Another. Petrol. an. j. Axung. Human. ij. Martiat. js. Ol. Salv. Nuc. Mochat. an. j. Succin. s. mice. Fomentations here alo may be with profit ued, uch as are made of Scordium, Sage, Wormwood, Lavender, Rue, Chamomill, Dill, Marjoram, Roemary-flowers, Red roes, Betony, Cowlips, Taney, St. Johns-wort, Scabious, and the like, being boiled in water and milk. After the application of which, be ure to keep the Parts very warm.

An Hitory. To conclude this; take this Hitory of a corpulent
man, over-filled with wine and beer, o that by a generall opinion he was reputed intoxicated. Being in this condition carried in a Coach to his houe, he fell down upon his back, and was left o leeping in the Coach untill he got to his own houe. But coming thither, being much tirred, and asked everall quetions, he gave no anwer to any; and being carried mute into his houe, he till remained in his leeping poture, and within a hort while died of a Convulion, before any Phyician could arrive at him. It was generally conjectured, the Wine he drank hatned his death by uffocation, being thus carried o trangely in the Coach lying all the while on his back in a leepy condition.

Cure of a Convulion ariing from Inanition. We come to the Second kind, the which although it be accounted lethall, yet where any hopes of cure may offer, we are thus to begin with the convelled Parts. The Patient's Diet therefore is to be of good Juices, as Broaths and Decoctions, to be made with Capons, Chickens, and Veal-broath, and the like, wherein may be boiled the Leaves of Mallows, Lettice, Purlane, Violets, Buglosflowers, and the like, and uch things as may trengthen and confirm the Parts, and create a moit habit in them. Of thee and the like may alo be made Conerves, Juleps, Electuaries, and Decoctions, by adding Sugar and convenient Liquours and Syrups. Purging is very improper here. Lenifying Clyters are very convenient Medicines. Emollent Liniments and Baths are here motly required; An Unguent.of which ort may be reckoned thee. Butyr. Maial. Axung. Porcin. an. js. Ol. Lilior. Violar. Amygdal. dulc. Another. an. js. Axung. Human. j. mice: or this; Axung. Porcin. Pomat. an. j. Ol. Olivar. Lumbricor. an. js. Ol. Violar. Cydonior. an. ij. Cer. q. . fiat nguent. or this; Another. Ol. Viol. Amygdal. dulc. Pingued. Gallin. Vitulin. an. ij. coquantur imul in decocto Malv. Alth. & Sem. Cydonior. colaturae adde Cerae q. . pro nguento. As for Fomentations, you may boil here Calves Feet or a Sheeps Head and Feet
in milk and water mixed together, and to thee adde Mallows, Marh-mallows, Violets, Lineed, Fengreek-eed, Chamomile-flowers, and Melilot-flowers: and with thee and the like the convelled Parts are to be fomented.

Hitory. Hercules Saxoniae writes, that Convulion made by Inanition may be cured. He doth propoe the cae of a Reverend Generall of Caina: a peedy Effuion of bloud out of the Haemorrhoidall veins caued not onely a Syncope, but alo a Convulion to eize on him, the which by Divine aitance he was perfectly cured of.

Now albeit Hippocrates aith, A Wound being received in the large Veins where much bloud is pilt and cattered, ofttimes Convulion and Syncope is een to ucceed, which is direfull, as he hath it Aph. 3. lib. 5. yet Hollerius writes, that the Patient does eldome die of this Dieae. And hence Dovinaetus, lib. 1. cap. 3. writes, that he aw a man fifty years old which fell into a Convulion and Syncope occaioned by a great Effuion of bloud, who by the benefit of Cupping-glaes and Bleeding was perfectly cured.

Of curing a Convulion happening by Sympathy or Conent. If Convulion do arie by Conent or Sympathy, the caue hereof is peedily to be inquired into: the which if it prove procatarctick, this is to be removed; if harp and painfull, this is to be awaged; if it proceed from Cold cauing a Numnes in the Nervous parts, and making them tiffe, this is to be amended. Now if a malign Vapour do offend the Origination of the Nerves, in this cae the Wound is to be dilated for dicharging of the peccant and venomous Matter. Flatulencies alo may create many pecies of a Spam, not onely eizing the extreme Parts, but alo forcing themelves into others: firt taking the Head by advantage of urprize; hence working into other Parts, and undermining them by the ene of Cold, throwing it elf between the Scapula's, diturbing the Body in its entire Senes with an Opithotonos, executing its vigorous influences of michief in one ide, firmly contracting
it, and girting it up from acting or performing any of its Functions. From whence may be collected, that its chief Caue is not an Humour, but ome cold and thick Vapour, the which by ome inclining advantage does diipate the whole; whoe chief Agent in this caue does lodge in the Head, as Fernelius doth oberve, lib. 5. cap. 3. Patholog.

The Medicines mot properly here to be applied ought to be of a liquid ubtance, and uch as may penetrate into the bottome of the Wounds: and thee ought both to dry, and diget, reolve, and attract this virulent Matter. And for this Ue Venice-Treacle, Mithridate, Myrrh and Aloes, diolved in Treacle-water, are very prevalent. Elixar Proprietat. its drops put into Sack is an excellent Medicine here. Now as touching Cold and Pain, I remit you to their proper places, where I have already enlarged. I conclude this with ome remarkable Hitoricall Obervations.

Hitory. Platerus writes, in Ob. uis, lib. 1. fol. 120. of a young Maiden, who falling from her hore by hearing unexpectedly a Pitoll dicharged, had hereupon a Reolution in her lower parts of her body, in that nature that he could not tir her hands or feet, neither had he any ene. Being carried in this condition to her Father's houe, he viewed the Wound, which was almot in the middle of her Back, to which he applied himelf; the which he conjectured was occaioned by her Fall. Upon examination of her upper parts, finding no harm or defect there, the lower parts remaining tupid, dull and reolved, the Chirurgeon immediately did apply hot Stupes to her feet, by which was ucitated omewhat of Heat. He being called in to advie, examined the whole occaion of this michief, and inquired into its caue from the Patient. She replied, the hearing a Pitol hot off unawares by one riding by her in the road o affrighted her, that he fell from her hore; upon receiving of which Fall he felt a
grievous Pain in her Back: growing faint herewith, and coming to her elf, he complained of her Back being wounded and reolved. Upon examining the Wound, which was on the right ide of her Back, near the eighth and ninth Ribs, coming downwards obliquely towards the Spine, he found it exactly round: and whereas in its Circumference there appeared no ign of Contuion, upecting it to have happened by the force of the Shot, he ordered her Cloaths to be examined, in which he alo found a hole made by the Bullet; upon which he fairly conjectured, that this Wound was made by this Shot, and that it had penetrated the Spinall marrow. Divers Chirurgeons being called into Conultation, they all did judge the ame, and by a generall conent, a Probe being ent into the Wound, part of the Vertebrae was found to be lacerated. Ten daies being expired ince the hurt, he grew wore, and troubled with Vomiting and a great Heat in the upper part of her Spine, with pain of her Head, and Spam about her Neck. Medicines being applied to thee with mall ucces, at the twentieth day he departed the world. And becaue a great dipute did arie at her death, what might be the occaion thereof, whether the Fall or the Shot, upon Diection, and by dilating of the Wound, ome part of the Spine being removed, the leaden Bullet did hew it elf lodged, the which had lacerated the Spinall marrow.

Another. Another is of Camerarius, de Oberv. Johan. Heii, who writes there of Chritopher Albertus, Son to an Apothecary, a young man of about twenty years of age, that he grew very melancholick, and by uing of a cold Diet, and uch things as were hard of concoction, did fall into an Abdominall Suppreion, accompanied as it were with Colick-pains, in which happened this Convulion called Opithotonos. Divers trong Medicines being precribed him, he took them without any effect. Afterwards having everall Clyters adminitred to him, by them he
eemed to receive ome relief; but in the interim, as oft as he covered the Stool to void his Excrements, this Paroxym invaded him. And upon econd thoughts, conultation being had why milder Medicines might not work better and more kindly, a more temperate Clyter was adminitred, made onely of Milk and Honey, adding to a pound of Milk four ounces of Honey: the which wrought very kindly, and caued the Fits omewhat to abate. But whenever the Paroxym eized him, three or four men could carce keep him in his bed: and thee ometimes happened three or four times in a day. Conidering thee Symptoms, it was generally agreed, that this Dieae was an Opithotonall Convulion, made by Coagulation in the Vena Cava, the which does abound ofttimes with thick and vicous Humours. His Drink for the Cure hereof was a Decoction of Saraparilla and Saafras, and every fourth or fifth day he had adminitred a Decoction of Milk and Honey: by which method the Fits began to abate, and on the 28th day of his Ditemper he fell into a breathing Sweat, after which the Spam began to vanih. But after this a Tremor did poes his whole Body, but chiefly his Thighs; for which his whole Spine was anointed, and by thee he peedily amended.

Hitory of Tetanos. Another young Gallant of twenty years of age, being of a thin Body, and perplexed with this Dieae, was thus cured. Jaon. cap. 21. de morb. Cerebr. ex Vealio, thus writes it. He pilt upon the Patients head almot twenty pitchers of water, four men holding the Patient upright, o as the liquour might decend upon all his lower Parts. This being done, he ordered the Patient to be peedily put to bed: within an hour after which the Patient was anointed from the Neck to the lowermot Spondyl, with his Arms and Legs, with nguent. Aregon, Martiatum, Dialth. Agripp. and Ol. Cator. and ome Chicken-broath precribed for his Diet; and by this method he perfectly recovered. Fabritius Hildanus hath a very excellent Obervation
of a Cynick Spam, fol. 37. Centur. 5. to which I recommend you.
And thus have I given you a full account of the direfull Symptoms which do attend deep and large Wounds: we come next to Wounds themelves.

div.head: CHAP. XII.
Of a Compound Wound of the Fleh, or a Hollow Wound.
div.p:
WE ought to deal with all Wounds o as they may anwer expectation: and now coming to Cavernous Wounds, we may as readily account that a Hollow Wound, which hath not onely lot a part of its Fleh, but that alo which happeneth by a imple Inciion, without los of Fleh, the Lips of which Wound, by reaon of the greatnes and large ditance, cannot be aptly united in the bottome, whence there does remain a Cavity therein. And as for the Cure hereof, we are firt to mind the Flux, for avoiding of Inflammation. And if occaion erve, and the time of the year does require it, we may breath a Vein, and precribe cooling Syrups and Decoctions, and order Purgations, and uch a thin Diet as may keep the Body in good temper. And becaue in uch large and hollow Wounds there is generally een ome preternaturall Matter to lodge in their bottomes, the which the Part of it elf is not capable to dicharge; we here ought in the firt place to ue Digetives, hereby to diget the Matter, and to bring it into a laudable ubtance, that is, uch a Matter as is both white, mooth, equall, and void
of all bad mell. And thee are to be applied no longer, then while this laudable Matter is made, and all Excrements be removed, keeping and preerving the naturall Temper of the Parts. And herein Nature is very ready to ait in this Operation: for as the Part is flehy, this is uddenly renewed, and retored by Bloud lodged in the Mucles, out of which is generated a new Fleh. With Digetives may alo be admixed Deterives: for as the firt are proper in the beginning, o the latter are as requiite in the following part. Examples of which I hall et down thus.

U.hi: nguent. Bailic. Aurei, Terebinth. Venet. lot. an.
U.U: j. Another. Vitell. Ovor. no. ij. Croc. s. mice. Or this: Bal. Peruvian. j. Ol. Catellor. Hyperic. gummat. an. j. Terebinth. Another. Venet. j. Vitel. Ov. no. j. Or this: Ol. Vitell. Ovor. ij. Terebinth. Venet. iij. Myrt. ij. Rein. Pin. Colophon. an. j Thur. in pulv. js. Sang. Dracon. vj. Cer. parum, fiat Another. Linimentum. Another for the ame: Thur. Myrrh. an. s. Sang. Dracon. j. Pic. Graec. & naval. an. ij. Pulv. Centaur. j. Terebinth. Venet. Rein. Pin. an. j. Sep. Vaccin. Digetive and Deterive. j. Cer. ij. mice. Digetives and Deterives together may be allowed thee. Mel. j. Terebinth. s. Bailic. Aur. an. s. Ol. Hyperic. cum gum. j. Vitel. Ov. Another. no. j. Croc. j. mice. Another: Succ. Apii ij. Mel. js. Pulv. Veronic. Hyperic. an. j. Farin. Fabar. s. Or this: Another. Succ. Apii, Scord. Arnoglo. Rut. an. j. Mel. Roar. jv. coque ad Syrupum, huic adde Farin. Lupinor. Pulv. Aritoloch. rot. Angelic. an. ij. Aqu. vit. s. mice. In thee Medicines being made warm may you dip your Tents and Doills or Pledgets, and o apply them to the bottome of the wounded Part.

div.p:
The Wound being hereby digeted and mundified, Satcoticks.next are we to fill up with Fleh by Sarcoticks: and thee are to be drying and deterging in repect of the Excrements. Of which ort may be reckoned nguent. Aegyptiacum, Apotolorum, Bailicon, Aureum, Fucum, Balam.
Peruvian. nguent. de Betonic. or the like. For this Ue alo this Powder prinkled upon the Wound is much commended: Rad. Irid. Florent. Aritoloch. rot. Angelic. Powder. an. ij. Fol. Scord. s. Oliban. Matich. an. ij. Croc. j. C. C. ut. & praeparat. j. mice, fiat Pulvis ubtiliimus. Or if you pleae, by adding a little Turpentine hereto, you may make it into the form of an Unguent, by adding to it alo a little Oyl of Roes and Wax.

The lat Intention is made good by Epuloticks; thee to have in them a Skinning quality: and of this ort are nguent. Deiccat. rubrum, Diapompholygos, nguent. album Camphoratum, Empl. Diapalm. De minio, &c. making your Cicatrizes of a good temper and colour.

Hitory. I conclude this with an Hitory of Fracazinus, which Alexandrinus doth write of lib. 7. De Simpl. med. facult. of one who received a Wound long and inuous, reaching from his Shoulders even to his Buttocks, in which part it was open: the exteriour Veells did end forth much of a certain Sanies; neither was it very deep, not penetrating much deeper then the Membrana Carnoa: the which could not be conolidated with many Medicines, but by the application of Cabbage-leaves boiled in black Wine was dried up, and the Patient peedily cured.

div.head: CHAP. XIII.
Of a Contued Wound.
div.p:
WE have already hewn how a Simple wound is to be cured; but when any other Affect is joyned to it, this Affect is firt to be cured, and then the Wound. Galen doth advie, if any Phlegmon, Contuion, Ecchymois,
Eryipelas, or the like, hould happen upon a Wound, thee are firt to be removed; for they onely do adde fewell to the fire. And this is held a certain rule amongt all Authours, that we mut never expect to cure a Wound, untill we have conquered the Symptoms. For as the Wound of it elf doth onely require Deiccation; o having Contuion joyned to it, this is readily to be turned into Putrefaction, and that to be converted into laudable Matter. And becaue the ordinary entrance upon the Cure of this Wound is ofttimes intercepted by the importunity of Accidents, let it be your firt care to repres thee, and then proceed to the Cure it elf. If the Accident be Pain or Tumour, allay the Pain by ome Anodyne Medicine; of which ort are Ol. Aneth. Chamomel. Lilior. Roarum, Crocus, and the like. Abate the Tumour by removing both its antecedent and conjunct Caue; the firt being the Humour firt flowing, the latter being that part of Humour which hath already made its flux. As to the firt, if it proceed of Bloud occaioning Fluxion, this is to be let out or dicharged by the place from whence it floweth, or by the place to which it floweth. This Paion is curbed and bridled by Phlebotomy, and a cooling Diet: and to keep it from flowing further, Revulion and Repulion are two proper engines to effect this; the firt withdrawing and courting the Humour into another part, the other repelling it when it is once ent. If other Humours do occaion this Fluxion, then dicharge thee by Catharticks, and uch as may anwer the nature of the Humour.

We come next to the Wound it elf: and here are we chiefly to conider thee two Intentions, (viz.) to procure Suppuration, and then to generate a new Fleh. And becaue, as Galen precribes, every Suppuration is to be procured by Putrefaction, and every thing that putrefies is affected with a hot and moit Humour, the chief Intention therefore here is, to apply uch Medicines as may
both heat and moiten; uch as are Mallows, Marh-mallows, Barley-meal, Chamomile-flowers, Melilot-flowers, and the like. As for example; Fol. Malv. Fl. Dialth. Catapl. Abinth. an. m. j. Rad. Alth. jv. coquantur in aqu. fontana, potea in mortario ubigantur, his adde Pulv. fl. Cham. Melilot. Roar. rub. an. iij. Farin. Hord. Fabar. an. iij. cum Decocto antecripto fiat Catapl. fine addendo Ol. Chamomel. Another.ij. Or this; Rad. Alth. lbs. Malv. Violar. an. m. j. coquantur & colentur, colaturae adde Butyr. Ol. Roar. an. iij. Vitell. Ovor. no. iij. Croc. j. mice. Or this; Another. Pulv. Roar. rubr. Fol. & Bacc. Myrtillor. an. ij. Farin. Hord. Fabar. an. j. Abinth. Betonic. an. s. Sem. Cumin. ij. Mel. ij. cum Vino autero q. . fiat Cataplama, fine addendo Ol. Roar. Chamomel. an. j. To the wounded Part are we to apply a Digetive made either of Turpentine, Bailicon, and Honey mixed together; or this: Mel. Digetive. Roar. Succ. Apii, an. ij. Vitell. Ovor. no. ij. Terebinth. Venet. j. nguent. Aurei s. Pulv. Myrrh. Alo. an. j. mice. In thee caes alo nguentum Apotolorum and Aegyptiacum, epecially when the bottome of the Wound is foul, may be applied; thus ordering it untill it be perfectly mundified; the which being done, fill it up with Fleh by Sarcoticks: and this will be done by nguent. Bailicon, Aureum, Balamum Peruvian. or Lucatelli. It being brought up to an equalnes, skin it with Diapompholygos, or Deiccativum rubrum. But if the Contued fleh will not be brought to Suppuration by thee, but dots rather eem to threaten a Gangrene, here are you to ue trong Lixiviums and powerfull drying Medicines, having in them power to reit Putrefaction; uch as are nguent. Aegyptiacum, Mercurius Praecipitatus, and the like, of which I have been very plentifull in my dicoure of a Gangrene. If any other Symptoms do happen, tudy their peedy overthrow, by uing uch methods and Medicines as may bring the Part into a better Temper. And if the Wound be o large that there is necearily
required a Suture, let this be done very looely; for it is enough, if by the benefit thereof you can bring the Lips of the Wound together.

Hitory. To conclude; A certain Gentleman having received a Contued wound in his Thigh, occaioned by a Shot, the Chirurgeon anointed the places which were contued with Oyl of Roes, and for this purpoe amongt the ret Unguent.did ue this Unguent; Ol. Roar. jv. Ol. ex Vitell. Ovor. j. Pulv. Vitriol. alb. j. Cer. alb. vj. Cort. med. Sambuc. ms. coquantur imul & colentur. With this Unguent were anointed all the contued Parts, which hath a ecret faculty of removing all evill Symptoms: and as to the Wound, he followed the method which we have already hown, by the benefit of which the Patient perfectly recovered.

div.head: CHAP. XIV.
Of Ecchymois, or Contuion.
div.p:
ECchymois, or an Effuion of bloud coagulated under the Skin, is allowed a Solution of Continuity, the which is generally accompanied with ome Contuion and Ruption. The Caues of which, whether procured by ome Fall, Stroke, or other Accident, you will bet undertand by the Patient's own dicoure. This Ecchymois does ometimes happen by the Apertion of the mouth of ome Veell, and then this is called Anatomois: the which is procured in repect of the Weaknes of ome Veell in that part where this plenty of bloud is cattered;
or by ome inward harp Matter which is allowed to have an inciive quality; or by Diapedeis, the which is a Trancolation or Exilition; this alo ariing from the Coat of the Veell being made rare and thin, and the Bloud being alo thin. But our preent dicoure does onely reach that which is made by Contuion.

This therefore is allowed a Solution of Continuity; and in repect of its profuion of bloud it produceth Pain, and hence ometimes do follow Abcees, the which by Tranpiration are to be digeted. A large Contuion is not without danger, for this does very often not onely procure Corruption of the Part it elf, but alo of the whole Body. This is generally reputed an Ecchymois, The true definition of an Ecchymois. in the which there is both a eparation and dilaceration of the Muculous parts, whilt Attrition is allowed to be in the head and tail of the Mucle. It taketh its diverity of figure from its variety of caue: the Parts about it are black, the Bloud being hut up therein, and cannot be dicharged by inenible or enible Tranpiration, but by Suppuration. According to the greatnes of the hurt may you judge of the danger; for great Contuions accompanying large Wounds do run the Part into Corruption.

Now whereas Hippocrates aith, that obtue Intruments are the mot proper engines for Contuion and Laceration, the mot proper Medicine for the cure of this hould be < in non-Latin alphabet > , or Suppurativum: the which ought to be temperate in heat and humour, Emplatick, and obtructing the Pores, and uch as may generate Matter. It ought alo to econd the nature and ubtance of the native Heat, and by degrees to encreae it. Hence is it, that in creating of Matter the Humour is omewhat altered: and if this Contuion does happen in any Muculous parts, that Part onely does maintain the Bruie which received the Blow or Hurt, whilt the circumjacent Parts do retain their own proper nature. For the Bloud being
out of its proper Cavity, does force it elf into ome other; and being in its motion hindred, does change its firt rudiment. And hence was it that Philalethus aith, that Bloud, Seed, and Milk, being out of their proper places, do oon run into knotty lumps and putrefy. Now in Converion of this Bloud into Matter, there is made a Pulation in the Arteries lodging in the Fleh, the which Pulation the ound man does not perceive, it lying there without Pain; and alo in repect of the great pace which is allowed them for their operation. But where there does arie Inflammation, Ecchymois, Eryipelas, or Abces, with Pain, the Wounds are alo inflamed, when they tend to Suppuration; becaue this putrefying Bloud does oon grow hot and fiery, and in this Ebullition and Fervour of the Bloud Vapours are raied, the which alo are communicated to the neighbouring Parts, and therein do alo generate an Inflammation. And this is done by Conent of Parts. The Heart taking its hare of this Inflammation does create a Fever, as Hippocrates offereth, cap. 47. lib. 2. Whilt Matter is making, it occaioneth more Pain, and does more readily ubject the Patient to Fevers, more then when it is accomplihed. The generation of this Matter does fetch its origination from trange Bloud, over-heated, untill putrefying it is turned into another ubtance.

Three Changes of Subtances. Now there are allowed three < in non-Latin alphabet > or changes hereof, which are made in the Bodies of Animalls. The firt is naturall, as the receiving the Meat into the Stomack, which is there digeted and concocted. The econd is preternaturall, or Putrednes. The third is bred out of a mixture of the former, and this is called Suppuration. The firt is made by a familiar Matter, and primogene Heat: the econd is made by an exterious Heat, and trange Matter: the third is framed by an inbred Heat, but this not chiefly governing, neither benign in Matter, not yet altogether etranged from it. Thee Rules and
Precepts, being worth a Chirurgeon's taking notice of, have I here preented from Hippocrates.

In an Ecchymois therefore are we peedily to procure Suppuration: and whereas Fluxion is chiefly to be relieved, tudy its Evacuation, by diminihing its tore which maintains it, by Phlebotomy, if nothing may hinder it, by Revulion to change its coure; and then ecure this concreted Bloud, the which if it be in the Body, is to be cattered by inward Medicines, by uch as can both diolve the concreted Bloud, and alo trengthen the Parts. And for this Ue Sperma Ceti, black Beer, Pulv. ad Caum, and the like, being taken inwardly, are good and proper. Or this Bolus; Pulv. Rhabarb. s. Bolus. Mumm. j. Rub. Tinctor. s. Sperm. Cet. gr. vj. make it into a Bolus with a little Diocord. Or this; Pulv. Powder. Symphyt. Terr. Sigillat. Rub. Tinctor. Mumm. an. j. Pulv. Rhabarb. gr. xv. mice, umat in hautu Vini generoi. The Skin of a Lamb newly pluckt off, and having Salt finely powdred prinkled thereon, with fine Powder of Scordium, Wormwood and Rue, is an excellent Medicine for a large Contuion, it being applied warm to the contued Part, and there permitted for ome time to remain on. Here alo are you to conider, if the Ecchymois do happen onely in one Part, whether it be mot apt for Reolution, or tend to Suppuration. That way which it enclineth to, you are to follow. If it tendeth to Reolution, apply Reolving medicines, to help forward its deign: if to Suppuration, procure iue, and mundify the Ulcer. And as in all other caes we oberve as a generall Maxime, that in the beginning we apply Retringents, to which omewhat of Dicuive medicines may be adjoined; o in the end we generally ought to ue Dicuive medicines: and for this purpoe take thee few. As, Far. Fabar. jv. Sal. marin. js. Pulv. Summitat. Catapl. Abinth. Scord. Rut. an. j. coquantur in Oxymelit. q. . ad Catapl. formam, fine addendo Pulv. Myrrh. Aloes,
Another. an. j. Another for the ame; Farin. Hord. ij. Pulv. Roar. rub. Myrtill. Foenugraec. an. s. Pulv. Scord. Rut. an. ij. Pulv. Salv. Veronic. Hyperic. Agrimon. an. j. coquantur in Vino rubro ad Catapl. formam, huic addendo Croc. j. Ol. Roar. Myrtillor. an. j. de Vitell. Ovor. s. Another. mice, fiat Cataplama. Another may be this: Farin. Hord. Fabar. an. jv. Bol. Armen. ij. Pulv. Gallar. virid. is. Camphor. j. cum Oxymelit. q. . fiat Cataplama. If by thee and the like you cannot reolve it, but it till does rather incline to Suppuration, bring it to Suppuration, and dicharge the Matter by cleaning the Ulcer: and to the dicoloured Parts you are to begin with comfortable Fomentations, which have in them a power to warm, trengthen, and run the Part into Maturation; uch as may be made of Wormwood, Sage, Rue, Scordium, Centaury, St. Johns-wort, Scabious, Veronica, Chamomile-flowers, Melilot-flowers, Cumine, and the like, boiled in water and wine mixed together: whereinto are to be dipped Woollen cloaths, and thee to be applied warm to the affected Parts. After this anoint them with ome convenient Oyls, as Oyl of Roes, Earth-worms, St. Johnswort, and the like.

I conclude this Chapter with thee two Hitories. Hitory.The firt whereof hall be of a Gentleman, who upon endeavouring to trike his Dog with his foot, did fall upon his Hip; with which Fall, being a very corpulent man, he felt a great Pain, happening by the Contuion he got by his Fall. The Contued place was well anointed with Oyl of Roes and Myrtills, by which the Pain ceaed, and no other Symptome or Inflammation followed the Contuion; by which onely he was perfectly cured.

Another. The econd is of a young Child of three years old, who falling down upon earnet puruit after two little Dogs, received a Contuion in the hinder part of his Head, not without much Pain, and Vomiting, with Spam in both of his Arms and Hands, o as he was generally
reputed to be beyond all hopes of Cure. Foretus being conulted herein, (who is the Authour of this Story) by anointing the Contued part with Oyl of Roes, and the nuch of his Neck with Oyl of Earth-worms, and making Frictions in the extreme Parts, the Child omewhat recovered, and was freed of his Spam. For his common Drink, was precribed green Betony to be boiled in Ale, of which he generally did drink. And the Contued place being anointed afterwards with nguent. Alabatrinum, by thee he was perfectly cured, and retored to his former health.

div.head: CHAP. XV.
Of Wounds made by the Biting of mad Dogs.
div.p:
WE arrive now at uch Wounds as do happen by the Biting of mad Dogs, and of other venomous creatures: and although other creatures, as Wolves, Cats, Foxes, and the like, may be mad; yet mot who have writ of this ubject do give the firt denomination to the Dog, as Antiochus, Paulus Aegineta, Oribaius, Cornelius Celus, and others. The generall repute of the Biting of Animalls is allowed to come under a double difference; for ome are venenate in their proper nature, and others are les venenate. Thoe are reputed venenate, which are lodged in venenate and virulent Beats; and amongt thee are reckoned the mad Dog, Serpents, Adders, Scorpions, Bailisks, Vipers, Waps, and the like. Others are aid to be les venenate, which have not in them this virulent pirit; of which ort may be reckoned Man, a Dog that
is tame, a Monkey, Hores, Swine, and the like. The Signs of either do declare their nature. Thoe which are venomous are mot dangerous, and great care not being had, they do commit their Venome to ome noble Part, and there implanting the poyon, do oon caue a peedy Death. Gordonius reporteth, that the Biting of a mad Dog is mot dangerous; for although the Patient do not feel it at preent, yet this lurking Poyon ome while after makes its appearance. I have read of a Boy, who being bit by a mad Dog, and being well after it for ix weeks, after this died of the Bite he received.

Seeing the danger is great, and how it aims at the Principalls of life, let us conult a while the reaon of this Poyon, and how it does communicate it elf. Read tells us it is communicated thee two waies; by Biting and Slaver, and by Slaver without Biting. This is ometimes received by the thick Skin of any Part. And this Matthaeus makes good, Con. 82. where he affirms of one putting his hand into a mad Dog's mouth, that within few daies after he became mad himelf. It ooner eizeth on ome Parts then on others, and is alo more readily taken by ome Perons then others. For it hath hewn its rage in ome peedily, whilt in others it hath had many daies and weeks to act its envy and malicious terrour. And hence may we collect, that this Spittle is pernicious which is contained in the Mouth, and thus agitated, rendred and elaborated into the form of Froath, the which does carry an acrimony and venenoity with it, by reaon of Choler which moves it, and this Tyrant does make this ebullition; the which being once made, is ent into the Wounds by the Teeth; by which impreion it is carried into the Body and its circumtantiall Parts; the which if they happen to be nervous, thee are preently timulated by the venenoity of the Humour, and hereby ofttimes a Spam and Convulive motions are created. If it enters either the Veins or Arteries, it peedily doth end
its venenate Vapour through thee to the Heart, and doth there tyrannize, tirring up Fevers, and exciting Syncope's, ometimes running the Part into a Gangrene and Sphacelus, by overcoming the naturall Heat by its venomous extraneous pirit.

Now as touching the knowledge of the Dog, whether mad or not, you may well gues at it by the Wound: for, as Avicen and Rhais write, if we rub the Wound with a piece of Bread, o as it may uck up the Bloud and Matter which cometh out of the Wound, this being offered to a Dog, if he refue to eat it, or to mell to it, it declares much of the Dog's being mad. Let thee Signs erve for Madnes confirmed; the Patient becomes Signs of a mad Dog's Bite.troubleome, and foameth at his Mouth, he hateth water and all liquid things, thee being the caue and occaion of his Madnes, his Pule is mall and inordinate, his Members dull and heavy, his Voice hoare, and his Breathing difficult. If he dies of his Bite, he is troubled with Syncope's, and a little before his departure you will meet him Convulive.

Cure. As to the Cure, thee Intentions are here chiefly required. Firt, to expell the Poyon from the Wound, then to trengthen the principall Parts, and defend them from it, and then to overthrow its malignity. The firt is to be performed by Alexipharmick Defenatives, the which hould contain in them Bol. Armen. Terr. Sigillat. Sang. Defenative. Dracon. an. ij. Pulv. Rut. Scord. Salv. Abinth. an. j. Farin. Fabar. ij. Hord. j. cum Album. Ovor. fiat Defenativum: or this; Spir. Vini rectificat. ij. Succ. Emplat. Rut. j. Extr. Scord. Theriac. an. ij. C. C. ut. & praeparat. Bol. Armen. an. j. Lap. Bezoard. j. mice, fiat Emplat. An Oyl for the ame: Ol. Lumbricor. Flor. Slotan. Oyl. an. j. Spir. Vini ij. Theriac. j. mice. And over thee apply this Cataplame: Farin. Fabar. jv. Pulv. Sem. Catapl. Cydonior. s. coquantur in aqua, cum pauc. Ol. Lumbricor. tunc adde Pulv. Fl. Chamomel. Melilot. Roar. rubr. an. j.
mice, fiat Cataplama, ub finem addendo Croc. s. If thee work not to any effect, apply Cupping-glaes and Ventoes to the grieved Part, with much flame; and make good Scarification: and if you cannot here well ue a Cupping-glas, yet you may carify and wah the Inciions with Spirit of wine wherein hath been diolved Treacle, or Oxycrate warm, or the like; and then in other caes may you ue Chickens, Rabbets, Pidgeons, Whelps, or the like, cut in the middle, and o applied hot to the Parts, thee having power enough in them to Emplat.call forth the Poyon. Thee following Emplaters are very beneficiall in thee caes. Caepar. aliquantul. coct. ub prun. Ferment. Farin. Sinap. an. j. Theriac. Andromach. s. Fol. Rut. Scord. an. ms. mice in Mortario, addendo parum Mell. fiat Empl. Fallopius does much commend Another.this: Pic. naval. j. Sal. Nitr. s. Sem. Sinap. ij. Caepar. Allii ub prun. coct. an. iij. Aaefoetid. Sagapen. an. ij. Stercor. Columb. js. Aritoloch. rot. Dictamn. Creten. Another. an. j. Ol. Lilior. alb. s. mice pro Empl. Or this; Galban. Sagapen. Opopanac. Aaefoetid. Myrrh. Piper. Sulphur. an. s. Stercor. Columbin. Caprar. Anat. an. js. Calaminth. Mentatr. an. s. olventur Gummi in Vino, his addendo Mel. opt. q. . pro Emplat. Thee are to be ued while the whole Poyon is extracted. Phlebotomy here is altogether ueles, for this does rather adde then extinguih the Flame: neither is Purging proper in the beginning. Keep the Wound open at leat for forty daies: if it be but mall, dilate it, for the more ready dicharge of this venenate Matter. Endeavour to trengthen the Parts inwardly by precribing a drachm or two of Mithridate in a morning, Venice-Treacle, Orviatan, Elixar proprietatis, this in ten or twelve drops; or by giving your Patient of Pil. Ruff. or Electuar. de Ov. j. in a morning. In Bitings which are les venomous, we may apply hot Oyl of Elder, the Yolk of an egg mixed with ome Butter and Saffron to eae pain, and over thee this Cataplame:
Rad. Alth. Malv. Violar. Abinth. an. m. j. coquantur in Catapl. vino & aqua, colaturae adde Pulv. fl. Chamomel. Melilot. Roar. rubr. Farin. Tritic. an. j. his addendo Vitell. Ov. no. j. Croc. j. Ol. Roar. Chamomel. an. q. . fiat Cataplama. After thee we mut come to Suppuratives, becaue of the Contuion; and for this Ue Bailicon and Fucum, or my former Digetive are proper. Then to deterge, fill up with Fleh, and skin the Wound. Fabritius Hildanus is very plentifull in Hitories of thee orts of Wounds, to whom I commend you, and hall conclude with thee Hitories, which are both rare and trange.

Hitory. Fracatorius writes of a Lad, who after eight months having been bitten by a mad Dog, the Poyon began to appear, and then it vanihed; in the interim there was not any Fever perceived, or any other ill Symptom appeared. The Patient not undertanding where this and how perniciouly it lodged, it at length made way to his Heart; the which when it had eized, it there fixed its mot implacable imprees of orrow and pain, o as he could neither tand, goe, or lie in quiet, but like one ditracted teered a very diorderly coure, growing very thirty: and that which heightned and added to the michief, he could not endure the ight of any liquid things, and had rather yield to death then to take any Cordialls or Juleps, were they never o advantageous. Hence did arie a foaming at his mouth, his eyes being trangely fixed; and within a few daies after thee direfull Symptoms made him yield to the grave.

Another. Cardanus, 9. Tract. 5. lib. 2. writes of Alexander Bracaeus, who was bitten by a mad Dog, and having many Phyicians in Conultation, they enquiring the caue hereof, found that he had kied a mad Dog; and the day following, as they preaged, he died. Hence therefore may we ee, that the Spittle of a mad Dog is the wort of Poyons; for being thus inwardly taken by a Kis, the Dog did bite him, upon which Bite he died. Nicolaus
writes, that the Son of a Painter in Venice being bitten by a mad Dog, and cured by his Phyicians, had not the igns of one bitten by a mad Dog until eight months after. And Amatus Luitanus, Cent. 7. tetifieth, that he aw a man of Thealonica, the third year after his being bitten with a mad Dog, to have run mad himelf.

div.head: CHAP. XVI.
Of Wounds made by the Bite of an Adder, or any other venomous Creature.
div.p: THee may be properly called Stinging Bites; and thee came into the world oon after Man's Fall, and have continued ever ince, for the punihment of inful Man. I hall begin this Dicoure with the Bite of an Adder, which by ome is called Coluber, quia colit umbras, or Ã Lubricis tractibus, as Oribaius oberveth; that is, becaue it haunteth Shadowy and grovy places, or from her winding Paths. When this Animall does bite a man, the Part becomes of a leaden colour, and very painfull. If not preently cured, foetid and black Matter does iue from the Sore.

hs Cure. As touching the Cure hereof, you may ue thoe which are precribed in the foregoing Chapter. Dres the Wound with Treacle diolved in the Oyl of Scorpions, inwardly giving your Patient Treacle-water, or Aqua Scordii compoit. to which may be added a little Vinegar, Carduus-water, Rue-water, and the like.

Hitory. Paraeus, lib. 20. cap. 23. hews how he cured a Cook bitten with an Adder, upon gathering of wild Hops from a hedge. So oon as he was bitten in the Hand, he ucked the Wound with his lips, hereby thinking to mitigate the pain, and extract the poyon: but o oon as his tongue had touched the Wound, it welled o big, that it hindred his peech; beides which, his Arm even to his Shoulder o tumefied, and caued uch harp pains, that he twice fainted away. In this mierable condition being undertaken by him, he wahed his Mouth with Treacle diolved in White wine, adding to it Aqua vitae; the Arm was carified with many and deep Scarifications; and the Bloud, which was both waterih and full of Serum, was permitted to flow plentifully from the incied Parts, the which were afterwards well wahed with Mithridate and Treacle diolved in Aqua vitae. The Patient was after this committed to his warm bed, and there caued to weat, not to leep, let hereby the Poyon might be drawn to the inward Parts. By this method all the malign Symptoms ceaed, and the Wound was kept open for a long while, for the dicharge of the peccant Matter, and wahed with Treacle and Wine: and within a mall while after he recovered. (By the way, uch people who do make it their trade to catch Adders, do apply the Powder of them to the affected Part, if they be bitten, and do take the ame inwardly.)

Bitings of Toads. To thee I hall adde Toads, for thee two are the mot venomous creatures we have in England. And what a Toad is, is o well known, that it will be needles to et down its decription. This onely I hall aert, it leapeth not as do Frogs, but creepeth lowly; partly by reaon of its hort legs, and partly in repect of its dull body. If it be tirred, it wells, and looks very ugly with its flaming eyes. It infecteth by its venomous Spittle or Slaver, and whom it thus infecteth it does inflict in them mot of thee following Symptoms: it generally
does change the Colour of the body, the Patient does find difficulty of breathing, is perplexed with troubleome Syncope's, with blacknes of Lips and Tongue, Raving, cold Sweat, and the like.

As touching the Cure hereof, Treacle, Mithridate, Orviatan, Electuar. de Ovo, Aqu. Theriacal. Bezoard. mineral. Harts-horn, Terra Lemnia, and the like, are good; and to the wounded Part ue trong Lixivium's, uch as I have et down in the Curing of a Gangrene, being made of Scordium, Rue, Angelica, Wormwood, Sage, Bays, and the like.

I will conclude this with two remarkable Hitories. Hitory.The firt is of Johannes Boccatius, who while he was porting with his Beloved in his Garden near a bed of Sage, by rubbing his Teeth and Gums with ome of the Sage-leaves, he peedily died. His Wife was called before a Judge, who enquiring of her how her Husband became poyoned, he carried with her ome of the ame Sage-leaves to hew him, and tating thereof in his preence, died alo, to the great admiration of all the Bytanders. The wie Judge conidering of which, did much upect this Sage, and ordered it to be pluckt up from the roots, and commanded it to be committed to a workman's care to clear the ground: upon the doing of which, there appeared a great black Toad, which had harboured at the bottome of the Sage, the which by its poyonous Vapour and tabifick Illuvies did infect the whole Plant with its venomous Saliva or Slaver; thee two taking whereof, it did occaion the los of both their Lives. And hence may be collected, although Toads have no Teeth, yet have they heard Gums, and the parts to which they adhere they do o cloely contringe and cloe, that they compell and force their whole Poyon into the whole part, and thereby do infect the whole Body by their fatning.

Another. I have alo read from a very Worthy Friend, of two Merchants, who while Dinner was providing, took a few turns about the Garden which belonged to the Houe, wherein they delighted themelves with the beauty and hape of the Sage-leaf; of which they pluckt ome, and thee being unwaht they put them into a Glas of Wine. They had carce dined, but by drinking of this Wine they were taken with a Vertigo, all things eeming to their view to turn round: and being thus blinded, they both fell into a Syncope, and were peedily afterwards overtaken with Convulion; their Tongues and Lips grew black, with a horrid Apect, accompanied with cold Sweats, and their whole Bodies were raied into a Tumour by this Venome; whereupon both very uddenly died. It being generally reported that they were both poyoned, the man of the houe and his ervants were all convened before a Judge, for upicion of poyoning thee two Gentlemen; who upon their Examination declared by a generall conent, that themelves putting ome Sageleaves into their Wine were herewith poyoned. The Judge hereupon ending for a Phyician, and enquiring of him whether Sage might be infected with Poyon, he preently aerted it might. He further enquired of the Mater of the Garden, whether any virulent Slaver, Froath, or Matter, was upon the Sage. To which they all readily anwered, There was. And upon making a Cavity at the bottome of the Sage-bed, there was found a great Toad, the which then was conjectured to poyon the Plant at the root by its Slaver and venenate Liquor. And hence may we collect how imprudent all uch men are, who do readily eat Herbs and Fruits newly plucked, without being either wahed or wiped.

div.head: CHAP. XVII.
Of Wounds made by Poyoned Weapons.
div.p:
IF any Wound be tinged with Poyon, we are to haten its extirpation by Alexipharmicks: and becaue this Poyon does conit of very ubtile parts, whoe envious qualities it chiefly does tudy to fix and hindge upon the Heart; and whereas this ill-conditioned Poyon does corrupt the Body, and turneth it into its nature, and is not here at quiet, untill it does reach the Fountain of life, there creating a change in the principall Faculty, and there getting conquet does peedily dipatch and demolih the whole naturall Faculty; let us enquire into its nature, and ee what forms and hapes it does carry. Hippoc. 6. Epid. Text. 6. calls it < in non-Latin alphabet > , or Maleficum; the Greeks call it < in non-Latin alphabet > or Corruptorium. And hence Virgil, Aeneid. 9. hath this vere,
ngere Tela manu, ferrÃºmque armare veneno:
and Homer, Ody. 1. hath this,
< in non-Latin alphabet >
< in non-Latin alphabet >
that is, Pharmacum homicidum quaerens, ut ei eet unde agittas oblineret. But as touching Poyon it elf, it is generally allowed a compound ubtance, not naturall, the Heart's great enemy, and that treacherous Invader which does corrupt the whole Body, and does overthrow the naturall Temper thereof. And as touching this, there are various Opinions extant: for ome there are who write, that it may be o made, that it cannot inflict its cruelty in ome in a moneth; in others in the pace of a year,
in ome in a greater time. And that it may be o made, as to kill ooner or later, is out of doubt. Now that which it chiefly aims at is the detruction of the native Heat and radicall Moiture, endeavouring both to extinguih and corrupt them. It hath various ubjects on which it hath its dependance, as a Vapour, Juice, or a terretriall ubtance: and thee three do comprehend all.

Theophratus, lib. Plant. 9. cap. 15. writes, that the Aethiopians did anoint their Arrows with a petiferous Root. Lead alo is very ready to take the impres of Poyon: for both Nature and Experience do make good, that as Metalls are purged by the Fire, and o forced to leave their terrene and faeculent ubtance and impurities; o although the Fire does perform this very exactly, yet thee Metalls may imbibe a trange ubtance by their nature. As for example, take Vinegar, Soot, Salt, and the Juice of Hore-Radih-root, and mix them together, and let them dry, and you will find them make the ubtance of Iron. And Iron it elf, being ofttimes infued herein, will oon harden at that rate, that unles you have experienced the ame, you can carce give credit to it: and on the contrary, being oft extinguihed in the Juice of Hemlock, Soap, and Marh-mallows, it will peedily grow oft. Tin and Lead being ofttimes extinguihed in the Juice of Squills, do o affect thee, that they do uncloath their outward coat, whilt the other thereby is made black and oft. The which could not be, if they retained not in them ome of its pirit and virtue. And although the Fire doth dimis and purge thee, yet they may be granted with eae to imbibe another kind of ubtance. Thus how oft have we een Copper tinged and grow yellow by applying to it pirit of Lapis Calaminaris, and Tutty; and again to grow white, by the pirit of Arenick, Orpiment, and the like? Whence we may inferre, that Metalls, out of which thee Intruments of michief
are made, as Shot, Bullets, and the like, may receive a pirituous ubtance anwering their nature, out of which, as out of o many various mercuriall, foetid and lethiferous waters, they eem to be framed, by adhibiting the Juice of Wolfsbane, Squills, Apium RiÃ»s, or Herba Sardonica, and the like, and of venomous Beats, which by reaon of their contrariety of ubtance do hurt and corrupt our ubtance.

As thus, for example: Apium RiÃ»s does infect by Laughing; of which Apuleius aith, that if one take thereof in the morning fating, it kills him with Laughing. Tragus, lib. 1. cap. 159. writes of a Woman gathering an Hemlock-root amongt Parnips, and boiling them together, and eating thereof, that it made her as it were o intoxicated, that he endeavoured to climb up the houe, and did think he could fly. But by taking a draught of Vinegar he was recovered hereof. A man having the Juice of Wolfsbane mixed with his Bread died the third day, with a great company of formidable Symptoms which attended him. This is reputed to have in it that venome that is carce to be overcome by the bet of Alexipharmicks. Nighthade alo hath allowed a veneniick quality, as Tragus affirmeth, Hitor. Stirp. lib. 3. cap. 43. Mercurialis. writes, that the Mandrake-apple, called by ome Bella Donna, being eaten by ome Children, allured to feed on it by its fair and beautifull looks, it hath peedily killed them. Lemnius declares, Herb. bib. cap. 12. that having in Summer-time carelely gathered a Mandrake-apple, he did hang this fair and pecious fruit in his Cloet, where itting a while he grew o leepy, that he could carce hake it off, forgetting his Apple did hang over his Head. Waking on a udden, and conulting with himelf what was or might be the caue of this his Sleepines, and cating his eyes upwards, he epied this Apple hanging over his Head, and removed it: the which being removed, he began peedily to grow freh and brisk
again. Ponzettus, lib. 6. cap. 32. de Veneno, writes, that he aw a man, who had taken a drachm and a half of Hellebore, to die preently. Matthiolus, lib. 4. cap. 141. writes, that a preent Poyon being made out of the Juice of white Hellebore, and Arrows or Shot being herein macerated and illinated, they do caue peedy death to that peron wherein they are lodged, or in thoe Parts through which they do pas.

Thus have I hewn you, that a venenate Mixture being made of any of thee, and Weapons made either of Wood or Iron macerated therein, and then ent into the muculous Parts, they do there peedily hew their venomous qualities; the which if they be not peedily fetched out, they do leave their pernicious marks of Venome, which does prove a perfect detroyer of the whole. And as daily experience does teach us, many petiferous and venenate Mixtures are and have been of late invented and found out. And if Bullets or the like Intruments be herein dipped, tempered, and tinged, and hot into any Part, occaion a Wound, although it be not adherent, yet in its quick paage this Poyon hath that ubtile, nimble and petiferous quality, that it does peedily creep from the mall Veells to the greater, untill it hath got advantage of the principall Parts; and having once got footing therein, it peedily does there exercie that furiounes, that it does contract the Life of man into a mall compas of warmth and heat. And hence let no man doubt, that Wounds thus made by Shot, or any other kinds of Intruments which have power enough in them to receive Poyon, but that they may be made poyonous. And by how much thee are made of very ubtile parts, by o much the readier may they penetrate: and their malign Vapours being ent through the Veins, Nerves and Arteries, do at once infect both the naturall, animall, and vitall Faculties, in which conflict they do uffocate by their contrary preternaturall mixtures. As often therefore as
any thing of Poyon is dreaded in a Wound, we are chiefly to have a repect to its dangerous attempts: and becaue uch Wounds as are made by poyoned Weapons are for the mot part mortall, not o much in repect of the quality of the Wound, as in repect of the quality of the Poyon; we are therefore firt to leen its vigour, and that becaue it aims altogether at the Heart, the Fountain of Life.

Cure. Two Intentions. In this Cure thee two Intentions do chiefly offer themelves; firt, that we trengthen the Heart againt its fury, and that we peedily draw forth the Venome the ame way and by the ame Orifice it was taken in. And though in other Wounds Solution of Continuity does onely require Union; yet here, having Poyon adjoyned, as a grand enemy to our Nature, this is firt to be extracted and dicharged. And this is to be done by keeping the Wound open. In other Wounds indeed it mut be our greatet care, to avert Fluxion and all other Symptoms from the affected Parts by Purging and Phlebotomy: but in poyoned Wounds, o long as the Poyon urgeth, we are here contrarily to endeavour the Attraction of this Poyon to the affected Part, and by that to dicharge it.

And here, that we may not run our elves upon the rocks of Mitake and Unadviednes, we are firt to conider in what part this Wound happeneth. For if it hath happened in the Nervous parts, it is very dangerous: for hereupon by applying of harp and biting Medicines or Cauteries, Convulion does ofttimes arie. If the Wound happeneth in that Part where we may not with afety earify, nor apply thee harp Medicines, we mut here apply uch Medicines as may fetch forth this Poyon by their own propriety and ubtance. We are with all peed to fetch out the Poyon, and to leen its vigour. Thus if the Fleh of the Wound be livid, and its colour contrary to that of other Parts, accompanied with extraordinary
Pains, Inflammations, and Debilitation of the whole Body, or Alienation of the Mind, and thee happen without any manifet caue, thee in every repect do declare Poyon to be preent.
