In thee caes the Chirurgeon is to arme himelf with Bole-Armeniack, Smaragd. Bezoar. Scorzonary roots, Scord. Rue, Angelica, Gentian, Tormentill, Bitort, Balme, Veronica, St. Johns-wort, and the like, being made either into Decoctions, Syrupes, or the like. Amongt Compounds may be reckoned Orviatan, Theriac. Andromach. Mithridat. Electuar. de Ovo, Diateeron, Confect. de Hyacinth. Aqua Theriacal. Scord. compott. Tinctur. Croc. Elixar Proprietat. and the like. As to the affected Part, this may be evocated either by Cupping-glaes with much flame, if to be permitted, or to carify the Part o as the bloud may come out plentifully. After this it is to be wahed with warm Vinegar, in which Mithridate or Venice Treacle hath been diolved. For this purpoe Chalk alo mixed with Honey and Treacle is very good. Garlick and Onions beaten with ome Carduus benedictus is by ome much commended. For this alo the Actuall Cautery is uefull, if it may with afety be applied. To the wounded Part may this be applied; Terebinth. Venet. ij. Ol. Hyperic. j. Theriac. Andromach. s. Euphorb. recent. Terr. Sigillat. an. ij. parum coquantur imul, and apply it. In this cae alo Praecipitate, or Aegyptiacum to which ome Mithridate is added, is very proper. Avicen for this Ue does much commend this following Emplat. Ferment. acr. Mell. opt. an. lbjs. Vic. Emplat. Quercin. jv. ex quibus fiat Emplat. Or for this purpoe take thee following. Ammoniac. Galban. Bdell. an. s. Another. Styrac. liquid. iij. Sulphur. ign. non expert. Myrrh. an. ij. Euphrob. Praecipitat. an. j. Ol. Mattheol. Terebinth. an. ij. diolventur Gummi Aceto Scillitico, & cum caeteris miceantur, & cum Pic. naval. q. . fiat Emplat. Or this: Summitat. Hyperic. m. ij. Cardu. benedict. Scord. Tabac. Another.
Vincetox. an. m. j. Rut. ij. Rad. Serpentin. ij. Abinth. s. contundantur, & modo Emplatri admoveatur. This alo is much commended by Quercetan, both for attracting the Poyon, and alo for drawing forth the Bullet, or the like: Another. Ammoniac. Bdell. olut. in Acet. roat. ij. Galban. s. Mumm. Thur. Matich. an. iij. Camphor. ij. Corall. utriuque, Magnet. praeparat. Aphalt. Carab. an. s. Rad. Aritoloch. rot. Serpentin. Arundin. an. ijs. Cer. Pic. naval. an. iij. Alabatr. iij. Ol. Terebinth. Ovor. an. q. . fiat Emplat. This Cataplam does much good, being applied to the Defenative.whole affected Member: Fl. Verbac. Hyperic. Roar. rubr. an. pug. ij. Fol. Rut. & Hyocyam. an. m. j. Camphor. s. coquantur cum Aceto in Cataplamatis formam. This does both eae Pain, and prevent Inflammation.

When the Poyon is all drawn forth, fill up the Wound being well digeted and deterged. And here, according to Celus order, are we to make a good Bandage over the Part, but not too trict. And if the Poyon have onely eized ome mall extreme Part, if there be no good to be done at the firt, amputate the Member; for delays do here prove very dangerous: hereby taking care that the Venome do not pread any further, for this remaining maketh the bet of Medicines of mall effect. In other caes diget, mundify, incarn, and skin, as you doe in other Wounds.

Hitory. To conclude; Cteias, an old Authour, in lib. de Rebus Pericis, writes of a Woman who through her whole lifetime dreaded Poyon, and made it her greatet care to ecape it. She invited another woman to dinner; who eeing her Knife lie on the Table, the which he for many years before never parted from her ide but at dinnertime, took up this Knife, and poyoned it at the end. She cutting her victualls therewith was oon dipatched of her life. The other parts of the meat which were untouched by the Knife were void of all Poyon. Hence alo may we learn, that all uch people as do dread Poyon
mut not let other people be their Carvers. For Mercurialis writes, lib. de Venenis, that this Woman under pretence of kindnes carved for the other which dreaded the Poyon, who dreamed not of any poyonous quality to be hrowded by her; which yet proved the los of her Life.

Another. A Captain being wounded by a poyoned Bullet, was by this following method cured. The Wound being carified, then the Actuall Cautery was applied, and afterwards this following Medicine ued; Ol. Sambuc. Mixture.j. Ol. Myrrh. ij. Sulphur. iij. Spir. vini q. . fiat mixtura: above which was applied Theriaca Andromachi, and this Cordiall Potion ordered him; Aqu. Aceto. iij. Mithridat. Cordiall.s. Syr. Limon. js. Diocord. j. Terr. Lemn. ij. mice. The fifth day was applied this following Unguent; Cer. Citrin. Pic. naval. Seb. Ovin. Ol. Antiqu. Unguent. an. ij. Galban. s. mice: and with this ometimes was mixed Aegyptiacum. The Wound being hereby digeted and mundified, it was filled up and skinned as other Wounds.

The Spaniards do generally poyon their Weapons with the Juice of white Hellebore, which Weapons thus poyoned if they happen to touch the Veins, o as the leat part of the Bloud be therewith affected, they oon die who are hurt hereby. Thoe Compoitions alo made of Arenick, Sublimate, Cinnaber, Realger, and the like, how apt they may be made for this ue, no knowing man will deny. But to treat further hereof would be too tedious: I therefore do recommend you to Schenckius, Parrey, and other uch Authours, which have writ fully of thee things.

div.head: CHAP. XVIII.
Of Gunhot-Wounds.
div.p:
SUch Maters of Art who have dwelt many years in the Wars, and have hazarded their Lives as well as their Fortunes with their experience therein, will currantly grant, that every young Chirurgeon, who intends to doe his King ervice and his Country a kindnes, his Art right, and his Patients pleaure, ought well to undertand the Therapeutick part of his Art, before he enters upon the Practick. And when they enter the tage of Gunhot-Wounds, they ought o readily to be prepared with the Knowledge of them, and the Intruments which do occaion them, that they may make their peedy addres to their Entrance, Form and Shape, and from thence derive their firt Intention. This part of Chirurgery does not o particularly belong to the City-Chirurgeon or Countrey Practicioner, Dometick Wars not being o frequent: yet to every one it is very uefull and profitable, as upon Accidents, or Duells, and the like. But as to thee Wounds, as they are artificiall, o hould they meet with a man of Art to undertake them. For hereto do belong many weighty Coniderations; as the Difference of thee Weapons, and the Places whereinto they penetrate. And out of thee two do arie two Intentions, (viz.) of Cure, and Extraction. The Weapons Shapes, Form, and Make, are alo to be conidered; and their ubtance of which they are made, being either of Wood, Iron, Steel, Lead, Bras, Glas, or Bone; with the variety of their Forms, being either long, triangular, quadrangular, round, obtue, harp, and the like; thee alo
being either large, or mall: repect alo is to be had to their Number, being one, or more. And having of every of thee given you a light draught, being conducted by Hippocrates, the Mater of the Ceremony, I here do commend you to the Figure, which does relate how the humane Body may receive the impres of many kinds of warlike Intruments, no Part being hot-free from the Head to the Foot. The Figure is preented you before, near the beginning of my dicoure of Wounds in generall; and alo in that of particular Wounds.

Before I enter upon the generall Treatie of Gunhot-Wounds, let us take a mall view, and ee what Gunpowder and Shot are made of. And here may we find, that a Francican Fryer, called Bartholdus, Anno 1380. being an Alchymit, was the firt that found out the true Compoition of Gunpowder, which is now in ue. Roger Bacon 1284. does make mention of Gunpowder, with everall others before him; but it never came at its due perfection of Compoition till the time of the aforeaid Fryer. Which Compoition we may find framed out of The Compoition of Gunpowder not venomous.thee Simples, Salt-peter, Sallow or Willow-coal, Sulphur, and Aqua vitae. This therefore in its eence mut not be allowed venenate, daily experience evincing the contrary, by hewing and declaring the contrary effects. Thus Sulphur (which is the firt) is o far from Poyon, that it is accounted a mot excellent Medicine for Affects of the Lungs, and not for thee alone, as Galen aith, 9. Simpl. 36. It is an admirable Medicine againt the Itch, and a thing at this day ued much for the ame. Its Spirit is ofttimes inwardly precribed in Juleps for the allaying of Fevers. And in this place, being of an Oleaginous ubtance, it retaineth the fire longer then the Coal being once kindled. Salt-peter is alo ued in Burning-fevers, cooling and allaying the Patient's thirt. And as all Salts have a Communion with each other; o this, being of thin and ubtile parts, is very free from any Venome.
For take it from its Habitation, where you may ee for the mot part how and where it dwelleth, it cannot be allowed to have any dealings with Poyon; for it is made out of a fatty Subtance, forcing it elf through the Walls of ome old and cold Cellars. As to Sallow or Charcoal, which is the third Ingredient, the which does peedily take fire, this alo is void of all Poyon. And for the Wine or Aqua vitae, how far this is different from Poyon, every boon Companion and Good fellow will ufficiently acquaint you. Thus have I preented you with a brief decription of Gunpowder, and its eence, and touching its tranmutation into a fiery quality. Experience and reaon will fairly contradict its having any commerce with Poyon. And if any be deirous to know the reaon, why Wounds made by Gunhot do generally look black; I anwer them, that it is not the effect of Heat brought with the Bullet, but the force of Contuion, which does dicolour the fleh. The which I am ufficiently atisfied in, being made an Example of the ame in the Dutch Wars 1665. and 66. where being Chirurgeon of one of his MAJESTIE's Ships, I was wounded by the wind of a 24 pound Bullet, by which my Arm was mierably fractured and contued. But to proceed; this Contuion cannot but be great in repect of its violence it is ent with.

And this brings me to the econd thing, the Shot or Bullet: and thee are made of Lead for the mot part in pitched Battels ahore, as in Armies; although at Sea chiefly of Iron. This is very currant alo, that thee of their own nature do carry no Poyon in them. For Lead being beaten to powder is good for old Ulcers; and applied in its own metallick form and beaten thin, it does depres the lips of old ordid Ulcers, and top the encreae of Scirrhous Tumours. Beides this, have we not een many Bullets hot into the Body, and there to have remained for everall years, without any hurt or detriment
to the Patient? Lead therefore of its own imple quality we ground to be void of all Poyon: but how ready this may be made to take its impres, we have already declared.

As touching the Differences of Gunhot-Wounds. We now therefore come to the Wound it elf. And he that will accurately undertand the difference of thee Wounds, mut well conider the Nature of the Parts which are thus wounded, their ubtance, ue, action, poition, ene, and figure; the eence of the Diviion or Solution of Continuity, and its proper differences: all which are the true rules which mut direct him to his curative method. To this knowledge alo does conduce the right undertanding of their proper differences, being either large or mall, uperficiall or deep, long or hort, thick or thin, and the like. Some of which are mot proper for detruction of the whole Body, others more apt for taking off a Part; ome mot fit for paing through the Center, others onely lacerating the Nervous and Muculous parts; ome having in them power to break Bones, others warrant onely to lacerate and contue the Fleh; ome of thee made of their own metalls, others having added to them trange bodies: every of which carry with them force enough to caue Solution of Continuity.

Signs of a Gunhot-Wound. The Signs of thee Wounds are alo taken from their Figure, or Colour, for they are generally round, and of a livid Colour; from the Sene being there inflicted, making or cauing an obtue ene in the Part, or Contuion, the Part chiefly uffering an Ecchymois by reaon of the Bullet. If thee appear, they declare a Gunhot-Wound.

Preage. Come we next to the Judgment and Preage hereof. Thee are generally allowed dangerous for three everall reaons, regarding either the Excellency of the Part affected, the Hurt and the vehemency occaioned by the greatnes of the Weapon, and then its Malignity. Thus
if the principall Parts, as the Brain and its ubtance, be wounded, we do judge the Wound to be lethiferous. If the Lungs, Diaphragma, Ventricle, Spleen or Kidneys be hurt by hot, every of thee auming the names of principall Parts from their Office, they are for the mot part deadly. Of the ame kind may be reckoned Wounds received in the Intetines or Bladder; thee being Spermatick and Membranous parts, denying Agglutination. If the Flehy parts onely be wounded, and the Contitution good, thee may with eae be cured. Wounds of this kind are harder of cure then others, by reaon of the Contuion. Wounds by how much the larger and deeper they are made, with dilaceration of the Nerves and Nervous parts, and fracture of the Bones, are accounted the more dangerous. Wounds alo in the Joynts have their variety of Symptoms, the which they do fetch from their greatnes. Thoe Wounds which have Venome complicated with them are very dangerous. In the mot deperate caes we are not perfectly to depair, for Nature does ometimes play that happy part which Art could never expect. And hence Cornelius Celus does advie, to ue our bet skill and judgment even in the mot deperate cae, rather then to leave the Patient void of all help.

Cure. As touching the Cure of thee Wounds, becaue they are complicated with various Indipoitions, they do require Five Intentions requited.a diverity of Intentions. And hence, as a generall Maxime, are we to take our Firt Intention from that Symptome which is mot direfull and urgent, not neglecting the Wound. Hence therefore, if any preternaturall body, as Bullet, Arrow, Splinter, or the like, do accompany this Wound, this is firt to be extracted, as being its chief Caue; the which being removed, the Affect does ceae: and without a regard to which, the Wound is not to be cured. For this does bring Pain and Inflammation with it, the which are firt to be corrected and abated. The Second is, to eae and awage Pain,
which is a great enemy to thee Wounds; for Fluxion does proceed hereby, and this does raie the Wound into a Tumour, the which is known by its colour, heat, and dimenion. The Third is, to bring the Contued and Wounded parts into a fair Digetion. The Fourth is, to mundify and cleane the Wound from all filth and excrements, and to fill it up with Fleh, and skin it. And the Lat is, to correct all Symptoms which may happen. Of each of thee in their order.

Firt Intention. And firt, as touching the Firt Intention, of this I have already ufficiently enlarged; where alo I have given you a view of thoe Intruments which are very proper for performing of this Operation: I hall therefore not charge you here with any further dicoure hereof.

Second Intention. Come we therefore to the Second, as touching the awaging of Pain: and of this alo I have fairly touched. But becaue in thee Wounds there is generally a vehement Pain attendant on them, which does weaken the Patient, hindreth Nature, caueth Fluxion, proternateth the Faculties, and produceth the mot direfull Symptoms, I mut here a little enlarge thereof. For if this be not removed, expect no happy proceeding as to your Cure. To this Symptom ought we to make a peedy application for its overthrow, by changing the Temper of the whole Body, and making ue of uch Topicks as may challenge its removall. Amongt uch Engines may be accounted Cataplams and the like, uch as may both abate Pain, and intercept Fluxion: and thee may be made of Beanmeal, Barley-meal, with Powder of Roes, Myrtills, Mallows, and the like, boiled in Milk. To which may be added Ol. Roar. Axung. &c. And for allaying and quieting hereof, take thee following Medicines. Ol. Sambuc. Oyl.ij. Sulphur. viv. ij. parum coquantur, & utere. Oyl of Turpentine with Hyperic. cum Sulphure are excellent Medicines here. Pain being bred by ill Humours or Cacochymy, thee are to be removed by right ordering of
the whole Body: (but this more properly belonging to the Phyician, I leave it to him:) then proceed to the affected Part. And for our Ue we may meet with everall Cataplams, Unguents, Oyls, Fomentations, Emplaters, and the like, for eaing of Pain in thee caes. To begin Catapl.with Cataplams: Rad. Alth. Conolid. major. an. j. Fl. Chamomel. Melilot. Roar. Hyperic. an. ms. Summitat. Abinth. pug. ij. his addendo Farin. Fabar. Hord. Rad. Alth. in pulv. an. js. fiat Catapl. cum Lacte. Or this: Another. Farin. Hord. Fabar. an. jv. Pulv. Myrtillor. j. Pimpinell. Conolid. major. Hyperic. an. s. coquantur in aqu. & vino rubro q. . cui adde Ol. Sambucin. Roar. an. js. Vitell. Ovor. no. ij. mice. As for Fomentations, take Fomentat.thee. Fol. vic. Pomor. minutim conci. cum fruct. m. iij. Rad. Alth. cum foliis Malv. Violar. an. m. ij. Lin. Foenugraec. an. ij. Fl. Cham. Melilot. Roar. an. pug. ij. Fl. Sambuc. ms. coquantur cum Lacte pro Fotu. This doth admirably abate Inflammations, awage Pain, and does very peedily run the Part into Suppuration. A Defenative Defenative.for the ame. Pulv. Roar. rubr. Myrtillor. an. j. Bol. Armen. Terr. Sigillat. an. vj. Succ. Plantag. Solatr. an. j. Acet. Roat. ij. Ol. Roar. Myrtin. an. ij. Cer. ij. mice pro Defenativo. Ambroe Parry in this cae does much commmend Ol. Catellorum or Oyl of Whelps, being Defenative.of great Virtue in Gunhot-Wounds. Oyl of Roes, Vinegar, and the Whites of Eggs beaten together, with a little Powder of Bol. Armen. and Sang. Dracon. and laid over the Part, will doe very well. In thee Wounds we are alo to repect Ligature, being neither to be applied too trict nor too looe: the firt occaioning Pain and Fluxion, and o Inflammation; the latter making a ready way for the falling off of the Dreings. And if there be fear of Inflammation, which does generally attend till the eventh day, ue the ame Remedies, and change them twice in a day. The Tents or Pledgets to be applied to thee Wounds hould be dipped in Oyl of Turpentine,
St. Johns-wort, and a little Aqua vitae mixed together: and ue thee untill the Inflammation be pat.

Third Intention. The Third Intention is atisfied by Suppuration, that is, by uch Medicines which by their innate Heat can purchae Matter, or bring the Wound to Digetion. And this ought to be done peedily alo, let the excrementitious and foul Matter lodged in the Wound, and not peedily fetched out by Suppuration, do procure Fevers, Pains, and other horrid Symptoms. And thee are allowed their everall orders. For the firt you may order this: Ol. Roar. iij. Vitell. Ov. no. j. mice. A econd Digetives.may be this: Ol. Roar. ij. Vitell. Ovor. no. ij. Croc. parum. A third is of this ort: Terebinth. jv. Cort. Thur. Matich. an. iij. Ol. Roar. Hyperic. an. j. Vitell. Ovor. no. ij. Croc. parum, mice. Quercetan does commend this; nguent. Bailicon ij. Butyr. recent. j. Another. Praecipitat. js. mice. Or for the ame Ue take this; Cer. nov. Rein. Pin. Pic. naval. an. jv. Sep. Hircin. Another. Medul. erur. Vitulin. an. ij. Oeyp. humid. j. Ol. Lin. lbj. liquefactis omnibus & trancolatis, fiat nguentum, cujus ume ij. & his adde Praecipat. ij. This is accounted a mot excellent Medicine in this cae.

Fourth Intention. The Fourth Intention is, to mundify, and generate Fleh where it is lot. And thee are performed by Mundificatives, Sarcoticks, and Epuloticks. And for this nguent. ex Apio, Apotolor. AEgyptiacum, or Honey of Roes, with Turpentine and Juice of Smallage mixt together, are good. And thee and the like are to be ued after a Digetion hath appeared, Pain and Inflammation being vanihed, and all other Symptoms abated. And for this Ue thee Medicines are proper. Mel. jv. Farin. Deterive. Orob. ij. Oliban. Ireos, an. j. Succ. Ap. jv. mice. Another for the ame: Mel. v. Farin. Lupinor. Hord. Another. an. s. Myrrh. ij. Succ. Ap. Abinth. an. js. Terebinth. Venet. js. bulliant Succi cum Farinis, & potea adde Pulveres, & fiat nguentum. If a great quantity of Sanies Unguent.
or Excrements does appear in the Wound, you may order this; Terebinth. clar. Succ. Ap. an. ij. Farin. Orob. j. Aegyptiac. s. plus vel minus: or this; Terebinth. iij. Vitell. Ovor. no. ij. Aegyptiac. j. mice. To diget and fill up with Fleh, thee following are mot uefull: as, nguent. Aurei ij. Bailic. Fuc. an. j. Terebinth. Mel. Roar. an. s. Farin. Fabar. iij. Pulv. Praecipitat. iij. mice. Injection.An Injection for the ame may be this, if the Wound be very hollow; Fol. Veronic. Betonic. Scabio. Agrimon. Hyperic. Centaur. Virg. aur. an. m. j. Aritoloch. rotund. Irid. an. j. coquantur in aqua & vino imul mixt. his colatis adde Mel. Roar. jv. ad lbj. Decoct. antecript. Myrrh. Alo. an. j. Spir. vini jv. The Wound being thus mundified from its Excrements, a filling up with Fleh will eaily follow, by hortning your Tents; and when it hath arrived at this, Nature, like a good Nure, does help forward towards the performing the ret, being aited by the application of Bailicon, Fucum, or the Powder.Ue of this Catagmatick Powder: Rad. Irid. Aritoloch. rot. Angelic. an. j. Oliban. Matich. an. ij. Croc. j. C. C. ut. & praeparat. j. mice, fiat Pulvis. To this, if you intend to have it more drying, adde Pulv. Tuth. Ceru. Litharg. Lap. Calaminar. or Alum. ut. and the like. The Wound being repleted with Fleh, a Cicatrice is to be ordered, drying up the Superficies of the Fleh, and framing it into the ubtance of a Skin. For which Ue this is much commended: Pulv. Calc. tetar. Ovor. optimÃ¨ calcinat. s. Borac. Alum. ut. an. j. Croc. Mart. j. fiat Pulvis. Or in tead hereof ue Deiccativum rubrum, Diapompholyg. Diapalma, and the like.

Fifth Intention. As to the lat Intention, which is Correction of Symptoms, I have thereof very much enlarged already; and thee, if they do happen, we mut endeavour to conquer, and, if poible, prevent them before they arrive. I have already preented uch Intruments as are neceary for Extraction of Weapons, and given you both their
Names and Figures, and hall not therefore need to repeat them again. In the adjoyning leaf you have decribed the Manner of Extracting a Bullet out of a man's Breat. Where we are to oberve, if poible, that we gain the true Poture of the Shot's entrance, for the more ready Extraction thereof. We alo hew you the true Ue of the Terebellum, how ued in the taking forth of a Bullet from the Thigh, with what Aitents are thereto required: and hall conclude this Dicoure of Gunhot-Wounds with ome Hitoricall Obervations, very uefull and advantageous to the young Chirurgeon.

Hitory. A Merchant was deperately wounded at Sea, and hot into the upper part of his Breat, which paed to the lower part of his Scapula. Being hereupon much tormented with Pain, and other evill Accidents, upon viewing thereof an Inciion was made for the Exition of the Bullet; the which being extracted, the greatet danger was over. In the whole time of his Cure he took this following Apozeme of Arcaeus: Hord. mund. contu. Apozeme. Paular. enucleat. an. iij. Rad. Buglo. contu. iij. Liquirit. ra. js. Sem. Cumin. ij. Jujub. no. 20. Prunor. no. 15. Rad. Petroelin. contu. m. j. coquantur omnia in aqu. fontan. lbxjv. ad 3. part. conumption. colaturae adde Pened. iij. Syr. Roar. de Quinque Radic. an. iij. Sacchar. alb. lbs. Pulv. Cinnamom. j. fiat Apozema. To the Wound was applied this Digetive; Terebinth. Venet. Digetive. lot. in Aqu. vit. jv. Vitell. Ovor. no. ij. Ol. Roar. s. Praecipit. praeparat. j. Croc. j. With this being digeted, it was thus mundified; Terebinth. Venet. lot. jv. Mel. Deterive. Roar. ij. Vitell. Ovor. no. ij. Farin. Orob. iij. Pulv. Thur. Matich. Aloes, an. s. Peucedan. j. mice. With thee the Cure was perfectly performed.

Another. Another hall be of a Captain, being a man of a Cholerick dipoition, and a trong Contitution, who received a Gunhot-wound about the middle of his Thigh which paed through it, not touching the Bone, accompanied
with a large Flux of bloud, the which being topped, his whole Thigh was anointed with Ol. Roarum, over which was applied Emplat. Diapalm. cum uccis. Digetive.To the Wound was applied this Digetive: Terebinth. lot. j. Ol. Roar. nguent. Dialth. de Peto, an. iij. Thur. j. Vitell. Ov. no. j. Croc. j. Over which was applied Catapl.this Cataplam: Fol. Violar. m. j. Summitat. Abinth. Roar. rubr. an. ms. Fl. Cham. Melilot. Scord. an. put. iij. Farin. Hord. Fabar. an. ij. Tritic. j. cum Vini rubri q. . fiat Catapl. fine addendo Ol. Chamomel. js. Roar. vj. Croc. j. mice. With the Digetive the Tents were armed, and applied untill the Wound was perfectly digeted, and the Echar removed by applying nguent. Aegyptiac. js. And this method was oberved untill the eventh day: the Wound being kept from Accidents by ordering a good Diet, and well regulating of the Body. And the Echar being removed, this following Injection was made ue of, both for Mundifying and Incarning the Part: Hord. bene mund. ms. bulliat in q. . aqu. ad lbj. cui adde Sanicul. Conolid. Saracen. an. pug. ij. Fl. Hyperic. Roar. rubr. an. pug. iij. fact Ã¢ alter Ã¢ ebullitione cola, & colaturae adde Syr. de ucc. Nicotian. j. Mel. Roar. Syr. de Ro. icc. an. js. mice. The Tents were armed with an Incarnative medicine, and every other day leened and made horter, and the Cataplam left off; but the Parts comforted with Stupes dipt in this following Fomentation: Fomentat. Herb. Abinth. Hyperic. Salv. Betonic. Agrimon. Scabie. Roar. rubr. Fl. Cham. Melilot. an. ms. coquantur in Vino rubro. The Wound with thee was well conolidated, and perfectly cured.

Another Hitory. A Souldier alo being hot into his Thigh about its middle, upon earch by the Probe for the Bullet, it was found to lodge upon the Thigh-bone. The Terebellum being applied before any Tumour appeared, the Intrument catching hold thereof drew it forth; and by following the ame method which I have et
down in the former Hitory, the Patient was perfectly cured.

Hence may the young Chirurgeon collect, that in any Wound made either by Shot, Splinter, or Bullet, if any part thereof do remain in the Wound, this is to be peedily extracted, while the Parts eem as if they were tupefied or benummed, no Inflammation at preent appearing: for hould this be deferred for ome daies, we may well fear a new Inflammation, Pain, or Haemorrhagy to upervene. And let him oberve (by Celus and Hippocrates direction) that he gain the ame Poture of the Patient, if poible, as he was in when he received the Wound.

Sometimes Arrows, Splints or Bullets may be left remaining in the Body for ome eaon, without doing much detriment thereto. As Albucais writes of a Woman, that having an Arrow hot near her Belly, and lodged in her Body, he recovered of her Wound, and performed all her functions very readily without any interruption.
Sometimes it hath been een, after many years being lodged, that they do make a way out for themelves, by framing Abcees for their Exition: as we may ee by thee following Hitories.

Severall Hitories. Alaharavius, Theoric. Tract. 16. cap. 1. writes, that he aw a man who had an Arrow hot into his Back, the which after even years made its way out with odour. Gilbertus Anglicus, lib. 15. Compend. writes of a man, who having an Arrow hot into his Guts, had it drawn forth with Excrements, and yet he ecaped. Paraeus writes of a Souldier, who received a Gunhot-wound in his Belly, between his Navell and his Loyns, and the Shot remaining therein not extracted, (becaue, although the greatet care was ued, yet the Bullet could not be found out) hence the Patient began to be afflicted with intolerable Pains. At the ninth day he was dicharged of his Shot
by Siege, and within three weeks after he became well. We ought to know, as I have already hewn, that if Extraction of Weapons cannot be performed with eae, that we are not to attempt it, if we judge the Patient may live without it. And therefore hould a man have very many Shot lodged in his body, you are never to attempt their Extraction: for how many hundreds are there in health at this day which have them remaining in them? Hitories. Fallopius, lib. de Vuln. cap. 22. writes, that he extracted a Leaden Bullet, which was received in the Groyn, five years after its reception, in which time it had fallen near the Knee, at which place it was drawn forth. Another Example he hath of a Noble Gentlewoman, out of whom was drawn a piece of Iron, which lodged in the Cavity of her Thorax for the pace of nine months. And to conclude, Camerarius, cap. 45. writes of a Country-man, who finding a broken piece of a Knife, did thrut it o forceably between the right Clavicle into the Breat, that the dometick Chirurgeons could not draw it forth. Within a few daies the man grew well, and the Wound was healed, and he thus lived ome years without Pain; ave onely a dry Cough perplexed him, and between times a mall Pain about the affected Part. After fourteen years he felt a pricking Pain reaching from the hurt place to the Scapula, and this for ome time together did every day encreae, untill a Tumour appeared, which was afterwards turned into an Abces, the which being opened, this piece of old Iron was extracted: after which the Wound was conolidated, and the Patient recovered; and the piece of Iron Camerarius writes he hath in his Cloet. Whence we may learn, if Wounds are inclinable to heal, we are to tudy their healing without Extraction.

Thus have I run through the generall Symptoms and Dicoure of Wounds in Generall. My next Task will be, to uher you in my remaining Dicoure, how to deal
with Particular Wounds: wherein I hall atisfy the ingenuous Reader touching every of the Parts as they do arie by Anatomy; and then, if they be wounded, hew how they are to be cured.

div.head: CHAP. XIX.
The Generall Dicoure of Wounds of the Head.
div.p:
THE Head is uch an admirable Syntax of diverity of Works, made and framed out of trange pieces, that he who undertakes to ail through all its Parts, Tempers, and Qualities, had need to be a good Pilot, who beides his knowledge of well Trimming his Veell, ought to have annexed an exact acquaintance with the Condition, Site, and Connexion of its Parts, to defend him from the Rocks and Shelves of Errour and Ignominy; and may well account himelf happy, if while he endeavours to hun Scylla, he falls not upon Charybdis, and o micarries before he arrives at his intended Port or Haven. For here he mut expect many Reaches to tack about, before he may be aid to make any freh way, and will be very ubject to run aground, unles he keeps Sounding with the Plummet of Reaon, and teers by the Compas of Judgment and Experience. And becaue Man was created for Judgment, Undertanding, and Reaon's ake, fit to receive the Imprees of enible things, and to apply himelf to the diverity of Objects, he tands much in need of Locall motion. And had this been framed of one continued
Bone, nothing might he appear more like to, then a Trunk of Wood, or Lump of Clay. Nature therefore, the good and kind Mitres of Form and Beauty, tudying how to accomplih him for tranaction of the variety of his upper Motions, hath with wonder framed his Cranium; it being appointed as the Guard and Defence of the Soul, the Tower and trong Arch of the Brain, the outward Guard, Palace, and Helmet of the Animall Faculties: which we may ee framed of variety of Bones, dicriminated and ditinguihed with a trange appearance of Sutures, the which receiving through them the ends of the Dura Mater, do form and etablih a thin Inveture, with which the Skull is cloathed and furnihed. By the advantages of which, although one part of the Cranium hould be fractured, yet it hould not pas through the whole. And becaue this Part of my Book is chiefly deigned and dedicated to men of Knowledge, whoe Converation is taken form Learning, and dwells upon the Study of doing publick good and ervice, whoe Heads are furnihed with naturall Wit, and endowed with a great quantity of Sene and Reaon; not to the Ignorant, who conider little, and undertand les; That I may quit this Dicoure freely, and free it from off the Stage fairly, before it acteth its Tragick part in the Scene of Wounds, I hall preume to preent all the Parts of the Head in their proper order, which does chiefly belong to our preent Task: both becaue the Knowledge of the Parts affected is very neceary for the undertanding of the Affects, Preages, and Cure, we being by Hippocrates commanded firt to gain an exact Knowledge of thee; and alo in repect of the great Advantage and Light they bring to thoe who well do undertand them. And ince I have entered the dicoure of this noble and beautifull Subject, I could willingly wih my poor Genius might herein anwer a generall expectation: and ince this is a difficult Task which I have undertaken, as touching
the variety of Wounds both Simple and Compound, be pleaed to accept my kind votes, where my abilities may eem wanting, and dres with kindnes every lape of Pen, and deficiency of Judgment. But to quit this, being already aured of having our Sails filled with the gentle Gales of our Friends and all kind Artits, we intend to teer the Veell of our preent Dicoure by the Microcope of Anatomy, which will give us the true reemblance of every Part as it lies in its order. In which place we firt meet with a Membrana Carnoa, or Hairy Scalp; under it planted two thin and membranous Coats; and then hall we arrive at the Cranium it elf.

div.head: CHAP. XX.
Of the Hairy Scalp, and Pericrane.
div.p:
AND firt, as touching the Hairy Scalp; here we may find, although the Skin of Man is allowed in all other parts to be very thin, yet upon comparing this of the Head with that of the other Parts, we hall, I ay, find it much thicker then that of the Thorax or Abdomen. And as this is the thicket of the ret, o Galen writes, lib. De Temperament. it is alo by o much the drier, by how much it is the harder. It hath Veins allowed it from the exteriour Branch of the externall Jugulars, the which do variouly expand themelves on both ides, and are united in the front: and thee do bring its nutriment. Arteries alo hath it from the exteriour Branch of the Carotides, derived to the roots of the Ears and Temples: and thee
do bring it its vitall Spirits. It receiveth ome ends of Nerves from the firt and econd Conjugation of the Neck, to give it Sene, having no proper Nerve allowed Its Ue.it, as have other Mucles. Its Ue is, as we ee, to invet and cover the Skull. If this be onely wounded, this Wound requireth onely Deiccation, as other imple Wounds.

Pericrane. Next come we to the Pericrane; and this is held by ome to be as a Perioteum to other Bones. This arieth from everall Procees of the Dura Mater, like thin Ligaments, the which in proces of time, by their expanion, do meet with and unite to one another; and thee are o firmly tied together that they form this Membrane, which is thin, oft, firm, and endued with an excellent Sene allowed it from the Nerves, dipered through it to the Occiput and Temples. Lindanus and ome others will have it to arie from the Tendons of the Mucles of the Front, Temples and Occiput, being variouly expanded Perioteum.over the Cranium. To this is generally allowed and granted as annexed a Perioteum, being a mot thin Membrane, of a quick ene, by the benefit of which the Head is aid to feel, its roots being herein implanted. And this is o cloely annexed to the Cranium, and o exactly on the other ide joyned to the Pericrane, that it appears but as one: which made Fallopius mitake, when he thought that onely one Pericrane covered the Cranium: but upon a curious earch you will find it double, inveting the Head. To thee Exteriour Membranes the bloud is conveyed for their nutrition from the mall Ramifications of the outward Jugulars, and the Spirits which they receive they have from the externall Branch of the Carotidall Arteries.

Three things worthy note Thee being wounded are thus to be treated: becaue they adhere cloely to the Cranium, being divided or lacerated, the Skull it elf hereby mut uffer detriment in ome meaure; and in this cae the Cranium is to be deraded
Secondly, the Pericrane being incied, the Bone is made bare, and may peedily be altered by the air, and therefore to be upected. Thirdly, if the Bone be not hereupon raed, no good Fleh can be made to generate, or adhere, the which upon its deraion does peedily grow: for thus the mouths of the mall Veells are opened, and the Bloud which iueth thence is a very proper Intrument to et forward the Cure, by being readily brought to Suppuration for the generation of Fleh.

Cure. In Simple Wounds of the Head, we may cure with Catagmatick and Cephalick Medicines, being by Hippocrates advied to apply no moit Medicines here; but rather, by how much the Skull and its parts are drier then others, by o much are we directed to ue a more drying method. The mot proper Medicines here to be ued are to be of Deterive, Digetive and Drying Qualities. Of this ort may be reckoned Myrrh, Aloes, Ireos, Gentian, Frankincene, Comfrey, Powder of red Roes, Matick, Sarcocolla, Dragons bloud, Bolearmeniack, and the like: and of thee, or any of them, may be made Powders which are to be prinkled into Wounds. Wine alo for Of Wine in Wounds.Wounds is an excellent Medicine, as Galen, lib. 3. Method. cap. 4. writes. And as a Wound does chiefly require Drying medicines, Black wine for this purpoe is a mot excellent Receipt; for it dries both of it elf and per accidens, and of its own naturall quality does dry up by Repulion: and the Humours being repelled, the Part affected is half cured. And whereas alo a Simple Wound does require Agglutination, Wine for this alo is the bet < in non-Latin alphabet > , for by its Atrigency it does joyn and unite the disjoyned Parts. And if you be to procure a new Fleh, here firt procure a good Digetion, either with Reina Terebinth. ij. Vitell. Ov. no. j. mice; or in Wintertime with this, Terebinth. Venet. vj. Ol. Hyperic. iij. Pulv. Thur. j. Vitell. Ov. no. j. The Matter being digeted, mundiy it, by adding to ome of the former ome Honey
of Roes; then fill up with Fleh by Bailicon, Linimentum Arcaei, and the like, and skin it with Deiccativum rubrum.

div.head: CHAP. XXI.
Of the Head it elf, and of its Sutures.
div.p:
WE come next to the Cranium it elf; where we may find with what Art it is made and contrived. It is made of everall Bones, as you hall ee expreed in the next Chapter. The Greek word for Bone is < in non-Latin alphabet > , quai
< in non-Latin alphabet > , ab adjuncto proprio; or < in non-Latin alphabet > , ab officio. I hall pretermit the generall dicoure of other Bones, my preent Task confining me to the Head. And here may The Temper of Bones.we conider of their Temper. For in Children we hall daily find in their primo Intuitu, thee are more cartilaginous then boney, and it is onely time and age that gives and bequeaths them their olidnes and drines: and although they may come under the name of Simple Parts, having no proper Figure allowed them, as have the Organicks; yet conider the rare Ue appointed them, their particular Shapes and Forms; and in thee alo, were not a certain Articulation and Commiure granted them, all Animall motion mut necearily perih. Some of thee we meet with accompanied with Protuberancies; others are like Valleys, giving way and hrowded under them: and hence do they aume their variety of names. And here alo may we ee how Nature, the rare Mitres of Curioity and Art, endeavoureth to keep this Fabrick
entire and trim, who, by her kind Invention and curious Cunning, hath to thee hard Subtances added a middle matter, both for their better motion, and action. And ince alo this Queen of Order and Form hath granted Man the Divine parks of Reaon and Action, and allowed him the Majety of Government, he hath not narrowly confined his Animall faculties to a trict Room, but hath allotted him a large Compas to exercie the ame; and to guard thee hath appointed this Cranium, as their bet defence and ecurity: and this brings me to the Dicoure it elf. And becaue Infants and young Babes, who have not arrived at a good age, cannot be granted to have in them a true and jut Symmetry and Proportion of Bones, thee I at preent pretermit, and hall onely treat of uch who have gained thee.

As touching the Head. And here we do grant, and generally allow, and account that the Head, which is et and fixed upon the Vertebrae of the Neck, does divide it elf into a Cranium and a Face; the Head being that Part which containeth the Brain, as we have already hewn. It is called Cranium or < in non-Latin alphabet > , Galea. As touching its Figure and Ue, more afterwards. In young people it is een to conit of fourteen Bones, ome of which are particularly proper to it, others common. The proper are the Frontall bone, two of the Sinciput, one of the Occiput, two Temple-bones, in each Ear planted, three Bones named Incus, Stapes, Malleus. The common are, Os Cuneiforme, and Spongioum, and two of the Mandibles, beides the Teeth. But to pas thee at preent, we hall particularly treat of thoe of the Skull, which are properly thereto belonging, and its Sutures. And here, as the Brain is the mot noble Veell of all others in the Body, Nature hath placed this on the Top, being as the Prince of the ret, and covered it with a Skull, for keeping in its own dominion the Seat of Reaon, the Treaure of Judgment, the Regiter of Memory, the Shop of Sene
and Motion, and the Royall Order of Contrivance and Execution. This being planted as the Angelicall part of the World, having allowed it Reaon to invent, Memory to retain, Judgment to execute, and Counell to advie. Neither hath he framed thee alone with Curioity; but viewing its Front and exteriour Veture, we mut grant that he hath o wonderfully lockt up this Treaury under the particular Keys of her Connexions, that it is pat the proudet Judgments of men to frame any one thing to compare with it. And conidering its Sphaericall Figure, and the Connexion of parts, it might well make poor Man fall into an humble adoration of his Maker, who hath thus guarded this Treaury, which contains in it the whole Life, Sene, and Reaon of mankind. It is not made of one Bone, but framed of many; which may be accounted an admirable piece of Contrivance: and o trangely fahioned, that no other Part of the Body dares compare with it.

And that it may not glory or boat of its fair and trong Its Ue.Structure, embracing onely the name of a Helmet of defence, you may find that it is allowed a proper Office granted it by the Divine Artificer. For you may ee it ordained as a trong foundation for the maintaining, keeping and propagating the interet and priviledges of other Bodies, planted both in it, and under it. Thus the Brain, by the benefit of its Sutures, tying its Membranes to this Skull, is kept in a fair Aequilibrium: and had it not been thus fahioned, thoe frequent Concuions or violent Motions occaioned by jumpings or leapings would herein oon create a great diturbance.

Of the Sutures, and their Ues. The Sutures alo are of much benefit to the Brain: for as it is placed in the upper houe, many Fumes and Vapours do acend hither from the Kitchin of the Body, which are not peedily to be dipatched by thee. What an ill condition are thoe poor people in, what torms of troubles and tempets of ditempers are uch people aaulted
with, who have thee wanting in them? Hence is it, that thoe that want thee are o frequently accompanied with Pains of the Head, and other Perplexities; which trouble not uch as have thee expulive Paages. Another benefit hereof is, that one of thee being obtructed, the other do upply its place: and though in this cae it is not capable to give o quick a dipatch, yet by degrees it performeth its office very promptly.

As touching its Subtance. The Subtance of the Skull does vary much in repect of age, being in an infant Membranous, and in one of riper years of a more Boney ubtance. It hath not a like Its Figure.Figure in all men, containing in it both the Cerebrum and Cerebellum. And this variety or diimilitude is not o much inconitent with the Eyes, Noe, Ears, and the lineaments of the Face, as in the Bones and Sutures. And the caue hereof is generally referred to the trength or weaknes of the Formative faculty, plenty or carcity of Matter, or its goodnes or illnes, as Galen declares.

Four Figures of the Head et down by Hippocrates.
Hippocrates does et down four Figures of the Head; two of which he aith are preternaturall. For in one hereof there is found no Prominency in the Occiput, and then there remain two Sutures, the Coronall, and Right; the Lambdoidall vanihing. In the other there is no Projecture about the Front, and then onely thee appear, viz. the Lambdoides, and Recta; and the Coronall is extinct. And thee two Figures in their Sutures do form the Letter T. The third is naturall, and is of a Sphaericall Roundnes, carrying with it the naturall Idea and Reemblance of the Head: but this being depreed, it expreeth an anteriour and poteriour prominent part; and being on either ide depreed, thee three Sutures do remain in the form and contitution of the Head, (viz.) Coronalis, Recta, Lambdoides, and being placed together exactly do make H. The fourth Figure is, when either Prominency is lot, which is contrary to the naturall figure
of the Head; then the Sutures do thus appear, X, and the Head is very round and phaericall.

Its Superficies. The Cranium is light both outwards and inwards, that it may neither eem troubleome to the Pericrane, nor Dura Mater. It hath and mut have allowed it its Inequalities, framed according to the bodies of the two Brains. It is framed of two Bones, thin, but hard, the one inward, the other outward, not much unreembling a Pumice-tone: and thee by Anatomits are called Laminae Calvariae, or the two Tables of the Skull; the outward hereof being more thick and hard, the inward more thin and oft: and hence is it, that the outward, by tout and hard blows being given it, uffers not much; whilt the inward may be rent and divided. And becaue alo man's Head is very various, as touching both the number and poition of its Bones, in their thicknes and thinnes, hardnes and oftnes, denity and rarity, equality and inequality; and becaue of the Veins and Arteries allowed them, for conveying their nutriment and utenance, paing between thee; I hall afterwards enlarge on thee for our better knowledge, and at preent hut up this Chapter with a brief dicoure of the Sutures.

The true definition of Sutures, and why o called. A Suture therefore is the perfect draught and reemblance of things own together. This I call a Compoition, which may thus be undertood. For that it is not < in non-Latin alphabet > an Union, but a certain Articulation made < in non-Latin alphabet > , is thus bet explained, in that it taketh its proper name from the reemblance of Cloath which is own together. Of their Differences.And of thee Sutures there are two kinds; the one proper to the Head, the other common to it with the upper Three proper Sutures.Jaw and Os Cuneiforme. Thee proper are either true, or fale; the true being in number three, the fale 1. Coronalis. five; the firt being ingle, the other double. The firt are the Coronall, Sagittall, and Lambdoidall Sutures; the latter having Companions annexed to them, as one on the right ide, another on the left. The Firt of thee
is called < in non-Latin alphabet >
Coronalis, from the Ancients, whoe cutome was to wear Garlands in that place. Our perons of Honour at this day here do place their hairy Towers. And this does ditinguih the Frontall bone from that of the Sinciput. The Second is called Lambdoides, 2. Lambdoides. from the reemblance it hath with the Greek A. It is alo called the Occipitall Suture, from its ite, it being placed in the back-part of the Head, eparating the Occipitall bone from the Sincipitall bone. This Suture is een ometimes double, containing in its middle a Bone with three corners, from whence it is called Triangularis. The Coronalis does reemble a Semicircle, croing the Front as far as the Scaly Agglutinations, and does there eparate the Frontall bones from thoe of the Sinciput. Sagittalis, the Third Suture, is placed between thee, and 3. Sagittalis. is a direct Suture, and divideth the Bones of the Sinciput, ometimes decending even to the Noe. There are beides thee four Batard Sutures, but not o conpicuous as Four Batard Sutures.the former. The firt two are planted above the Ears, one on either ide, above the Petroa; thee rather deerve to be nominated Scaly Agglutinations: the other two belonging to the Os Sphenoides, on its anteriour and poteriour part. Bedies thee there are five Commiures Five Commiures.belonging to the Cranium, and to the upper Mandible, by ome called Harmoniall Sutures. The firt is made in the right Orbit of the Eye, proceeding outwardly from the end of the fifth Suture, and is common to the firt Bone of the Front, and upper Mandible. The econd appears in the lower and laterall eat of the Eye. The third acends outwards to the uppermot part of the Noe obliquely from the inward ide of the Eye. The fourth proceeds obliquely through the middle of the Jugal bone, and joyns to the Temporall bone. The fifth is in the breadth of the Noe, and in the amplitude of the Notrills, and the bridge of the Noe. All thee are ordained by Nature Their Ues.to be as Vents and Dicharges to end forth and dipatch
both Fumes, Vapours, and Excrements: framed alo for the ingres and engres of the Veells, which are procured for the nourihing of the Brain. And hence may we well admire the true Judgment of Hippocrates, who writes, that uch people who have mot Sutures in their Head are Three Reaons not to make any Inciion into the Sutures, given by Hippocrates. mot healthfull. We are advied by him alo, in Sutures not to make any Inciion, for thee three Reaons. 1. Becaue they are weak and eaily perforated by the Saw, and thus the Brain and its Membranes hurt. 2. Becaue through thee Sutures both the Veins and Arteries do pas, and thee being touched with any iron Intrument, it may perhaps or by chance reach the Membranes. 3. Becaue Calloities being here contracted they do much hinder Tranpiration.

div.head: CHAP. XXII.
Of the Cranium and its Bones.
div.p: THE Bones of the Head are of two orts, ome peculiarly proper to the Cranium, others chiefly belonging Six proper Bones.to the upper Jaw. Thoe properly belonging to the Skull are Six.

Frontall. Of which the firt is called Os Frontis, by ome Os Puppis, having allowed it a vat magnitude, in its upper part, being in Children of a oft ubtance and double. It contituteth the whole Front, and the more elate part of the Eye-lids. Its figure is emicircular. In Children it appears double, but in Aged people this is worn into one: and is circumcribed with a tranvere Suture. In this Bone
is to be oberved a large Cavity, being between either ide of the Noe, from whence are expanded two Cavities to the Cavity of the Noe.

Two Sincipitalls. The Bones of the Sinciput or Vertex are placed in the upper part of the Head, quare in figure, onely omewhat extended in length, not plain, but concave, o framed by reaon of the phaericall figure of the Head to which they are accommodated. They are joyned to the forward lines of the Frontall bone, Coronall Suture, and to the back-part of the Occipitall bone, and Lambdoidall Suture. Their ubtance being in young people hard, but ofter then other Bones and thinner, both for the more peedy and eay tranition of Vapours: and hence were they made with many mall Cavities on the inide, with many Incriptions where the Veells run: and thee epecially in young Children, by reaon of their great plenty of moiture, are rather oft and membranous: and as they creep up to a riper age, thee alo do exceed both in their drines and hardnes: and, as Pliny aith, thee eldome begin to harden untill Children do begin to peak. The outward Superficies is thin and lender, inwardly aperate and rough, through whoe paages ome Ramifications of the Jugular veins are inerted. And hence may the young Chirurgeon Note.learn, that he do not lacerate the Veins when he ueth the Trapan or Trafine. Thee Bones were framed for dicharge of vicous and tough Humours, which are generally redundant in Infants Brains.

By Galen it is called Os Occipitis,
< in non-Latin alphabet >
Os Occipitis. quÃ²d ibi fibrae nerveae oriantur. By the Arabians it is held to be the eat of Memory, and does hut up and cloe the back-part of the Head. It is alo called Bailare, and Os Pyxidis, or the Nowl-bone, contituting the poteriour and lower part of the Head. It hath a Triangular figure, inwardly concave, outwardly convex. It is of a hard, thick and dene ubtance,
tronger then any of the other Bones of the Cranium, the better and more ready to defend any Backblows, and uch Hurts as may happen in the back-part of the Head. It is connexed to the Bones of the Sinciput and Temples, and ometimes to the Sphenoides. It hath two large Procees at the ide of the Medullary paage, which do receive the Cerebellum, planted at the Bais thereof, which are articulated to the firt Vertebrae of the Neck, and do erve for the motion of the Head, and for its flexion and extention. It hath a round Cavity placed between thee two Protuberancies in its Bais, through which the Medulla does decend from the Head to the Back. This is an excellent guard againt all injuries and aaults which may be inflicted on the back-part Note.of the Head. And it is a principall Maxime, in Wounds of the Head, to prohibit Inflammation: which is chiefly occaioned by the Veells being lacerated, and the Bloud thence iuing, and there corrupting, by whoe corruption the Parts alo are corrupted; and hence cometh Pain, and a uperfluous Heat, out of which two is framed Inflammation: and therefore we are to procure a peedy Suppuration. And Wounds happening in thee Parts are of greater danger then thoe happening on the Fore-parts, and more ready to putrefy in the Summer then in the Winter, the Cold not o readily being capable to caue Putrefaction. Wherefore the young Chirurgeon ought to have regard to thee Obervations.

Two Temple Bones. But to the next, which are the Temporall Bones, by ome called the Temple Bones, by the Greeks named < in non-Latin alphabet > , being received on either ide of the Head, or poeing the laterall Region thereof: thee are the mallet of all the Bones of the Head. In the upper part they are almot emicircular; but in their lower parts, by reaon of their inequall Aperities and Extuberancies, with their Procees ubitent with their Cavities, they do carry a manifold figure and form. There are two
Cavities worthy our obervation in this Bone. The greater is accompanied with a Cartilage, between the Auditory paage, and the Proces of the Jugal bone, the which does receive the head of the lower Mandible. The inward is les, and common to the Occipitall bone, eated at the ame Proces backwards. And in this Part Oberver.alo it is worthy obervation, that the Mucles peculiarly appropriated to thee Bones are covered with the Pericrane, and the ubjacent Bones are alo detitute thereof; no other part of the Body being thus trangely framed.

The chief of the Bones I have already named; the other two are Sphenoides, and Ethmoides. The former Os Cunesforme.Bone is by the Greeks called < in non-Latin alphabet > , or the Wedgebone, which it much reembleth. It obtains a various figure; and by ome it is called Os Bailare. In Infants it coniteth of many Bones united together by a Cartilage, and thee generally are in them allowed to be four. The firt thereof does carce recede the latitude of a finger from the fore-parts of the Occiput. The econd comprehends the Sella Equina, and the Procees appointed for the Viive nerves. The third and fourth are plain Procees. In Children if this Bone be carefully examined, you will find it conit of three Bones; one contituting its Bais, which does frame the Sella Equina, and does expand it elf forwards towards the ides like two Wings; and the other like leer joyned to thee: all which in proces do run into one. It is eated in the middle of the Head, encompaing and enwrapping the proper Bones of the Cranium, and ometimes the Bones of the upper Mandible every way, thereto annexed by the mendoe Sutures, the which are altogether obliterated by age and growth. It is allowed both outward and inward Procees: four outward, two placed forwards near the eventh of the Bones of the Notrills and Palate, in which cohering with the upper Mandible,
and from their reemblance called Aliformes; two alo appearing backwards, protended with a double mitre towards the Styloides. Such as have a further deire hereof, let them frequent Anatomicall Lectures, and reade Anatomicall Authours, and they will find their time will not be pent in idlenes or frivolouly.

Os Ethmoides. The lat is called Os Ethmoides, Spongioum, and Cribroum, omewhat reembling a Sponge, and planted in the middle Bais of the Front, ited in the convex part, between either Eye, to the econd of the Mandibles, and Sphenoides, per Harmoniam; the which age does alo wear out. This is boared with very many mall Cavities, much like a Sieve, amongt which thoe are the larget which are nighet the Crita Galli. It is covered with the Dura Menynx, the which in this part is very porous and perviated with many Foraminula's, through which does iue out that tough and vicous Phlegm which does decend from the Ventricles of the Brain. And as you Its Ues.ee the Parts of this Bone are various, o alo are its Ues. One Part maketh way for Air and Odour, for the refrehing of the Brain, this being breathed into it for the generation of animall Spirits. And hence is it, that thoe that be troubled with a Coryza (the which we commonly call a Poe) cannot mell, becaue thee Perforations are topt up with Rheum. Galen and Laurentius do adde this farther Ue thereof, that by thee Perforations, when need requireth, a plenty of Excrements may be peedily and together dicharged. But others on the contrary do write, that nothing can this way be brought to the Brain, becaue thee pongious Flehes are o placed, that nothing can penetrate through them from the Notrills to thee little Pipes, much les be conveyed this way to the Brain it elf.

Thus have I given you an account of all the proper Bones of the Cranium: I hall here preent you with a Figure of the Head, how it may variouly be wounded;
and on the other ide you may ee a Scheme of all thee Bones, firt as they are placed in their naturall Figures with their Sutures, and then may you view them apart with their names under them. This I have thus delineated for the better atisfaction of the young Chirurgeon. In the Firt you have the Figure of the whole Head with its Face, known by thee Letters, A. B. C. D. E. F. G. H. In the Second, the Bones of the Vertex with the ret, thus alo noted, A. B. C. D. E. F. G. H.

list.head: The Firt Figure.
list.item: A. The Bone of the Vertex.
D. Os Sphenoides, or the Wedge-Bone.
E. The firt of the Bones of the Mandible.

list.item: A. The Bones of the Vertex.
H. The Squamoe Suture of the Temples.

list.head: The Third, Fourth, and Fifth Figures, hewing,
list.item: 1. The Bones of the Vertex joyned together by the Sagittall Suture.
2. The right Bone of the Vertex from its outward face.
3. The left Bone of the Vertex inwards.

list.head: The Sixth, Seventh, and Eighth Figures repreent the Frontall Bone, in its ite, outwards, and upwards, and inwards.
list.item: A. A Cavity which penetrates from the Cavity of the Bone through the Frontall Bone.
B. The Back-part which is committed with the Bones of the Vertex.
C. The Fore-part committed with the Bones of the Mandibles.
D. The Sides by which it is joyned with the Sphenoides; and the two Occipitalls by themelves, at the Ninth and Tenth Figures.

list.head: The Ninth and Tenth Figures hew all the Bones of the Occiput, thus marked.
list.item: A A. The heads by which they are connexed to the firt Vertebra.
B B. The Cavity in which the duplicated Membrane of the Brain makes the Front.
C C. A hollow Inculpture framed for the Veells and Eminencies of the Brain.
D D. The common Cavity of the ix Pair of Nerves of the Brain, with the Temporall Bones, through which doth pas the greater Branch of the inward Fugular Vein.
E E. The Cavity of the eventh Pair of the Nerves of the Brain.
F F. The mall Cavity of either ide of the great Cavity, which arieth from the Originall of the Dura Mater, and penetrates to the Cavity of the Neck.
G G. The Cavity through which does pas the Spina medullaris, and the firt Artery enters the Brain.
H. The upper part of the Occipitall Bone, committed with the Bones of the Vertex.
I. The lower part committed with Os Sphenoides.
L L. The Sides by which it is joyned with the Temporall Bones.

div.p:
Having thus preented you with the Scheme and Figure of the Head, and of the variety of its Bones, their Nature, Site, Temper, and Connexions, with their Ues, and the like; we arrive now at the dicoure of Wounds in generall, where we may meet both with Simple, and Compound: the firt of which I have already paed; the latter remains. And herein alo are we advied by wie Hippocrates, the Father and Patron of Reaon
and Experience, that we do well undertand the Dieae, and the Praeage thereof, before we undertake the Cure: and this more particularly in Wounds of the Head, where no evident Signs are made apparent, in the firt daies, of danger; which whilt they appear under mean hapes to the ignorant Chirurgeon and as Trifles, are peedily undertaken by him; but within few daies they procure uch a Troup of bad Symptoms, as oft hurry the poor Patient and dipatch him into another world. And although of the Brain and Heart the Heart is counted the mot noble; yet its Thorax being wounded, by which it is guarded and defended, even into the Cavity thereof, the Heart it elf being kept inviolable, or not touched therewith, the Patient thus wounded, if skilfully dealth with, is carce een to come under the verge of danger: whereas we ee by daily experience, Wounds happening in the Head, although the Brain be not touched, or its Membranes, do very often occaion Death. And hence is it, that he in the beginning of his Book De Vulnerib. Capit. does advie the Chirurgeon, not to contemn or corn the leat Wound happening in the Head, but adviedly to undertake it with Art; let by an inconiderate dreing, (as too oft happens by the illiterate Practier) for want of well expurging the Matter which is inwardly lodged, there follow a ordid Ulcer. And in many caes the bet of Chirurgeons, without a due repect and inquiry, may herein fail. And becaue the differences of Wounds are generally taken from their Caues, being either Pungent, Contuing, Lacerating, or Inciing; every of thee have their proper Intruments to perform or effect their deigns: as Swords and Rapiers to prick or tab; obtue Intruments, as a Stone, Club, Fall from a high place, and the like, for lacerating; and for inciing, Knifes, Daggers, Faulchions and the like Intruments. But becaue you may in very many Authours meet with Dicoures hereof, as
in Andr. Ã Crue. Caear. Marcell. Read, and everall others, I pretermit them, and come to the Signs of Wounds of the Head in generall.

div.head: CHAP. XXIII.
Of the Generall Signs of Wounds of the Head.
div.p: WE are by Hippocrates Authority not to depend or build our faith upon one Sign in Wounds of the Head, nor yet to be atisfied with a few, in caes of great danger; for it is thee onely which do bring the Chirurgeon into the knowledge and acquaintance of his buines, and direct him the more readily to execute his Office and hew his Art.

Inciion a Fracture. And becaue Inciion is a Solution of Continuity happening in the Cranium by ome inciing Intrument, o far as it hath touched the Bone, it ought to be reckoned a Fracture. But this taketh its name from its Caue.
Perforation. Perforation is alo made by a Sword, Arrow, or the like; and this is called a Solution of Continuity: and this draws its name from its Caue alo.

Generall Signs of a Compound Fracture. If Dimnes of ight or a Cloudines appears, Vertigo, Vomiting, Bleeding, at noe, mouth, and ears, the Patient mute, and uddenly falling to the ground, and hence iue Fever, Convulion and Delirium, thee are generall Signs of a Compound Fracture.

Wounds in a Cacochymick body. Wounds of the Head received in a ditempered peron, or uch a man who is of a Cacochymick body, are the hardet to cure, the Bloud being altogether improper for uniting of Parts.
Wounds in Children. Wounds in the Heads of Children ofttimes prove unhappy, they being of a hot and moit Contitution, and this not o apt for the admittance of Putrefaction.
Wounds in Times. In Summer-time the Patient lives a horter time then in the Winter, for in this time the unnaturall Heat is not procured for Putrefaction, as Hippocrates oberves.
Contued Wounds. Contued Wounds are more lowly cured then Incied Wounds, for thee require a greater time for Suppuration, as Hippocrates ets down, lib. De Vulner. Capitis.
Tumour in Wounds. If a Tumour accompanieth a Wound in the Head, and hews well, but uddenly vaniheth without dicharge of the Matter which was contained in this Bulk, it is of ill conequence.

Fever upon a Wound. If a Fever happens before the eventh day, it is of les danger then appearing after, this generally being accounted the time by Maters of Art for the ceaing and abolihment of Accidents.
The Lips of Wounds livid. Hippocrates writes, it is an ill ign, if the Lips of the Wound do look livid, for this is a great ign of the Decay of naturall Heat, as he hath it Sect. 7. Aph. 2.

Wounds in the fore-part and in the hinder-part of the Head. Wounds happening in the fore-part of the Head are more dangerous then thoe of the hinder-part, becaue as herein is contained the greater quantity of Brain, o alo are its parts both thinner and lighter: and hence is it, that uch as receive Wounds in thee parts do ooner die then uch as do receive them in the hinder part thereof, becaue of its Sutures, as Hippocrates alo writes cap. 7. and 8. lib. de Vuln. Cap.
Wounds of the Sutures. Wounds in the Sutures are very dangerous, as I have already hewn you, for three epeciall reaons already precribed, as Hippocrates writes lib. de Vuln. Capit.

Wounds of the Temples. The Temples being wounded are very dangerous, the Articulation of the lower Mandible upon eating or drinking does hinder Union, herein alo being planted the Auditory paages, and the Jugular veins and Soporall Arteries are here much ditributed, and the like, as Fallopius writes in Hippocrat. lib. de Cap. Vulnerib. cap. 9.
Ill Symptoms in Wounds. Blacknes in the neighbouring Parts appearing near the Wound, Convulion, Paley, Ravings, and a Chillines over the Body, are here very ill Symptoms.

Good Signs in Wounds. Thee are reputed good Signs in Wounds of the Head, when the Patient hath no Fever, keeps his Senes, leeps well, his Body is oluble, the Wound looketh well, and yields a laudable Matter.
In Compound Wounds. In Compound Wounds with a Fracture, expect not to have the danger all pat untill the hundred daies be expired.

Wounds to be earched by the Probe. Hippocrates does advie, if we cannot find out Fractures joyned with Wounds by the Finger, to ue the Probe: and if hereby you meet with any Aperity or Inequality in the Skull, you are to upect a Fracture. Yet he farther adds, that in all Parts this is not to be credited; for if the Sutures be wounded, thee may deceive you, as he writes, Sect. 6. de Vulnerib. Cap.

The generall Symptoms attending Compound Wounds. Hippocrates alo, lib. de Vulnerib. Capitis cap. 18. writes, that thee Symptoms do generally attend Compound Wounds; viz. a Singing noie in the ears upon the receiving the Wound, falling after the blow, Syncope, a Dulnes and heavines poeing the Patient after the Wound received, Dazling of the eyes, a Giddines of the brain, an iuing of Bloud both from the ears, noe, eyes, and mouth, Vomiting, and the like. Of
which expect their Caues and Reaons in the Preages.

Other Symptoms. And to thee are joyned and added by him, cap. 45. de Vulnerib. Capit. a contant Pain of the wounded Part, the Patient's mind much inclining his Hand to lie upon it, a vomiting of Choler, with Fever, Convulion, Paley, Delirium, Dulnes of peech, Deafues, los of Memory, Judgment, and Undertanding.
Other Signs And after all thee, as he farther precribes, if the Hair be cut aunder and tick up in the Wound, it is a perfect Sign of a Fracture in Cranio, Hippoc. c. 18. lib. de Vulnerib. Cap.

div.head: CHAP. XXIV.
Of the Preages of Wounds of the Head.
div.p:
WE arrive now at the laudable part of practice, wherein is hewn the excellency or weaknes of the Chirurgeon: and therefore let all young Students in Chirurgery know, they ought to be very cautious in their Preages, for the leat hurt here is not void of upicion. And therefore he who undertands aright the Preages of Ditempers, may well be compared to a skilfull Pilot, who can foretell a Storm before it happens, and hereby can alo leen the danger which threatens, upon its appearance. Even thus
ought he to be o tudious, as to tell the event which is like to enue upon a Fracture made in the Skull.

1. Wounds therefore are mot lethall which happen in the Fore-part of the Head, the Back-part being defended with a thick Occiput, a good Safeguard to defend a back-blow; and alo becaue herein lieth the mallet part of the Brain.

2. Wounds of the Head being received in the Winter do uffer the Patient to live longer then thoe made in the Summer, for herein the native Heat is mot copious and trong: and why the naturall Heat is herein more intene, Galen heweth out of Aritotle, becaue by reaon of externall Cold it does gather together its Spirits inwards and towards the inward Parts; on the contrary, in Summer the naturall Heat is expanded and exploded to the externall Parts, and is as it were there diolved and diipated, the which in Winter is contracted and cohibited.
3. Large and deep Wounds are by Albucais advice not to be relinquihed, becaue ometimes they are een to be cured beyond hopes, having a repect to their Accidents.
4. Proceed according to Art in all uch Wounds as you have any hopes of cure or recovery.

5. If a Patient have received a Fracture in the Skull, pronounce not all danger to be pat untill the hundred daies be expired; for many have died about this time, as Hippocrates writes, cap. 48. in lib. de Vulnerib. Cap.
6. If the Wound in the Head accompanied with a Fracture have no fearfull Symptoms goe along with it, yet it is not void of danger.
7. If a Fever and other bad Symptoms follow a Wound, and the Lips thereof at the econd dreing look black or livid, and grow flat, it's a bad Sign.
8. If in a Wound or Percuion of the Head Stupor and Idlenes happen, it is of ill conequence, for none of thee appear without hurt of the Brain; and they bring Death, if they be powerfull and great.

9. The Memory being impaired, the Eyes growing dim, the Tongue failing, the Ears growing deaf, the Patient accompanied with Fever, Delirium, his Tongue black, the Wound growing dry or livid, and Convulion, Paley, or Apoplexy following, thee are the forerunners of Death.
Wounds and Contuions penetrating and not penetrating the Cranium without hurt of the Brain, may with care be cured: but the Brain being hurt, it ofttimes proves mortall.

10. If the Bone do appear black, and this Blacknes is not to be removed by the Actuall Cautery, this does argue bad Matter to be lodged under the Cranium, the which if it corrupteth the Bone upwards, does alo corrupt the Membranes inwards, it being more eay to corrupt the Membrane then the Bone: and in this cae it is more afe to open untill you come to the Bone, that it may be removed; and o to remove, if poible, the Caue of its Blacknes.
11. If the Cranium be fractured, the Parts above mut uffer Solution of Continuity, except it happens in a Contrafiure or Countercleft.
12. If the Fleh about the fractured Skull appears of a Leady colour, it's ill, as Hippocrates writes, Aphor. 2.
13. If it appears black and dry, it is a ign of Mortification of the Part.

The differences of the Parts wounded do preage either the ecape or death of the party wounded, ome of thee being trong, others more weak, ome of a quick ene, others of a more dull feeling: and this Hippocrates heweth by many Examples, in lib. de Cap. Vuln. cap. 2.

14. And as touching the Symptoms of Wounds, he writes them in this order. Whereas Pain is generally occaioned by Solution of Continuity, after this follows Watching, Los of Appetite, and an Affluxion of Humours; thee procure Inflammation, and this entertains Fever, ometimes Convulions, Gangrene, and Mortification, if not by Art prevented.

15. It is a great ign of Death in an ill-cured Wound of the Head, if a Fever does upervene in Winter before the fourteenth day, or in Summer after the eventh; for it is generally to come at firt, or happen in the firt daies, brought hither by Pain, Inflammation, or Suppuration.

16. If after the eventh in Summer and fourteenth in Winter a Fever happens upon a Wound of the Head, it behoves the Chirurgeon to be fearfull of his Patient, for
he is not void of upicion of danger; this Fever for the mot part being excited by Corruption of the Brain, its Membranes, or Cranium.
17. The Bone of it elf being light and equall, but being Carized it appears aperate and rugged.

18. The Bone appears white, becaue Inflammation does draw forth the Bloud, jut as Fire does the moiture from Wood; the which being altogether extracted, leaveth onely a Cinder, which hath in it a kind of a whitih ahey colour.

19. In large Wounds of the Head, a peculiar Symptome is Convulion; and this Spam being in one part of the Body, does corrupt many. And it is the thoughts of ome Authours, that Convulion is made in the ound Parts by Inanition and penury of Humours and Spirits; whenas in the hurt Part there is felt a mot harp Pain, the Humours thither poting themelves, do gather and unite together, and by this conflux the ound Part is exhauted, and therefore forced to yield to Convulion. And thee Convulions here happening are a ure ign of Death, ending their ill Matter to the Bone, and a corrupt and malign Vapour from the affected Part into the ound Part.
20. Wounds in the Temples are mot dangerous, they being thin and weak; and becaue remarkable Veins, Nerves and Arteries border upon them; becaue alo the Pericrane does cover their Mucles.

Thus having for your benefit et down very many Preages and Symptoms which follow Wounds of the Head, chiefly collected from Hippocrates, the Father of good Authorities; I hall alo leave with you his bleing
and advice, That in every point of your Art you carry your elf wiely, and chiefly in this of Preages: that if you predict according to the event, your Patients may admire and honour you; but unadviedly to erre herein, you will as readily be accounted amongt the number of fools by them. Of which ort of people I am afraid we have too many at this day in our Nation; and it were to be wihed our renowned Art might not be rent into o many pieces by them, and divided into more parts then ever I believe God Almighty intended. But Vix ea notra voco. Paulo majora canamns. The Chaldaeans did exceed others in Knowledge, as Diodorus does report; their Children learned the Rules of Knowledge and Philoophy in their Infancy from their Parents, and o continued the propagation of the ame to their Succeours. This I may and mut confidently ay for the Honour of our Nation, that Chirurgery may boat in this, that it hath very honourable and eminent Patrons cattered about; but thee are not very frequent; uch Sons of Learning, as well as Art, as can vindicate its Rights and Priviledges. Yet this I mut allow, that it is crept into acquaintance with uch trange Creatures, and owned in its profeion by uch mean Spirits, that Hippocrates aying may readily be confirmed for a truth, that the Name with the Name is no fale Heraldry; but the Name amongt thee with the Art is but mall and little.

div.head: CHAP. XXV.
Of Inciion of the Hairy Scalpe, and Opening the Skull.
div.p: WE come now to the Operative part of Chirurgery required in the caes of Wounds of the Head; And becaue the heads of Children are tender, looe, oft, and thin, having in them much blood, not hard, thick, and firm; and becaue alo a more peedy Purulency of matter happens in thee more than in uch who have arrived at a greater Age and tronger Contitution: Thee being, like oft Wax, very capable to receive the Impreions which any Intrument may inflict. Thee Bones alo in thee young Children, in relation to their plenty of Heat & Moyture allowed them, are very ubject to receive Putrefaction. Conidering alo their Imbecillity and Rarenes, with the weight of the intrument hurting, and capable to occaion herein a Wound and Fracture, and how peedily it may communicate its affects hence to the Brain and its Membranes, and where either a Fiure, Colliion, or Sedes is here made, how careful ought we to be, and well to conider and cautelouly to weigh how we are with thee to deal: Some of thee in repect of the largenes of the wound, and Concuion of the Brain, do oon and peedily dipatch the Patient of its life. Others not imprinting their Cruel Darts untill the 4th or the 7th day.

Four Kinds of ill Symptomes pronounced by Hippocrates.
Hippocrates like a Wie Judge does pronounce thee are Four dangerous Sentences in Wounds of the Head happening in Children or Men: As firt, Wounds of the head being neglected, or lenderly examined, do ofttimes bring an unexpected Death, there being no good repect or care taken in the right ordering the Body:
Thus by the imploy of ignorant Pretenders to the practice of this Art, too oft are the King's Liege People Cheated of their Lives, by procuring michiefs to the ubjacent Membranes, applying of a Trepan to the Sutures, and harp Medicines hereupon: Thee being more proper for exciting of pain, and this drawing inflamation with it; who like people half ditracted are at their Wits ends, fearing the Coldnes of the Air, but not undertanding how to temper or correct it, who upon endeavouring to echew the danger of the one, make nothing to plit themelves upon the Rock of Unadviednes in the other. A Third alo Hippocrates brings in mall and lender Wounds, the which not being at firt well treated, prove upitious beyond the expectation of their narrow Genius; who by ordering their Patients thin Broaths, Ptians, and the like, do give way for their Patients to drink Wine, to eat and drink at pleaure, and if poible to any Exercie, not forbidding Venery, although the greatet enemy to Wounds in the Head, nor prohibiting any paion, all which to a Judicious man appears as idle as any one thing in the World, Knowing that thee will create Choler in the body, and raie feuds in the humours, cauing that Intemperiety which in time committing and communicating it elf to the head, hereby inflameth the Animal pirits. A Fourth may be attributed to uch, who are o unhappy as at the firt view to pronounce peedy Death, acquainting both Patient and Relations that there are no hopes left either of Cure or Life. And what power; force, and vigour this may have have in any man, no Judicious or Ingenious man is ignorant of: For if by Hippocrates his Rules and Aphorime we are Ordered to hope well, and to think the bet, and give comfortable aurances to the wounded Patient, this being as an Exact Rule and Maxime as touching Health; o on the Contrary to create Depair, and dicompoe the Patient with the unhappy thoughts
