of a uddain Surprizal and a peedy Change, mut as conequently make dull and flat the muical trings which are the vigorous and nimble Intruments of Man's Life, Sene, and Motion. And to conclude this Dicoure, how oft have we een men dye of mall and light Wounds in their Heads, not by reaon of the Brain being hurt, or the Skull uffering a fracture, or the like, but chiefly by hidden caues happening either by Accident or Nature, having their Bodies overcharged with bad humours, macerated by Venery, welled up by Dropies, and according to other inward Dipoitions and Tempers: Several alo are the Intentions of divers Authors as touching Solution of Continuity in the Head, but thee do not make much for the relief of the Patient.

A Wound with a Fracture in Childrens Heads. But to proceed; Francicus Arcaeus advieth us, That when a Wound happeneth with a Fracture in Childrens heads, without any bad Symptome attending it, not to remove any Bone if the parts of it cleave together; but onely to be anointed with his Liniment which he hath Chritned by his own name, by having ome mall Feathers dipt therein, and o applying it warm to the part affected. But if any bad Symptome appear, as Convulion, Vomiting of Choler, Fever, or Palie, and the like, then to dilate the Skull as Hippocrates does order, Cap. 47. lib. de cap. Vulnerib. And being once opened, they are to be dret as we dres other men. But let this erve for Advice. We come next to the peron affected, who is the Object of our preent Dicoure, in whom both occaion and neceity commands the Ue of the Intrument. And here are we to conider, that we make an Artificial eparation of the oft parts about the Skull, having hereby a more ready way made for our dresing. After this are we to prevent all Accidents, and to remove all evil Symptomes; and then to conider whether it ought to be done, and might be performed with afety, and what parts it is to be made in, and what is to be performed
after this; all thee being as the general Rules and Maximes which are to be oberved as touching the Operation. Hippocrates lib. 1. de Vulnerib. Capit. teacheth us it is to be done both by Authority, and upon Neceity, and then in that daily Experience declaring for want and Omiion of thee Operations, the Death of undry People have followed, which by a timely ue hereof might have been prevented.

Where Section may be made, and where not. Next by Hippocrates's Rules alo, Section may be made in any part of the hairy Scalp, except the Sutures and Temporal Mucles; the Reaons for either of which I have already hown. The Inciion being tranverly made, you are to eparate the Pericrane from the Cranium in every part, inomuch that it be cleared on every ide both for Prevention of Fever, Inflammation, and the like; as Hippocrates writes, Cap. 38. lib. de Cap. Vuln. This being done, the Wound is to be kept open by applying Doills and Pledgets to be put therein made of fine Lint, thee to be armed with a Retrictive if a large Flux appear, or with the white and yolk of an Egg beaten up together, to awage pain; as he alo directeth, Cap. 29. lib. de Vuln. Cap. and this o to be kept for 24 hours. Thus having hewn the things that are to be done, we are in the next place to give you the Reaon of its doing, and this may contain in it thee In 4 caes the Head to be Opened.Heads: That the pieces of Skull or Weapon may from thence be removed, or that a depreed part of the Skull may be reduced into its proper place; That Matter or coagulated Blood collected between this and the Membrane Dura Mater may be dicharged; And that we may apply proper Medicines for the Wound and Fracture: All which Hippocrates directs in Cap. 31. lib. de Vuln. Cap. The time alo of its apertion is et down by him, Cap. 34. it being to be done before the fourth day, and may be done after this too, if bad Symptoms command it; and o the eventh or ninth day may erve.
We next are to hew you how this is to be done, and with what Intruments; and amongt thee may be reckoned the Capital Saw, Rapatories, Levatories, Trepan 4 Intruments required in Trepanning. and Heads. The Figures of which you hall have exactly delineated at the end of this Chapter.
I will only touch upon the ue of every of thee, and hall come to the Trepanning it elf.

Thus the Rap is generally ued in a Fiure, and Foul Bone, and when you ue them, place your Patient in a good poture, let him have his Ears topped with wool, cover the Wound with Linnen Cloath, that the Patient may not have the lips thereof touched therewith. The next is Levatories, thee ued chiefly for the raiing up of a depreed Skull; when you ue thee, take care that an even hand be kept. Thirdly, we come to the Capital Saw, this chiefly ued in a depreion or Fracture on one ide of the Bone, ued alo to remove away the ditance of the Cranium, left after the application of the Trepan, and this brings me to the Trepan it elf; wherein we may enquire its ue, and in what Of the Trepan and its ue.places it is to be applied, and what method ued after it. Of each in their order:

And becaue Perforation, Trepanning or Trafining is of great ue when the Bones are extreamly foul, but of mot ue in thee Dieaes of Fiures, Fractures and Contuions of the Cranium; and ince the Ue hereof is of great moment, and the Operation of great danger, how much hould the young Chirurgeon make trial of his Art upon dead Skulls, which is a ready way to bring his hand in ure to practie upon the living? Wherein he ought alo to be very cautious in what caes he is to apply this; for neither a Fiure or Fracture do abolutely require this Intrument, as without which they were not to be cured: And Nature, we may ee in many caes in light Contuions, ueth her endeavours very happily for the dicuing of the extravaed Blood, without the
aitance hereof; except the innate heat be much leened by extream cold. But indeed in uch caes as where the extravaion of the Blood doth occaion Putrefaction, this is to be applied with all peed; for this Putrefaction doth bring a great company of ill Symptoms with it, and oft-times Death it elf. It helps to raie the depreed Bones from the two Membranes, and helps all thoe Inconveniencies as Splints and the like, by making way for their exition; and hereby alo have we brought a fair method to give us to ee our work before us: This is not to be applied upon the Fracture if the bones be evered; not upon a Suture, becaue hence the Nerves, Veins and Arteries by which the Dura Mater is annexed to the Pericrane, might hereby be lacerated: Neither is it to be applied to the Temples, both in repect of the Temporal Mucle, and alo of the Squammoe Suture.

The manner of Trepanning. Thee being premied, the hair being haved, and the Skin and Pericrane divided in form of a Cros, and the Cranium made bare and fit for your Operation, let the Patient be well placed, and his head firmly held, his Ears being topt with Cotton, then et on the Trepan with a Pin, which I have already acquainted you mut neither be upon the Fracture or Suture. The Chirurgeon holding the Intrument in his left hand, and with his right gently turning about the ame until he have fixed it; this once being fixed, let him take out the Pin, and apply the Trepan again without it, till keeping it in its motion, and if you perceive any mall filings of the Skull appear, remove your Trepan, and wipe them away; this Trepan is ometimes to be dipt in Oyl, both for its more ready and eaie performing its Office, and ometimes in Water that it grow not hot. If any Blood appear, it is a certain ign that it hath penetrated the firt Table, and this directs you to be very careful how you proceed, let you hurt and wound the Meninges
by an unhappy lip, being a very great caue of Death. When you perceive the piece of Bone is looed by the Trepan, you may with a fine Levatory or mall Intrument free it by degrees from the other parts of the Cranium, o as you may without danger take it up with your Forcipes, if any ragged pieces appear, which may hurt the Meninges, you are to remove them; all being removed, apply a piece of white Taffaty or Satten dipt in Mel Roarum & Oleum Roarum until the 7th day, after which ue the Oyl of Roes & Ol. Hyperici together, anointing the Head round about the wounded part with Linimentum Arcaei, and fill up the Cavity with Doils and Pledgets armed herewith, if any Scales remain, Arcaeus reporteth by the benefit of his Liniment they will fall away within Twenty or five and twenty days. Continue your digeting Medicines whilt the matter appears (as we have hewn in imple Wounds, then Sarcoticks; and in this cae this Powder being prinkled upon the part, is much commended, Pulv. Ireos. A Sarcotick Powder. Alo. Thur. Mirrh. Aritoloch. ana j, mice. Or this, Sang. Dracon. C. C. an. js Mirrh. s Thur. Irid. an Another. j, mice, fiat pulvis Subtiliimus. Thee to be prinkled upon the Bone that is decaded, and the other vacant place. If the wounded Cutis be not much, you may ue Unguents, as Unguentum de Betonica, Linimentum Arcaei, and the like; then procure a Cicatrice with Epoluticks. And thus have I given you the true method of Trepanning the Skull: Its figures here to be ued, are or may be reckoned an Inciion-Knife, a Raor, a Capital Saw, a Trafine or Trepan with heads, a Levatory, a Raperatory. Each of which you have fairly delineated in this following Figure; and on the other ide, you have preented a Figure of the true manner of its operation, and how it is to be placed upon the Cranium. And before I conclude this Chapter, to make good Hippocrates's Authority, I hall preent thee
two Hitories: in the firt you may ee how Paion can alter both Scene and Actor; and in the next, how upon very mall and light Wounds Death may follow. 1 Hitory.In the 19th Obervation of Fabritius Hildanus Cent. you may Read of a young Man who being of a trong and Cholerick contitution, having received a Wound in his left Bregina with Fracture of the Bone, the Wound being dilated, and brought to Suppuration, the pain ceaed; and the Bones extracted, the Wound mundified and began to fill up with fleh, and all appearances of Symptoms banihed, and it was near covered with a Cicatrice; upon exerciing himelf in Venerial Celebrations with a common Strumpet, within few hours after, he fell into a Fever, and intolerable pain of his Head, the Oppoite ide grew reolute, the arm in the hurt ide correpted with a Spame, and being acquainted with thee Symptoms, thee not giving way nor yielding to any Medicine, at the fourth day hut up the lat hour of his life.

2 Hitory. The econd is of a Noble Virgin, who being hot in Dancing, by michance falling upon the back part of her Head, he there received a light Wound, carce perceiveable, accompanied with no pain or inflammation; The firt and econd day this being neglected, it began the third day to eem painful; upon which, ending for a Barber, he haved her Head, and he carce perceived any appearance of a Wound, inomuch that he thought he ent for him to laugh at him; the fourth day after, he was correpted with a ad pain in her Head, and Fever: Hildanus being called for the ixth day, he found her deliriated, her Face and Eyes inflamed, her Tongue growing black; and the day following he poured forth the lat and of her life.

div.head: CHAP. XXVI.
Of Contuion.
div.p: AS our Dicoure hath hitherto guided us to the Knowledge of Signs, and Praeages in Wounds of the Head, and hath alo hewn what Intruments are neceary in order to the Cure of Fractures of the Skull: Our next intent will be to hew you the variety of Fractures, which may be aid to poes the Skull, and of thee there is great difference allowed amongt their numbers. Hippocrates only naming five, viz. Fiura, Contuio, Effractura, Sedes, and Reonitus.

Galen on the contrary nominates eight, and thus calls them, < in non-Latin alphabet > . And thee are the differences of Fractures which are of the Head, ome of which are accounted imple Fractures, as thee three, Contuio, Rima, Sedes; others more compound, as thee 3, Depreio, Cameratio, Exciio; the other two being Colliio & Contrafiura or Reonitus, of each of thee in their Contuion a imple Fracture.order; in which I begin with Contuio. This Species of a Fracture is called in Greek < in non-Latin alphabet > , or < in non-Latin alphabet > , or Contuion, and this is a proper name given to every Solution of the Mucles and flehy parts; but here it is more properly termed an Impulion in the Cranium, occaioned by the weight or violence of ome ponderous and external Intrument, much expreing Intruments of Tin or Bras, the which being mote or trook by any hard or heavy Intrument, do occaion an inward bent and welling. Paulus lib. 6. c. 90. denies Contuion to be any Fracture, when as only in it is made a Dent in the Bone, the continuity of the Skull being altogether entire.

2 Differencies of Contuion. In Contuion, thee two Differences are generally oberveable, the Bone being either wholly contued, o as that the Dura Mater is forced to flee from the Cranium; or, not wholly Contued, but Superficially. Thee do generally happen in Children, whoe Skulls are thin, and more properly allowed to be Cartilaginous than Boney. Suddenly after the blow is given, or hurt occaioning this Contuion, it doth not appear; nor yet the hurt which is contracted in the Bone: but within a few days after, the colour of the Cranium changeth, and will appear whitih without rednes; and if it be carious, it will appear livid or blackih; and where this appears, you are by your Rape or Scraping Intrument to take away o much of the Bone until the blacknes is quite extirpated, and then to heal the Wound by Incarnatives. And becaue it oft-times happeneth that Children and Infants by reaon of the weaknes of their Heads and Legs are oft ubject to fall from high places, being left alone, and hereby do receive very ad and mierable Contuions in their Heads. And here according to Hippocrates's Aphorim, the Blood being praeternaturally transfued into ome Cavity, doth there corrupt: That we may precribe a right Curative method, we are to take notice, that this putrifying Blood be not permitted to decend to the Dura Mater: And therefore ometimes opening the Cutis for the dicharge of this matter, the Patient is brought into great danger. And that this effect may more accurately be treated, we are to abtain from Section or Inciion; for by the reaon of this copious efflux of Blood, the Spirits become reolved, and Fluxion excited by occaion of this Inciion; and Children hereupon alo being diturbed and vexed, by crying, and the like, the Veins of the Head become tumified, and Inflammation follows, and very oft Death it elf: And therefore for a more afe method to be ued, Take this:

A mot exact way to Cure a Contuion in the Cranium. The Head being haved, apply thereto Bolters made of linnen Cloath or Tow dipt in the Whites of Eggs, Vinegar, and Oyl of Roes together; and let thee thus mixed be kept on for a whole day, to be framed in that conitence that it do not grow dry; in Summer time to be applied cold, in Winter hot: For hereby the flux of humours is prohibited, and in ome meaure Reolved; The day following apply this Cataplame, Pulv. Catapl. Roar. Rubr. fol. et Flor. Myrtill. an. ij. Farin. Hord. Fabar. an. j. pulv. Abynth. Betonic. an. s. Mel. ij. cum vino autero fiat Cataplama, fine addendo Ol Roar. Chamomel. an. j. Cer. q. s. fiat Cataplama. This is to be applyed twice in a day, o as it may comprehend both the Contuion and its neighbouring parts; and this continue untill the 9th or 11th day, in the which time you will find the Contued blood to be reolved, and the Cranium to be brought to its former habit. The 11th day being pat, by Galen's advice we may apply Empl. Diapalma to be thin pread, and this to be changed every third day. After the 20th day, for abuming the humours and retoring the collied Cranium into its proper place. Empl. de Betonica is to be applyed. Ambroe Parrey advieth this Emplater, Farin. Tritic. j. Ichthyocoll. in aqu. Empl. Betonic. et alv. olut. s. Pulv. Matich, Thur. Farin. Volital. Sang. Drac. Gyp. an.
j. s. mic e, coquantur in aqu. Betonic. & alv. ad jutam conitentiam. ParticalidÃ¨ admoveatur.

Cupping-Glaes. In thee caes alo Cupping-Glaes are very much commended, but in young Children they are not very proper; for by kind means ued you will find Nature run through a great part of your work. But I will not deny but they may be very ueful in ome who are grown to a pretty age, as we may ee in this Story of a Boy, Hitory.who falling from a Hore upon the ground, had his right Bregma truck by one of the hores feet, the which did both depres and contue his Skull, of which blow he
lay as dead without ene or motion, with his Eyes cloed up, the blood coming through his Ears and Notrils, who by the benefit of a Cupping-Glas applied to the part with much flame, within 17 dayes without any Inciion of the Cranium, he was retored to his former health.

Hitory. Another Hitory I hall here write alo, to hew of what trength Paion is in young Children. A Lad of 15 years of age having received a Contued Wound about his Bregma, with Fracture, the Wound being at firt dilated, and the pieces of bones extracted, it was brought to a happy uppuration, and all evil Symptomes diappeared. The Eleventh day being pat, the Child being vexed, and moved to Anger, uddainly fell into a Fever, and Phrenie, o that in four dayes after he dyed: he being diected, the Membranes of the Brain were found inflamed, and both the Ramifications of Veins and Arteries much tumified with blood.

Another Hitory. I will conclude this with that Remarkable Hitory of Hugo Blotius, who writes of Charles Nephew to Charles the 5th of Spain, who after having been troubled with a Quartan Ague, was by his Phyitians directed to walk and refreh himelf in the Air; As he was going out of his Chamber door, and eeing a Maid of Honour making of Garlands, made hate to her; he hereupon being urprized, making hate away, fell againt the barr of her Chamber door; the Young Gentleman being herewith vexed, that he hould be the Occaion of this michief, in a fury going to his Chamber, meets with an unhappy Fall, which caued a wound in his head, coming from her Chamber: The Chirurgions hereupon being called, they preently rowled it up, and intended to conolidate the Wound, neglecting the efflux of matter, inomuch that his head peedily tumified, and this Young Gentleman lay as if he were in an Apoplexy. Andraeas Vealius, an Expert Anatomit, and well skilled in Chirurgery,
being ent for, affirmed, That the chief method which mut give any hopes of life, mut be the opening of the Pericrane. The which by general conent being allowed, no ooner was this done, but a faetid matter came forth: The young man oon recovered himelf, and by the benefit hereof, as one retored from the Grave, he was raied from this deep leep.

div.head: CHAP. XXVII.
Of Rima or Fiure.
div.p: Second Fiure. THE Second Kind of thee imple Fractures is called < in non-Latin alphabet > , or Fiura, or Rima; and by Paulus is decribed a uperficial or profound Diviion of the Skull, and hence is by him called < in non-Latin alphabet > , or Rima Superficialis; and this by its not appearance is a very frequent occaion of death. This may be aid to pas through either one or both tables, if it uperficially pas no further than the pongious bone between both the Tables it is thus far dilated; if it pas between both, it is epecially to be dilated thorough the firt if not both, making a way through the econd, leaving a competent Apertion for the dicharge of the coagulated bloody matter. Hippocrates declares that there is no Fiure without a Contuion; and does further adde, That this for the mot part is made by a ponderous Contuing Intrument, as a Stone, Wood, Iron, falls from a high place upon ome harp hard body: And when either of thee or the like do happen, they do caue a Fisure in, or cleave the Cranium: Jut as an Earthen Veel receiving a crack upon falling on a hard body.

Differences of Fiures. Of thee many differences arie, ome of thee being thick, others thin, others very thin, and thee chiefly
at the beginning before they have contracted Matter, for the Knowledge of which there is required a Judicious and Artificial Conjecture to be taken from the Intrument hurting, the occaion, the age of the Patient, and the Temper of the affected part, and other Symptomes which may be taken from the hurt; for thee do declare the mot inconpicuous igns of the Fiure: as ome being hort, others long; ome broad, others narrow: ome treight, others crooked, according to the Intrument hurting. Some of thee wholly paing through the Cranium, others uperficially onely entring it. But where a Fiure hath been made through either Table, and paed to the Dura Mater, and hence by conequence made it to flee from the Cranium, and by this diviion the mouthes of the Veels laid open, o as that they pour forth their blood which was collected and inerted under the Skull, which Veels conveighing this blood to the Brain ariing from the inward Jugulars, and o paing upwards, and there expanding themelves very plentifully about the Dura Mater, are by Concuion very eaily lacerated and broken, and the blood herein being collected, unles a peedy way be found out for its Expurgation, we may well gues of the Patient's micarriage. And if any man neglect to rae thee Fiures at the firt, although there be no need appear of his dilatation, he may for a few dayes find that the Cure may ucceed according to expectation, but hall as readily meet, that to take heed and beware hereof is the mater event of Fools, who by unadviednes meet Accidents followingwhich will much cros their Expectation. For when this hath arrived at the Eleventh or Twelfth day, either ooner or later, Matter then beginning to putrifie between each Table, and that this putrifaction will communicate its elf to the Membranes of the Brain, and the Brain its elf; and hence will follow Fevers, with inordinate Stiffnees, Watchings, Vomiting, Delirium,
Troubles, and Inquietudes; and if the Wound do happen near the Eye, the other Eye does appear to be inflamed; and after thee the Patient is urprized with Singultus, and reolution in the oppoite ide: And as touching the Wound you will ee the Lipps fall, a mall Matter appear, and this is crude and indigeted, intemperate, and of a bad mell; hewing and declaring its want of native heat, and when the Patient leaves the world, his lat minute is hut up, in an appearance of blew or dry, or pale and dry. But when we have any command from hope to proceed here according to Art in others who have their Skulls Fiured; if it be not to be dicerned by the Eye, caue the aid Patients breath to be topped; after which done, if you meet with a thin humour, or bloody Matter, it portends a good ign. But if this way fail, then apply Ink which is thin and may penetrate, and let the affected part be dreed with this, and let this erve for the firt dreing. The next dreing with a Sponge being wet, wah off the Ink from the Cranium; and if you ee any entred in, follow this tract untill you have wholly obliterated it; and for this Ue, the Trepan is not o proper an Intrument as is the Rapar, or the thin Intrument mot ueful for this work. It being dilated, dres the Wound as I have already directed you, after the application of the Trepan.

Hitory. And becaue I intend a little to enlarge upon thee Fractures, I hall here produce everal Hitories, which will be of great benefit to the Young Chirurgeon. And the firt hall be of a Fisure onely penetrating the firt Table; the econd of a Rima, penetrating both Tables; and the third of a Wound in the right part of the Head with Contuion and Fiure of the Cranium.

As touching the firt, and this, Glandorp writes of in his Speculum Chirurgorum, fol. 43. of a man Forty years of age, being of a Phlegmatick and Cacochymick habit and Contitution of body, being too much intoxicated with
Wine, and endeavouring to climbe a Ladder, fell down backwards, whereby he had a Contuion not far ditant from the Lambdoidal Suture; hence did arie pain, and inquietude of his body, and from his Notrils did flow forth much blood. For this, becaue it onely appeared as an Ecchymois, the Cutis being entire, his head being haven, this Cataplame was applyed; As . Summitat. Abynth. Meth, an. pug. iiij. pulv. fl. Chamomel. Melilot. an. pug. iij. Roar. Rubr. Cheiri an. pug. ij. Farin. Cicer. Fabar. an. j. Hord. vj. Cum vini Q. S. fiat Cataplama, in fine addendo Ol. Roar. j. s. mice. The pain not herewith being awaged, it was begun to be upected, whether either the Pericrane alone, or the Cranium with it was hurt alo. Hereupon a Cros Inciion being made, there was found Matter to lodge between the Cranium and Pericrane, the bone appearing black, and a Fiure onely een to penetrate the firt Table: which blacknes was wholly raed out even to the econd Table, after which was applyed and prinkled a Catagmatick Powder, and to the Wound was applyed a Digetive, by which the hurt and contued parts, and the effued blood might be both digeted, putrifie and be mundified. And for this purpoe, this of Gal. 3. & 4. Method. Med. was ued: nguent.. Terebynth. Lot. in aqu. Malvar. j. Unguent. Dialth. cum Gum. iij. Mirrh ij. Unguent. Aegyptiac. j. s. Vitell. Ov. Q. S. mice. The contued fleh being ablated, a new fleh was generated by the above-written Balome, and in the interim the other parts of the Cranium were prinkled with the Powders untill they had procured a new fleh, and a Cicatrice was obduced by Empl. or Unguentum Diapompholigos.

Another Hitory. The Second is of a Youth of 14 years of age, who climbing a Tree and a bough breaking, he fell down, whereby he received a very large Wound, Vomited, was deliriated and convelled; the flux of blood which followed was peedily topped, his head haved, and the
depth of the Wound earched into. The cleft through which bubbles, Wind and Matter (his Noe and Mouth being hut and topt) was een to pas; becaue he grew deliriated, and his pirits drooped, uch Medicines as eae Pain were applyed: The next day he beginning omewhat to come to himelf, was acquainted, that without a peedy application of the Trepan, he mut be pronounced to be in danger of los of life; and being provided for the performance of the ame, he had a Cordial precribed him, his Body kept oluble by Clyter, and his Head Trepanned a little under the hurt, and an exquiite and convenient Dyet being precribed him, the Wound was afterwards Cured, as we have already hown in the former Hitory.

A Third Hitory. The Third was performed by the mot Excellent Anatomit Adrianus Spegelius, Ordinary Profeor of Anatomy and Chirurgery; and this was of a man even times Trepanned in one part of the head, and yet recovered; who having received a Wound in the right part of his head with Contuion and Fiure of his Cranium: here it being much dreaded that Matter or collected blood might lodge under his Cranium, his body being made oluble by Clyters, and a good Order of Dyet precribed, that the Trepan might be applyed with more freedom: The Pericrane was dilated in form of an X, and the flux of the blood being topped, it was after the firt day, Trepanned the third day, then two dayes after that again, and few dayes after this he was Trepanned again; and thus o often until he had uffered even times being Trepanned in one part of his head, (viz.) in the cincipital part thereof: inomuch that a great part of the Skull was exempted in that ide; after which the Wound was thus handled: Upon the Dura Mater was firt prinkled this Powder; . Cort. Thur j. s. Rad. Aritoloch. Rotund. Irid. Pucedan. an. j. mice, fiat Pulvis.
And this is to be prinkled upon the Part, over which is to be put a piece of Silk or fine Linnen Cloath dipt in Oyl of Roes, the Cranium alo being to be prinkled with the ame Powders, and to the lips of the Wound nguent.to be applied this Digetive, . Terebinth. Venet. lot. in aqu. Veronic. j. Matich. j. Ol. Roar. ij. Vitell. Ovor. q. s. fiat Digetivum. Over this to be applied Diapalma, the Head being to be anointed with Ol. Roar. et Cheirin. And Cloathes dipt in Red Wine in which have been boyled ome Capital Herbs, to be applyed thereto. After which let it be rolled up, every other day the Medicines to be renewed; The eminencies of the bone, and the blacknes to be caled off, the Wound being abterged and mundified, it is to be incarnated with Unguentum de Betonica; This not to be done untill all cales be removed, and then Cicatrized: And this Man to admiration, without any Fever and Pain, or other Symptome, perfectly Recovered.

div.head: CHAP. XXVIII.
Of Sedes or a Fracture, hewing the place of the Intrument where it was impacted.
div.p:
< in non-Latin alphabet > , or Sedes, this is the third Species of a Simple Fracture; o properly called, when as the Bone remaining in its natural tate, makes the place conpicuous where the Weapon had been infixed. It's called a Solution of Continuity in the Bone of the Head, made by a harp cutting Intrument, leaving its print in the Cranium, remaining in its natural tate, not broken inwards.
Paulus does give us thee two Species hereof, the firt whereof he calls < in non-Latin alphabet > , which is by him held to be a diviion in the Cranium with everion or elation of the offended Bone. The other he alo calls < in non-Latin alphabet > , as when the fractured Bone of the Skull does recede from the other Bone, even as we ee a Chip fall from the Body of the Tree when it is hewed or chopt from it; and hence called the Ablation of the bone. A third Species hereof is named by Hippocrates, and by him called < in non-Latin alphabet > , and this is a large & deep Cutt penetrating the Cranium, as Philotheus explains it, Comment. Aphorim. 16. Cap. Lib. 6. < in non-Latin alphabet > , or Diviionem Profundam. There are everal differences allowed hereof by Hippocrates. It being ometimes imple without Fiure, Colliion, and Effracture; and this he hath in his 10th Sentence. Sometimes with Fiure and Contuion, and ometimes onely joyned with Contuion. Sometimes this happens in a direct line; otherwhiles in an oblique. And here alo Hippocrates advieth, That that Wound which is obliquely made in the Cranium is les terrible, than that which is made directly; for in an oblique Wound the ubject parts are les Concued. Out of this imple Sedes are alo framed thee Compounds, both in regard of the Weapons which do variouly afflict the Cranium, and alo in repect of the Bones themelves; ome of which are olid, others more oft. And hence is it if a Weapon having a blunt edge, eize on a olid part of the Cranium, beides this Inciion, it alo maketh a Fiure; and where it happens in a part of a middle ubtance between both hard and oft, this is partly fiured, partly collied by reaon of the Sedes. He therefore who will undertake the Cure of any of thee three fore-cited Fractures, ought well to undertand their everal and ditinct Species, before he applyes his hand, and not too rahly peed himelf upon thee dangerous Cures which are of o great
import as touching the life or decay of Mankind. Without the great care in minding and oberving of which, or temerariouly neglecting hereof, the Old Proverb may in uch be well verified, Caecus Caesum ducens, &c. And having thus given you the general Directions here very appoite for this part and pecies: To conclude this, if it pas through both Tables, and there do remain no frutulaes of the Bone bordering upon the Dura Mater, and room enough left for the dicharge of the Matter occaioned by the largenes of the Wound, Dilate no further, but oberve the method already decribed in my general Dicoure of Wounds of the Head; but hould any mall pieces or plints of the Bone offend the Dura Mater, and the paage not wide enough for the dicharge of the Matter, then may you come to the ue of the Trepan; if it onely pas into the firt Table treat it as you are directed in a Fiure, and afterwards dres it with Unguent. de Betonic. or Linimentum Arcaei.

Hitory. Falloppius in Comment. de vulnerib. Capit. Hipp. 16. writes, That he aw in a Scholar being wounded in the back part of his Head by a weighty Sword, wherein the place of the Sword was apparent; the Bone being caled, and neither finding Fiure or Contuion, not finding or knowing how this happened, upon a further earch, he came to the econd Table, and in this he found a large Fiure: and the reaon of his proceeding after this manner was, the outward part being Contued, this Contuion was communicated to the econd Table, and whereas the outward could not fall into its elf, nor the inward Table into its elf, hereby it uffered this Fiure, the which he evidently found out: And therefore in all uch caes we are directed by Fulloppius his Advice, to abrade the Cranium even to the lower plate.

div.head: CHAP. XXIX.
Of Exciion.
div.p: HAving dipatched thee three Simple Fractures in Cranio, we next come to three Compound Fractures; and thee are called Exciio, Depreio, and Concameratio; of each of thee in their order, and to begin with Exciion: And this Species of a Fracture is called < in non-Latin alphabet > or < in non-Latin alphabet > , and this happeneth, when the ubtance of the Bone is amputated, or the Cranium o wounded, that it eparates from the Hole. If the Frutula or Sliver cut away thus, adhere to the Cutis Muculoa, and the Wound penetrates no further than the firt Table, this is to be eparated from it, and the Cranium to be moothed with the Rapatory; but if both the Tables adhere to the Membrana Carnoa, they are not to be removed, but to be reduced to their proper places, the Wound being mundified and deterged with white-Wine, or Spirit of Wine mixt with Mel Roarum; then adjoyn the Cutis Muculoa to the other with convenient Stitches, as Ambroe Parrey advieth; who alo doth order, that if any part of a Bone hould be cut out, accompanied with a large Wound, or evered from any other part of the Cranium and do only adhere to the Pericrane, and Muculous Cutis, it is not from thence to be removed. And although this may appear as a uperfluous and uperficial Caution, and look as an ueles Maxim, yet it is not to be contradicted; for a Callus will hereupon generate peedily, the which by the trength of Nature will be oon procured as Celus oberveth.

Hitory. The truth of which, certain Experience makes good; as he alo heweth in a Captain, who having received a very large Wound upon his Coronal Bone, which equaled
the breadth of three Fingers, occaioned by a large and trong Sword, o as that it eparated each part from the other, o as that the neighbouring Bones did not cohere; but carce adhering to the Pericrane and hairy Scalp, he fell with his Face forward upon the ground, and had ome part of his Dura Mater hanging over his Eyes. Ambroe Parrey being conulted about this his Cure, doth peedily reduce the Dura Mater into its proper place, by removing it from the Cutis of his Face, oberving Hippocrates's Rules, not to leave the Brain unarmed naked: Wherefore the Blood being deterged, which was fallen upon the Dura Mater, and the protrated Bone reduced into its true place, and with a Suture made with three Stitches in the upper part, he cloed up the Wound, and ordered that the Matter remaining might be dicharged, by the vacant paces between the Sutures or Stitches; and hence between thee vacancies were put in mall Tents and Doils, by the which the Parts were kept open, and the Matter dicharged: And although the Body was tabbed through in everal other places at this time, occaioning many Wounds, by God's Mercy he recovered, without any los of Pericrane or Cranium, but what neceity compelled to be taken away.

div.head: CHAP. XXX.
Of Effractura or Depreion.
div.p:
THis Species of a Fracture is called < in non-Latin alphabet > , Effractura, Depreio; and by Paulus Aeginetta, Deeio & Introceio: And this is framed both of Contuion and Fiure, under which are contained < in non-Latin alphabet > ,
or Appropinquation of Bodies, and < in non-Latin alphabet > , or Concameration, and < in non-Latin alphabet > , Effractio: All the which by Paulus are allowed as o many various Species of Fractures, the firt of which by him is owned to be a diviion of the Bone, in which the hurt Bone falleth downwards towards the Dura Mater, out of its natural place, and therefore it is o called, < in non-Latin alphabet > , or propÃ¨. Camarois is a diviion of the Cranium with its Exaltation, the Bone advancing upwards. Galen doth thus ditinguih them, Lib. 6. Meth. Medend.
< in non-Latin alphabet > by him being called a Fracture, whoe Bone happens upon the Dura Mater upon its depreion; < in non-Latin alphabet > that which hath the Bone exalted. But this Species of a Fracture doth much differ from a Fiure, becaue in this is an Introceion, but none to be found in a Fiure, the Bone in that remaining in its proper tate and nature: from a Contuion alo; for although the Bone do introceed in it, yet the Continuity thereof is not olved; whereas in a Depreion or Introceion, the Bone is fractured into many hivers. And here alo Hippocrates his obervation may be well applyed; as we daily ee, hard things do rather break than bend, whereas oft things we ee do more readily bend than break: But in a Wound happening with a depreion of the Skull, we ee apparently, that there is not only made a Divorce of Parts in the Cranium, but fractures them o, that they are een to lodge upon the Dura Mater, there compreing it, the which lacerated Parts here thus happening, do hinder the motion of the Brain, and are oft-times een to appear fixed, like o many Splints or Shivers upon its Membrane, terrifying and perplexing it. And the cae lyes here parallel with the Heart; for as the body of the Heart doth attract and expel its Subtances, by its extending and contracting Quality in its proper times and circuits, o alo doth the Brain, in which is eated the animal Spirit contained in its Ventricles, tranmit the ame to every Part,
being thereto incited by a fit and proper motion, and thereby doth ditribute and elaborate the ame. But when this motion is intercepted by a compreion of the Bones and Splints, and the like falling thence, this ditribution and elaboration mut necearily be violated, which motion doth evidently appear in wounded people, whoe Heads are detected, and in new born Children. Without doubt therefore the Parts being thus fractured, the Membranes mut hereby receive much prejudice; and in thee dangerous caes, the Chirurgion hath left him but mall ground to build any hopes for a Cure. In uch matters therefore which carry uch evident peril with them, the buines is chiefly to be left to Nature, the bet and mot afe Mitres for preerving her Parts in form, ave only we are to ait her with our bet skill and endeavour, to prevent all evil Accidents and Symptoms, which may intervene before the fourth day, if you come at the firt, and o from the fourth to the eventh.

And as to the Cure hereof; Thoe Splints or Shivers which are quite looe, raie up with your Elevatory, and take them away: But if you meet with a Fracture, that is only looe at one end in the Bone, adhering in the other, here are you to ue the Trepan, to be applied as near to the fractured Part as may be, and then to take away a mall part of the Cranium with it; and if you cannot reduce the depreed Bones to their proper places, eparate and take them out by Art, and ue that care, that you may happily conclude your Cure without any danger to the Dura Mater, or its ubjacent Parts.

Hitory. Fabritius Hildanus, Ob. 3. Cent. 2. doth write of one of forty years old, in the Bihoprick of Colen, who was mitten in his Head with an Iron Bullet, which weighed a pound and a half, cauing a large Depreion and Fracture in the left Bregma; upon the receiving of which,
he fell upon the ground like a dead Man, with the los both of peech, ight and hearing; beides which, he was correpted with a Palie in the oppoite ide: the Cranium being in few days elevated, and reduced into its natural ite, he recovered his peech, and the Symptoms began to grow remis; and at length was retored to his pritine health.

2 Hitory. On the contrary alo he writes of a young Man of fourteen years of Age, who falling from his Hore backwards, was o mitten by him, that it occaion'd an Impreion in his Skull; but in repect little or nothing of evil Symptoms appeared at the firt, the Wound alo being but mall, the Patient was neglected, who within a mall time after, being beyond expectation urprized with terrible Symptoms, beyond all methods and applications, he was correpted with a Fever, pain of his Head, and inquietude of his whole Body; the Wound grew inflamed, inuous and full of Matter, and the Cranium found to be depreed, and in few days he ended his Life.

By thee two Examples we may apparently find, how neceary it is at the firt to reduce the depreed Cranium into its natural ite, and how dangerous in the contrary the Neglect hereof may prove, as we ee in the latter of thee two Hitories; for in mall and lender Depreions of the Cranium, the motion of the Brain may be hindred, and epecially if they happen upon or near the Sutures. How to elevate the depreed Skull, you are directed in Fabrit. Hildan. Oberv. 6. Cent. 2. to which I recommend you.

div.head: CHAP. XXXI.
Of Concameration.
div.p: IN the lat Chapter I have in part hewn you what < in non-Latin alphabet > is; it is made, when one part of the Head is mitten with a Lance or any uch like Intrument, and upon endeavouring to extract this, it o cloely adheres to the edges of the Cranium, that it forceth the Skull up with it; and this is called Concameratio, much reembling an Arch or Ridge acending, but leaving a vacuity underneath: if it onely pas the firt Table, mooth the Skull with a fine Rape, and then heal it as you do other Fractures in Cranio; but if it pas through both, you mut lay Open the Skull with the Trepan in the depending part, for the more ready dicharge of the Matter lodged within, which oft-times is not to be emptied out by the wounded part. If by accident any piece of the Skull fall off here upon the Dura Mater, you are to make o large a Dilatation as that you may come at this plint to remove it; and o to Cure this Wound as you are already hown how to cure the former. This Species of a Fracture happens o eldome, that it is not o much as mentioned by Hippocrates. I hall conclude this Chapter with two Hitories.

1 Hitory.
Valleriola, lib. 5. Ob. 9. writes of a Shoe-maker who having received a large Wound in his Head, occaioned by a Spear or Lance, with a Fracture of his Skull reaching the Dura Mater, was eized with Reolution and Convulion after the 7th day, and did continue peechles all the even dayes, yet with great care and pains he was recovered.

2 Hitory. The Second is of Vertunianus Comment. ad Libr. Hipp. de vulnerib. cap. who writes of one who received three
deperate Wounds in his Head; The firt happening in his Front, two tranvere fingers above the eye, paing thence to the Zygoma, dividing the Eye in its middle; the econd in the left Bregma, entring even to the Dura Mater, two fingers in length, and one finger in breadth; The third, the wort of the ret and mot dangerous, happening in the Occiput; this being four fingers long, and two fingers wide: hence followed very direful Symptomes, on the eventh day a Fever eized him, with a trange numbnes and tupidity; his courage failed, with los of Memory, an involuntary intetinal Flux econded thee, no Matter iuing from any part of the three Wounds, the Dura Mater appeared immoveable and black, all which did attend him even to the 30th day, o as there was little hopes left of any recovery, yet he was perfectly Cured. This Hitory which he ets down, he received from Dr. Pigraeus, Chief Chirurgeon to the King, who was a Man of great Worth and Repute; whence younger Chirurgeons may learn, That Patients oft-times pronounced irrecoverable, beyond hopes or expectation, have been een to be cured, and to have lived beyond the mortiferous Signs of Hippocrates. Such Wounds therefore are not to be neglected or diregarded, o long as Life gives any hopes to continue.

div.head: CHAP. XXXII.
Of Colliion.
div.p:
THis Species of a Fracture is called < in non-Latin alphabet > , or Colliio; neither doth the Cranium altogether uffer Fractures, but a Suture alo may endure a Colliion, and receive a Solution of Continuity, both by Separation, Depreion, and Colliion. The firt two whereof we have already treated on. We come now to the third. And here may we premie, That Fractures happening upon the Sutures, are harder to cure than to find out: For here are we neither to Derade or Open with a Trepan, by reaon of the Dura Mater, which upholds the Brain, being tyed to thee parts alo, upon every light occaion being ubject to Inflammation; but how few daily tudy thee Precepts, and bear them in their Memories! And as I have already hewn in my Dicoure of Sutures, no Inciion is to be made here, they being both weak, and eaily perforated, hereby ubjecting the Brain to michiefs: Becaue alo through thee the Veins and Membranes do pas, the which being but lightly touched by any harp Intrument, are made peedily to flee thence. And then thirdly, becaue a Callus being here contracted, doth hinder Tranpiration. Hence alo Worthy Hippocrates writes, That there's nothing more difficult in the undertaking of Wounds of the Head, than firt to precribe a true Method as touching Section or Inciion, when, and where to be made or done, neither uperficially nor diminutely. And becaue he would not pretermit thoe places which are dangerous and will not admit Inciion, here as he propoeth the Temporal Mucles, o alo doth he bring in the Sutures, to be dangerous
places to make any Inciion in. Yet becaue it o happens, that a Colliion doth happen in the brims of a Suture, and the Dura Mater which paeth through it occaioned by a violent Compreion, uffers detriment in thee direful caes, where a Troop of fearful Symptomes doth accompany them, as Fever, Vomiting, Convulion, and the like, and having no other hopes of aving your Patient but by your ue of the Trepan, you are advied upon this neceary Point to apply your Trepan on either ide of the Suture o carefully, that your Intruments do not touch it; hereby preventing thoe horrible Symptomes which happen on the contrary.

Hitory. To Conclude this, Valleriola, Oberv. 10. Lib. 4. writes of Claudius Allobrox, who being wounded in his Head with a great Military Sword, according to the Petroe Sutures, his Skull being variouly cut and depreed even to the Lambdoidal Suture; and which was a trange Wonder, he all this while was not correpted with any Fever or other evil Symptome upervening; the which are generally een as common attendants on uch large Wounds; the depreed and effracted bones being Extracted, the Man was perfectly Recovered by the benefit of Mel. Roarum, a Cephalick Powder, and Empl. de Bettonica, within the pace of two Moneths.

div.head: CHAP. XXXIII.
Of Contrafiure.
div.p: WE arrive now at the 8th and lat Species of a Fracture in Cranio, and this by the Greeks is called < in non-Latin alphabet > , Quai ab Eccho Reponionem; ome call it < in non-Latin alphabet > , Quai Reonitus, or as an Eccho anwering any ound. Paulus Aeginetta will not grant this to be any Species of a Fracture, Lib. 6. and doth own, that they are mitaken who write, That upon a Blow being given on one ide, a Fracture hould appear on the other: And do further allude, That it is not in mens Heads as it is in Glaes; for they being empty are oon broken, the Skull of Man being both olid and full, and therefore not o eaily fractured. Soranus who doth defend the contrary, taketh up this opinion as his Buckler. That in all glaen Bodies or Veels which are hollow, being mitten in one part, they generally do crack or break in the other; and this may as well happen in the Head, as in any other Part: And the Reaons which he brings are thee; The Air contained in thee glaen Bodies which do receive the Blow, being hereby contued and illied, doth carry the ame to the Back-part, and there force a diviion. And why the Air hath force enough alo to do this, is ufficiently evident, whenas we ee it hath vigour and trength enough to divide Mountains, and eparate Hills; and hence may it be granted much more readily, to have power enough in it to break a Glas in the contrary ide; and when this Fracture doth happen by reaon of any included Air, the Greeks do call this Apochema.

But to enlarge a little further; In every Percuion which is made in the Body, is there perceived or felt an
Impetuoity and Agitation in the Spirits contained therein; and this is a pirituous Subtance, which doth exhale continually from the Body: And hence is it that Bodies in Exhalation are diipated; and this doth inhabit in the inward Parts of the Body; and therefore in every Percuion we hall meet with a pirituous Habit agitated.

Again, Many have been een to have their Heads fractured in the back-part of their Skulls, and yet by a large Flux of Blood through their Notrils hereupon happening, have been perfectly cured and recovered; and whence hould this Blood flow but from the lacerated and dirupted Veels? but you read not of many cured, who being mitten on the fore-part of their Heads, have their Veels rent in the back-part thereof, becaue the Blood here hath not any paage allowed it for its dicharge. This Fracture is ometimes een to happen on the ame Bone, and then this falls out either to be laterally or perpendicularly, the firt having in it a Wound given in the right ide, and a Fracture hereby purchaed in the left; or from the upper Part to the lower, and here both Tables are generally allowed to be fractured. Or it happens in many Bones, and thee alo do communicate the Blow to the oppoite Part, where meeting the Cranium in its violent motion; as two Men readily upon a quick motion meeting each other, doth make them give way and fall back: Thus the Skull receiving a Blow, doth communicate the ame very peedily to the other Part thereof, and there doth frame a Fracture, being denied a peedy paage through it.

Hippocrates in thee kinds of Fractures, will admit of no Remedies, or the undertaking of their Cure, the affected Part not being eaily found out: Yet he further advieth us, That where any upition of a Fracture doth offer, although it be a matter of difficulty to find it out; yet he lays down this as a Method for undertaking the
ame, epecially if the common Signs do appear, as Fever, Vomiting, Bleeding, and the like; and no Fiure hereupon being found in the wounded Part, we are to examine the oppoite, and if any Tumour or oftnes do there appear, you may preage a Fracture in the Skull, ubjacent to that Part; or as he directs, Fol. 325. de Vulnerib. Capit. to have the Head haved, and then to apply Empl.this following Emplatre: Pic. Naval. Cer. an. iij. Terebynth. Venet. j. Pulv. Matich. Irid. an. ij. mice, fiat Empl. pread it upon Leather, and apply it to the oppoite Part, and let it lye thereon for 24 hours; and if after its removal, the Cutis Muculoa in any place do appear moit, oft, and tumified, more than the other Parts, it yields a certain ign of a Fracture. Caear Arantius in lib. de Vulnerib. Cap. doth call this Infortunium, here being in it the wort of Accidents; and that which makes it of great danger, is the hardnes of finding the place out. And ince this is o difficult, the Fiure lying obcure under the Cutis, and without any notice thereof being taken, at firt how cautelouly and coniderately had a Chirurgeon undertaken uch a matter of danger, wherein he is advied both by Rule and Authority to gain its true knowledge, before he undertake any Cure: For having attained its artificial conjecture, upon dilating the ound Part the Patient doth oft-times micarry, and what mierable calumny this may bring upon his head, any rational Creature may eaily judge. And as Hippocrates allows, may well be called Infortunium; for on the contrary ide, if Section and Inciion be not made in this cae, the Part affected runneth into an Abces; and this alo is acribed to the Chirurgeon's negligence; o as we may behold, being concerned herewith, how ubject he is to Calumny and misfortune, and an unkind apprehenion. And ince as Hippocrates writes, we cannot arrive here at the true place, and o thence dicharge the Matter inwardly lodged; for want
hereof the Part uddenly doth uppurate and inflame, and hence throwing it elf upon the Dura Mater, through the Fiure, doth at length reach the Brain it elf. And hence are we by his Directions either not at all to undertake this Cure, or be therewith concerned; or if being thereto allured by perwaion of Friends, we are to ue our greatet endeavour to gain its Knowledge; the which once having arrived at, you are, if the econd Table be fractured, the firt remaining whole, come to the application of your Trepan, both for the dicharge of Splints and Matter. And if upon acting your part with Judgement added to your Art, it o happens your Patient micarry or die, you hall have thee four Excues to defend you: As the Cranium being depreed by a violent Contuion, and then doth preently return to its proper place; if the Fiure be only Capillary and Superficial, and hard to be found out; when the econd Table is fractured, the firt remaining entire; and when a Fiure on Fracture doth happen in an oppoite Part to that which was wounded; any of thee four being capable to deceive the bet and mot wie of Chirurgeons. And becaue this is a hard matter to cure, or undertake the Cure hereof, I hall enlarge omewhat herein both by Example and Hitory, for the benefit of young Chirurgeons.

1 Hitory.
Ambroe Parrey writes of one, who having received a mall Wound in his right Bregma, occaioned by the fall of a Stone thereon, the which made both a large Contuion and Tumour; and that it might more certainly appear, that if any hurt might happen to the Bone, the concrete Blood was forthwith cleaned and expreed, and the Wound laid bare by Theodoricus, an excellent Chirurgeon, and a Man of a good repute in his Art, who omitted nothing in this cae his Art and Judgement could afford. Upon a fair Dilatation being made upon the Cranium, the Bone was found entire, yet a Fracture
was much upected by him; upon the receiving of which Blow, the Patient uddenly fell to the ground, and vomited, and had all the other Symptoms which attended Fractures in Cranio. Parrey being ent for, examining the caue of his Fall, upon a diviion of the Pericrane on the contrary ide, and with the capital Saw being applied to the oppoie part of the Wound, there was found a great quantity of Matter to iue forth, falling alo upon the Dura Mater, and making an Abces in the body of the Brain it elf; he had no Suture beides the two quammoe Sutures: And hence therefore by Hippocrates's Authority, confirmed both by Reaon and Experience, one Part may be fiured, whilt the oppoite Part is only wounded.

2 Hitory.
Nicolaus Florentinus 7 Sum. ecund. Tract. 4. Cap. 1. doth affirm, That he was an Eye-witnes of this following Hitory, which was of a certain Artificer, who being at his Work, was mitten with a Key in his right Temple, the which occaioned both a Contuion and a mall Wound in that Part which was mote therewith, without any Cleft or Fiure. The Wound being dilated, nothing of Matter did appear; at the 20th day a great horrour and Fever did invade him; and on the 23d day a Livor and Gangrene eized him in his left Temple; the mortified Fleh being wholly eparated even to the Cranium, the Cranium it elf was found fractured in the ame place.

3 Hitory.
Falloppius alo cap. 14. Com. lib. Hipp. de Vulnerib. Cap. writes, That he oft-times hath found by Experience in dead Bodies, who have died of Wounds received in their Heads, who in the wounded Part have had no Fracture, and upon opening the contrary ide, he hath found a plentiful collection of Matter, and a large Contuion.

4 Hitory. And in Com. cap. 13. Hipp. de Vuln. Cap. he writes, That he aw in a Noble Scholar, who being wounded in the back-part of his Head by a weighty Weapon,
where the mark of the Weapon was apparent, the Bone being deraded, o as there was neither een either Cleft or Contuion. Upon further enquiry hereinto, the upper Table being entirely abraded, and coming to the econd, there was found a great and large Fiure: And in all uch caes he advieth, where any uch large Wounds may or hall offer themelves, to abrade even to the inward Table.

And Petrus Spererius doth write of Rinaldus Corteius, who had in his Study or Cloet a Cranium, in which the lower Table of the Cranium was rent and lacerated, without any apparent or evident ign of Rupture or Laceration. The Fractures are thus et down: At A. Contuio; at B. Fiura; at C. Teli Sedes; at D. Exciio; at E. Depreio; at F. Concameratio; at G. Colliio; at H. Contrafiura: And becaue both ides cannot be expreed by any Figure, where the Wound was given, and where the Fiure happened, I have in this lat only expreed the Rima or Cleft.

div.head: CHAP. XXXIV.
Of Wounds of the two Meninges.
div.p:
THE Cranium being ablated, and its diverity of Fractures dicoured of, we may find the Brain covered with two Membranes, indued with an exquiite ene: Thee by the Greeks being called Meninges; by the Arabians Matres. And as we find the lower Belly cloathed with a Peritonaeum, and the middle with a Pleura, o alo may we ee the Brain covered with two Membranes, tretched over the Cavities of the Cranium, Nature having formed thee for the better conervation
of the Brain, they being contituted of Spermatick parts.

Of the Dura Mater. The firt of thee immediately planted under the Cranium is the Dura Mater, the which by Falloppius, Bauhine, and many other accurate Anatomits, is aid to be framed of two Membranes; it receives into it Veins, and a few Arteries, thee being contituted not only for the afety of the Brain and its Nerves, but alo for the upporting of the two Brains, dividing alo the medullous Matter into a right and a left ide, and into an anteriour and poteriour Brain, the one being properly called Cerebrum, the other Cerebellum, the two ides thereof being divided by a Falx, the which hath allowed it four Cavities for the tranition of its Veels. The whole Brain is upported in that good order by this, and planted with that difference from the Cranium, that it may exercie its proper and free motion; and where occaion erves, it may be allowed to yield o fairly, that upon the application of the Trepan, it may with afety be allowed and performed by a dexterous hand, being guided by a olid judgement. Inwardly this Coat is light and lubricous, perfued with a waterih Humidity: Outwardly it is aperate and hard, enwrapping the Cranium and its Cavities, and adhering thereto by many mall Fibres, ent through the errated Sutures, out of which being expanded about the Cranium is framed the Pericrane. It receives its Arteries from the Carotides, and doth end forth a plenty of Ramifications of Veins, which it takes from the inward Jugular Vein; it's een doubled in the Vertical part of the Brain, decending inwards.

Of the Pia Mater. This being artificially removed, we next meet with a Pia Mater; and this is a very thin Membrane, by Galen called < in non-Latin alphabet > , the which he had from Hippocrates in lib. Epilep. where he aith, That < in non-Latin alphabet > doth divide the Brain in the middle; it arieth from the firt
catterings of the Sperm, and doth immediately adhere to the Brain, containing the Veins and Arteries of the Brain in it; it's ubtance is thin and oft, framed thin, that it may with eae ininuate it elf into the Brain and its Cavities, and that it may expand its Veels through its Body; it is oft and of exquiite ene, becaue it communicates a tactive virtue to the Brain and its Nerves. Nature placed this, as Galen writes, 8 lib. de Uu part. between the Brain and Dura Mater, let the Brain might be offended by o hard a Neighbour; and as Plato writes, even as a Medium between Fire and Earth; thee being of a contrary Quality, the Almighty hath interpoed Water and Air. Even thus the Brain and the Cranium being of a different nature, mould and ubtance, Nature hath put thee two Membranes between; and that we may admire the agacious foreight of Nature in her operations, we may ee how admirably he hath wrapt up the Brain in this Pia Mater, and how he hath incompaed this with a thicker Membrane.

And having thus given you the brief Dicoure of the Anatomy of thee two parts, we are now to enquire into what prejudices thee may be brought, for they may uffer both Pain, Inflammation, Apotemation, Blacknes, and the like.

Where therefore the Membranes of the Brain are hurt, there generally attend thereon great Pain, after which follows a Vomiting, ometimes Delirium, Convulion, Rednes of the Eyes and Face, and as Galen writes, the Stomach doth hare with the Head in its griefs, and the Head with the Stomach, by a conent of the decendent Nerves being placed at its mouth; and hence doth follow a los of Appetite, and a weaknes both of the digetive and expulive Faculty; a rednes of the Eyes mut follow, for their Coats have their Originations from the Membranes of the Brain; a Fever alo ucceeds, by reaon of the exagitation of the animal Spirits lodged
in the Brain, and thee accidents are greater or maller, according to the greatnes or parvity of the hurt. And becaue the Pia Mater is eldom hurt alone, but the Brain doth hare and communicate with it in its harms, hence doth oft-times follow an Apoplexy, los of Voice and Reaon; for the Pia Mater being hurt, the Brain it elf doth oon decay, it being chiefly made of Veins and Arteries, through which are carried the vital Spirits prepared in the Rete Mirabile, or according to thoe which are made animal; and thee do not only cover the Brain, and nourih it, but alo pas into its Venters, and by or through its Orifices are its vital Spirits conducted into the body of the Brain; and hence happens los both of Speech and Reaon.

If therefore you perceive that there is an immoderate Flux of Blood upon the Membrane's being wounded, you are peedily to prohibit it, that you may come to the Membrane it elf. And becaue Pain is here a very troubleom Companion, allay and abate this next, both for prevention of Inflammation and Convulion: And for this may you ue Oyl of Roes, Oyl of St. John's Wort, Oyl of Myrtils; thee or any thereof to be applied warm to the Membrane. Foretus doth order, That in Wounds of the Dura Mater, for the firt 4 or 6 days the whole Head is to be anointed with Oyl of Roes, and after that time to apply Unguentum Matriilvae, thus made: nguent. Terebinth. venet. Rein. pin. Cer. nov. an. iiij. Ol. Roar. lbs. pulv. Matich. Thur. an. j. gum. Elemni ij. pulv. Matriilv. Betonic. an. iij. Matriilv. & Betonic. imponentur in infuione in Vin. opt. lbx. per diem: potea adde caetera exceptis gum. Elemn. Matich. Thur. & coquantur fortiter ad Vini medii conumptionem, ut mixtura it coloris viridis, & tunc coletur, & demittatur coagulari, epera coagulum Ã Vino, & totum coagulum accipe. & iterum in cacabo impone, & coquantur ad Vini conumpt. hoc peracto iterum cola, cui colaturae adde Gummi emper agitando dum
optimÃ¨ incorporentur. This is to be applied for 9 or 10 days; after which time leen the quantity of the Oyl, and increae the quantity of Mel Roarum; o as about the 14th day this is altogether to be ued, and then with atringent Lotions and Powders compleat the Cure.

Galen's Retringent Powder. In a large Flux of Blood Galen's Retringent Powder may here afely be ued: Alo. j. Thur. ij. pulverientur ubtiliimÃ¨ ovi
que albumine ubactÃ¢ pulv. Leporin. excipiantur & imponentur. After which may be applied this Dreing: Colophon. iij. Myrrh. Alo. Matich. Sangu. Dracon. an. j. Croc. j. Sarcocoll. s. mice, fiat pulvis; mix this with Syrup of Roes, and apply it to the divided Membrane, over which apply Empl. Diapalma. The Matter being well digeted, this is to be expurged and deterged either with Mel Roarum, or Syrup. Ã¨ Rois iccis. Or in this cae may you ue this of Ambroe Parrey: Mel Roar. ij. farin. Hord. pulv. Alo. Matich. Ireos, an. s. Aqu. vit. parum, fiat mixtura. In this cae alo may this be afely ued: As to take Oyl of Turpentine with Aqua-vitae, and Powder of Aloes, and a little Saffron; this being accounted an excellent Medicine for drawing forth any Matter.

Inflammation of the Dura Mater.
The Dura Mater being inflamed, you may ue this: Sem. Lin. Pyll. Roar. Rubr. an. j. Solan. Plantagin. an. M. j. coquantur in aquÃ¢ fontin. & fiat fotus.

For Grumous Blood. Where any grumous or clotted Blood appears, this is accounted very good: Spirit. Vini ij. pulv. gran. Tinctor. ijs. Croc. j. Mel Roar. is. Sarcocoll. iij. coquantur omnia leviter, & colatura infundatur uper Membranam donec nigrities obliterata fuerit. And for cleaning the Membranes if they putrifie, ue Aqua vitae, with Mel Roarum. Or if this be not trong enough, add hereto Syrup. Abinth. with a little fine Powder of Myrrh and Aloes. Galen doth precribe as an excellent Medicine the Juice of Calamint, for the uniting of a divided Membrane, prinkling hereupon a little Farin.
Milij, this moderating the heat of the Juice. And becaue Wounds of the Pia Mater do generally prove mortal, the Brain hereby being brought into trouble, being expoed to the Air, this eaily corrupting it by external cold, extinguihing the heat of the Brain: And yet becaue thee Wounds are ometimes cured, you are alo here ordered, if any large Flux follow hereupon, to top it with the aforeaid Powder, and then to dry up the Wound by Sarcoticks and Epolonticks.
I hall end thee two with ome Hitorical Obervations.

The Firt hall be of Matter collected or gathered between the Dura and Pia Mater: And this was of one, who having part of his Cranium cut, o as that the Cutis and Fleh did cloely adhere to the Bone, his Head being haved, and convenient Remedies being precribed, part of the Bone being laid bare, was prinkled with Cephalick Powders, the Wound followed with Digetives, and a convenient Diet ordered. On the third day an intolerable Pain eized him, with Vomiting, Convulion, and a rednes of his Eyes and Face: Hence was upected Matter to be contained between the Cranium and Dura Mater, or between that and the Pia Mater. Wherefore the Cutis and the Pericrane being eparated from the Cranium, with the capital Saw ome part of the Bone was taken out, o much as neceity required; the Cranium was dilated (not with the Trepan, becaue the Wound and Fracture happened near the Sutures) and nothing of hopes of any recovery appeared; but the Dura Mater eemed to be elated into a Tumour, the which with a dextrous hand, and a crooked Inciion-Knife, was dilated, not hurting the Pia Mater. Which done, much Matter iued out, which was inwardly collected, and to the Part affected was applied this following Medicine: Syr. Roar. iccar. s. de ucc. Bettonic. vj. Ol. Roar. complet. j. pulv. Sang. Dracon. Matich. an. j. mice;
the which was continued, until the Matter was wholly dicharged, both out of the capacity of the Cranium, and alo out of the lips of the Wound: Then by applying Incarnatives and Epolonticks, he was perfectly recovered.

1 Hitory. Dodonaeus writes of one, who having received a Wound in the upper part of his Head, in the left ide thereof, by a retue Intrument of mall weight, and no ways upected to be dangerous, the Cranium being uppoed to be whole, and no ways violated, and o negligently cured; the Ditemper increaing on him, within a few days after was eized with a tupidity and his Pule grew very mall and quick, he not being very capable to give a good anwer to a quetion, and in a mall while the right ide of his Head became reolute, the left receiving the Wound. Hence followed a pernicious opor and tupidity; the Cranium being ublated, the Dura Mater was found livid in the left ide, and the Brain in that Part phacelated, the right ide of the Brain being carce hurt or injured, the whole Head having in it neither Fiure nor Cleft.

2 Hitory. Amatus Luitanus Cent. 2. Cur. 83. hath a remarkable Hitory; which is of two young tout Men, who fighting a Duel out of the City of Rome, the one tabbed the other through his Forehead, of which Wound he fell down to the ground, and there was left as a dead Man; being found thus by Spectators, that he might ecape if poible with thee Wounds, from the jaws of death, although mall hopes were given hereof by the conent of Chirurgeons, who were engaged upon conultation about him, preaging that there were but a few hours between him and the Grave, the Wound being both a horrible and penetrating Wound, and generally believed that it had penetrated the ubtance of the Brain. But contrary to their verdict and preage, without any ill Symptom happening, within 50 days the Patient was
cured; and although the Wound had penetrated between the Ventricles of the Brain, yet they might remain unhurt, and the ubtance of the Brain not much injured hereby, although it had paed either Membrane, as it did this Patient's.

Note. Hence therefore may all young Chirurgeons note, who have the humane Body to practie on, that they be well skilled in Anatomy and knowledge of the Parts, let for want hereof, they be like a blind Man hooting at a mark; and if they gues aright, it is as uncertain to the one as the other none indeed which practie o blindly, deerving the Name of a Chirurgeon, nor may the Patient expect to receive any comfort or help by them or their pretences.

div.head: CHAP. XXXV.
Of Wounds of the Brain.
div.p:
WE come now to the body of the Brain it elf the which alo we hall firt conider by an Anatomical examination, before we treat of its hurts. And here may we with Aritole premie, in Lib. 2. de partib. Animal. cap. 7. That all uch Creatures as have Blood in them, have alo a Brain allowed them. It is called < in non-Latin alphabet > , becaue it is contained < in non-Latin alphabet > , in the Head. It is generally allowed the principal part of the Body, proved both by its ituation, figure, and defences; and alo in repect of its ues. As to the three firt of thee, I have already dicoured; and as to its ue it's mot excellent: For as Varolius aith, The Soul of Man being not tyed to any bodily Intrument, cannot apprehend thoe outward things which
are without it elf, unles it be by the mediation of a Corporeal Organ, into which the Species of forms of material ubtances may be tranmitted, by which afterwards they may be exhibited, and in which place they may both be apprehended and contemplated. Hence therefore who will deny that the Brain is the mot noble of all the Members, eeing it is the Seat of all the Animal Faculties, Imagination, Sene, Dicoure, Reaon, and Memory? And hence Aphrodiaeus calls it < in non-Latin alphabet > , the Organe of Widome. Homer calls it < in non-Latin alphabet > , the Heaven; hence coming all Sene and Motion which is betowed on the ubjacent parts. It is ituated in the Head as in its Catle; and in the Upper part as being the Palace of the Soul. As to its Magnitude and Connexion, it is generally found in Man of a great quantity, becaue it being the Intrument of his Reaon, it is neceary it hould require and contain in it a plenty of pirits: It's knit to the Cranium by Veins, Arteries and Nerves, with the ret of its parts: As to its Subtance, it is made of Sperme and the maternal Blood; and out of thee two is generated this glandulous matter. It is generally white from its permatick matter furnihed with many pirits: It is oft, being the Original of the oft Nerves; in its Cerebellum it's not o oft, this being the Origination of Nerves which are more hard: It is of a cold and moit temper; and Hippocrates in his Book de Carnibus, calleth it < in non-Latin alphabet > , or the chief Seat of cold and glutinous moyture, framed thus to hold and contain the ubtile animal pirits; and cold, for tempering their heat. I hall pretermit the diviions of the Brain, and its Coats, and come to its inward parts, where we may meet with it furnihed with a callous body, two triated bodies, a Thalamus Opticus Nervorum, Natiformal Prominencies, Medullary Procees, Glandula Pinealis, Orbicular Protuberances, called Nates, and Tetes, an Infundibulum, and a Cerebellam with
its ubtance and ubtracted Cavities. All which may be een at large in Dr. Tho. Willis, in his Book De Anima Brutorum: To which I recommend you.

We come now to thoe hurts which the Brain may receive: And they may be aid to come under thee heads, as Wounds, Apotemations, Putrifaction, Syderation or Sphacelation, Concuion, and Tumour; and of each of thee in their Order; premiing firt the true Signs and Symptomes which may direct us to the Diagnois and Prognois of the Brains being thus diaffected: And being guided herein by Hippocrates's Rule, my bet and thy afet authority, as he hath it in Aphor. 50. lib. 6. Signs of a Brain woundedif any have their Brains wounded, they mut have herewith accompanied both Fever, and Vomiting of Choler; And in Lib. 8. Cap. 4. with thee a los of Speech: And uch as have uffered Concuion, became Dumb, as he writes, Sect. 7. Aphor. 58. Then alo are they generally eneles, and deliriated, and have a los of their Sight, as he hath it, Lib. de Vuln. capit. thus expreing it, If the Brain be wounded, the reaon growes weak, and other ill ymptomes encreae; and ometimes part of the Brain comes forth with danger of los of life. And beides thee, if the Brain be wounded, the Matter which cometh forth will be thick, round, and of a marrowy ubtance. And as Hippocrates hath it, Aphor. 18. lib. 6. Wounds of the Brain if they have not reached the Ventricles, they are curable, although the ubtance of the brain it elf be wounded; but thee being wounded, the cae will be dangerous. Beides thee, upon the brain being wounded, you will find your Patient have a foaming at his mouth, a cloudines overcating his ight, a Delirium accompanying thee, with a Convulion, Fever, Vomiting of Choler, los of Reaon, Dumbnes, a Palie, and latly ee him correpted with an Apoplexie.

Preages. As to the Preages of Wounds of the Brain, the leat is not een to want danger, conidering either the noblenes
of the part, and its neceity of motion, with its moyt nature, and the conent of the Nerves which it brings into miery and calamity with it. All thee being conidered with the not eaie paage or entrance of Medicines to Wounds here received, may well grant thee Wounds not eaily to be Cured, nor yet to go without danger. Yet Hitory makes good, that large Wounds ometimes being here inflicted, have been cured, as you hall ee more at large at the end of this Chapter; and that chiefly in thee three caes; As when they happen in a ound & trong body, meeting with an artificial dreing of this Wound; and latly to the true Providence of the Almighty, who can as well lengthen the Lives of ome, as horten the ame of others. And becaue my firt Dicoure is of Wounds of the Brain, by Joan. Andreas a Cruc. as he hath it, Lib. 1. Cap. 14. he will have the Wound wahed with a Decoction of Roes, Myrtils, and Bettony and if pain appear, to apply either warm milk, or ele the luke-warm blood of a Pidgeon, or Aqua Pimpinella, and then untill the 14th day be pat to dres it with Oyl of Turpentine and the pirit of Wine. The Oyl of Turpentine he thus doth order to be made, Oyl of Turpentine. , Terebinth. clar. lb iij. arenae fluvior. depurat. lot. et icc. lb i s. Omnia in curva boccia cum uo recipiente ponantur, & boccia in vae terreo, inter quod & Bocciam cinis in ea adit copia, quod nullo modo tangi point, & lento igne fiat elambicatio, & quod primo ditillat aqueum et, & nullius momenti, ecundo coloris aurei ac denioris ubtantiae & optimum et pro uu. Alo thus he orders it to be made, . Terebinth. clar. lb ij. Later. recent. lb s. Matich. Styrac. an. j. Lateres igniti Oleo extinguantur, & fracti reliquis Miceantur, & per Alembicum excipiuntur tres liquores, quorum ecundus & tertius unt Optimi. Or he doth advie intead of uing of Turpentine and Spirit of Wine, this; . Terebinth. aqu. conolid. lot. ij. aqu. vit. Syr. Roar. an. j. pulv. Oliban, Matich, Myrrh an. ij. Mum.
gran. Hyperic. Sangu. Dracon. an. j. mice & fiat medicamentum, and apply it; over it to be applied Empl. de Betonica, anointing the whole Head over either with Oyl of Roes, or Oyl of Roes and Oyl of Myrtils mixed together; and this ue for 7 days; and if no Matter or Digetion then appear, then with warm Water, Rhodomel, Myrrh and Aloes we are to dres the Parts, ever oberving thee Rules in Wounds of the Brain:

As touching Topical Medicines, that we have more regard to the Membranes, than to the Brain it elf and hence are we directed to apply more drying Medicines, for the affected Parts do require the ame, they being both of a moit, oft, and dioluble ubtance and temper, and hence the more eaily corrupted; and in thee alo are we not to proceed violently but gently, aiting Nature in the rectification of thee noble Parts.

p.hi: In thee caes he alo doth much commend this following
p.U: Vin. Montan. xx. ucc. Betonic. iiij. ucc. Calamenth. ij. Myrrh. Oliban. Alo. Matich. Sang. Drac. Centaur. minor. em. Hyperic. an. j. contundend. contuis macerentur omnia in vae probe occluo, tum lento & claro igne exhalet tertia pars ac coletur decoctum, cui adde Spirit. Vini ij. Ol. Terebinth. iiij. reponatur Decoctum in vae vitreo optime clauo; and above this Liquor to apply Avicen's Cephalick Powder, and to cover it with Empl. de Betonica, or the like.

div.p: Falloppius in thee caes, as you may ee Com. Hipp. de Vulner. Capit. c. 45. doth order Oyl of Roes, and Oyl of Turpentine, to be ued together in Wounds of the Brain; for as the one eaeth Pain, o doth the other dry up the Humidities; and this to be applied till the 7th day be pat.
And to prevent all Putrifaction, and to dry up all Humidities, Read doth much praie this: Vernic. alb. Balam. nigr. Ol. Hyperic. optim. an. s. mice.
And to conclude this, Take ome of thee Obervations, where we may ee a great part of the Brain to come forth, occaioned by a Wound, and yet the Patients recovered.

And here may we meet with plentiful hitorical Obervations; and the firt Fabritius Hildanus hath, who 1 Hitory. being called to one John Hortman's Siter, who having received a contued Wound in the right Bregma, with a Fracture and Impreion of the Cranium, he preently hereupon vomited Choler, and indigeted meat; the left ide was reolute, having Convulions in her right; her Head being haved, everal pieces of Bones came out, and others, much reembling a mall Vetch, were drawn out of the ubtance of the Brain. The day following Slotanus his Mater coming with him to view the Wound, upon dilating the Wound, were drawn forth many and mall plints of Bones, and a part of the Brain, the bignes of a Hael Nut; and thus was a mall part of the Brain extracted at everal times, yet the Patient recovered.

2 Hitory. Another of his is of a Countreyman, who having received a great Fracture on his Head, by the occaion of a mall apparent Wound, being lenderly dreed he fell into a Fever, and grew delirious, the Cutis being incied in form of a Y; there was preently extracted three plints of Bones; and upon further earch he found in the Wound a part of the Brain, the bignes of a Nut. His former Chirurgeon eeing this, depaired of his recovery; yet being aured, that great Wounds of the Brain have been cured by a diligent hand by a care and true method, his Fever abated, and his Delirium vanihed, and his relaxed ide was cured.

3 Hitory.
Glandorp. Ob. 5. writes of a Man, who had a great part of his Brain ablated, yet he recovered: And thus he hath it; A Countreyman being much wounded in the anterior part of his Head, out of which his Father in
the firt days had drawn forth many great pieces of Bones, and uch a part of the Brain, as is carce to be contained in an Egg, in its middle.
