Hereto having applied convenient Remedies, he was urprized with Convulions, the which the 7th day had almot overcome him, and was correpted with a Paley in his oppoite ide; yet he was cured of his Wound, and two years after died of the Pet, but carce could endure the noie of Drums, Trumpets, or Guns.

4 Hitory.
Nicolus. Ser. 7. Tract. 4. Sum. 2. Cap. 91. writes of a Man wounded in his Head with a Sword, which Wound paed even into the ubtance of the Brain, upon the Vertex, in the fore part of the Front, even to the middle of the Head. The day following he fell into a Paley, and ent forth the uperfluity of the firt and econd Digetion inenibly, and eat nothing for 6 days, and drank only cold Water with Syrup of Roes; and after the 6th day he deired Victuals, and did eat, and by a regular order and method he recovered.

And Carpus writes in Tract. aureo. that he was an Eye-witnes of ix Men, from whom a great quantity of the Brain came forth, and that were cured; of which, two were much taken with a Paley on one ide, yet lived two years, and the other he both aw and cured.

Braavolus, Com. ad Aph. 18. Lib. 6. Hipp. writes, that he hath een mot trange Wounds of the Brain cured: In one epecially he aw taken out as much of the Brain, as would fill a Pullets Egg, and yet the Patient recovered, but could carce peak well, and grew afterwards tupid.
Another he writes of, who had almot half of his Head ablated, with a part of the Brain, and yet recovered; but at length grew o tupid, that he could not peak, nor undertand.

5 Hitory. And to conclude this: Horat. Augenius Lib. 9. Epit. 2. writes, that he aw the whole ubtance of the Brain
wounded, and its Ventricles diected, and ome part of the Brain came forth out of the Wound, and yet the Patient recovered. And thee may be ufficient Authorities to confirm, that large Wounds of the Brain have been cured, being undertaken by a judicious hand.

div.head: CHAP. XXXVI.
Of an Abces of the Brain.
div.p: THis is the Second Michief which may happen to the Brain; yet many there are who deny any Abcees can or may be made in the body of the Brain; and thus endeavouring to prop up their Opinions, do trive to bring many others into their Opinion and Errour.

But thee both Authority and Experience do eaily confute and contradict: For here firt Hippocrates writes, If either Matter, Water or Blood, do flow through the Notrils, Mouth or Ears, of any which is troubled with Pain in his Head, thee will oon dicharge it. And Galen, Avicen, and Rhais do affirm, That Nature hath found out thee as its mot proper Channels, to empty and dicharge its Excrements, and hereby to exonerate the Matter which is bred in the Brain.

Hitory. And although this Event is by many Authors propoed deperate, yet Francicus Arcaeus Lib. 1. Cap. 6. doth relate ome Stories, wherein he hath cured ome People hereof, and doth bring in an Example of one who received a hurt at the City of Valuerda, ten miles from the Town of Llerena; (uch a Hitory he writes is not extant) who by the Divine Aitance, who gives the chief bleing to the means, was perfectly recovered: And thus it was; While ome Workmen were at
<1 page duplicate>
<1 page duplicate>
their Labours, about building a Tower in that City, a Stone falling from the ret, which was a Cubit inlength and breadth, and 12 inches in thicknes, and in weight 24 pounds: This Stone falling from the others, as it was hoiting up, fell down, and bruied, depreed, and hivered his Skull. Hereupon the Patient fell to the ground, and there lay near half an hour, and was given over for a dead man, being enles, and was thence carried to his Houe; and hence followed commotion of his Brain, and for three whole days he not only lot his Speech, but Motion too; a great part of his bones of his Head were depreed, and laid upon the Brain, and blood flew both out of his Eyes and Ears; his Head and Neck was tumified, and looked of a black colour. After the 8th day, the Head opened pontaneouly, both from the Sinciput and Occiput, and alo in either ide; and then three Apotemes brake forth, the Bones being retored to the proper places. The 3d day following his Speech came to him, although imperfectly, and his Eyes opened; and the 20th day following he began to ee, and recover his enes, and within the pace of four months he was perfectly cured, and being a young man was afterwards married.

And becaue Putrifaction and Sphacelus of the Brain are deadly Symptoms, and not to be found out by the opening of the Skull after the Party be dead, I hall not enlarge on thee, ave only I will conclude this Chapter with that of Coiter. Lib. Obervat. Anatom. & Chirurg. who writes of having diected many Heads which have been wounded, in which he hath found more than half of the Brain putrified, and the Ventricle on the ame ide to be accompanied with a fetid, green, and thick Matter, and to have een in the Cerebellary Subtance very putrid Apotemes.

div.head: CHAP. XXXVII.
Of Concusion of the Brain.
div.p:
NExt followes a Concuion or Commotion of the Brain, occaioned by ome outward violent caue invading the Brain, happening either by a Fall from a high place upon a hard part, being either toney or rockey; or may be occaioned by a Shot, Lance, Bullet, Key, or the like: Hence alo by this violent blow, or other the like Accident, the Veins and Arteries by this Concuion may be lacerated, and not onely thoe which do pas the Sutures, but alo thoe which are prinkled between the two Tables to the Diplois; hence alo the efflux of blood running between the Cranium and the Membranes, or between the Membranes and the Brain, being there concreted, do occaion many dreadful Pains, and caue a blindnes and a cloudines over the ight, and Vomiting, occaioned by the upper Orifice of the Ventricle, being hereby affected by the Nerves of the 6th Conjugation, the which do pas from the Brain into it, and thence effued into the whole Capacity of the Stomach; and hence alo are the other parts drawn into conent herewith: Occaioning vomiting of Choler, the Bilis in this cae being more active, and encreaing in plenty; and this generally attends Concuion of the Brain. Then meet we with Inflammation correpting the Brain it elf, the which the corrupted and putrid blood doth excite, drawn forth from the Lacerated Veels by the violence of the accident, and effued through the whole ubtance of the Brain; and this kind of Inflammation doth procure a Fever by communicating it elf to the Heart and to the whole body; and if it proves vehement, it proves both dangerous and
mortal; if the commotion be violent, it caues a dumbnes and los of peech in the Party. And as Hippocrates writes, Lib. 7. Aph. 78. They who have endured a long Concuion of the Brain, mut of neceity become dumb. And if to thee Evils a Sphacelus and corruption hould ucceed, with a difficulty of breathing occaioned by an Impediment of the Animal Faculty, Death doth uddainly follow.

Having given you the chief Signs and Notations of a Concuion, as touching its Cure, we are ordered (becaue in a Concuion of the Brain the Veels are een to be Lacerated under the Cranium) to breathe the Cephalick Vein, and to take away a plentiful quantity of blood, and to order a good and thin Dyet; and as touching the affected part, the Head being haved, there may be applyed according to Ambroe Parrey's direction, a Cataplame made of Bean-Meal and Barley-Meal, with Oyl of Roes and Oxymel. Not to apply any cooling retringent Medicines here, thee hindring the breathing forth of the fuliginous vapours by the Sutures, the body is to be kept open by harp Clyters to prevent the acent of fumes and vapours up the Brain. And if the Patient be of a Plethorick Contitution, to repeat Phlebotomy, by breathing either the frontal vein, or that under the Tongue. Cupping-Glaes are here alo very neceary Intruments, being applied to the Scapulaes. Repulives are here to be ued to the 4th day, then to ue Dicuives, beginning with uch as are milde, and Decoction.of a gentle nature, as is this Decoction, Rad. Alth. vj. Ireos Cyper. Calam. aromatic. an. ij. fol. alv. Beton. Marjoran. Melilot. Roar. Rubr. Staechad. an. M. s. Sal. commun. iij coquantur omnia imul. S. A. in vino Rubro & aqu. fabror. fiat Decoctum. With this the head is to be fomented twice in a day, by dipping a Sponge herein, and applying it to the affected part. But this is to be premied, That we be ure not to apply any thing too
hot here, let hereby we purchae Pain and Inflammation.

Vigoes Plaiter. Then to apply Vigo's Cerote thus made; . Furfur. bene triturat. iij. farin. Lent. ij. Roar. Myrtillor. fol. et gran. ejud. an. j. Calam. Aromatic. j. Chamomel. Melilot. M. s. Nuc. Cupres. No. 6. Ol. Roar. Chamomel. an. ij. Cer. alb. ij. s. Thur. Matich. an. iij. Myrrh. ij. pulverientur, et liquefactis Oleis cum Cer. mice Omnia imul in formam Empl.

A Cataplame of the Author's. I cannot let that mot Admirable Medicine pas, for its worth, which hath for many years been experienced by my Honoured Unckle Cropp, and his Ancetors; a mot true and happy Compoition in thee direful caes; of which I have with admirable Succes had the advantage to peak the truth of it. And indeed I dare boldly aert, there cannot be a better extant in all Fractures of the Head, and Concuions of the Brain, being thus both rightly made and applyed; The Compoition of which is this; . Farin. Fabar. Furfur. an. iiij. fol. Roar. Rubr. fol. & Bacc. Myrtillor. an. s. Squinanth. Staechad. an. pug. j. fl. Chamomel. Melilot. an. M. s. Sem. Coriand. Ani. an. iij. fl. Betonic. Matricar. Aneth. an. pug. j. Summitat. Abinth. M. j. pulverientur omnia et miceantur cum vino malvatico lb j. ad Catapl. formam; in fine ebullitionis adde Ol. Chamomel. Aneth. Myrtin. an. j. Cer. flav. j. Croc. j. pulv. Calam. Aromatic. s. mice; fiat Cataplama. Before the application of which, the Wound is to be dreed, and the Head to be anointed all abo t the affected parts with Oyl of Roes, Oyl of Dill, and Oyl of Myrtles; then to be covered over the woundedpart with Empl. de Betonica; and then apply over all this Cataplame.

Hitories. I hall adde here ome Hitories of Note; and here firt we may ee Dodonaeus writing, Cap. 1. Oberv. Medicinal. of one who having received a blow on his let part of his head with a thick Club or Staff, the Cutis
being whole, and no ign of hurt appearing, the Petroe bone underneath being fiured, and having a long cleft, hence followed a tupidity, but not o deeply but upon being called he could tirre himelf, but uddainly fell into a lumber again with his Eyes being hut; and untill the 14th day was pat, his tupidnes encreaed o as that he could not tirre, after which Death eized him, his head being opened, the Dura Mater was een altogether uffued with blood under the Os Petroum, and a purulent Matter about the Brain it elf.

Another. Fabritius Hildanus is very plentiful in Hitories of the Brain being Concued, amongt which he hath thee, Oberv. 13. Lib. 1. The firt is of a Gentleman, who being mitten in the right part of his head fell upon the ground, vomited, lot his Speech, and bled both at his Ears and Notrils, who being carefully handled, was perfectly recovered, and his peech in few dayes returned to him.

Another. The Second is of a Huntman, who falling from a Tree upon the ground, preently vomited, and cat forth much blood both through his Ears, Mouth, Notrils and Palate; hereupon he grew dumb, and was Apoplectick without ene or motion even to the 11th day; his head being haved, and anointed with Oyl of Roes and Oyl of Myrtils, and a Vein opened in his Arm, with harp Clyters being adminitred, and the like proper Remedies, by God's aitance and his diligence, to admiration he recovered.

Another. And to Conclude, Alexander Benedictus, Lib. 1. Cap. 5. De Medend. Morb. writes, That if we may believe Experiments, the Leaves of Ground Ivy put between the Membranes of the Brain, do eae pain, if they be oft, mixed with a little Vinegar and a Decoction of Roes. Hence ome of our late Writers do order a Cerote Empl.made of Gum. Hedetae, whereof this is the Receipt; . Gum. Heder. iij. Rein. purgat. s. Cer. iij. Ol. Roar.
ij s. Ammoniac. ij. Terebinth. Venet. iij. Succ. Corymbar. Heder. iiij. Farin. Fabar. Q. S. fiat Empl. And this hath been approved to be excellent in Wounds and Fractures of the Head, epecially in an Old Man of Eighty years of age, who being mitten by the Beam of a houe falling upon his head, he hereupon grew peechles, he being forthwith let blood, and this Plaiter applyed to his Bregma, he lived without Wine and Fleh, and ubited with Ptyan and broken bread, without any Liquor or Water; for he loved none: And thus for 15 dayes was his life conducted; with los of Speech: The 16th day he began to peak, and within few dayes after was perfectly cured of his violent Concuion, beyond all hopes.

div.head: CHAP. XXXVIII.
Of a Fungus of the Brain.
div.p:
THis Fungus is a Tumour of the Brain much reembling a Muhroom; of which ort ome are een to be hard and bloodles, accompanied but with mall Sene: Others more oft, and endued with an exquiite Sene, being of an ill Smell, broad above, and narrow beneath, bred of glutinous and thick humours, being half rotted; o made either by the Aire, or coldnes of the Skull, it being opened, and the Brain wounded. Thee alo are reported to be of a very peedy growth, much like Muhrooms, having their encreae from a plenty of thick humours iuing from the affected parts. In
thee caes we are advied, if it growes above the Cranium, to keep it down by a trong Ligature, and to conume the remaining part, taking care that we in thee caes do not ue too trong Cathartick Medicaments.

And becaue Gulielmus Fabritius, a man of excellency in his Art, and a Mater to be followed, hath given a lively Example of the curing of thee Fungoities, I hall commend you to his Method, & for atisfaction hall preent the whole Hitory, as he hath it in Oberv. 15. Cent. 1. of one of 14 years of age, who received a Wound in his Right Bregma, with a large Fracture of his Cranium by the Fall of a Stone from a high place, which weighed Twelve pounds ten ounces; he being thitherto called, he finds the Boy peechles, blind and deaf, with a vehement Vomiting, and a continual throwing forth of blood both by his Mouth, Ears and Notrils, his head being haved, and the Wound dilated, the Cranium was een to penetrate deeply into the ubtance of the Brain, and the Dura Mater much rent: The Splints that Night being taken out, the Cure was treated with art; and although the Symptomes were o direful, that there was but mall hopes of his recovery, yet within 20 dayes thee vanihed, and the part of the Dura Mater rent by the depreed Skull did fall out by Nature and the benefit of Medicines, which gave encouragement of danger being pat. But the 21th day a new Evil attended him, which was a large Fungus ariing from the Wound; the which o encreaed in Twenty four hours, that it exceeded the bignes of a Hens egg; the which was cured by thee following Medicines: Ordering him this Clyter in the beginning every day, afterwards every econd or third day; . Rad. et fol. Alth. Malv. Parietar. Mercurial. fl. Cham. Melil. fol. et flor. Betonic. an. M. s.
Sem. Fenugraec. Ani. Lin. an. s. coquantur in aqu. ad conumpt. 3. partis in lb j. colaturae alvae Benedict. Laxat. & pec. Hier. Picr. an. iij. Vitell. Ov. j. Sal. pug. j. Ol. Camomel. ij. M. fiat Clyter.

Fomentation. Then was applyed this Fomentation twice a day to the Wound; Fol. et Fl. Betonic. Salv. Camomil. Melilot. Roar. Summitat. Marjoran. Rorimar. an. M. j. Sem. Ani. Faenugraec. an. j. incidantur et contundantur pro fotu.

After this let the Head be cleaned with warm cloathes, after which let the Fungus be all over it prinkled with this following Powder, and alo the Wound; Rad. Powder. Caryophyllat. Angelic. Calam. Aromatic. an. s. Rad. Aritoloch. Rot. Irid. florent. Lign. Guaiac. an.
ij. fl. Salv. Summitat. Marjoran. Rorimarin. an. pug. j. fiat pulvis. Over which was applyed this Emplaiter, . Empl. Empl. de Betonic. iiij. Gum. Elemn. Solut. in Ol. Roar. j. pul. Roar. Myrtillor. an.
j. Matich. Calam. Aromatic. an.
j. s. cum q. . Ol. Roar. fiat Empl. With thee the Fungus vanihed in 14 dayes, and within 10 Weeks the Patient was perfectly recovered.

Another. Cornarius Emblemat. 71. ad lib. 4. Diocord. writes of a Citizen who before he arrived at 40 years of age, had his Skull in the publick Market chopt edged wayes, and his Membrane hurt; and he carried 6 Fungoities in his head for a long while after, the bignes of o many great Nuts as we call Chesnuts, the which within ome while afterwards fell away of their own accord.

Johannes Schenkius writes, that he remembers a Boy who falling from a Ladder, upon his head, received thereon a large Wound in the left part thereof. An ignorant Quack being ent for, not examining the hurt of his head thoroughly, hatened the Wound to agglutination, whence happened, that between times for ome years afterwards the Boy felt a pain in his head, as
if he had been mitten with a Key, and within ome time afterwards out of the ame part did grow a Fungus equalling the bignes of a Chenut; hence followed a violent Fever, and an intolerable pain of his head; the skin of the head of its own accord being dirupted, the whole Tumour without any difficulty, and as it were cut off with a Knife, opened, appearing as it were of a horney ubtance, coagmentated in everal coats, and incruted much like the tone in the Bladder, generally believed to be occaioned by the Fall upon the head, and of the hurt of its ubtracted Membranes.

Thus have I ended the whole Dicoure of the Head, with its Membranes, and thoe diverities of evil Symptomes which do attend the Brain. And although Wounds of the Nerves might by ome look better in other places, and more aptly be placed according to the places where they are mot generally injured; yet becaue they have their Origination from hence as their Fountain, I hall dicoure of them here, and alo hew you how Nerves punctured, contued or incied, are to be Cured, intending to joyn Wounds of the Arteries with thoe of the Heart; and Wounds of the Veins with thoe of the Liver. Thee being as their chief Oceans from whence they fetch both their Vital and Natural Blood and Spirits.

div.head: CHAP. XXXIX.
Of Wounds of the Nerves, made by Puncture.
div.p: ANd becaue thee Nervous Bodies are Parts of great worth and ue in us, whoe hurts and michiefs, without a true method ordered and precribed, do yield mot horrid Symptoms, how well ought the Chirurgeon to examine and know their Nature, Temper and Fabrick, that hath to deal with them, being either punctured, incied, or contued?

And that I may bring in this Dicoure with the bet advantage to the young Chirurgeon, I hall firt hew by the Glas of Anatomy what a Nerve is; how it differeth from a Tendon and a Ligament; for what ue it was framed, and to what end it was contituted; how it is planted into the Mucle, and there doth exercie its moving Faculty: And then having given you its view, you may conequently judge how careful and active you ought to be, in the treating its harms and hurts.
But to hew what a Nerve is.

What a Nerve is. A Nerve in general is called < in non-Latin alphabet > , lectere, by ome called < in non-Latin alphabet > , tendere, being planted at the end of the Mucle, both for its extention and contraction.
Of thee Nervous Bodies are reckoned by Galen three kinds (viz.) Nerves, Tendons, and Ligaments. Of each of thee in their order.

An Organick Part. It's called an Organick Part, being an Organ conveying animal Spirits; it's made of a white Subtance, pun and wrought out of many mall permatick Fibres, contituted with mot ubtil Pores, for tranition of the
animal Spirits; it is made of a threefold Subtance; the firt being medullary and white, ariing from the marrow of the Brain; the econd and third gives it its double Membrane, inveting this Subtance: And conidering all Nerves do take their Originations of and from the Brain, and as Picolhominus, Bauhine, and other expert Anatomits do write that from the medullary Part hereof, doth pas hence through the Cavities of the Cranium and Vertebres, and o decending forwards. And as alo ome of thee Nerves are oft and others hard, as I have already hown, ome being mot neceary for conveying of the animal Spirits, o by their ordinary Influx a Nutrition doth follow, and by this Influx the Parts ordained for ene and motion may the better be moved, and more exquiitely be allowed to receive their ene. And becaue they are the proper Trunks and Channels, by which the animal Spirits are carried and conducted to the intruments of voluntary ene and motion, their Membranes being the intruments of thee enes, the which by how much they receive a greater quantity of Nerves, and o conequently animal Spirits, they mot exactly and exquiitely receive and obtain a more liberal plenty and freedom of motion and ene.

What a Tendon is. Capar Bauhinus will have a Tendon to be a imilar Part, continued from the beginning to the ending of a Mucle, being of the ame kind and nature with that of the Nerves, and bred out of eed, as are the other permatick Parts, which opinion is continued by many at this day.

Andraeas Laurentius, with Galen, and others, are of a contrary opinion, allowing this to be a diimilar Part, framed and intertexed out of the concoure of mot thin Fibres, Ligaments and Nerves interwoven together; it auming its greatet bulk from Ligaments, and a leer from the Nerves and their Fibres. And becaue provident Nature being careful to leave no empty pace
between thee Fibres, he hath planted a flehy Subtance between their Series, where we may meet with its empty paces filled and tuffed up therewith.

To conclude this, A Tendon is nothing ele than the fibrillous Subtances of Nerves expanded and exploded, made and framed much in form of your Indian Hammocks, which are interwoven of fine Thread or Silk, whoe middle Part although expanded and filled up by the intertexture of their woollen Parts, yet are contracted in either end, and brought into a maller and lenderer Subtance, by the advantage of o many fine Chords interwoven and brought to one point.

What a Ligament is. A Ligament is the 3d; and this by the Greeks is called < in non-Latin alphabet > , or Vinculum, both by Hippocrates and Aritotle; from its figure and colour it is called Nervus, it being a cold, dry, firm, and imilar Part, yet looe and flexible, collected out of many Parts; it gains its Subtance from the eed, as do the two former, bred between a Membrane and a Cartilage; harder than a Membrane, that it may not eaily break, and ofter than a Cartilage, for a more prompt motion of the Mucles; it is not nourihed by Marrow, as Columbus conjectured, but with blood paing through the capillary Arteries, this being either large, narrow, plain, long, or hort, in figure according to the variety of the Parts; it arieth from the Bone, and is inerted therein; its Ues are chiefly two, that hereby the Members may obtain a good and proper motion, and alo in their motions that they do not recede from their places, or that in a violent motion they may be kept in their proper places.

And ince we have preented a hort view of thee three, we may fairly by a brief Dicoure expres their annexions: For as every Mucle hath allowed it a Nerve, ome having more, as the Diaphragma, and the temporal Mucle three. Galen therefore doth nominate that Part wherein the Nerve is inerted, the Head of the
Mucle; the middle Venter is the flehy Part thereof, ditinguihed into many tendinous Interections, the Tayl thereof being tendinous, annexed to the moving Part thereof, the which do much vary, according to the trength or mall motion of the Parts, both in Form and Magnitude, being either narrow or broad, long or hort, thick or thin.
Now as touching the Hurts of thee Parts; and thee are generally accounted Four, as Puncture, Inciion, Contuion and Ditortion.

Puncture of a Nerve. We begin firt with a Puncture of the Nerve: And here may we ee thee little Bodies, being endued with an exquiite ene, they being hurt, mut necearily Preages.threaten danger; for light and lender Hurts here do produce Spames; and thee happen by Pain, the which doth lead the whole Body into intemperiety and paion. Fiures of the Nerves are hard to cure, by reaon of their cold nature, being in ubtance both cold and exanguial, their Humidities admitting no digetion. Such as are tranverly wounded, are more dangerous than thoe which are hurt in a direct line; for hereby both Sene and Motion are detroyed at once, and therefore are to be upected. Contuion happening here doth produce its effects alo, by reaon of its thick and vicous humour, which doth replenih them, and makes them fit for putrifaction, they being denied their native heat; and hence follows Inflammation and Putrifaction at the beginning.

Cure of Nerves in general. As to the Cure of Nerves in general here is chiefly to be tudied the removal of Pain and Inflammation: And for thee a good order of Diet, a ubtraction of the antecedent Matter, that it flow no further to the affected Part, and application of convenient Topicks for awaging of Pain, educing of Excrements, and vindicating of the Parts from Convulion; thee are good and proper Engines to work with.
But to come to each in their order; and to begin with a Puncture of the Nerves.

The wounded Nerves do require very drying Medicines, having an attractive quality in them, being of thin Parts. Now whereas this is an accident, which doth mot commonly happen to them, by the ignorance of the Chirurgeon ometimes, as well as by the aault of ome violent Thrut, Puncture, or the like; here are two copes to be precribed: The firt of which toucheth the Part affected, which is to be treated with trong drying Medicines, and uch as may eae Pain; and the econd to hinder Inflammation. The Nerve therefore is to be opened, and its thin and humid Subtances to be dried up, which do procure the inward injury; and for this Ue you are to apply hot Medicines, for the educeing thee Vapours, attracting of the Humidities about the affected Part. And here be ure before you undertake any application, that you remove and extract all extraneous Bodies, which may lodge in the wounded Part, if any remain therein, as Needles, Glas, Bone, Splints of Wood, or the like, hereby taking care that we add no affliction to the afflicted Part. Hence are we by Galen's Authority here directed for Women, Children, and the like perons who are tender and oft, to ue Turpentine by it elf, or to mix therewith Sulphur or Euphorbium. And to hinder Inflammation, is a great intention in Punctures of the Nerve; and this is to be conquered by Phlebotomy, once or more times to be made ue of, as occaion may require, hereby to dicharge a good quantity of the Blood, both for prevention of Fever and Inflammation.

Next may we torm this by Catharticks, which have power to banih it by iege, by firt preparing the Body with Mel Roarum, Syr. de Betonic. Oxymel, or the like; then to precribe a convenient Cathartick, made either of Caia, Manna, Rhubarb, Senna, Confectio
Hamech. Diacatholicon, Elect. Ã¨ ucc. Roar. Pil. Coch. Rudii, or the like. And here alo as to the affected Part, we are here to conider both the breadth and narrownes of the affected Part, and its Wound; for if the Wound be o narrow, as that the Matter cannot have vent for its exition, and the trength and force of the Medicine cannot reach the Puncture, here are we to dilate, and make the Wound wider, by cutting it o wide, as the Nerve may well appear; if the Wound be large enough, we are here to view the Symptoms which attend and offend; and here if Pain offers, this is to be abated: And for this purpoe Galen propoeth Oyl warmed, and with this to foment the Part; and hence is it alo that we always ue hot Oyls in Punctures of the Nerves, for this doth peedily make Pain ceae and vanih. But ome may eem here to quarrel with Hippocrates, who writes, That Oyl is humecting and mollifying, and o an enemy conequently to the Nerves, which do require drying Medicines, and therefore how to be approved of in thee caes? It's true it is oftning and humective; yet we find that a punctured Nerve being kept for 2 or 3 days in Oyl, hath not received any injury thereby, but hath hereby rather gained a large mitigation of Pain, and therefore in repect of the Symptoms is advantagiouly here to be ued, the Pain being abated. Next indeed in repect of the nervous Subtance being cold and dry, we are authorized to ue hot and dry Medicines; dry, that they may keep up and maintain the proper temper of the Nerves; and hot, that they may take off all cold from them; the true temper of thee Medicines are to be very drying, and moderately hot. In a punctured Nerve we may alo note, That the Nerve which is thus punctured, can endure the mot hot Oyl, which the Finger cannot. Whence I collect, That a Nerve hath not in it a mot exquiite ene, but only an exquiite ene; and therefore all uch Medicines which are here to be applied, hould
be freed of all aperity and harpnes; and the ubtance of the Nerve being hard, the temper of the Medicine hould be thin and penetrating.

Note. Another thing herein worthy note, which I mut not pretermit, is, That if any Matter remain at the bottom of the wounded Nerve, it is as bad as poyon, executing there its traiterous venomous qualities, procuring for its companion, Pain.

Wherefore we are further to note, That the proper Medicines which are here to be ued and applied, ought not only to be hot and drying, but to have in them an educeing and extracting quality. And thee Medicines are either imple or compound; amongt the Simples may be reckoned Roine of the Fir-Tree, Turpentine, Gum Elemni, Oyl of Turpentine, and Oyl of Fir; thee being both thin bodied, and having in them an educeing and extracting quality, to fetch every ichorous Matter from the bottom of the Wound. Stronger than thee may be reckoned Liquid Pitch, Ol. Petrol. Sagapen. Opoponax, Sulphur vivum, Euphorbium, and the like.
Note. Another thing remarkable in thee Wounds, is, That no Lint is here to be applied, for this doth choak up the Matter, and hinder its exition, and hence follows intolerable pain.

Falloppius doth much commend Euphorbium, as the bet and chiefet of Medicines for thee kind of Wounds, and calls it his Sacra Anchora, it never deceiving him that ueth it, but doth further anwer expectation; yet he makes a vat difference between Euphorbium, the bet being newet, and appearing like black Rein at its ends; the old is yellow and reddih.

Unguent. Now having hewn the Simples, it's time to come to Compounds, of which take thee; Sagapen. Opopanac. an. ij. Tereb. V. ij. Ol. vetut. s. mice; or if you deire a tronger, take this; Aae faetid. j. Ol. vetut. Another. Pic. naval. Cer. an. s. mice pro Linimento. To this alo
may be added Ol. Sambuc. Sulphur viv. an. j. mice ad mellis piitudinem.

Ol. Hyperic. Fallop. Falloppius in thee caes doth highly commend the magiterial Oyl of Hyperici thus made; Terebinth. clar. ij Ol. Terebinth. j s. Roar. Complet. iiij. Verm. terretr. lot. in vino j s. Rubr. Tinctor. iij. Sem. & fl. Hyperic. M. j. Rorimar. Milleol. Centaur. maj. an. M. s. Sulphur viv. s. tritis terendis inciis
que incidendis miceantur addito vino malvatico, ac parum coquantur, deinde adde em. & flor. Hyperic. & coquantur ad vini conumpt. tunc exprimantur, & in vas reponantur, & erva ad uum vae bene clauo. And when he ueth it in Punctures of the Nerves, he follows Galen's advice, Lib. 6. Meth. cap. 2. thus precribing it: Euphorb. j. Ol. ante cript. xij. Cer. iij. mice pro Unguento; this is to be applied until all pain doth ceae; this alo increaeth new Fleh, and doth produce a Cicatrice, and o doth perform all intentions. Or in the like caes may thee be ued: Tereb. clar. Ol. Hyperic. Rein. Pin. an. iij. Sulphur. ign. non expert. j. Croc. s. mice, & lento igne bulliant. Or this alo of Galen: Cer. non. j. Terebinth. pie. graec. an. s. Euphorb. ij. mice.

Hitory. To conclude this Chapter, be pleaed to take thee few Hitories. The firt hall be of Glandorp in his 41 Obervation, of One whoe Nerve was prickt intead of a Vein; whence followed direful Symptomes, the which was cured as followeth: A Woman in the Moneth of June deiring to have a Vein breathed, happening to go to an unskilful Chirurgeon, who carce knew the difference between a Nerve and a Vein, prickt the Nerve intead of her Vein; hence did arie great Pain, and a large Tumour in the affected part; the Barber-Chirurgeon applyes to the part Oyl of white Lillies, with which he anointed the part, and afterwards directed this Cataplame made of Mallow leaves, & Violets, with Bran; thee rather encreaed the pain, and the hand began to look
livid, his Father being ent for, eeing the parts began to run into a Gangrene, firt precribed this Cataplame; Catapl.. Pan. tritic. Siligin. lb s. Furfur. ubtilis. pulv. ij. Pub. Rad. Acir. j. pulv. Scord. s. fl. Melilot. Chamomel. Roar. Rubr. an. pug. 3. Farin. Orob. ij. cum Oxymelit. q. . fiat Catapl. The Writ and whole Arm was anointed even to the Nuch of the Neck with thee Unguents, . Ol. Roar. Lumbricor. Camomel. an. s. Vulpin. Olea. Scorpionium an. iij. mice. The Night following, both Delirium, Fever and Convulion eized her; and for this was precribed a Cordial, wherein was Aqu. Langij & fl. Tiliae, and over the whole hand and arm was applyed the aforeaid Cataplame; the Wound being dilated, was afterwards dret with this; . Terebinth. Unguent. Venet. lot. in vino albo j. Mel. Roat. Colat. ij. Myrrh. ij. pulv. Scord. j. Lumbricor. terretr. praeparat. j s. mice. The Gangrenated parts within a few dayes began to eparate, and by the application of thee Medicines, topt; the echar of which being removed, under this was the Nerve, or rather the Tendon een to look black; the which was amputated, and extracted: After this was applied an Incarnative Medicine, and at length the part was cicatried. The Elbow and the whole Hand was immoveable; for which, with great Succes, were applyed thee following Medicines, . Ol. Lumbricor. Roar. an. s. Vulpin. Lilior. albor. an. iij. Chamomel. Liniment. Unguent. Dialth. cum Gum. Auxung. Human. an. ij. mice pro Linimento. With this was embrocated his hand and his whole arm, it being firt fomented with this . Rad. Alth. recent. Conolid. Major. an. j s. Herb. Fomentation. Alth. Malvar. Violar. an. M. j. Salv. Marjoran. an. M. s. Haeder. Terretr. Abinth. Summitat. Hyperic. an. p. iij. Coquantur in aqua fontana, ad fomentum. The parts being thus fomented and embrocated, latly was applyed this Emplaiter pread upon Leather, . Auxung. Porcin.
j. Oxycroc. s. Empl. de Melilot. de Mucilagin. an. vj. Mice. With thee dreings he perfectly recovered and gained the motion of all her hand and arm, ave only the Thumb.

Another. Foretus, Obervat. 20. fol. 183. writes of a Woman, who pricking her little finger with a Needle, had the 4th day after a great Tumour thereon, and the whole hand appeared as if it had been correpted with a Phlegmone; but it tended not to uppuration, the natural heat not being diminihed; and hence followed omewhat of an oedematous Inflammation, for which this Medicine of Euphorbium was applyed, anointing the fingers therewith, . Cer. Rein. Pic. an. iiij. Euphorb. j. Terebinth Ol. Commun. an. s. mice. And for the Inflammation was applyed Unguent. de Cinerib. Solitum. by which the flux of humours was topped. In the interim was applyed an Emplaiter made of Reolvers and Strengtheners; after which was fomented the parts with a Decoction made of Wine, wherein were boyled Wormwood, Camomile and Salt; by this the Inflammation was wholly abated: then was the finger anointed with Unguent. Dialth. bathing the head with the broath made of Sheeps Guts; And thus at length was he recovered.

Horatius Augenius, lib. 9. Epit. 2. writes of a Taylor, who receiving a prick by his Needle between his nail and the fleh of his right Thumb, dyed thereof, and writes that Ludovicus was witnes thereof.

To conclude this, take that of Amatus, 1. Curat. 38. Punctura acus in Digito, thus writing of an Old Gentlewoman threecore years of age, who prickt her Thumb with a Needle near the nail thereof, the which grew very painful, o that 12 dayes he could carce ret; he being ent for to her, and examining the matter, found about the juncture near the nail a mall collection of
matter, the which being let out, and anointing the hand with Oyl of Roes, he was within two hours freed of her pain, and in few dayes after perfectly cured.

div.head: CHAP. XL.
Of Tranvere Inciion of the Nerves.
div.p:
THis by the Arabians is called Gauziratus; and here we may behold it either wholly cut, or cut in part; if it be wholly cut, it occaions a weaknes of the part onely; but if it be but cut in part or half way, it declares the ame by a great Fever, and fear of Convulion, and hence ought we to breathe a vein, and to trengthen the affected parts, by removing its ill temper if any have appeared. In this cae where the nerve is thus cut, the Wound mut necearily be large; and in this Wound this method is to be followed, if pain be preent, foment the affected part with hot Oyl; but if neither Spame nor pain appear, there needs no ue thereof. If any humours have flowed, thee are to be dicued; as . Ol. Roar. Myrtin. Matich. an. j s. Succ. Plantag. Centinod. an. j. Acet. alb. s. Verm. Terret. lot. in vino albo j. Coquantur ad vini conumpt. et aceti & Succorum, tunc adde. Bol. armen. Terr. igillat. Santal. Rubr. an. iij. iterum parum bulliant, & addito parum cerae fiat Linimentum: The Wound to be filled up with Turpentine or Spirit of Turpentine. If any ichorous Matter do upervene, we are to ue tronger Deiccatives, and uch as may force the humidities out; as . Terebinth. venet. ij. Ol. Hyperic. j. pulv. Subtilis. Sulphur. Unguent. vin. ij. mice. et aliquantulum bulliant. Or this, . Terebinth. V. .j. Ol. Aneth. j. Sulphur. preparat. ut
ante ij. mice. Or, . Ol. Terebinth. Matich. Lumbricor. an. ij. Euphorb. recent. pulv. s. Croc. s. mice. Or this, . Ol. abietin. Hyperic. Magitral. Fallop. Matich: Lumbricor. an. j. Rein. Pin. s. Sulphur. vin. Euphorb. an. ij. Croc. parum mice, lento igne parum coquantur. Cataplames alo in thee caes which have in them a drying, trengthening and prohibiting faculty, operating without much Stipticity, may be of great ue here; and for this ue doth Galen propoe many Simples, of which thee may be made, as Dittany, Feverfue, Camypitheos, both the Centauries, Stoechas, Comfrey, Ivey, Betony, Turpentine, Earthworms, Bean-meal, Lupines, Fenugreek, Oyl of Matich, Camomile, and the like. If Inflammation doth appear here in the beginning, we may ue this, Catapl.. Fol. Roar. Rub. Myrtin. an. M. j. Beton. Camomil. an. M. s. Coquantur vino nigro autero et pitentur, tunc adde Farin. Fabar. j. s. Hord. iij. Ol. Roar. Matich. an. j. Lixivij tenuior. q. . mice. And with this proced to the 7th day, and when a good digetion appears, and all evil Symptomes be removed, you may deterge the Wound Unguent.with this, . Litharg. Aur. Vino Lot. ij. Ol. Matich. Cer. Mell. an. j. mice: This being done, unite the parts Powder.with this Powder, . Pulv. Verm. Terretr. preparat. gran. Tinctor. Equiet. Oliban. Aritoloch. rot. an. ij. mice, fiat Alcotiol. per petiam tranmisus.

Hitory. Glandorp. Ob. 42. fol. 103. writes of a Young Man, who being of a Plethorick Contitution, received a Wound, with which was hurt alo a Nerve, but its Fibres were not wholly cut or divided, hence iued great Pain, Fever, Delirium; and the third day after followed Convulion, a Vein being breathed, and a good Dyet precribed, the Symptomes not by thee being conquered, the Nerve was wholly divided: After which it was thus Digetivum.dreed, . Pul. Roat. Colat. vj. Terebinth. Lot. in vino Rubro s. Ol. Lumbricor. ij. Pulv. Lumbricor. Terretr. Matich. an. j s. Vitell. Ov. q. . mice. The Symptomes
being leened, was applyed this Cataplame; . Farin. Fabar. Lupinor. Orol. an. ij. s. Pulv. Scord. Catapl. Tapibarbat. Roar. Rub. an. pug. j. Pulv. Lumbric. Terret. ij. cum Oxymel. q. . fiat Catapl. By thee and the like dreings he perfectly recovered.

Another. He produceth another Hitory worthy Note, of a Noble-man, who being of a Cacochymick habit, and affected with a Lues Venerea, who in a Duel being wounded, had an oblique Inciion into one of his Nerves, and o as the Nerve was not wholly divided; hence followed Fevers, Deliriums, and great pains, the affected parts being embrocated, and Anodine Cataplames applyed, and no eae by thee received, a diviion of the Nerve was propoed, which would be the readiet way to prevent Convulion and all other evil accidents, he not permitting this to be done, there did arie an Emprothotonos, in which he mierably dyed.

div.head: CHAP. XLI.
Of a Contued Nerve.
div.p:
AND here may we meet with a Tumour and an intolerable pain, ariing from the Blood percolated per Anatomoin, from the mall veins, and ee the affected place begin to grow livid, having an affinity with an Ecchymois; and the fleh hereupon being contued is peedily to be uppurated, and the Contuion dipatcht without much pain: And becaue in Galen's time thee Contuions were very frequent, and he very happy in their recovery, we hall follow his method and
example, who advieth us in every attrition of the Nerves or Contuion thereof, that we peedily make evacuation. And becaue in thee Contuions the firt intention is to well order and dipoe the body, Phlebotomy and Pharmacy, with a thin Order of Dyet, is to be precribed, both for toppage and prevention of pains and fluxions: And to the affected parts apply Bean-meal and Oxymel mixt together, this both attenuating and digeting the egreed blood. Sometimes we may ue Farina Orobi. cum Oxymeleti, adding hereto Powder of Ireos. But becaue Galen doth direct us in thee caes to atringe, he orders Red Wine to be mixed with the former. In thee caes alo Unguent. Alabatrinum is alo good, if the Cutis be rent and exulcerated, thoe Medicines Note.are here bet which can dry up mot: And hence Avicen aith, If a Wound happens with a Contuion, the proper Medicines here are to be Dryers, which may unite the parts, awage pain, and hinder Inflammation; And for this purpoe Ol. Terebinth. Hyperic. with Powder of Earth Worms, Matich, and compleat Oyl are good. And for the awaging pain, Order this, . Unguent. Alabatrin. Farin. Fabar. Pulv. Lumbricor. praeparat. et cum pauco vini et Oxymelit. fiat. Empl. And if any putridnes appear, this is to be removed with Honey.

Hitory. To conclude this whole Dicoure, take thee few Hitories. The firt whereof Foretus in Lib. 6. Obervat. Chirurg. Oberv. 40. writes, of One whoe Nerve was contrited and attrited with a mall contuion of the Cutis, to which was applyed a Cataplame made of Beanmeal with Honey and Vinegar mixt together, and in the punctured obcerated Nerve, the Mos which growes upon tones, being mixt with Sulphur Wine and Vinegar upon a red hot Tile, and afterwards applyed, did wonderfully awage his pain, and did reolve the Matter which was collected in the Nerve; and for the Tumour
thereof, Ol. Terebinth. with a little Salt being boyled together was applyed with good ucces, and without any other Medicine, Ol. Irini being onely applyed to the Contued Nerve, perfectly cured it. And becaue Ditention Ditention & Ditortion of the Nerves.of the Nerves which is the 4th Paion that they may endure, or a Ditortion may happen by a full, extraordinary motion, or other violent external caue which may hinder and molet the motion of the part; In this cae we are to apply either Empl. Diachylon cum Gummi, or De Mucilaginibus, or a Cataplame made of new Marh-Mallow Roots, Lillies, with Bean-Meal and Faenugraek eed and the like boyled together. Beides alo, in a contued or ditorted Nerve ometimes a hardnes remains, as oft-times it happens by reaon of the acces of thick and vicid humours, whence a dulnes doth eize the part, Emollients and Digetives are here to be applyed, uch as are Bdellium, Ammoniacum, Galbanum, Diachylon magnum, with liquid Storax, Oyl of Lillies, Dill, Gooe-greae, and the like. If the Tendons Wounds of the Tendons.be hurt, they mut be cured as you cure thoe of the Nerves, but the Medicines which are here to be ued ought to be more trong and dry. If the Ligaments be Wounds of the Ligaments.hurt, thee require till tronger Medicines; for as thee have but mall ene of feeling, o they require tronger Medicines, not communicating with the Brains, they ariing from the Bones, and ending therein alo; o any drying Medicine may be ued without offence, therefore fill up the fleh and conolidate thoe Wounds as you do others.

Hitory. I conclude the whole with a very Worthy Story of a Souldier, who being wounded about his Neck, and the Nerve lying bare and unharmed, was cured exactly with this method; . Terebinth. lot. in aqu. Salv. Mel. dipumat. an. s. Farin. Orob. ij. Pulv. Lumbricor. Terretr. j. Ol. Roar. Lumbricor. ij. mice. Let thee and every thing that you apply to the Nerves or nervous parts be
Note. applyed warm; For according to Hippocrates's, Aphorim. 5. 17. cold things do here create Convulions, Ditentions, Livors, Rigors, and Fevers, as well as in Ulcers, it hardens the skin, and creates inupportable pain; over the dreing apply Empl. Diapalma, anointing the Circumjacent parts with Oyl of Roes and of Earth-Worms, dipping your Stupes in Red Wine, and the intected Nerve being covered with fleh, was afterwards Cicatrized, and the Patient cured.
Thus have I ailed through the general Coat of Wounds. My next Task hall be to Treat of Particular Wounds as they fall in their Order, beginning from the Upper Parts, and ending at the Foot.

div.head: OF Wounds in Particular,
CHAP. XLII.
Of Wounds of the Forehead.
div.p:
HAving run through all the Wounds of the Head, We next come to thoe which may happen to the Front or Forehead, called Frons Ã ferendo, becaue it carries in it the lively reemblance of Heavines, Cheerfulnes, Sadnes or Moroenes: And that which makes it o moveable, is the two Mucles of which it is compoed; the which Riolanus doth call the Membranous flehy Mucle, it begins from the Eye-lids, and ends where the hair begins; it coniteth of a Cuticula, Cutis, a little fat, and a Membrana Carnoa; it hath two orts of Fibres allowed it, for helping forwards the elevation of the Eye-lids. If a Wound happens here, and that with hurt of the frontal Bone, here are we to tudy ecurity of the parts, more than their beauty, becaue thee Wounds are dangerous; for here the Wound is to be dilated, and the Bone to be deraded, and the ame method to be ued as I have already hewn you in Wounds of the Skull: But where
Wounds happen here without any hurt to the Bone, here are we to tudy their Cure to be performed with the leat of Scarr or Deformity: And as a Wound may happen here, without los of ubtance, here are we to Cure as we do other Wounds; yet with this repect to regard the habit of the Body. Hence alo if a Flux of Blood be preent which may hinder union, this is firt to be minded, then are we to proceed to the uniting of the parts. And becaue Sutures here do leave their marks, we are to abtain from thee, and to apply uch Medicines as may unite the Lips of the Wound; the which being conjoyned are o to be kept: and for this ue a mall and narrow Ligature is very proper, applying ome agglutinative Medicine to the Wound before you ue the Ligature: As hereto adding the white of an Egg well beaten, to which may be added Dragons blood, Matich, Frankincene, Sarcocolla, and the like, to be made into the Conitence of Honey; this way may you prevent an ill Cicatrice. In a tranvere Wound of the Forehead, no Ligature is proper; but here we are advied to come to the titch, and the econd dreing to cut off the titches, and to apply ome agglutinative Medicine; thee only to be ued alo where the lips of the Wound are at much variance, the which are by Suture to be brought to a mutual Contacture: For agglutination, Empl. Barbarum is very good, and Diapalma will do it; and where a good union is purchaed, the place is to be anointed with Axungia Humana, the which by its natural property doth effect a fair Cicatrice. In thee caes, where you intend to procure a Cicatrice, Unguent. Tuthiae is very good, or Unguent. Cerusae in Summer time. And thus much of thee Wounds.

To conclude this, take thee Two Hitorical Obervations; The firt of Glandorp, fol. 91. Oberv. 13. who writes of a Lady, who falling everal times in one and the ame place, purchaed hereby a large Contuion in her
Forehead with an Ecchymois. Upon which followed Delirium and Vomiting, Nature endeavours to uppurate the matter, and to ait her, was applyed this Cataplame, . Medull. Pan. Tritic. iij. fol. Malv. recent. M. S. Betonic. p. iiij. Farin. Tritic. j. cum . q. Lact. Vaccin. fiat Catapl. fine addendo Ol. Lilior. j. Axung. Suill. s. Croc. s. Vitell. ovi no. j. fiat Catapl. The Tumour being enlarged, and the matter ripe, let a right Inciion be made (which in thee caes are generally thus to be made, it being contituted of right Fibres) in the lower part upwards both for the better abterging and expurging of the Matter, a Ligature being applyed on the lower part for prevention of its decent, being dipt in Wine and pret out, the Matter was at length wholly dicharged, and by precribing a good Dyet, and procuring Incarnation, the Wound was Cicatrized and Cured.

Dodonaeus fol. 267. writes of an Old Man, who having received a Wound in his Forehead, was freed from blindnes: And he further annotes of a Woman of Fifty years of age, who by falling from a high place had her frontal Vein wounded, much blood iuing thence, he uddainly did peak, and that impediment of her Tongue was looned, which for ome Moneths had been tyed up by an Apoplexy.

div.head: CHAP. XLIII.
Of Wounds of the Eye-lids.
div.p:
THe Eye-lids being appointed by Nature as the drawbridges to lift the Eye up and down, are ometimes wounded: Thee are framed for keeping out dirt and ill vapours from the Eye, and keep back all injuries from aaulting or coming near the Eye; they conit of a thin Cutis, having no fat allowed them; inwardly wrapt up with a thin and light Pericrane, for the more eaie motion: each Eye hath two, one whereof we call the lower, in man not of much ue, the other the upper, being of great ervice to Mankind, endued with two Mucles, the firt being right, eated in the upper region of the Orbit, within the Thalamus of the Eye: the other aid to be Orbicular; but this by Riolan. and Spigelius is taken for two: Julius Caserius, Sect. 1. de Orig. Vi. Cap. 18. writes, That hence may be taken thee Indications, uch as have an elated upper Eye-lid, are proud and fierce; and uch as have them depreed, are humble and mild. But to come to their Wounds: If the Ligaments of the Mucles be not diected, ue no Suture; for this doth bring intolerable pain and abces: but if thee be incied, titch them up with a deep and firm titch. Now a Wound of the Eye-lid may happen either by a imple Inciion, or with Inciion with los of ome of the ubtance. In cae of a Wound caued by a imple Inciion lengthwayes made, according to the Series of the Fibres, here are we to ue Cephalick and Agglutinative Powders, uch as have no harp quality in them. If the Inciion be tranvere without los of ubtance, here procure an exact agglutination, o as the lips of the Wound may fairly and evenly anwer each other: The Sutures
or Stitches that you make here mut be deep, for taking fat hold. If a Wound happens here with los of Subtance, tudy the dicharge of Matter, and procure a good Conolidation; and for this Ue Sarcoticks are the bet Medicines, as Balam. Lucatell. Liniment. Arcaei, and the like. As for Sarcotical and Agglutinative Medicines here to be ued, this Powder of Galen is very excellent; Bol. armon. Terr. igillat. Sang. Drac. Sarcocoll. an.
j. mice; or if you pleae, to 2 drams of the firt two you may add a dram of the lat two; above the Powders being very finely beaten, is to be applied a piece of fine and oftlinnen Cloth, dipt in the white of an Egg and Roewater beaten up together; for this doth hinder Inflammation, and over thee apply convenient Bolters.

To conclude this Chapter, I hall end with this obervable Hitory; the firt whereof hall be of a young Hitory.Man, who looking upwards, had a mall Stone fell down upon the upper Eye-lid, the which did both hurt it and its Cartilage, and diolved its Continuity. A Suture being preently made, and the Parts encloed by a Needle, the Cartilage remaining unhurt, there did arie a great Inflammation both of the Adnata and Eye-lid, with pain; to the Wound was applied an agglutinative Medicine, with Empl. Diapalma; into the Eye was injected a Collyrium; a Vein was breathed; a good order of Diet precribed; and this Collyrium ordered: Sem. Melon recent. excorticat. s. Aqu. Roar. Euphrag. Plantag. an
vj. Contundantur emina in mortario marmorio cum q . aquar. upradict. & cola, colature adde Terr. igillat. opt. Tuth. praeparat. an. ij. the which are to be bound up in a piece of linnen Cloth, and o put into it. And becaue his Body was very Cacochymick, he was ordered thee Pills: Pil. Luc. Major. s. Pil. Coch. s. Diagr. Pill. gr.ij. cum Ol. Ani. q . fiant Pil. no. 5. deaureantur. Thee being adminitred, the Inflammation ceaed, and the
other Symptoms vanihed; the Wound was Cicatrized with Diapompholigos, and the Patient cured without any blemih.

div.head: CHAP. XLIV.
Of Wounds of the Eyes.
div.p: I Shall continue my Dicoures with a brief Anatomy of the Parts, as I treat of them, being very advantagious to the young Chirurgeon, to direct him in his handling of them, if wounded. And in this place of worth we mut make a top, to admire the wonderful Fabrick of the Eye, of what Parts it conits, and how variouly thee may be hurt and wounded.

But to begin with the Ancients: See how Laurentius and Spigelius, and Bauhine peak of it. That whereas the Soul of Man, although it be imple, < in non-Latin alphabet > , yet it cannot make its entrance into the Ergatulum of the Body, or arrive at undertanding, reaoning, and peculation into Fancies, without the help of Senes. As therefore the Head is the Seat of Senes, and Houe of Reaon, o alo are thee Senes as Guardsmen to the Soul, and are planted as Internuntij in its Region. And although there are allowed 5 Senes, yet the chiefet and principal of the ret is Seeing, and that in thee three repects; for this declares and hews to us the variety of Objects, and their differences. 2dly, Their ways and methods of operation are mot noble, and do exceed the ret, for viion is made in an intant. It's thee that give us our ight and light alo, the which the ancient Stoicks called the Divine Viion; Heichias calls them < in non-Latin alphabet > , Solis Portas; the Latines call them
Oculi, ab oculendo: They are lodged under the Eye-lids as under a Veil; they are the two Lights of our Microcom, appearing as our bright Stars, being as the Indexes of the Mind, and mot inducing to weetnes and comfort of Life: to pas their admirable figure, ite, connexion and temper, we come to its rare compoition. And thus may we ee it framed of ix Mucles, thus called, Superbus, Humilis, Bibatorius, Indignatorius, Amatorij, or two circular Mucles; having thee common Membranes allowed it, the which I hall only name, Adnata, Innominata, Cornea, Sclirotis, Uvea, Choroides, Arena, Retiformis. It hath alo thee 3 Humours, as a Waterih, Vitreous, and Crytalline Humour granted it, with an Optick Nerve, Veins, Arteries, Fat, and Glandules: Of each of thee you may read more at large in Laurentius Spegelius, and Demerbroke.

Having thus hewn how the Eyes are the Organs of Sight, we may alo ee how they may be affected, wounded, punctured; and thee Parts having their Nerves and Membranes immediately ariing from the Brain, this declares them to be of an exquiite ene, whoe Coats are very thin, and perpetually in motion; hence are hereby Fluxions eaily received into them; and thee do require both an artificial and careful method to be ued. In thee Parts we are alo advied by Galen, That we abtain Note.from all oleaginous things, thee here both inflaming and cauing Pain: 2ly, To keep the Eye from the light, for this weakens it. And to cure a imple Wound happening here, thee three Intentions are required; To prevent Inflammation, and top all flux of Humours, Inflammation.to mitigate Pain, and to unite the eparated Parts. Of each of thee in their order.

And firt of preventing Inflammation: And for performing this, Breathing of a Vein, ordering a thin Diet, applying repelling Medicines to the Front, are good and neceary, made of the whites of Eggs, Roe-water, Bol.
armeny, powder of fine Tutthy; into the Eye may be put too of Troch. alb. Rhais fine Opto in fine powder, with Plantain-water; if the right ide be affected, let the Patient lye on his left. Of this intead of the former may Collyrium.be ued; Troch. alb. Rha.
ij. Aqu. Plantag. Roar. alb. an. ij. Tutth. praeparat.
j. miceantur in Mortario & Unguent. fiat Collyrium: Or this, pulv. Lap. Haematit. praeparat. ij. Camphor. Alo. lot. an.
ij. Tutth. praeparat. Seiph. alb. an. s. mice in Mortario plumbeo & fiat Linimentum. If the Wound hath Inflammation adjoyned, we are to mind this, not neglecting the Wound; and for diolving and dicuing the concrete Blood occaioned by Contuion, or the Laceration of its Coats, into the Wound is to be intilled Pidgeons blood lukewarm, or Womans milk, over which is to be applied a Cataplame made of white Bread, powder of Wormwood beaten with the white of an Egg, at night fomenting the Eye with a Decoction made with Troch. alb. Rha. the Mucilage of Quinch-eed extracted in Roe-water, and a little prepared Tutthy.

p.hi: The econd is to awage Pain, and repel the defluxion of Humours: Thee following may be directed; as,
p.U: Fol. Plantag. Roar. Rubr. fl. Melilot. Camomel. an. m. . Decoction.Sem Faenugraec. ter lot. s. Alo. Myrrh. Thur. an. j. Croc. gr. iiij. Tutth. praeparat. Pompholig. praeparat. Ceru. lot. an. ij. Troch. alb. Rha. cum Opio j. Aqu. Roar. Faenicul. an. q. . fiat Decoctum, with which the Eye is to be waht oft-times in a day.

p.hi: A Powder for the ame is this:
p.U: Troch alb. Rha. cum Op. pulv. Tutth. Opt. praeparat. Pompholig. praeparat. lap. Haematit. Gum. Arabic. Tragag. Alo. an. j. Croc. s. mice, fiat pulvis tenniimus. This is to be ued to the 4th or 7th day.

div.p:
Empl. Falloppius doth much commend this Plaiter for awaging Pain: Carn. pomor. dulc. ub prun. coct. ij. fol. papaver. alb. coct. ub prunis Hyociam. ita coct. an. j s.
Croc. j. farin. Faenugraec. ij. lact. Muliebr. Ol. Roar. an. q. . fiat Emplatrum, extendatur uper petiam, & imponatur uper oculi claui palpebram.

Uniting the divided Parts. The third Intention, which is the uniting of the eparated Parts, will be made evident in the enuing Dicoure. If therefore the Wound be a imple Wound, only penetrating and inciing the Cornea or Conjunctura, and this happens, without any exition of its interiour Body or Humour, this is to be united. And for the performance hereof, we mut be very careful and have regard to the Eye, for it's irritated by every mall thing; hence therefore if Pain afflicts it, remove it by Revulion; if the Wound be deep, the weapon which occaioned it, mut pas through the broad and long chink about the Orbits: If the Wound pas into the Brain, it is mortal; if it reacheth not o far, but only doth enter the aqueous Humour, and makes that fly out, or the vitreous or Crytalline Humours; in thee caes Sarcoticks are mot proper, and thee are to be ued in very fine Powders, of which I have been very plentiful, they being made of Terra igillata, Bol. armen. Sang. Dracon. Sarcocoll. Lap. Calaminar. and the like. And becaue it ometimes falleth out, that part of the wounding Intrument doth tick in the Eye, if it ticketh o fat, as that it may not eaily be removed, without effuion of ome of the Humours, and that it doth not prick the Eye-lids, this is bet to be kept in, and to dres the Wound with anodine Medicines until the 7th day, as Fallopius advieth, and then to ue Agglutinatives. But if the piece doth caue pain, and a continual gleeting, and hurts the Eye-lids, this is thus to be dreed with Unguent. de Betonica, with which the Tent is to be armed, over which may be applied Oxelaeum: Or for the ame Ue this is excellent; Ol. Vitell. Ovor. s. Abietin. Unguent.
ij. Croc. gr. iiij. mice in oculum infundendum; and this to be ued until the 7th or 9th day.

To conclude this with ome Hitorical Obervations, Hitory. Glandorp fol. 98. Ob. 15. writes of a Nobleman, who being challenged by another to fight a Duel, was wounded by his Antagonit in that part of the Cornea which is Diaphanous: The waterih Humour paed out here; he felt intolerable pains; a Vein being opened (viz.) the Cephalick Vein, and 6 ounces of Blood extracted, to the Eye for the preent was put Aqu. Roarum nothing being more ready, and o was it rouled up. In the interim this following Emplaiter was applied to the Nuch Veicator.of his Neck: Carn. bovin. alit. & in fumo exiccat. ij. Ferment. recent. js. Smegm. com. s. Sal. ij. incidatur caro ubtiliimÃ¨ & imul miceantur & cum q. . Aceti fiat Collyrium. pata. The 2d day was ordered this Collyrium: Aqu. Roar. j. Euphrag. Faenicul. an. vj. pulv. Mirabol. Citrin. j. lap. Calam. praeparat. ij. Troch. alb. Rha. cum Opio j. pulveres liquentur in petia & in aquis upradictis upendantur; of which every four hours was intilled ome very warm. Oft-times to make his Body oluble, he was ordered Caia, a thin Diet being precribed, and uch as was cooling; he took afterwards thee Pills: Pil. Coch. Aurear. an. s. Matich. gr. vj. cum vino malvatico fiant Pillulae: Hereby he was perfectly recovered without carce any car, and recovered his ight.

Another. Another he hath of a young Man of carce 16 years of age, who having his Eye hurt, the waterih humour with part of the vitreous humour flowed out; for which Efflux, the firt day a Vein in his Arm was opened, from whence was drawn forth 5 ounces of blood, to the Nuch of his Neck was applied the former Veicatory; hence followed great Inflammation and Pain, for the awaging of which Womans milk was precribed; Catapl.then was applied this following Cataplame: Sem. Cydonior. iij. aqu. Roar. iij. & fiat Mucilago, coletur, colaturae adde Carn. pomor. odorif. coct. ij. farin. Hord. ubtili. pulv. q. . mice, fiat Cataplama. The Inflammation not
being topt by thee, Cupping-glaes were applied to his Scapulaes, with much flame and carrification, and Veicatories applied behind his ears, out of which iued much water; the Pain not yet abating, he had an Iue made in his Neck, from whence within few days after a great plenty of Matter was dicharged, and hereby the Inflammation ceaed, and the pain began to be mitigated. For conolidating the Coat of the Cornea, A conolidating Collyrium. and the eparated Lips, was ued this Collyrium: . Aqu. Roar. Euphrag. Faenicul. an. js. Cort. granator. js. fl. Balaut. Roar. Rubr. an. pug. j. Mirabol. Citrin. Nuc. Cupres. an. j. Thee being cut and bruied, let them tand in infuion in the Waters for 8 hours, then boyl them, and to the trained Liquor add thee following Ingredients, being tyed up in a fine piece of Cloth: Cort. mirabol. Citrin. levigat. cum aqu. upradict. ij. Troch. alb. ine Op. j. Tuth. Lapid: Calamin. praeparat. an. s. Ceru. lot. ij. his addendo Syr. Roar. icc. j. with which Collyrium the Eye was waht 3 times in a day; this being ued, the lips of the Wound was joyned, and for procuring A skinning Collyrium. a Cicatrice here, the Part was wahed with this following: . Aqu. Faenicul. Rut. Celidon. major. an. js. ucc. Faenicul. js. Tartar. praeparat. gr. vj. Sacchar. albi. iij. Sacchar. Saturn. vel. Sal. ejud. gr. iiij. Troch. alb. cum Opio j. Tye up the Tartar and the Salt of Lead in a fine Cloth, and let them hang in the aforeaid Waters; with which was procured a good Cicatrice.

Another. Solonander Sect. 5. Con. 15. writes of a Woman, who cutting of Wood, had a liver thereof fell into her Eye; he preently taking the yolk of an Egg, with Cerus and Oyl of Roes beaten together, and applying it to the whole Orbit of the Eye, intead of a defenative, and inwardly putting into the Eye the white of an Egg, mixt with Womans milk and Roe-water, was perfectly cured.

div.head: CHAP. XLV.
Of Wounds of the Face.
div.p: IN the foregoing Chapters I have hewn you the upper Parts of the Head, and thoe Parts which are covered with long Hairs: We come now to that Part which by ome is called Vultus, Ã voluntatis Indicio, it being turned every way forwards and to the ides according to our wills: It is alo called Facies, becaue it maketh the difference between Man and Beat. And here might we look into its Beauty, and conider in every repect its fair compoition: We may well admire its Maker; for although the treauries and tore-houes of Judgment, Sene and Reaon, are placed in other Parts, yet for Beauty this doth urpas them: For in this may be eaily een the torms and tempets of Anger and Paion, the ilver treams of Love, the igns of Health, and the attempts of Death: Here may we lively ee repreented the Idea's of Joy, Anger, Sadnes, Melancholy, repreenting the obcure Parts of Man, as by a glas; ome of its Parts are containing, others contained. The Cutis hereof hath in it this one remarkable thing, the which as it is variouly perforated in the Eyes, Notrils, Ears and Mouth; as it is wholly nervous in the other Parts of the Body, in this it is muculous and flehy. And becaue I intend to treat of all its Parts in their everal orders, I hall not give you any further trouble to read more hereof, but fall upon its Dicoure of being wounded.

And here although uch Medicines as are already et down, may erve for the curing of Wounds of the
Face, yet becaue it's the comely Part of the Body, and beauty of its Front, affording a wonder to its Spectators, here ought it to be our greatet care that we leave no cars, or foul Cicatrice. If the oft Parts be only wounded, cloe the lips of the Wound with evennes, by a fair Ligature, and agglutinative Medicines; and herein are we directed to make ue of narrow Rowlers, thee being mot proper for performing this Intention. As for agglutinative Medicines, I have already preented you with a plentiful quantity; thee may be made of Frankinence, Bol. armoni. Terra igillata, Dragons blood, Beanmeal, with the white of an Egg beaten up with Roewater, or the like. If the Wound be large and wide, you mut come to the ue of the dry Stitch, the which I have already hewn in my Dicoure of Sutures and Ambroe Parrey is very full hereof, expreing both way and method, and therefore in this cae I do recommend you to him. In thee caes Linimentum Arcaei, and Balamum Lucatelli are good, over which may be applied this Cataplame: . Bol. Armon. ij. Thur. Matich. Sarcocoll. an. s. Myrrh. Aloes an. j. Sangu. Dracon. s. Farin. Hord. Fabar. an. j. mice, & cum albumine Ovi mit. cum aqu. Roarum q. . fiat Cataplama. Before the application of which, the aforeaid Liniment or Balom is to be anointed all over the wounded Part, and the lips of the Wound to be touched therewith.

Arcaeus lib. 1. fol. 68. de Curand. Vulner. hath thee two Hitories: The firt of which is of a Man who was deperately wounded, from his Eye-lid and Noe to the lowet Lip, o as the Noe with the upper Mandible and Teeth fell down upon the Chin; the Wound being titcht up, and the Mandible and its Bones being repoed into their proper places, it was afterwards rowled up with a Tape a fingers broad about his Forehead, from below upwards, and there own up; and in form of a Cros was another Rowler titcht to the former, from one Ear to the
other, and by applications of good and proper Medicines the Wound was healed, and the Patient retored to his former health.

He writes another Story of the ame Man, who being mitten under the Chin even to the upper Mandible by a Bull's Horn, opened part of the Face therewith, and di-joyned his left Eye from the Noe with the end thereof; the place being titcht up with a Needle, the Mandible was retored as you ee in the former, and he perfectly was cured; his Mouth was inwardly wahed with a Decoction of Barley, Roes, Balautians, and honey of Roes; and thus he was in a hort time recovered, many pieces of Bones coming forth by his Palate, which were broken by the Horn, and left remaining in the Cavity of the Palate.

div.head: CHAP. XLVI.
Of Wounds of the Temples.
div.p: THE Temporal Mucles being very trong, are by the Greeks called Crotaphites, whoe Fibres, by how much they do recede from their middle, they are o much the more obliquely carried with a Tendon. They do receive in each of them 3 Nerves, the firt ariing from the 3d pair, the 2d from the 4th, and the 3d from the 5th pair; in which repect this Mucle being either contued or punctured, great danger of Convulion and death approacheth.

Another thing worthy note in this Mucle is, That it is covered with the Pericrane, by which the ubjacent Temporal Bones are detitute thereof. Hippocrates doth advie in Wounds which happen here, by reaon of the
direful Symptoms which they do produce, the Patient doth not continue long. And for the confirming of this, Jacotius Com. 1. Aph. Lib. 1. Sect. 3. Coac. Hipp. writes, That he hath oft-times een Convulive motions happen here by a light hurt in thee Parts. And Braavolus ad Aph. 9. lib. 7. writes, Upon ome of the Temporal Veins being wounded, a mortal Convulion hath followed, without any help or toppage of the Flux. Yet Ambroe Parrey writes, Let any Chirurgeon might be afraid of cutting the Temporal Mucle, where occaion doth require the exemption of the Bone by the Trepan, he doth here produce a Hitory of an Experiment of his own, which he practied on one in the War of Henry the II. who being mitten with a Stone, with that violence that it fractured the Os Petroum, and very much contued the Temporal Mucle, without any apparent Wound: To the which he being called into conultation with many other Phyitians and Chirurgeons, it was generally agreed that the contued Fleh hould be dilated, for the better coming at the Bone: The day following the Fleh was dilated, and the day following, which was the 3d day, a Trepan was applied; the which being done, ome mall frutula's of Bones were taken away, and putting in a leaden Pipe into the Part through which paed much Matter, the Patient was ordered to hut his Notrils, and Ears and Mouth, and force it through here, the which paed from between the Dura and Pia Mater; the ret of the Matter was forced out by a Syringe, with which was injected a Traumatick and deterging Decoction, and the Patient was at length recovered.

And for atisfying of this Point, you may read of Glandorp in his Specul. Chirurg. Ob. 9. fol. 82. of a Child of 12 years of age, who having dahed the left part of his Head againt an obtue piece of Wood, did hereby contue his Temporal Mucle on the ame ide: He hereupon preently grew immoveable, vomited blood, and lot his
peech; the hairs being haved, it was anointed with Ol. Roarum, and covered with Melilot Empl. until a Cataplame could be made; the which being applied, the motion returned again, and the Imagination till Catapl.eemed omewhat hurt. The Cataplame was this: . Betonic. alv. Marjoran. an. P. iij. Roar. Rubr. Primul. ver. Lillior. convall. an. P. iiij. pulv. fl. Cham. Melilot. an. pug. ij. Farin. Hord. Fabar. an. ij. Orob. j. cum Lact. vaccin. q. . fiat Cataplama, fine addendo Ol. Violar. js. Vitell. Ovor. no. j. Croc. j. mice; the which being o rouled up as to keep it on, about the middle of the night he began to ret; the morning following he returned better anwers to quetions propoed, and began to perceive great pains of his Head, and griping of his Belly; Clyter.for which was ordered this Clyter: . Violar. Malvar. an. M. j. Alth. Betonic. Verban. alv. Rorimar. an. pug. iiij. Rad. Alth. j. em. Lin. Faenugr. an. vj. Ani. Coriander. an. iij. coquantur in . q. aq. fontin. ad xvij. colaturae, adde Elect. Diacath. vj. Ol. Roar. Aneth. an. j. Sacchar. Rubr. colat. x. mice, fiat Enema. the which he retained for half an hour after its injection, whereby he received much eae, and the pains did begin to grow remis, and the 3d day he walked about. But becaue a flatulent Tumour appeared in the Mucle, this following Decoction was precribed for it, in which a Sponge being dipt, was applied, being well pret, to the affected Part:
â¢â¢ coction.. fol. Betonic. M. . fl. Camomel. Aneth. Melilot. Roar. an. pug. ij. Sem. Ani. iij. Aqu. fontin. vin. optim. an. lbj. coquantur adtertias; the which being ued for ome days, the wind was dicued; and over the Part was applied Empl.this mixture: . Empl. Diapalm. s. Melilot. iij. Ol. Camomel. q. . fiat Empl. Thee being ordered, and a convenient Diet precribed, he was retored to his health.
He hath another Hitory in his 12th Obervation hereof; but becaue I would not be too tedious, I commend you thither.

div.head: CHAP. XLVII.
Of Wounds of the Noe.
div.p: THis, as it is the intrument of Smelling, carrieth with it according to Laurentius, both Beauty and Majety. Hence did the Egyptians in their Hieroglyphicks, ignifie a wie Man by his Noe, who could thereby mell other mens politick tratagems. Aritotle doth call it < in non-Latin alphabet > , in 11. Cap. Hitor. Animal. the word taking its derivation from < in non-Latin alphabet > , becaue through its notrils do pas the Excrements of the Brain. Cicero writes, that it is placed above, for the better reception of Odours, and Nature placed it in a traight line, that Repiration may not be interrupted, but pas freely. It is divided into two Cavities by a partition, the odoriferous Spirits, or Air, do generally wim in them. This diviion alo is generally believed was thus made, for the more perfect receipt of the Sene of Smelling; for we mell even in our breathing. It coniteth of a Cuticula, Cutis, Mucles, Bones, Cartilages, and an inward Coat, all which have their proper actions.

But becaue many worthy Authors of Anatomy have fully and plentifully enlarged on thee, I hall not trouble you further therein, but fall to our preent task, where we may meet with it wounded either in its oft Parts only, or alo in its hard Parts. We hall firt begin with its oft Parts.

Where by the way we are to note, That as the Noe is Boney in the upper part, o is it Cartilaginous in the lower part. If the Cutis be only wounded, a dry Stitch may erve, not to come to Suture, but rather to ue agglutinative Medicines, endeavouring to our utmot to
procure a fair and even Cicatrice. A mall skar here very evidently appearing, hence ought we to tudy to preerve its Beauty, by curiouly joyning the lips of the Wound together. In thee caes uch Medicines which are here to be ued, are to be of a oft conitence, and yet having in them an atringent and drying quality, hereby cloing the lips of the Wound with that advantage, that carce any mark may be een; and for this Ue Unguent. Deficcativum Rubrum, Album Camphoratum, and uch as I have already mentioned, may do well here.

Wounds of the Bone of the Noe. The econd ort of Wounds which may be allowed to happen here, mut either reach the upper and boney parts, or the lower and Cartilaginous parts. Now if the upper part be wounded o as the Bone be fractured, the firt Intention here is to reduce the Fracture, then joyn and unite the Wound: And for the performance of this, according to Aquapendens his advice, cap. 29. de Vuln. fol. 895. we are to put into the Noe a fit piece of Wood, wrapt about with oft linnen Cloth, o as it may eaily enter thereinto, outwardly ordering the Noe with your fingers, for the true confirmation of it; this being done, we are to put in a Quill or mall Pipe into the Noe, made of Reed, or the like, thee not being exquiitely round, but omewhat harp above and flat below, to preerve its natural figure: For this Pipe hath thee 3 Faculties allowed it; as that it keeps the conformation of the Part, and doth hinder the falling of any of the Bones into the Notrils; then it makes a free paage for breathing, keeping the Notrils open and latly, makes the way free for the dicharge of all Excrements from the Brain; here alo take notice, that this Pipe be not put too high, let it doth occaion ternutation, and hereby do diorder the reduced Fracture, and conolidation of the Wound.

The Bones being thus reduced, we next come to the uniting of the eparated Parts; which may be done by the dry Stitch or Agglutinatives; and as to ay, Epolonticks, Bol armeny, Dragons blood, Terraigillata, and the like, being beaten into fine powder, and mixt with the white of an Egg, to the conitence of Honey, is very good.

Of a Tranvere Wound. If a tranvere Wound happeneth here, you are to apply to each ide of the Notrils a fine linnen Boulter, moitned in red Wine, and pret out, over which to apply a Rowler, having a hole made in the middle thereof, for a more free breathing, owing this to the backpart of the Head.

Of a Wound of the Cartilage of the Noe. The Iower and Cartilaginous part of the Noe being wounded, the ame Pipe is here again required; then the lips of the Wound to be united, and brought together by Ligatures, and the ame Medicines to be ued, as I have already hewn. If the Cartilaginous part of the Noe be wholly cut off this Wound is incurable: But that the beauty of the Face may not be thus deformed, you may frame a new Noe for it out of the skin of the Arm, or any other Part; but this is both a laborious, difficult, and long Work; it's made by carrifying the pin of the Noe, and cutting the skin of the Arm, anwering that part of the Noe which is lot; and the skin being thereto applied, and own with the carrified part of the Noe, the Arm is afterwards to be tyed to the Head, o as it be not any ways moved, for this would hinder Agglutination: Agglutination being made, the Noe is to be carrified with deep Scarrifications, o as the fleh appear red; then the neighbouring part of the Arm is to be cut, and put to the Noe, and own; and this is o often to be repeated, until the whole Noe be cut out, and the skin of the whole Arm be almot ablated, and agglutinated to the Noe. But to conclude this:

Hitory. We read of two Mariners, cutting one another with their Knives: The one cut the other o, as that he had the Cartilaginous part of his Noe as it were cut off; it was titcht up with 3 titches in a good form, two at the ides being made, and the 3d in the middle, yet o Liniment.as the Cartilage might not be damaged; after which was applied this Mundifier and Incarnative: . Ol. Roar. Compl. iiij. Succ. Nicotian. Apij an. js. coquantur ad Succorum conumpt. & colature adde Rein. Terebinth. j.
ij. Virid. Aer. j. Cer. q. . fiat Linimentum. With this was anointed the Dreings, with which the parties were dreed; and over them was applied Empl. Diapalm. In the inward part, let uperfluous fleh hould grow therein, was applied a hollowed Tent, armed with Diapompholigos; and that the mucous Subtance may be derived from the Notrils to the Palate, he ued this Apophlegmatime: . Cubebar.
j. Pyreth. Staphiacr. Agaric. Crud. an. j. Pulp. Paular.
ij. Sacchar. in . q. aqu. Salv. Solut. q. . fiant Troch. the which being aright applied and ordered, he was perfectly recovered, without any impediment of Speech.

div.head: CHAP. XLVIII.
Of Wounds of the Ears.
div.p: IT's called Auris, ab Hauriendo, the Air being drawn in thereby. Aritotle calls thee Parts, Senus Dioipunae, they being created for Undertanding; thee are framed with no les Art than the former. They are by the Greeks called < in non-Latin alphabet > , in Englih, Ears, from Hearing. They are framed of many Parts, the which do as well erve for the reception of found, as alo for the intenion thereof.
