They are the intruments of Hearing, but not the principal Organs; for if thee be lot, as we ee it inflicted as a punihment upon perjured perons, yet the Sene of Hearing doth continue, as well as the Sene of Smelling, if the Noe be amputated. Thee Senes being lodged within the Cranium, they gain a emicircular hape; on the inide excavated, Nature hath made them two, that one being injured the other may perform the Work. Vealius compares the whole Ear to a Fan. Gaza calls this Pinna, being much like a broad Cartilage, or Fin of a Fih. By ome it is called a Wing, broad, for the better embracing the ound, which afterwards doth decend by the inward Compas unto the arched Cavity that guides it to the Head. The outward Circumference is called < in non-Latin alphabet > , the inward called < in non-Latin alphabet > .

But as touching the outward parts of the Ear, thee being the proper Subjects of our preent Dicoure: And here may we ee a Cuticula, as the common covering of this part as well as of the ret; next a Skin, enwrapping both the outide and inide of the Ear; it hath Veins dipered on either ide from the external Jugulars; Arteries
it hath from the inward Carotides, which do pas to the backide of the Ear; two mall Nerves it hath backward, and two from the ides of the 2d Conjugation; they have both proper and common Mucles allowed them, found out by Ealloppius; two others they have alo; in all, four. The outward ubtance of the Ear is neither boney nor flehy, but moderately hard, yielding a ound, an Eccho being as it were framed without, and o carried inwards its Cartilage arieth as it were out of the Temples; it's tyed to the petroe Bone by a Ligament, which is trong. There are many other parts belonging to the inward Ear, but Anatomy doth ufficiently hew thee, therefore I pretermit them. If the Ears be hurt by outward Caues, the danger is not great; yet if part thereof be quite cut off here, it never groweth again; and if they are only wounded, they require a right Suture, and agglutinative Medicines; and as Hippocrates writes, the dryer any part is, the more drying Medicines doth it require. If the Wound be to be titched up, here are two things to be oberved: That you only bring together the parts of the Skin on each ide of the Ear, without touching or hurting the Cartilage: And then 2dly, If the Wound doth reach to that Cavity we call commonly Meatus Anditorius, you are to keep a pongy Tent in it, to prevent the growth of a pongy fleh, and that no Matter may fall into it, which may exulcerate the inward parts; both which are et down for our intruction by Aqua pendens, fol. 904. cap. 33.

The Wound being either titcht up, or joyned together, we are to ue drying Agglutinatives, uch as are powder of Bol. armen. Dragons blood, Matich. Red Roes, Balaut. to be mixed either with the white of an Egg well beaten with Roe-water, or to be prinkled in the lips of the Wound; over which is to be applied Empl. Barbarum or Diapalma, or the like; the which Empl. Barbarum is thus to be made: Bitumin Judaiac. Pic.
Arid. Rein. Cer. an. xij. Terebinth. Thur. Opoponac. Cerus. an. ij. Litharg. aur. j. Ol. Myrtin. iij. acet. q. . fiat Empl. It the Cartilage be rent, Celus doth highly commend this following: . Ra. Aerugin. xij. Spum. argent. xxx. Alumin. Picis arid. Pineae an. xij. Ol. Myrtin. Acet. an. q. . fiat Empl.

Hitory. To conclude: A Souldier being hot through in the middle of his Ear, it being much wounded, the Wounds were titched up, the Cartilage was not hurt; and becaue he bled much at the Wound, this was preently applyed: . pulv. Lap. Haematit. ij. Bol. armen. js. Cerus. j. mice, fiat pulvis; over which was applied Empl. Diapalma; afterwards it was rouled up, ome parts of the Cartilage laid bare, over which was prinkled ome of the aforeaid Powder, topping the Ear inwardly with Cotton or Wool, and the Wound being mundified was oon healed and skinned.

div.head: CHAP. XLIX.
Of Wounds of the Lips.
div.p:
THee by Cicero are called Labra Ã Lambendo, of licking, they are two in number, being both flehy, fungous and moveable; and as they are outwardly covered with a skin, o inwardly are they inveted with a Membrane coming to the Stomach and Mouth: and hence is it that the Skin is een to hake and tremble upon Vomiting. They are of great Ue to Man, to help forward his peech, to void his pattle, and to defend his Teeth from cold Air; they have both proper and common Mucles allowed them, and thee are held Six in number; two moving them upwards, two downwards,
<1 page duplicate>
<1 page duplicate>
and the other to either ide of the Mouth. Thee are generally wounded lengthwayes: if the Lip be cut above or below, it is preently to be titcht up; for whilet the Patient moves his Mouth, he doth hinder Conolidation. Some are born with Lips divided, but thee are to be cured by Needles, hereby joyning the diverted parts. Outwardly may be applyed agglutinative Medicines; inwardly more properly Syrups, to be ordered.
And for further appearance how you are to act here, Hitory.take thee one or two Hitories.

The firt hall be of a Scholar which Glandorp mentioneth, who falling upon a Door in a dark Night, fell upon a Stone which cut his Lip, and brake two Teeth of his upper Mandible; and here becaue there was a eparation of the parts, an actual and deep Suture was made, and the Teeth reduced into their places; the Wound was filled with Deterives and Digetives, which were outwardly applyed: Inwardly the part was touched and Unguent.anointed with this: . Syr. de. Ro. Sicc. j. de Succ. Nicotian. Mirtin. an. s. Unguent. Aegyptiac. j. mice. Over this was applyed a part of this Plaiter, . Ol. Roar. Litharg. aur. an. iij. A â¢ ung. Porcin. ij. Vitriol. alb. ij. s. mice. When it was well mundified, and began to heal, this was next ordered, . Tutth. praeparat. Lap. Calamin. j. Corn. Cerv. Ut. s. Alo. gr. vj. With which was generated a new fleh and a new Cicatrice: And for confirming the looe Teeth, this following Decoction, Decoction.. Herb. Hyperic. Hypocyt. fol. Ro. Rubr. Balnut. ap. iij. Cort. Granator. j. fol. et Fruct. Myrt. ar â¢ Pug. ij. Nuc. Cupres. s. coque imul in aqu. Hordeat. Chalybeat. colaturam erva aduum.

div.head: CHAP. L.
Of Wounds of the Tongue.
div.p:
WE are come now to peak of our good or bad Friend, called by the Greeks < in non-Latin alphabet > , being tyed within the pale of the Teeth, or imprioned between the two barrs of the Teeth and the Lips. It's the notable Intrument both of Tate and Voyce; its Bais doth ret upon the Bone Hyois; in Man it is omewhat long, and ometimes een to be longer in ome Men than in others. It is oft, broad, and looe, that it may be conveyed, dilated and variouly dipoed; it is tyed to the Larynx, and to the Os Hyoidis, upon which its Roots do ret. It's made of proper fleh, a coat, Nerves, Veins, Arteries, Mucles, and a Ligament; and this is very trong, membranous and broad: and o had it need, for the keeping up of the Tongue ometimes, and is as the bridle of the Tongue ometimes to curb its unrulines. It receiveth its Coat from that which doth alo invet the Mouth, Palate, Aeophagos and Larynx. It's pun and made of fine and thin Fibres, for the better reception of avours. Its ubtance is oft and rare, much like a ponge, for the more peedy moytning with the humour which doth carry this apor in it; its fibres are expanded through the length of its mucles: Which is not o in the Tongue it elf, It receiveth two Nerves from the third and fourth Conjugations. It hath two Veins called Raninae, iuing out of the inward branch of the external Jugular Veins. It doth receive its Arteries from the leepy Arteries; it's framed of many Mucles, and hath many Mucles allow'd it at its thick end, and thee do help forward its functions of
peaking, and rowling of the meat, and its tating. Its mucles are in number five pair, thus called, Styloglosi, Myloglosi, Geneoglosi, Ypioglosi, and Ceratoglosi. And this Tongue, although it be but a little member thus furnihed, is of great ue, Expreing our Minds, and yielding us our tating quality, being as Hippocrates writes, the meenger of the Brain; and is alo very ueful as touching life, for this helpeth forward Matication or chewing, aiting alo deglutition, by turning the meat over it, towards the Gullet: all which good turns it doth to Mankind.

Now as touching its Wounds. The Tongue being thus guarded with a Sett of Teeth, and lodged within the Mouth, might eem to be defended againt all outward Injuries, yet this is ometimes een wounded: for when the Cheeks and the Jawes are wounded, the Tongue alo may take hare of the Wounds. And it may be o wounded, that even a part of it may be cut off, and here the los is irreparable: If a part hereof doth adhere to the ound part, here it is not to be cut away, but rather to be titched up. Wounds happening here are dangerous for thee two caes, becaue here we can neither ue dry titch nor Ligature; and then becaue Emplatick Topicks have no power to hold on here. In every Wound of the Tongue, in which the ound part is cut or divided, the Lips are to be adjoyned; and this is to be performed by Suture, as Aquapendens teacheth it: which is thus to be performed; The Tongue is to be drawn forth out of the Mouth, being holden by the Hand by a piece of Cloath between, you are to make o many and o deep titches as are to be taken, for the true unition of the divided parts. The Wound being well titcht up, we are to cut off the thread near the Knot.

Next are we to ue agglutinative Medicines, which may be made into Powders to be prinkled into the
Wound: Such as are Bol. armony, Dragons Blood, Myrtils, Balautians, and the like, being finely powdred for this purpoe, this Decoction is very good, . fol. & fl. Decoction. Ligutr. Plantag. Roar. Rubr. an. M. j. Cort. Granator. Balaut. an. s. Coquentur in aqu. Chalybeat. lb ij. ad 3. part. conumpt. in ColaturÃ¢ olve Acat. ij. Syr. de Bo. Sisc. iij. mice pro Decocto. To this alo may be added a little Allom, and let the Tongue and Mouth be wahed therewith. If pain be preent, Almond milk is good to wah it; let his Dyet be cooling, and he nourihed with liquid things, as Ptyan, Barley-Waters, Julep of Roes, and the like.

Hitory. And as there is carce a member or part of the Body which moves more, and is o moit and looe, o if this part be wounded tranverely, it is altogether incurable; yet if it be not wholly cut off, it's not to be accounted incurable, as may appear by this following Hitory of a Maid, who falling upon the Ground, having her Tongue extended, that part which was between her Teeth was almot cut off, and remained on only that pace where he wanted two of her Teeth. Hildanus being called to her, who is the Author of this Hitory, he tryed to Cure her this way and method, with the aforegoing Gargarime or Decoction, with which the Tongue was waht oft-times in a day; after he held in her mouth Syrup of dryed Roes of Quinces, of Ribes, and the like, he drank nothing but thin Barley-Broaths, Almond-milk, and the like; and by thee he was perfectly cured: neither was her peech any ways hurt, after which he lived for 12 whole years.

div.head: CHAP. LI.
Of Wounds of the Neck.
div.p: HAving run through all the Parts of the Head, We come next to the Neck, where we may meet with that part o properly called the Rock, which lyes jut under the Head and Face, and upon the Breat. It obtains a round Figure, and becaue in thee parts are found various bodies, and this wrought out of their diverity of works, thee may hew diverity of Species in thee Wounds. For beides its Mucles and Cutis, which it hath betowed on it, in its forepart it hath planted the Apera Arteria, or Wind-Pipe, under which is placed the Aeophagus or Gullet. At its Sides are put both the Jugular Veins and Arteries; in its back-part may we ee the Spine; forwards and upwards the Throat and Larynx; under it the Jugulars.

It hall therefore be Our preent Task to Treat of thee in their Order. And as from the Heart the great Artery, and from the Liver doth arie the great Vein, o from the Brain is produced a great Trunk extended through the whole Spine, which may either be called Spinal, Doral, Cervical or Lumbary Marrow. And hence the Neck, being as the Vicar of the Brain, or the Medulla, which is kept in the Spine, if this be cut or wounded in the middle, the Nerves are oon reolved and ditended, the enes flagg, and the Senifying Quality doth perih: and hence we do ee the Patient to avoid both Urine, Seed, and Excrement voluntarily.

Thee Wounds are to be treated with the ame Care as thoe of the Brain; for a deep and penetrating wound happening here, doth produce direful Symptomes, cauing hereby both los of Sene and Motion. Now if the Neck be wounded in the fore-part, the Apera Arteria and Gullet can onely be hurt; if in the fore-part above the Larynx, the Jugular Veins and Arteries; if in the back-part, the Spinal Marrow; and if none of thee be hurt, no Wound here happening can be allowed dangerous.

And in all thee caes we are to top firt the Flux of Blood, then to bring the Wound to a good digetion with this, . Terebinth. Lot. ij. vel ejus loco Ol. ejud. Digetivism.ij. Ol. Roar. j. Aqu. Ardent. s. mice. And inject this hot into the Wound, and over it apply Empl. de Betonic. or Diapalma. If herein there be required Sarcoticks and Epolonticks, I have already given you a plentiful Collection of thoe which may be here ued.

div.head: CHAP. LII.
Of Wounds of the Throat, Larynx, and Wind-pipe.
div.p:
IF a Wound doth happen in thee Parts, as in the Throat or Larynx, thee are the Signs; the upper part of the Neck, los of Voice and Air happens: But when it reacheth the Wind-pipe, it is more dangerous, both in repect of the exquiite ene wherewith thee Parts are indued, the Aeophagus hereupon tumifying, and o hindring Deglutition: Hence follows a decay of Nutriment, and danger of Suffocation; and alo in repect of the Veins and Arteries herein lodged and inerted, and their perpetual motions; for it's hereby that the Air is conducted into the Ventricle, the which being hindred in its inpiration, doth oon occaion an expiration. Hence therefore may we account thee Wounds dangerous, and yet not to be left unattempted without help, the Wind-pipe being the proper Intrument for Voice, outwardly being Cartilaginous, and inwardly Membranous and flehy. When this is wounded, it is generally known by the Senes; oft-times the Wound is occult, and the rather becaue here is no large Flux of blood follows thee Wounds, but ometimes Pain, ometimes there is perceived a tinking Breath, hoarenes of Voice, a drynes of the Fauces, and in proces of time the Patient doth become Empyemated. When Wounds only reach the outward Parts, thee may eaily be cured; but when the Cartilages are divided, thee are rarely cured, thee Parts being both hard and exanguial, and continually in motion, and accompanied with frequent Ditillations, thee being ufficient impediments to
hinder Agglutination. Beides which alo, if any Humour do accompany this Wound, it huts the paage, and doth make a fair way for Suffocation, the Oeophagus being hereby compreed. But to treat of every of thee a part, beginning firt with thoe of the Throat. Cure of Wounds of the Throat.

If any one be tabbed with a harp-pointed Intrument, as by a Pen-Knife, Dagger, or the like, and the Wound hath not touched the Wind-pipe, you are here, if a large Flux of blood follow, to top this by uch proper Medicines, as I have already propoed for performing the ame. The next Dreing may you apply to the wounded Part, a mixture of Myrrh and Aloes diolved in Brandy-wine, with which the Part wounded is to be dret; after this diget, incarne, and procure a Cicatrice, as you have Directions in the former Cures.

As for the Cure of Wounds of the Larynx or Wind-pipe, Cure of Wounds of the Larynx and Wind-pipe.if the Wounds be made tranverly, let the Patient bend himelf forwards; if it be traight, according to the length of the Pipe, here the Patient is to hold up his Head, hereby bringing the lips of the Wound together; then titch up the Wound artificially; and for this Ue, uch Pins as you ue in the Cure of hair Lips are bet here. This being done, agglutinative Medicines are mot ueful, uch as is Linimentum Arcaei, Balamum Peru. Balam. Lucatell. and that Unguentum Hipanicum which Aquapendens writes of in lib. de Vulnerib. lib. 2. fol. 805. above which may be applied Empl. Diapalm. de Minio, de Betonica, or the like. In thee Wounds are you to take epecial care, that none of your Medicines do touch the Wind-pipe o as to enter it, for hereby may you procure Suffocation. Inwardly here alo may you order the Patient to drink warm Milk by degrees, or ome magiterial chalybeated Decoction, adding hereto Comfrey, Centaury, Betony, or the like; Eclegma.or uch an Eclegma as this: . Rad. Conolid. major. ub prun. coct. iij. Pulv. Tragag. Arabic. an. ij. Bol. armon. j.
Spec. Diatrag. frigid. js. Syr. Roar. ice. Myrtin. an. q. . fiat Eclegma; and let the Patient keep this in his mouth. If the Wound be large, narrow it with a Stitching, or part thereof, and with a deep Suture, applying over it Empl. Barbarum; or this Medicine: . Terebinth. lot. in aqu. Conolid. major. s. Vitell. Ov. no. j. Matich. Cort. Thur. an. j. Croc. s. mice. And this procuring a fair Cicatrice, next apply a Sarcotick Powder, which is to be prinkled upon the Wound, for filling it up with fleh. Hippocrates doth write, That the Greater Centaury and Terra Sigillata are of great virtue, being inwardly precribed, in thee Wounds.
To conclude this, take thee Examples:

p.U: aith, That he cured one who being in Prion, wounded himelf with a harp Knife in the Throat, which Wound penetrated the Wind-pipe, o large that one might put his Finger into the Wound, o as both his Nutriment which he took, and the Medicines which he received, came out by the Wound, and yet this Man was in few days recovered.

div.p: Another. I in this City cured an old Woman, who in a melancholick & deperate humour was reolved to cut her own Throat; and for compleating this, having a Pen-Knife by her, ending her Daughter out, without mitruting any uch matter, he continued ome while abroad before he returned; her Daughter being gone, he hut the Door, and tabb'd her elf o in the Throat, that the Wind-pipe was penetrated; he bled very much: I being ent for, eeing her bleed very plentifully, I topt the Flux; and the econd Dreing I dret her with a Digetive, much according to that which I have already et down; then I filled the Wound up with fleh, and skinned it up; applying a Candle to the Wound, you might eaily ee its flame to yield to the wind which came from the wounded Part.

Another. And this is worthy note which Bodinus in Theatro Naturae mentioneth lib. 4. pag. 460. why uch who have their Larynx wounded, do both loe their Tate and Speech; where he writes, That Gulielmus Prince of Orange, having received a Wound in his Neck, had lot the Sene of Tating; and that a French Souldier by the like Wound became mute. There is a double Nerve inerted in the Larynx, which arieth from the 3d Conjugation, one part whereof doth make the Tongue apt for Speech, the other part for perception of Smelling or Sapour.

Another. Another having received a Wound in the Apera Arteria, the Wound being obliquely made, divided 3 Cartilages, inomuch as the Patient could hardly make a noie or peak; the Wound was titcht up, and then was applied this following Medicine: . Thur. Matich. Pulvis. an. j. Bol. armen. ij. Farin. volatil. s. mice. Thee being beaten up with the white of an Egg, and made into the form of a oft Cataplame, was applied to the wounded Part with convenient Ligatures. Inwardly was precribed him ome Lohoc Sanum, and he left it the 3d day, in which time did arie a mot intene Fever, and a great Inflammation of the Fauces, and when the Parts were unrouled, they were een correpted with a Gangrene and Sphacelus, and in that day about night the Patient hut up his lat minute.

I hall not add to this Dicoure, Wounds either of Veins or Arteries, but hall rather deire you to cat your eye on my Treatie next to Wounds of the Heart; for as the Arteries have their Originations from the Heart, I hall refer you thither for the Cure of thee, that being their Origination, this place as others but their Inertions, and the Cure of any of thee not differing, be they wounded in what part of the Body oever.

div.head: CHAP. LIII.
Of Wounds of the Oeophagus.
div.p:
WE come next to the Oeophagus or Gullet, called by the Greeks
< in non-Latin alphabet > , from < in non-Latin alphabet > , which ignifies to carry Meat. The Arabians call it Meri and vecet; the Latines, Gula, being as the common road, or as we have it in our Englih Proverb, Gutterlane, to conduct Victuals from the Mouth into the Stomach. It begins at the lowermot Cavity of the Throat, at the Roots of the Orifice of the Stomach; it marcheth in a direct Line along the 5th Spondyl of the Bret, Its Connexion.omewhat inclining to the right ide. In its Origination it's tyed to the Throat, by that Coat which incompaeth the Mouth, to the Ventricle by its Continuation, to the Bodies of the Spondyls, to the Weazon and adjacent Parts by the help of Membranes. Its Figure is Its Figure and Subtance.round and long. Its Subtance is of a middle ubtance between Fleh and Nerves. It hath allowed it 3 Coats, one common, and two proper: The firt is bred out of Its 3 Coats.Ligaments, made as its Cae for the two proper Coats: The 2d is flehy and thick, looking towards the Neck, having in it only tranvere Fibres: The 3d is of a diimilar Subtance, within whoe inward Superficies is upertrated a mooth and oleaginous Veil, having in it right and lender Fibres, to draw nourihment after the Mouth hath received it. The act of Deglutition is helped by its Mucles, but thee are accounted amongt the Mucles of the Larynx. Its Cavity is always kept moit by its Glandules called Tonillae. It hath but few Veins and Arteries. Its Nerves are notable, coming from the 6th pair, and thee at length are fatned into the Stomach.
It's of great Ue, being as a Tunnel to let through both Its Ue.Meat and Drink.

Thus have I hewn you how the Oeophagos is placed between the Fauces and the Os Ventriculi, being as its general Receiver, being framed both of a nervous and flehy Subtance; nervous, that it may extend it elf upon occaion; and flehy, that it may fall again.
Wounds happening here are very perillous, becaue both Meat and Drink do pas through it, which do hinder Agglutination.

Wounds here happening may be known by their Site, ometimes by the Sene of Feeling; for this is carried in a direct and trait Line all along, under or beneath the Wind-pipe, and when this is wounded, either Blood or Matter is vomited, and the indigeted Nutriment doth ometimes pas through the Wound. When the Patient lyes down, he feeleth much pain between his Scapula's, but upon traightning his Neck he feels ome eae. When any Tumour doth arie here, it doth narrow the paage, and doth occaion a Fever, and a great ene of Inflammation. Hence therefore in thee dangerous caes Celus advieth the Chirurgeon, to tudy and conider which of thee Wounds are curable, which hard to cure, and which are incurable; and not to undertake the lat, but with honety to acquaint the Patient's Relations and Friends of the deperatenes of the Hurt, left he by his improvidence and inconideratenes gain the dicredit of being either ignorant or deceitful.

Cure. Thee Wounds ometimes do prove lethal, the meat and drink paing hereby, hindring agglutination; and although the bet which happens here may not be reckoned without hazard and danger, yet being by daily Experience atisfied, that many here wounded have been cured, is encouragement enough for us to declare the method here to be ued. And here by Hippocrates's authority we are to precribe inwardly a gentle and
thin Dyet, this by degrees to be taken; here therefore the Patient is to lye downwards, holding the Medicine in his mouth as long as he can; for a perpetual Matication in the mouth doth much detard Agglutination. Let his Dyet be liquid, and nourihing, if it might happen here to you as it hath to ome others, that deglutition is altogether ablated, that nothing may decend this way into the Stomach, in thee caes that the Patients may not famih, we ought to inject nourihing Clyters according to the advice of Oribaius and Aetius: if need requires your aitance of prohibiting the flux of Blood which may happen here, in this cae may you afely ue Troch. de Spod. or Terr. Lemn. attenuated with a little Purlane-water, or Spawn-water. Or if thee be not in readines, to take ome Chalybeated Water, which is to be ued as the other.

If here we hould come to Deterging, we may afely Decoction.ue Hydromel or Julap. Roar. Or this Decoction, . Herb. Sanicul. Centaur. Minor. Equiet. an. iij. Hord. Mundat. M. ij. Paular. Jujubar. Liquirit. an. vj. Coquantur Omnia in aquÃ¢ ChalybeatÃ¢ & vino imul mixt. ad Tert. part. conumpt. colaturae adde Syr. Roar. iij. Mel. Roar. ij. iterum parum ebulliant & cola. But where you ue Honey, Galen advieth not to boyl this, but rather to add it in the end; for boyling of it doth make it more rancid. When you would ue Incarnatives or Sarcoticks, then are we here to add Agglutinatives. And in Unguent.this cae Empl. Sanctum is admirable, formerly hown you: Or in the want thereof, to ue this, . Terebinth. Clar. aqu. Conolid. lot. iij. Pulv. Myrrh. Thur. Alo. Bol. armen. an. s. mice & fiat Unguent. Or this, . Thur. Another. Myrrh. Terr. Lemn. Galban. an. iij. Chalcit. Alumin. Roch. Spum. Argent. an. ij. Rein. Terebinth. x. Ol. Myrtin. j. Cer. flav. q. . fiat Unguent. Thee to be applyed without Tents or Lint, over which may be applyed Empl. Diapalma de Betonica, or the like.

Another. To conclude this, A Saylor being wounded by a broad Knife in the 5th Vertebre, vomited a great Quantity of blood, and in his Vomiting ome part of the Chyle which was contained in his Stomach paed out of the Wound, whence was upected that the Oeophagos was hurt; it being examined by the Probe, did evince the ame. For which was precribed this Medicine, . Terebinth. aliquot. lot. in aqu. Malv. j. Syr. de Ro. icc. iij. Digetivism. Bol. armen. j. Sang. Dracon. Matich. Farin. Volatil. an. j. Med. Vitell. Ovor. mice. Tents being herewith armed, were put into the Wound, over which was applyed Empl. Diapalma, inwardly did he take this following Lohoc, . Syr. de Ro. Sicc. Cydonior. an. j. Myrtin. vj. Lohoc. Pulv. Sang. Dracon. iij. Bol. armen. j. mice. After which was ordered this following Decoction, . Hord. A Conolidating Decoction. mundat. M. j. Bulliant in . q. aqu. ad Crepat. add. Herb. Hyper. Piloell. Alchymil. an p. iij. Pirol. Conol. Sarracen. an. pug. ij. Cort. Granator. j s. Rad. Pentaphyl. Tormentil. an. ij. Sem. Coriandr. praeparat. Ani. an. ij. Cinamom. iij. Coquantur omnia imul, & colaturam erva ad uum. Of which Decoctionhe took 3 ounces a day with the aforeaid Syrups: Part of which was injected into the Wound by a Syringe; in the interim he was perplexed with much Pain and Inflammation, an Inunction being made of the Oyl of Roes, over which was applyed a Cataplame made of the Crums of Bread with milk, the yolk of an Egg and the like; this to be ued to the 14th day: The meat and drink which he took inwardly was thin, and flowed out of the Wound; and the 15th day being expired, no further Matter pat out: hence the Oeophagus being judged to be conolidated and agglutinated, the Tent from that time being made horter, was at length covered with an Incarnative, and the Wound in 24 dayes perfectly Cured and Cicatriced.

div.head: CHAP. LIV.
Of Wounds of the Spine.
div.p: NExt arrive we to Wounds of the Spine, or the Backbone eated in the back-part of the Neck; if the Wound do not pas the Spine, it then doth divide the Mucles, and in this cae are you to dres this Wound as you do thoe of the flehy parts, as Aquapendens orders, fol. 913. De Vuln. If the Bone be injured by the Wound, dres this as you do a Fracture in Cranio. If the Spinalis Medulla be wounded, it is either wholly or in part divided. Preage.If it be wholly divided, it occaions a perfect reolution of the Body, cauing here a deprivation both of Sene and Motion: If it be but cut or divided in part, hence followes Convulion, and oft-times death. In thee caes therefore are to be applyed uch Medicines as may eae Pain, top or prevent Convulion, and cure the Patient. Wounds here happening, are of no les danger than thoe of the Brain; for the Spinal Marrow hath its Origination from thence, and has its Coats covered with the ame Membranes as do cover the body of the Brain. It hath Nerves allowed it for yielding it much Sene; and its Motion and Sene it hath from the ame Principals: And ince Topicks can carce reach it, and the direful Symptomes which attend thee Wounds, as Paley, Convulion, Deprivation of Sene and Motion, and the like, thee Wounds may be well reckoned dangerous.

Hippocrates doth reckon them Lethal, yet that uch have been cured, Experience doth evince: And how to cut this part, be pleaed to take with you thee Directions: In all deperate caes of this ort, our later Practitioners, the Blood being topt, do ue hot and dry Medicines, being of thin parts, that they may the better penetrate
into the depth of the Wound; and therefore in thee caes we are to ue uch Medicines as be of a thin, liquid, and moyt ubtance; of which ort are Ol. Hyperic. Ol. Lumbricor. and the like. Or here alo may be ued Ol. Chamomil. Vulpin. Ovor. Matichin. Terebinth. or the like. Or . Ol. Hyperic. Ovor. an. j. Terebinth. s. Theriac. Andromach.
ij. mice. Or . Ol. Vulpin. Lumbricor. Terebinth. an. s. pulv. Matich. s. mice. Turpentine here is a very good Medicine, being well waht, adding to it the yolk of an Egg, a little fine Powder of Frankincene & Saffron, the which may be ued to the 4th day, anointing all the circumjacent parts with Oyl of Roes, Chamomile and Matich. The 4th day being pat, adde to thee ome Syrup of dry Roes, Myrrh, and Aloes, in that body and thicknes as they caue no pain in the Wound by their aperity; the which being done, leave out the Turpentine: the pain being awaged, cover the Wound either with Aureum or Bailicon, or the like, applying over it Empl. De Betonica or Diapalma, and then procure a Cicatrice.

Foret. fol. 18. lib. 6. Ob. Chir. writes, That if the Spinal Marrow be wounded about its beginning, death mut necearily follow, becaue a Convulion of the whole Body doth ucceed: but if it be wounded in the lower part, this is not o deadly, unles the Wound be large, or made by apuncture, although Convulion doth ucceed it.

Foretus, Ob. 46. lib. 6. fol. 230. writes of one being Hitory.wounded under the Scapula in the Back, the Wound penetrating the Thorax and Spine; at the which time a Wound happened in the flexure of the Cubit of his Arm; hence he pit much blood, which denoted that the Wound had penetrated the Thorax in its back-part, and he threw forth concrete blood downwards. He being called to this Patient, for diverion ake in the Arm of the contrary ide breathes a vein, and the Wounds were thus handled by Petrus a Chirurgeon of Delph, and Gerard
the Younger: Preently after the breathing of his Bailick Decoction.Vein, this Decoction was precribed him; . Caul. Bab. Scabios. Veronic. Cap. Vener. Polytric. Ungul. Caballin. an. M. j. Hord. mundat. pug. j. Raur. Liquirit.
vj. Uvar. paul. enucl. j. Jujub. Sebat. an. no. 5. Coquantur in aqu. Com. ad lb j. Colaturae Syr. Cap. vener. j s. Violar. Jujub. an. s. mice pro Apozemate, to be taken twice in a day. Eclegma.For his Cough he was Ordered this Eclegma, as alo for his pitting of blood; . Con. Borag. Diatrag. frigid. an.
iij. Syr. Cap. Vener. j. Syr. Violar. Jujub. an. s. mice. This he took oft-times with the end of a Lyquirice-tick well beaten and bruied: after this he began to grow Feverih, and therefore his Breat was embrocated, not onely for removing the pain, but alo for dipatohing this Unguent.febrile heat, with this following Unguent; . Unguent. Decoct. Reumptio. j. Afterwards he took of this following Decoction at his pleaure, . Hord. Commun. M. j. Liquirit. Ra. s. Cap. Vener. Uvar. paar. an. M. s. Sem. 4. frigid. Major. an. s. Cicer. Rubr.
j. Coquantur in aqu. com. ad lb j. Colatur. addendo Syr. ex infu. Roar. Violar. an. s. pro Julapio. With thee and the like inward Decoctions, the Patient recovered of his deplorable Condition, and was cured of his 3 Wounds: And for the mundifying and incarning thereof, this was ued, . Mel. Roat. Empl. Lanfranci. Colat. iiij. Farin. Hord. s. Terebinth.
iij. Cer. Rein. an.
ij. Thur. Matich. an.
j. Myrrh. Sarcocoll. Mum. an. ss. Ol. Matich.
iij. M. fiat Empl. Thus have I run through all the Wounds which do or may happen in the upper Region; We decend now to the middle Venter, where we hall Expres all the Parts, their Wounds, Signs, Preages and Cures.

div.head: CHAP. LV.
Of Wounds of the Thorax.
div.p:
But to fall upon its harms; before we enter upon the Dicoure whereof, be pleaed to conider what noble Parts it containeth in it, and enwraps. It's outwardly guarded with Intercotal Mucles, interwoven between the Ribs, and filling up the Ditances between them; and thee by ome are reckoned to be in all 44, thee alo being of great ue, being formed obliquely; for we generally ee that they help Dilatation; for every thing retcheth which is obliquely made or obliquely drawn; thee Mucles, by the general opinion and conent of all Anatomits, do erve for Contriction and Dilatation of the Thorax. Next may we meet here with a Diaphragma, which ignifies to ditinguih, this ditinguihing the Intruments of Nourihment, from thoe of Life and Repiration, or is as an overthwart partition. After this appears a Pleura, o called from the Ribs, which by the Greeks are called < in non-Latin alphabet > , this being tretched under them all, excepting the 12th. This Membrane doth incloe the whole Cavity of the Thorax, and doth anwer its Figure and Magnitude. This is all over double, partly becaue of the hardnes of the Bones, and
partly becaue betwixt both the Membranes, the Intercotal Veels might more afely pas. Next this is Mediatinum, o called from dividing the Chet in the middle. Columbus doth call it Interepimentum, being as a Hedge dividing two Patures. This holds up the Heart, and erves as a ecurity for the paage of the Veels. After this may we ee the Pericardium, by the Latines called Capula Cordis, enwrapping the Heart, and carrying in it its Pyramidal Figure, ariing from its Bais, produced from the Coats which the Pleura doth afford the four Veels, which do iue out of the Heart. Its contained Parts are double, as Veels and Bowels: The Bowels are two, the Heart and the Lungs: The Veels are the Branches of the great Vein, and the great Artery, born up into the hollow part of the Throat with a glandulous Body called Thymus.
But becaue I intend not to trouble you with thee twice over, I hall as I dicoure of thee Parts being wounded, give you a brief Deciption of every of them as they fall in their Order.
And firt as touching Wounds which may happen in the outward part of the Thorax.

Wounds here happening are either allowed to penetrate or not penetrate the Thorax; and uch as do penetrate, may either be made with or without offence; and this offence may be manifold, as either wounding the Heart, Lungs, Pericardium, Diaphragma, great Artery, or acendent Vein.

Signs. To know a penetrating Wound may be by thee Signs manifeted: If the Wound penetrates far, the ending in your Probe or earching Candle will give ome atisfaction hereof; or if it penetrates Cotton or Wool being put to the Wound, you hall ee it give way to the Breath which comes out of the Wound. If the Patient doth hut his Mouth and keep in his Breath, the Wind will break through the Wound with a noie, o as a
Candle being applied to the Orifice, the Wind will diipate the flame of the Candle. Yet ometimes if the Wound happens near the Mouth of the Bret, Air may come forth, and the Probe may pas a great way in repect of the great pace and Cavity, which makes the interepient Membranes, eparating and ditinguihing the Cavity of the Thorax.

Preage. Wounds happening in the back-part of the Thorax, are mot dangerous, becaue in this Part are planted mot Nerves and Tendons; and as Hippocrates writes, Every Wound of the Thorax goes not without danger, in repect of the Matter which falls down into the Cavity thereof. If the Heart be wounded, the cae is deperate; or if the Diaphragma in its nervoe Part, or if the Lungs be largely wounded, or the Pericardium. But more of thee in their proper places.

Arcaus cap. 1. de Curand. Vuln. fol. 71. writes, That he hath een many pretend the curing penetrating Wounds of the Thorax, the which they either carce obtained, or ele peedily after procured the death of their Patients, although thee Wounds were not of their own nature lethal. And whereas it is the general opinion of all Authors, Wounds deeply penetrating the Bret, are for the mot part incurable, and that uch who have gained ground of thee Wounds, do generally labour under a Phthyis, or a perpetual Fitula; yet ome have been cured hereof without either of thee. And for curing thee Wounds, let this be your Method: In not penetrating Wounds, the ame Cure is to be ued here as you are directed in a imple Wound. In a penetrating Wound the ordering of the whole Body is to be regarded, both for the evacuating and dicharging of Blood, Humours, Matter, or Excrements, which may fall from the wounded Part into the Cavity of the Thorax, let being therein left, they corrupt and putrifie, and o bring death in the end: And thee may be 3 ways dicharged; as either
by the Orifice of the Wound, by the Mouth and Coughing, or by Urine. Now when Blood or Matter is coacervated in the Cavity of the Thorax, it is attended with pains of the Sides, and a heavines about the fale Ribs, accompanied with purulent Spattles, a fetid Breath, and a troubleom Cough, and a Fever moleting the Patient. And hence becaue the outward Air being altogether unprepared, doth ruh and pas hither, it doth much offend the inward Parts, and the inward Air paing out hereby, doth both weaken, hurt and diolve the trength and vigour of the Parts. And another ill Symptom which attends thee Wounds, is, they cannot outwardly or conveniently be deterged, and hence they degenerate into Fitula's and Empyema's, exciting there their purulent Collections, and hence death follows. And uch who upon receiving a Wound here, have annexed therewith a Vomiting and Syncope, or Loones, death is ure to catch hold of thee.

But to return to the 3 former propoed Intentions, beginning firt with the dicharge by Urine. And in thee The Firt.caes the Medicines here to be ued are called Diureticks: And Gal. lib. 5. de Loc. affect. writes and affirms, That thoe things which are lodged in the Thorax, are to be carried off and expurged by Urine. And hence he uppoeth that the Matter is firt carried into the Branches of the Vena Azygos, hence into the Vena Cava, to the right Ventricle of the Heart, and paing thence downwards from the decending Trunk of the Cava to the Liver, to come to the Emulgents. But this is a great way about. But Nicol. Novocomenis an excellent Phyitian aith, That it paeth from the Vena ine Pari near the Diaphragma, and is carried by a direct ducture through the Spine to the Emulgents, and doth give us this Hitory, for the better crediting of the former:

Hitory. Of a Friend of his which received a Wound in his Thorax: The Wound was not by the Phyitians found
penetrating, becaue in repect of the narrownes of the Orifice, no great part of the Probe did enter into the Wound; the fleh alo topt the Cavity thereof, o as neither pirit or breathing might pas through it; yet out of the upervening accidents the Wound was conjectured to be penetrant; for above the Diaphragma was felt a heavines, he pit blood, with Coughing, accompanied with Fever, Watchings, and ometimes the Part appeared blewih about the Ribs, wherein was contained Matter. And for this dicharge, they conulted to open the Thorax between the 6th and 7th Rib; the day before which this hould have been done, it happened, that the Patient let forth about an ounce and a half of bloody Matter, by which he was freed from all his pain, Fever, and other Symptoms; in which caes were ued thee Diureticks. Thee being preent, was precribed him a Decoction made of Maiden-hair, Parly-roots and Betony; and if no Fever was preent, to the former was added Smallage and Fennel. In his Diet is to be oberved, That in thee Wounds all Inflammation be abated, and for this was given him Ptyan, with cold Seeds.

The 2d Way. The 2d way is the dicharge of this Matter by the Mouth; and for this Ue Poca being taken lukewarm, is good; Vinegar doth wonderfully dicus and diolve the concrete Blood; and Galen ordereth to obtund its Acrimony, by adding much Water to it; in this cae cooling Syrups do well, and do work by Urine. Here alo are we advied to oberve, That if the Patient do cough much, to make it more eaie to him, we may order him Syrup of Lyquirice, Oxymel, or Syrup of Vinegar.

The 3d Way. The 3d is performed by the Orifice of the Wound, the which ome will have peedily to be hut up, let hereby the vital pirit might expire and pend it elf, and the outward Air paing in at the Wound may corrupt the inward Parts. Yet this is contrary to Sene, Reaon
and Experience; for the Wound is to be kept open, for this Matter is not eaily or readily to be dicharged by Urine, nor yet emptied out by the Mouth, the Orifice of the Wound being the bet and mot ready way to dicharge the ame; and this is to be performed by Tents or Pipes.
Intentions. But to come cloe to the genuine Intentions herein required, and afterwards hew you how this is to be treated:

And herein are 6 Intentions which offer themelves: As firt, To top the Flux of Blood. 2dly, To prevent all Fluxion. 3dly, To dicharge the contained Matter. 4thly, To deterge and dry up the Wound. 5thly, To order the inward Parts aright. And then latly, To prevent all other Accidents.

As for the firt, I have ufficiently already enlarged. But becaue here ome of the concrete Blood may be lodged in the Cavity of the Thorax, this is both necearily and peedily to be uppurated. And hence therefore Wounds of the Thorax are preently to be agglutinated, or kept open, being conentaneous in a Cut where the great Veins and Arteries are untoucht, and when no Flux of Blood doth appear here to peed Agglutination, either by Suture or Ligature, or any other ingenious method; for thus the Parts may be united, and the innate Heat preerved, and the Matter dicharged by the Mouth. But if there be any upition of coagulated or concreted Blood, the Wound is to be kept open, for the dicharge of all Matter and Excrements: And for this Ue ome do make ue of leaden Pipes, which they have made for the ame purpoe, to convey and draw forth this Matter, called by the Greeks Piuleus, or Eductorium; the Matter being dicharged, the Parts are to be united and dried up.

But a little further, as touching the coagulated Blood, it being a matter of great concern in this place: Here are
we not to tudy too peedy an unition of the Parts, until every ill Juyce or Matter be expurged and dicharged. The Wound therefore, as I formerly have writ, is to be kept open by Tents, both for the preerving the noble and ignoble Parts entire. Hence ought the careful Chirurgeon to examine well the affected Parts, and then to the dicharge of the Matter; this is to be done by its proper places; the Blood being uppreed, the Wound is to be roul'd up.

The 2d Intention. The next Intention here required, is, in great and deep Wounds to hinder all Humidities or Humours, coming from any other Part of the Body to the affected Part; and this is to be performed by breathing a Vein, and Purgation, Cupping-glaes, Ligatures, and the like, as I have already hewn.

The 3d Intention. The 3d Intention is the dicharge of Humours and Matter lodged in the Cavity of the Thorax; and for this Ue take this: . Rein. Pin. Vic. Querein. Mel. Ammoniac. Galban. an. ij. Cer. ij. liquecat Cera, potea Reina, tunc adde pulv. Aritoloch, Rot, Rad. Conolid. major. an. Unguent.s. & fiat Unguent. Or . Ferment. acr. Axung. Porc. Empl. Another. Empl. Sanctum. an. ij. paular, enucleat, j. Terebinth. venet. iij. Ammoniac. Galban. an. s. Cor. q. . fiat Empl. Or this Unguentum Sanctum, o much eteemed for its admirable qualities which it hews in this Cure, for it doth excellently diget and trengthen the Parts, and dicharge every Excrement afely from the very bottom. This is its Compoition: . Rein. Pin. recent. clar. & odorat. xij. Ol. Laurin. opt. Terebinth. venet. an. ij. Gum. Elemni iiij. miceantur Reina & Gummi imul, & lento igne liquefiant emper agitando cum Spatha, tunc adde Ol. Laurini & Terebinth. & iterum parum bulliant, emper movendo ad Empl. formam. And when you apply this to the wounded Part, let it be pread all over the circumjacent Parts.

In ome caes Injections are alo very beneficial; neither are externals, but internals alo very requiite. I
have already enlarged on this ubject in my Treatie of Tumours, there dicouring of Empyemaes; and therefore hall abbreviate here. The Matter being dicharged, the place is to be mundified with Mellicrate; and if you deire a greater dryer, add hereto Agrimony, Centaury, Adders Tongue, Betony, in Wine adding to the trained Decoction a little Honey; this to be injected into the part. If a plenty of Matter appear, and thee be too weak, we are to give inward Potions and Decoctions, as this; Decoction.. Caryophylat. Rad. Artheme. Pimpinell. Pentaphyll. Violar. Caul. Rub. an. j. Rub. Tinctor. caeter. quantitas Coquantur in vino.

Theophratus doth much commend thee, as Sanicle, Avens, Perwinckle, Trefol. and Ground Ivy, being boyled in white Wine, adding to the clear Decoction a little Honey; and of this let the Patient drink 4 ounces three times in a day warm.

There was an Old Emprick who in all Chronick Ditempers and old fitulated Wounds ued this Decoction; Decoction.. Cinnamon. Zinz. Caryoph. Piper. an. iij. Coquantur contu. in menur. 6 vini albi u
que ad 3tiae partis conumpt. coletur & ervetur. tune Recipe Caryophylat. Valerian. Piloell. Centaur. minor. Rub. Tinctor. Artheme. Pimpinel. an. M. s. Exiccantur & fiat omnium pulvis ubtilisimus, accipe hujus Pulveris ij. Decoct. praedict. vj. to be taken the firt thing every morning; And by this method he cured very many of thee Wounds without any other help.

Powder. This Powder ued for the ame effect is very admirable; . Caul. Rub. em. Cunap. conolid. minor. Caryophylat. Piloell. an. M. j. Rub. Tinctor. M. ij. mice, fiat pulvis ubtilisimus do. j. in vino albo. While thee are inwardly taken, the outward Wound is to be brought to digetion by Turpentine, the yolk of an Egg, a little Frankincene, Bailicon, and a little Powder of Saffron; and if you intend to mundifie, add a little Honey and mix
with the former; then fill up with Unguent. Aureum or Fucum, and skin with Diapalma or Deiccativum Rubrum. Having thus run through all the general Parts and Intentions of Wounds of the Thorax, give me leave a little further to hew how the Patient is to be placed, the Patient being laid in his bed, tretched out to his full length, and the Orifice of the Wound downwards, let him thus continue untill the Chirurgeons dreings be all ready, hereby endeavouring to dicharge all contained blood by Coughing or the like. Then put into the Wound a Flamula or Silver Pipe, uch as are ued in a Paracentheis, dipt in the white of an Egg, having a tay on both ides hollowed to receive a thread; and this is to be ued untill the Matter doth abate: when this affords but a mall quantity, procure a peedy Conolidation either with Linimentum Arcaei, who is the Author and Director of this method, or Balam. Peruvian. or any other the like Conolidating Medicine, over which apply Diapalma: Thee things being done, you may, if occaion require, breathe a Vein, and then adminiter Potion.this Vulnerary Potion; . Rhubarb. s. Rub. Tinctor. Mum. an. j. Terr. Sgillat. s. Aqu. Scabio. Buglos. & Decoction. Succ. granator. an. j. After this he advieth this Decoction; . Hord. mundat. iiij. Paular. enucleat. iij. Rad. Buglos. iij. Liquirit. contu. iij. Jujub. no. 20. prunor. no. 15. Rad. Petroilin. contu. M. j. fiat Decoct. in aqu. Pluvial. lb 14. ad Conumpt. tertiae partis. Aromatizetur decoctum cum Cinamom. iij. et Coletur. in ColaturÃ¢ olve Penid. iij. Syr. Roar. Simpl. de 2. Radic. ine acet. an. ij. Sacchar. condit. iiij. of which the Patient is to take 6 ounces every 4th hour, he being ordered to take no other food for 3 dayes. And to conclude this Dicoure, when the Patient doth breathe freely, findeth little pain, and no weight about his Midriff, and the Quitture be mall and laudible, then is it time to hut up. And I with it hall hut up this Dicoure with ome Hitorical Obervations.

Hitory. The firt is of a Gentleman, who having received 3 large Wounds, but the chiefet of which happened under his right Bret, penetrating deeply between the pace of the Thorax, whence happened a large Flux of Blood into the Diaphragma, upon which ucceeded a Fever and vehement Coughing, with a harp pain in the wounded Side. I being called, I ordered the Patient to lye with his Head downwards, and to hut both his Mouth, Eyes and Ears, hereby forcing the Lungs to end forth the contained blood by the Wounds. After this I put my finger into the Wound for the better educing of this blood, the Patient being laid into his Bed again, I injected frequently into his Wound a Decoction made of French Barley, Honey of Roes, and Red Sugar at firt; afterwards I added more of deterging Medicines, as Wormwood, Centaury and the like: but thee, becaue of their bitternes were oon left off.

Another. Glandorp, fol. 139. in his Book named Specul. Chirurgor. Oberv. 26. relates of a Young Man, who being wounded between the 6th and 7th Rib, out of which iued much blood, and a Pungetive pain followed in the ame Side, Sarcoticks being hereto applyed, Matter was generated, the which at the 12th day was not dicharged out of the Wound: The 14th, 15th and 16th dayes he made no water; the day following he made Urine with pain, in which was een Sanguinolent Matter. Whence was conjectured, That Nature had found out a new way, Diureticks being given him, and an opening Dyet precribed, this Matter pat by the Urine to the 8th day; the which appearing no further, the Wound was Conolidated, and the Patient Cured.

Another. Foretus, fol. 76. Ober. Chir. Ob. 16. writes of a Young Man of 16 years of age, who having a naked Knife in a Bagg held under his Coat, and not remembring it, wretling with another Boy, wounded himelf, by receiving a Fall from him, in his Breat; whence iued a
very large Flux of Blood: Having drank this following Potion.Potion he began to amend; . fol. Colluteae
iij. infunde in aqu. Plantagin. Ungul. Caballin. Semel. Ebulliendo, et forti expresioni adde Electuar. de Succ. Roar.
ij. Pulv. Rhubarb. Nuc. Mochat. Mum. an. s. Mel. Roar. Colat. s. mice, fiat Potio. After the taking of which, the Wound in a hort time Conolidated. This Potion is very admirable for the diolving and expelling of concrete blood. If you deire to atisfie your elf further hereof, Francicus Arcaeus will give you many other Hitories of thee Wounds and their Cure, in his Book De Vulneribus Capit. fol. 71. 85. and o on: The which I commit you to, deiring not to fill up this Treatie of Wounds with too many Hitories.

div.head: CHAP. LVI.
Of Wounds of the Diaphragma.
div.p:
THis by Plato is called < in non-Latin alphabet > , of a word which doth ignifie to ditinguih by ome Septum tranverum. It is a Mucle erving for Repiration, and doth differ from all the Mucles of the Body in its excellency, ite, figure, and action. It is eated in the Cavity of the Body, being o'rethwart and oblique; it's Nervous in the midt, and that partly for the more ecurity that it may perform its various motions without hurt; and partly that the Vena Cava, and Oeophagus which do pas through it might not be treightned, and o the coure of meat and blood hindred. It is united to two of the mucles of the Abdomen, the Oblique Acendent, and Tranvere; Its figure is almot Circular. It hath Veins, Nerves and Arteries allowed it. It is of much ue,
for it ventilates the Hypochondria, helps forwards Expulion, and doth ditinguih the noble from the ignoble parts; and that which is oberved by ome, in ingle Combats of Gladiators, ome have been een to dye laughing, being wounded in this part, and eeing we have already hewn you how it is, a round and capacious Mucle, ubtended to the inward ide of the Ribs, tyed to them, being in the upper part flehy, and in the lower part membranous and permatique, receiving a Wound hereupon being the Intrument of breathing, it ends forth froathy blood, a thin pirit, the Spine mourns hereat, and the principal bowels are drawn upwards; if the Wound be large, running the part into Inflammation, the breathing is very dull, accompanied with pain through all the parts of the Shoulder, a great Cough ucceeds with noie and pain, the pattle looks livid, a vomiting and pitting of froathy blood follows: And they which are thus troubled do eat with great difficulty: The neighbouring parts haring of thee evil excrementitious juices and humidities are attracted hereby, hence diturbing the whole frame of the Mind, hence follows Delirium; and for this very reaon the Ancients called this part Phrenes: hereupon happening a violent Fever ariing by the great conent of the Heart, Wounds here happening, if they penetrate not too far, are with great Care and Difficulty to be Cured, not hindring its motion. If it happen in the Nervous parts that a Wound falls hereon, here may you declare the Cure either hopeles or helples; thee are the general Signs and Preages which do attend thee Wounds. If the flehy part of the Diaphragma, as we have already offered, be wounded, it may be cured with care; and here are we firt to top the Flux of blood, and to prevent Inflammation by well regulating the whole Body, and to agglutinate the Wound with all convenient peed; yet not untill all Blood and Matter be dicharged; hence breathing of a
Vein for Revulion is proper. As touching Topicks, we may here ue the ame Medicines as are directed in Wounds of the Thorax, uch as may top a Flux of blood, prevent Inflammation, and agglutinate; the Orifice to be kept open by a Tent or a Silver Pipe, as is already directed; and the ame Intentions and Medicines which are already precribed.
And for further atisfaction, I will here preent you with the Method how to Cure thee, being directed by Glandorp, who is the Author of this following Hitory.

Hitory. A Saylor receiving a Wound in the flehy part of his Diaphragma, in the left part thereof, about the end of the 11th Rib of the Thorax, within few dayes he was perplexed with great pains of his head, and of the wounded ide, neither could he breathe freely; its depth was earch'd by the Probe, and it was conjectured that the Wound did penetrate; A Vein in the ame Side was Breathed, and a convenient Dyet precribed, and Unguent.this following Unguent was precribed for his Side; . Unguent. Pectoral. s. Dialth. cum gum. Ol. Roar. an.
iij. Croc. s. mice, into the Wound was put a long Tent armed with a Digetive, and over this was applyed Empl. Diapalmae. Inwardly did he take this Vulnerary Decoction.Decoction; . Herb. Sanicul. Veronis. Pirol. an. P. iiij. Conolid. Saracenn. Botrys Trichoman. an. pug. ij. Fl. Borag. Buglos. an. P. j. Sem. ani. Eoenicul. an.
ij. Cinamom.
iij. Fujub. no. 6. Dactyl. no. 4. Coquantur in aquÃ¢ Hordei q. . Of which he took 3 ounces with 2 cruples of Powder of Crabs eyes, the Body being bound, ometimes the Patient received a Suppoitory, ometimes he took a Lenient by his mouth. Matter being generated hereby, and the Wound being mundified, the Tents were hortned and armed with an Incarnative, and in a hort time afterwards it was perfectly skinned up.

Another. The Second is of a Wound which happened in the membranous part of the Diaphragma, but this brought
Death with it. A Souldier thruting his Rapier a little under the Xyphoidal Cartilage, hence did arie Pain, and a great Flux of blood, with Syncope, and difficulty of breathing, with pains in his lower Belly about the Pubes, the parts much tumifying above the Navel, and about the Thorax; his Speech failed, and in this Syncope he dyed. The Body being opened, the Orifice of the Stomach, and its left part, and part of the Duodenum, and part of the Colon were found wounded to the Thorax; and the lower Belly, epecially about the Pubes, did abound with grumous blood.

Another. Ambroe Parrey, fol. 230. writes of a Captain, who being wounded by a Bullet, paing by the ends of the Sternon near the Xyphoidal Cartilage, entring through the flehy part of the Diaphragma, and through the Intertitium which lyes between the 5th and 6th Ribs, the Wound being Cicatrized outwards, yet there remained a weaknes of the Stomach, and a pain of the Guts, much like the Collick pain; and Eight moneths after the pain grew very violent, and within a while after he dyes: The Body being open'd by Guillemau, the Collick Gut was een much ditended with Wind; and that this hence did make its paage into the Thorax by the Wound of the Diaphragma, and yet the Wound carce equalled the bignes of a Mans little Finger.
Another. Hollerius Com. ad Aphorim. 16. lib. 6. pronounceth, The Septum Tranverum or Midriff being wounded in its Membranous Part, may not be cured, but in its flehy Part it is cured with eae.
Alexander Benedictus remembers a certain Souldier, who being here wounded, was perfectly recovered.
And Hollerius writes, That he oberved in a Man which was hanged, and was afterwards diected in the Phyick-Schools, that he had had a Wound in the flehy Part of the Diaphragma Cicatrized.

div.head: CHAP. LVII.
Of the Lungs Wounded.
div.p:
THee being the Intruments both of Voice and Breathing, are by the Greeks called Pneumones, upon reception of the Air, which they call Pneuma. And although thee in mot Creatures do hang looe, that they may move more freely, yet by the mediation of the Veels of the Weazon, they are hung to the Neck, and tyed forwards to the Bret-Bone, and backwards to the Spine. And Nature taking care to maintain this Motion, he hath united them to the Pleura, that o by this connexion they might follow the Dilatation of the Chet, though it were perforated. They adhere to the Heart by the Pulmoniack Vein, or Arteria Venoa, and the Vena Arterioa. Their Figure they gain according to the proportion of the Parts of the Chet, being both gibbous and welling. They are divided by a Mediatinum into a right and left, that one Part being hurt, the other might work for both. Their Subtance is looe, pongey and rare, made as it were of frothy Blood. They have allowed them a Membrane bred out of the Pleura. They have 3 Veels deeminated through them; it receives 2 from the Heart, and thee according to the opinion of ome, are to be moved according to the motion of the Lungs, others according to the Heart. Their ue is to aire the Heart in its dilatation, moderately cooling and tempering the heat of the Heart, for want of which the natural heat growes weak. Thee being framed for fanning the Heart, upon being wounded they occaion a difficulty of Breathing; the Blood which here comes forth is pumous or frothy. Sometimes there is perceived a noie or murmuration, the Neck of the
Patient is convelled, the Face inflamed, and then afterwards grows white, and many Changes in a mall time act their Parts here. If the Lungs be inwardly wounded, the Tongue hath a change in its colour, they breathe hort, and cough frequently, the Wound mall, but affording much Matter, they live a good while, but pine away into a Conumption or Myame; for the incied Lungs do beget ill Tempers and Inflammations, the which having once obtained, they leave mall hopes of Agglutination; for upon expiration or inpiration omewhat of Air is received, by which the hurt Parts are offended; and at bet, if Medicines might be allowed a fair reception into the Lungs, yet they mut be moved by inpiration and repiration, and lacerated by Coughs. And where the Veels are wounded which are lodged herein, or the Subtance of the Lungs wounded, thee are generally accounted lethal for everal Reaons, they being in continual motion, moit, and ubject to Inflammation, no Medicines eaily reaching them, a large Flux of Blood attending thee Wounds, and a great part of this Blood mut necearily fall into the Thorax, he which by its weight falling upon the Diaphragma, doth caue hortnes of Breath; and after all, the Heart mut conequently hare with them in their michies, the Lungs having their Veels from thence; yet dangerous Wounds here, have been cured; as we hall afterward hew by example. But to proceed:

Wounds of the Lungs are known by their proper Symptoms. Evacuations being premied, breathing of a Vein is here requiite, and Cupping glaes and Ligatures for revulion of Humours. As to the uperfluities of the Lungs, thee are to be carried off by Purgation, good Diet, and Medicines. And as to Topicks, whether either inwardly adminitred, or outwardly applyed, they ought to be of a drying quality, and of that agglutinative faculty, as may both act its own Part, and
yet not prove mordacious. And here may we oberve, That all Metals or Medicines having a aline quality in them, are not to be ued here, thee being not to be ruled and governed according to the native heat of the Part; uch as are Verdegreae, Burnt Bras, Lead, Cadmia, Cerus, Litharge, Chalcit. Pompholix, and the like. But thee following may afely inwardly be taken, as Succ. Hyppo cyt. Balaut. Malicor. Matich. Gallar. Acac. Terr. Lemn. Bol. armen. Gum. Arabic. Tragag. Centaur. majus, and the like; thee or any of them to be boyled in retringent wine. Andhere by Hippocrates we are advied, That in thee Wounds, and Wounds of the Thorax, we order no Medicine without Honey in it; for this makes its way through, cleanes the Bret, facilitates the Spattle, and brings no hurt to the affected Parts. Troch. Diacod. Tabulat. Roatum, and the like, are very good in thee caes. Potion.Or this admirable Potion: . Caryophylat. Rad. Artheme. Pimpinell. Camom. Pentaphyll. violar. Caul. Rub. Conolid. major. Cimar. Rub. Centaur. minor. Piloell. Fragror. Conolid. minor. fol. Olivar. Verban. Tormentill. Millefol. an. M. j. Rub. Tinctor. Quant. Caeterum coquantur omnia in vino Montan. lb 60. ad med. conumpt. colaturae adde Mel. lbij. of which let the Patient drink morning and night. Troch. Trochicus for the ame: . Sem. Caul. Rub. Sem. Cannab. Tanacet. Rub. Tinctor. Conolid. major. an. part. aequal. pulverientur & in vino odorifero & Sacchar. albiim q . fiant Trochici. Of which let the Patient take j. or ij. morning and evening, which are very beneficial in thee caes. Outwardly may be applied this Unguent: . Minij. xxiv. Pic. naval. iv. Ol. Roar. xx. mice & coquantur Mnguent. ad Unguenti formam, tunc adde Terebinth. venet. ij. mice, fiat Unguentum. In thee Wounds alo thee are very proper: . Caryophylat. Sanicul. Pimpinell. Rub. Piloell. Tormentill. Conolid. utriu
que Centaur. an. M. s. Coquantur in vino & aqu. Plantag. imul mixt. & colaturae adde Syr. Myrtin. or Syr. de Ro. icc. And this way of
Cure is to be ued until all Symptoms diappear, and the Thorax well mundified, and to proceed according to Art gently, for abtergeing, conolidating, and cicatriceing the Wound.

Matthaeas Glandorp. fol. 130. Ob. 24. hath this Obervation of a noble Souldier of 27 years old, being of a anguine Complexion, and a trong habit of Body, who received a Wound between the 6th and 7th Rib of his Thorax, in the left ide thereof; hence iued much pumous Blood, with Wind and Air; from hence did arie alo a Fever and great pain. The Lungs being hurt, and in repect of the Pleura being wounded, he being of a Plethorick Contitution, had the median Vein opened in the ame ide, and 3 hours after was injected this following Clyter: . Rad. alth. j. Mercurial. Violar. Malvar. an. M. j. Botry. Pulmonar. Farfar. an. pug. iij Sem. Lin. Faenugraec. an. s. Ani. Foenicul. an. iij. fl. Cham. Melilot. an. pug. ij. coquantur in aqu. commun. q. . ut colaturam redeat; ad ix. his adde Elect. Lenitivum. j. Diaphoenic. s. Sacchar. x. Ol. Roar. Violar. an. j s. mice. The 2d day did arie a great Cough, but without any pitting of Matter, with pain of the Side, for which was precribed this Liniment: . Unguent. Reumpt. s. Dialth. Liniment. Pectoral. Ol. Amygdal. dulc. an. ij. Croc. s. mice: With which was anointed the whole Thorax. For his Cough was ordered Troch. Bechic. And for the wounded part of the Lungs was directed this Lohoc: . Lohoc. Lohoc. Pulmon. Vulp. an. & expert. an. vj. Syr. de Farfar. de Hyop. Roar. iccar. an. j. Pulv. fol. Hyop. j s. fl. Sulphur bene expurg. iij. Troch. de pod. pulv. s. mice, detur cum Baculo Liquirit. of which he took everal times in a day. For his Drink he took Barley-water, and ometimes 4 ounces of this vulnerary Potion: . Hord. A vulnerary Decoction. mundat. M. j. bulliat in aqu. ad Crepituram, tunc adde Farfar. Scabio. Pulmonar. maculoae an. pug. iij. Sem. Ani. Foenicul. an. j s. Cinam. iij. Injub. no. vj. Uvar. paar.
enucleat in vino ablut. s. Liquirit. pro dulcorat. q. . & erva ad uum. The Wound being narrow was dilated with a crooked Inciion-Knife the 4th day, where was een part of the Lungs hurt; for the which was ordered this Powder: . Pulv. Rad. Tormentill. Bitort. Pimpinell. an. j. Sang. Dracon. ij. Bol. armen. j s. Troch. de Carab. j. fiat omnium pulvis ubtiliimus, which is to be prinkled into the Wound. In the interim a bloody Matter began to flow forth, and the 19th day was precribed Potio purgans.this Lenient: . Mann. Elect. j. Diaphoenic. s. Syr. ex Infu. Roar. vj. Decoct. pectoral. q. . fiat Potio. The pain of the Side began in a hort time to abate, the Efflux of the Matter topped, the Cough abated, the Wound conolidated, and the Patient perfectly recovered.
Another. Gemma lib. 1. Comocrit. Cap. 6. writes, That he aw the Fibres of the Lungs ablated both by Abcees and Wounds, and yet the Patients lived.
And Falloppius writes, That he hath een Inflations of the Lungs cured, and others to have dyed of the ame: Wherefore the Lungs, as he aith, have their equal fates, as he writes de Vulnerib. cap. 12.

Many other good Authors have Rare Hitories of Wounds here happening, the which I mut pretermit, as you may read in Hortius lib. 3. Oberv. De Morb. Pector. Oberv. 11. Arcaeus, lib. 2. cap. 1. Gulielmus Fabritius, Centur. 3. Ob. 36. And Johannes Schenkius in his Book de Obervat. lib. 2. de Vulnerib. Pulmonum. To which I recommend the Ingenious Reader. Next come we to Wounds of the Heart. Beginning with thoe which may happen in its Pericardium.

div.head: CHAP. LVIII.
Of Wounds of the Pericardium.
div.p:
I Shall here alo continue my former Cutome, in giving you a hort Survey of this Membrane, and its Ues, and then fall to its Wounds and Curative Method. It is a Membrane enwrapping the Heart wimming in it, and defending it from Injuries, o far ditant from it as its pulifying actions do require: It arieth at the bais of the Heart, from the common diruptions of the Pleura, outwardly covering the Veels of the Heart. Riolanus will have it a double Membrane; it outwardly adheres to the Mediatinum, in the lower part to the Center of the Diaphragma; it hath mall Arteries given it for its nutrition, mall branches of Nerves it ends forth to the Axillaries, and doth receive mall Nerves from the left recurrent, and the 6th pair paing towards the Heart. It contains in it a liquor, the which doth keep the Heart moit, making its motion more facile, and prohibiting its drynes. It hath been oberved by Practitioners, That this part being wounded, the liquor hath paed out; but the Wound being Cicatrized, the Patients have been recovered, and this hath renewed its growth again. This Pannicle thus covering the Heart, by ome being called Capula Cordis, being alone hurt is not very dangerous, being by Galen reckoned as an ignoble part; and hence he produceth a Story of Marulus the Son of Mimographus, who although his Heart did lye bare and uncovered, and the Pericardium corrupted, yet he recovered. This Membrane is o much ofter than a Bone, as it is ofter than the Lungs, and being as the Hearts Marupium, it being wounded,
it loeth its tore of Serum, whereby the Heart is kept moyt; hence followes ometimes Syncope, Fever, and Cardialgia, or Palpitation of the Heart. Wounds happening here are to be dret as you do thoe of the Diaphragma and other parts of the Thorax; and therefore I hall not init hereon, but give further atisfaction as touching ome Hitorical Obervations hereof.

Hitory. And the firt is of Benivenius, Cap. 42. de Abditis, who writes in cutting off an Abces which grew upon the 7th Vertebre, the which had eroded the inward Membrane by its Matter, a little part of the Heart lay bare to ight, yet this Man by great Care and Diligence being ued, was Cured hereof and recovered.

Another. And Cardanus, Comment. ad Aphor. 18. lib. 6. Aphorim. Hipp. writes, That in Antonius Algiate he aw part of the Pericardium ablated, and the Man cured; but omewhat of upition remained, for he lived not many years: And hence indeed Petrus Salius de Curat. Morborum pag. 256. cap. 7. writes, That thee Affects of the Pericardium do generally bring a Conumption in the end, and hereupon happening a Hectick Fever, to which oft-times a Syncope is connexed, the Patients die hereof.

div.head: CHAP. LIX.
Of Wounds of the Heart.
div.p:
WE arrive now at the Prince of the middle Region, the great Mater of life, and the Fountain of Arterial blood. And as the Soul of man is by it elf individual and imple, the which Hip. calls < in non-Latin alphabet >
natura inapectabilis, although it be individual in the whole, yet it is aid to be manifold in repect of its variety of faculties, and diimilar tructure of Organs. Of the upper we have already dicoured, we come now to the econd and middle, where we may ee the Heart as Plato calls it the eat < in non-Latin alphabet > , becaue < in non-Latin alphabet > , by Phyicians it is aid to be the houe of the vital faculty, or < in non-Latin alphabet > the principle of life, and firt author of pulation, which flourihing all parts do exhilarate, this languihing they pine away, and this perihing they decay. The Philoopher writes that this contains in it the artificial fire of Zeno, herein being contained the divine and celetial heat, the which former times feigned, fetcht its heat from Heaven, hereby giving life to man. It's a Bowel carries in it much dignity, for it is not to be long corrupted with injuries, neither does it pin out its grievous punihments of life, for being once hurt it brings preent death. It's called by the Greeks
< in non-Latin alphabet > , < in non-Latin alphabet > , which is Vibrare. Its figure is Pyramidal. It's eated in the middle of the Thorax, circumcribed in its forepart with the Sternon, in its backpart with the vertebrae of the Back, in its upper with the Clavicles, in its lower with the Diaphragma, in its right and left ides with twelve ribs. In its Temper it is the hottet of the bowels. In its paive
qualities more moit than the cutis. Its whole tructure is framed of Fleh, Fat, Veins, Arteries and Nerves. Its Fleh is interwoven with three kind of fibres, right fibres from its bais to the end of its harp point; then oblique, which are obliquely produced according to its length, and latly tranvere for orbiculating the heart, paing through its ventricles. The heart draws blood by the help of the right in its Diatole through the Venacava into the right, and Air by the Venous Artery into the left Cavity. It enjoyes its attraction by the help of the Oblique, and by the tranvere it contracts and traitens, and hereby expulion is here made. Its Vein is called < in non-Latin alphabet > or Coronaria, encompaing the whole bais of the heart like a Crown. It hath oft times two coronary Arteries alo running through its whole Arteries. Its mall Nerves it hath from the ixth Conjugation. I hall not enlarge any further upon its Anatomical dicoure, although I might here bring in its Ears, its Ventricles, Valves, and Diviions, but hall rather deire you to look into Laurentius Bauhine, Deemerbrooke and the like, who are full enough in every one of thee. We come now to the ubtance and body of the Heart it elf as touching our dicoure of Wounds, and here may we ee, the heart being truck, much black and thick blood to iue thence, epecially if its right ventricle or ide be wounded; and hereupon we hall ee the face oon grow pale, cold weats attend the body, and a trange mell accompany the whole man. Jut under the right or left breat the wound is made, the pule doth much vary and act its changes, the extream parts grow cold, the mind troubled, and death follows. If the left ventricle of the heart be wounded, the blood is of a more roie colour, more pirituous, pinning out. And in thee direful caes we generally meet with Syncopes, cold Sweats and Chillines. The heart being o noble and generous a part cannot endure a divorce in it without death, for it's the beginning
of life, and elaboratory of the vital Spirit, being in continual motion, full of blood, and this ofttimes emptying it elf into the cavity of the Thorax, there threatning uffocation, as I have already aid. If it happens in any of the Ventricles, this wound mut necearily be lethal, by reaon of the great expence of blood which is made and lot. Another ill affect here may be the Air, the which paing into the wound does ofttimes occaion death. If the wound do happen in the ubtance of the heart, and do not reach any of its Ventricles, the Patient may live for two or three days but not much longer. The prince of life being corrupted, doth oon ditribute and hare of its hurts to all its ubject parts, and thee of neceity mut contract by their Rivulets from the Fountain of its hurts and michiefs, it being as the Radix or Ocean both of Veins and Arteries, it being as Aritotle writes the bet of all bowels, ditributing to, and not receiving from any part, giving life and motion unto others, and diffuing its proper virtues as it pleaeth it elf, and expoing its griefs and orrows to other parts according as it thinks fit. Hip. Aphor. 6. affirms that wounds of the heart are lethal, epecially if they be large, and penetrate its ventricles. Superficial wounds here happening may be cured. But thee wounds whatoever are o rarely cured, that you hall carce read of any one man here being wounded to have recovered, but in the pace of two or three hours to have yielded up his lat breath. For as Fallopius writes, hould we either conider the excellency of the heart, or its ubtance, death mut necearily follow, its ubtance being hard and not to be agglutinated. And if we regard its perpetual Motion alo and Temper, we may oon ee it inflamed; and if to thee we add the greatnes of the wound, we may find it time lot in expecting ever to gain cure here. And for the proving of this I hall produce ome worthy Hitorical Obervations. Galen lib. 5. Cap. 1.
de loc. affect. pronounceth, that if any wound do reach the Ventricle of the Heart, and there follow a large flux of blood, the party mut necearily die. And that epecially if the left Ventricle be wounded. Yet if the wound have only penetrated the ubtance of the heart, and not reached its Ventricles, thee may live that day or the next, but eldom any longer, for inflammation hence ariing it oon puts out the light of his life.

Hitory. Cyriacus Lucius de uis obervat writes that for reolving the Quetion, about the eats of the principal faculties, and their originations amongt Phyicians, it was not of little weight to produce the Hitory of one who being hurt in the left part of his Thorax, the wound penetrating the ubtance of the heart, and either Ventricle thereof, being made tranverely, fell hereupon as it were void both of his enes and reaon for almot the pace of a whole hour, he oon dying of this wound. His body being opened, all the pectators might ee and undertand the hape of the Intrument which made the wound into his heart, and might very well judge of its form and fahion. And to conclude this dicoure, Ambroe Pary lib. 9. cap. 30. writes that he aw a Noble man who fighting a Duel with another received a wound under the left breat, which penetrated the ubtance of the heart, its Fibres being tranverely incied, and hereupon after walking a matter of two hundred paces fell down dead. The dead body being opened, the wound might eaily be een to pas into the ubtance of the heart, the bignes of a finger, hence was alo een a great and plentiful effuion of blood in the Diaphragma.

div.head: CHAP. LX.
Of Wounds of the Arteries and Veins, and of the Vena Cava and Great Artery.
div.p: Of the Vena Cava. THE blood being purged from all its bitter and lutulent excrements, doth how it elf more pure, red and incere in this its large veel, the which hall in this place offer it elf. And this Vein by the Antients was called < in non-Latin alphabet > , that is large and hollow, this being the fountain of humane nature, and the floodgate of our Microcom, and the common mother of the ret, except the Umbilical and Port-vein. It is bred out of the Gibbous part of the Liver, it is eated according to the length of the back, and runs directly through both Venters, hereby conveying of its blood to all parts. It is divided by Anatomits into an upper and lower Trunk, the upper penetrating through the Diaphragma and acending upwards does ditribute many of its branches into all the upper parts; the decending Trunk leer than the former adheres to the Spine on the right ide, and does dipere everal of its branches through the Liver.

Of the Great Artery. The Great Artery is exceeding large at the left ventricle of the Heart from whence it arieth, and for this reaon all Anatomits do allow the Heart the Origination of Arteries. And before this do fall out from the Pericardium above the valves it doth afford, are ometimes two Coronary Arteries, the which like a Crown do encompas the Bais of the Heart, and a little under the great Vein, or Arteria venoa, it arieth upwards and
penetrates the Pericardium, and is divided into two equal parts, the one called the acendent, the other the decendent Trunk. This Trunk doth very fitly anwer the body of a Tree, and doth incline to the 5th Spondyl of the Thorax, and omewhat declining towards the left giveth way unto the Vena Cana. From this Trunk are branches dipered, which do accompany the ramifications of the Port and hollow Veins into the whole body. Thus have we given you a hort urvey of thee two great Trunks by Anatomy.

Signs of the Vena Cava wounded. If the hollow Vein be wounded, a Flux of black Blood ucceeds, the wound happens in the right ide, the Veins do peedily empty and flag, the face looks pale, and the extreme parts do grow cold, the faculties wax weak, and oon after thee the Patient's life is taken from him.

Signs of the Great Artery wounded. If the Great Arterie be wounded, ariing from the left ventricle of the Heart, ditributing its vital Spirit through the whole Man, and tempering his native heat by a Sytole and Diatole, the flux of Blood appeareth florid, and the wound mut be in the left ide, the motion of the Arteries do vary and change, the extreme parts grow chilly, and a perturbation of mind doth cloud the animal faculties, a Fever follows and creates a preternatural heat in the parts, a Palpitation of the Heart follows, after which you may uddenly ee the Heart it elf yield.
