For wounds happening in either of thee two mut conequently procure death by reaon of the quick and plentiful dicharge both of Blood and Spirit, hence following an interception both of the faculties and functions both of Heart and Lungs.

div.head: CHAP. LXI.
Of Wounds of the Veins and Arteries.
div.p:
WE come now to the general dicoure of the Veins and Arteries, where we may ee how they vary by Anatomy. A Vein is by the Greeks called What a Vein is, and how made.
< in non-Latin alphabet >
abundare, becaue a plenty of Blood doth abound in it. This is an Organick imilar part, membranous, long, thin, hollow, containing Blood in it, and carrying the ame to the Heart. It's aid to be Organick in repect of its action or ue, for conveying the Blood. It hath a membranous ubtance, moderately oft, the better for ditenion; it hath one proper coat, intertexed with a threefold kind of Fibres, the which is manifetly apparent in varices, the which when its tranvere and oblique Fibres have been rent, the coat of the Vein eems looe, neither is it to be ever retored to its former natural tate. It's nourihed with the Blood which paeth through it, it's nourihed as are the Arteries. The Veins are inwardly furnihed with valves for admitting the reception of the Blood, and making a free paage for its addres to the Heart, and hindering its reflux from it. They take their material Origination from the eed, but whether they take their firt Origination from the Liver by the Vena Cava and Porta, or from the Heart is yet much diputable.

What an Artery is, and how made. An Artery by the Greeks is called < in non-Latin alphabet > being generally in motion, or < in non-Latin alphabet > becaue it keeps air or pirit in it. It's an Organick, imilar, long, round, and hollow part, ordained for conveying the pirituous Blood. Organick in repect of its action or ue, the Blood being herein contained, being much like the
ditillation of Wine, the which being the oftner ditilled doth yield a more pure and ubtile pirit. Thus the Blood, the oftener it is dilated in the Heart, its pirituous particles are the better diolved from its thick mas, and are the better attenuated. The ubtance of an Artery is membranous, o framed for its better dilatation and contriction. It coniteth of a double proper coat outward and inward. The outward whereof is oft and thin; endowed with many right, few oblique Fibres: the inward is more hard and thick. And it is very neceary that it hould be o, epecially about the Heart which doth receive the warm Blood falling from the Heart. This coat hath in it many tranvere Fibres, few oblique and right, the better for contriction; for hould the Arteries not be made firm by thee tranvere Fibres, by their great pulations they would be dilated, and o remain. For this Caue of Aneurim.is the caue of Aneurim: This coat being rent with its Fibres, the Blood doth oon make its entry and paage into the firt oft coat, the which by reaon of its oftnes is oon extended, and hence doth arie a Tumour in the part. They are nourihed with pirituous Blood which doth pas through them, in which becaue there are in it many aline particles, a good part of which comes to the coats, it maketh their ubtance both more firm and thick.

Having thus given you a brief Anatomical dicoure of thee parts, we are next to look into their wounds, and here are we to enquire whether this Wound was given by a Sword, or Shaft, or occaioned by a fall upon a harp Stone, or inwardly by ome alt and corroding humour. All thee are to be collected either from the Patient, or by their proper igns. That there is a breach of ome veel profuion of blood is certificate enough, herein comprehending the place by the glas of Anatomy, conidering the largenes of the wound, and impetuoity of the Blood flowing. Now whether it flows from a Vein, or an Artery, may be collected from thee igns.
As firt, the Arterial Blood being both roie and florid, alo paeth out with leaping, pinning forth in its dilatation Secondly, this Blood is more thin and fluid than that of the Veins. And thirdly, as this is florid and roie, o the venal blood is black and thick. Again, the Arterial Blood is more hot than the Venal, neither hath the Venal Blood uch Spirit allowed it.

Preages. Becaue Blood is the treaure of life, if this flux be not immediately topt, it brings a diolution of the whole man. For in thee great fluxes we generally ee Convulion, Syncope, Singultus and the like, as continual attendants hereupon. The cure of an Artery cut is much more difficult than that of a Vein, becaue the Arterial Blood is more fluxile, and its body more hard and always in motion. An Artery cut overthwart, is ooner healed than that which is incied longwie.

Cure. As to the Cure, we are advied by Galen to caue a peedy top to this flux, and then to cure the wound. And this is to be done either by averion or derivation, or making the matter more firm that it make no further addres, by obtructing the mouths of the Veels, either by joining the lips of the wound together, or by obturation of the Veels by compreing them together with the fingers, and keeping them o compreed until the blood do become grumous. I have already in the beginning of my dicoure hown eight everal ways of tanching of blood, and this may be done either by a certain regulation of the whole body, or well ordering of the affected part. The Diet here ought to be thin, cold and of ubtance thickning, omewhat retringent, o as it may both cool and thicken the blood; and for this ue Lentils, Rice, Jujubes, Quinces, Medlers, Pomegranates, Prunes and the like are proper here. Let his drink be either cold water or chalybeated water or Poca, Barley-water, of Julip of Roes, Plantain-water, Spawn-water or the like. The part affected ought alo to be cooled,
and hence repercuives are proper whereby to repel the blood from the affected part. Hereupon both upon the part and its origination is to be aued Poca, Blackwine, Juice of Nighthade, Lettice, Plantain and the like. The flux is to be averted either by revulion or derivation; for revulion Phlebotomy is to be intituted, if the flux be large, and the pirits will allow it. For this ue alo Cupping-glaes either without or with carrification are proper engines here, as alo Ligatures, Frictions, Unctions, Fomentations and the like, all which are to be applied to the contrary part. Now come we to the Veel it elf which is wounded, and here are we to oberve, that the lips of the Veels are to be hut up; and here if an Artery be diected, we firt apply our thumb and finger upon the Veel for its compreion, after which the wound is to be wahed with Poca for the expurgation of the concreted blood. The blood being cleaned and the wound dried up, we are to prinkle ome retrictive powders into it, over thee to apply a convenient liniment upon the preent removal of the finger, after the application of which, to apply the finger upon it again. And when you take off your dreings, you are to take them ingly off, with a due obervation of keeping your finger on untill you have wholly removed all your dreings. The wound being expleted, its uperficies is to be prinkled with retrictive powder, then covered over with a rowler, which was dipt in harp Wine and oyl of Roes. And here are we to oberve that we do make three or four ligations upon the wound, and o to mount your ligatures upwards towards the originations of the Veels, o as the blood may be retracted from the affected part. Then remove your ligature the third day, changing alo your dreings, in which time you may afely proceed in this operation. The Chirurgeon ought to be well skilled in Anatomy, for Nature hath planted and mixed Nerves with Arteries as cold bodies that
by their heat they may be cherihed: for if in thee caes the Chirurgeon do not eparate the Nerve from the Artery by a mall hook, he will bind up both parts, and if the Nerve be compreed, it peedily is deprived both of its ene and motion, and hence doth follow a tupidity of the whole member. In thee caes therefore the Nerve is to be eparated from the Artery, and then the Artery to be bound up. And in our ligations we are to take care that they be not made too trict. Fallopius fol. 211. writes of an infirm Mechanick who received a wound in his Vena Poplitis, in which wound it behoved the part to be rowled up without which he mut necearily have perihed; the wound was rowled up although the Artery was cut, yet within the pace of a year after the man perceived a pule in the Artery of the Malleolus. For which reaon he thinks in uch a proces of time that the Orifices of the Arteries do meet together again and conjugate; but this is not always approved of, neither doth ue of ligatures always appear here proper. For in ome caes the Artery is to be tranverly incied: for this is the proper nature of the Veel upon uch an inciion, to make towards its Original, and to hrowd it elf under the Mucles, and with eae join their Orifices with them. And Gal. lib. 5. Meth. teacheth us this way of diection of an Artery, as firt, to lift it up with a hook, then to eparate it from the Vein and Nerve, and then to divide it; the which being done, the Artery is to be tied up or twited by the hook, for hereby the Orifices of the Veels are compleatly obtructed. But if the wound be o deep and do penetrate o far as that we cannot come at it, in thee caes Ution is mot proper, for hereby the flux of blood is topt by cringing the mouth of the Veel and at its ends procuring an Echar or crut; but this very eldom doth happen. And here I do advie with all imaginable caution that you take care of the Veel that it be kept from being burnt up, becaue
this action is both painful, cruel and difficult, and we proceeding here as it were hood-winkt; beides all which if this crut or echar hould fall off, it would ubject the part to a new flux, the which is eldom conquered by the bet of medicines. In thee deperate caes thee things are to be oberved, That you firt make this with a red hot Iron, taking care that the concreted blood be not cauterized in the wound, but this firt to be expurged with Poca. A econd caution is, That we make not too much adution, but only o far as to caue a corrugation of the veel, by the firt or econd application of the actual Cautery. And ometimes a potential as well as an actual Cautery may here properly be ued, and for this ome do precribe Soot as the bet of medicines both for procuring an echar and alo for uppreion of the blood. But this is not to be ued in all places, as the face or eyes or the like, for it always doth leave its mark of blacknes. We in thee caes do generally ue Calcanthum, or calcined Vitriol. Some do ue oyl of Vitriol or Sulphur, others for the ame effect do precribe Troch. de Minio, but it is a michievous medicine in thee caes, for that beides its exciting of pain, it doth alo encreae the ame. Having by thee or the like medicines granted that the flux of blood is topt, our next intention is the agglutinating of the wound. And here becaue there is an echar to be removed, emollient and digeting medicines are here to be applied, as nguent. Dialth. Bailicon, freh butter, Axungia Porcina, or the like. Then is the wound if deep to be filled up with fleh by Sarcoticks, and skinned by Epouloticks. And here by the way according to Galens advice lib. 5. Method. we are to apply to wounded Arteries o much the more drying medicines than to Veins, by how much they are of drier bodies: wherefore a Vein wounded without los of ubtance is to be cured as you do wounds of the fleh. And Gal. lib. 5. Meth. cap. 7. relates that Arteries may alo
be conolidated, for he aith that he hath een them agglutinated in Women and Children, and to be every way covered with fleh, and that both in the Forehead, Ancles, and Arms; and brings in this Story of a young Chirurgeon not much skilled in his art, who was about by a Phyicians order to breath a Vein in the Arm, but cut the Artery intead of the Vein; the blood which iued out was yellowih, thin, and full of pirit, coming out with leaping. He being called to this Patient with ome other Phyicians, a Plaiter being made ready for the uppreion of the blood he joyned the Artery, and applied over it the Medicine, and bound a oft Spunge over all; unrowling of the dreings the fourth day the incied Artery was apparently een to be conglutinated, after which were applied the ame Medicines again, and o for ome days to be continued, and within a mall while his Artery was perfectly cured.

Hitory of Arteries wounded. Dodonaeus Medicin. Oberv. Cap. 49. writes of a Spaniard who falling upon his face, cut an Artery, and the Cutis being rent herewith the blood iued out very plentifully; many Medicines being tried in vain, his friends deired him to top this Flux if poible. Coming to him, and viewing the wound, he could find no better Medicine than an actual Cautery to perform this, hence with all diligence he cauterized the incied Artery, and preently uppreed the flux of blood, the which being topt, the remainer of the cure was performed with eae, and the Patient peedily recovered his pritine health.

Another. Foretus lib. 6. Oberv. Chirurg. Ob. 35. writes of a young man in Delph whoe Artery of his thigh being wounded, was not to be conquered by any Medicines, or its flux of blood intercepted by atringents; yet by the benefit of the actual Cautery he was preently freed from death. Benivenius cap. 49. de Abditis hath another Story hereof after the ame manner of one whoe Artery was cut, and not to be cured without an actual
Cautery. Fabritius Hildan. ob. 18. writes of a man of 40. years of age, who being of a cholerick and angry dipoition, and being wounded in the head, the left oporal Branch of the Artery which lies under the Temporal Mucle was incied; the flux being topt by the application of his retrictive Powder at firt, he brought the wound to digetion the Fifth day after his hurt received; he that gave the wound unhappily comes unawares into his Chamber, the wounded man not knowing of his coming, and being troubled and vexed at the ight of him, upon this paion the Artery opened and divided it elf again, hence iued uch a flux of Blood that it could carce be topped, yet this man at lat grew well, and recovered. Hereby may we ee what influence Anger hath over us, it being the mot terrible of all paions, and the mot fertil mother of infinite evils.

Of Veins wounded. Dodonaeus ol. 267. med. ob. writes that in his time a Barber endeavoring to pluck out the hair from a mans notrils, did unhappily cut the mall Vein which is within them planted, hence followed uch a flux of blood that many Phyicians could not find any way to top it, but the poor man mierably ended his life.
Thus have I run through all the parts of the middle Venter, and the chief parts which are mot ubject to be wounded, we proceed to the third and lat.

div.head: CHAP. LXII.
Of Wounds of the Abdomen.
div.p: HAving in my former dicoures hown the upper and middle Regions, wherein we have dimantled every of the parts, we come now to Natures workhoue, wherein we may ee her nutritive Engines by which he doth utain the whole family. This being as the Kitchin of the Body, guarded with an outward armour of Mucles, then wrapt about with a fine permatick Peritoneum, inwardly may we firt view its fatty Kell framed with curled veins, and criped fat, being as a warm rugg keeping warm the Stomach and Guts. Next thee the admirable eries of Intetines, in whoe midt is planted the Meentery taying them in their proper places, and conveighing to them the meeraick Veins, by which the aliment is convey'd unto the gate of the Liver. After this appears a Pancreas, the Liver, bladder of Gall, Spleen, Ventricle, Bladder, Ureters, Kidneys and the like. But of each of thee in their order.

We begin with wounds of the Abdomen, and here we may meet with two orts hereof, the one being imple and not penetrating, the other being more compound and penetrating. And before we concern our elves with the cure hereof, let us ee the igns by which we may know thee. And thee again may be een to penetrate with, or without the exciion of any part, with or without hurt of the ame. A penetrating wound we may find either by the probe or earching candle; for if a great way in, it's a ign of a penetrating wound, oberving Signs of a penetrating wound.here alo that the wound be made directly. For if the wound be made obliquely, you may put your Probe
or Candle a great way in between the Mucles, and the wound notwithtanding not penetrate. Again if you make any injection of Wine and do inject it into the wound well warmed, if the wound penetrateth, it will remain and lodge in the Cavity. If not, it will make its peedy exit. If the Omentum or Intetines come out of the wound, thee are evident tetimonies of its penetration. Preages.As for uch wounds as do not penetrate they are void of danger unles they be very large; and that is wore which is made in the middle part than in the ides, for the middle part is more nervous, and more difficult to titch up; beides the guts do more eaily pas out here than at the ides and o do hinder agglutination. And as Celus faith, all penetrating wounds are accounted dangerous, becaue they are mot commonly large and always deep, becaue the air which paeth into the wound does hurt the guts, and likewie alo becaue the matter ofttimes does fall into the Capacity thereof. And he further noteth, that as he cannot ecape who is wounded in the body of the Brain, Stomach, in the Gate Vein of the Liver, or whoe pinal marrow is mitten; o alo may he not be aid to be cured, to whom the middle of the Lungs, Jejune, mall Guts, Kidneys or Bladder are wounded. In thee wounds thee Intentions are required. If any part comes out, to repoe this, then to titch up the wound, to apply agglutinative Medicines, and to remove all evil Symptoms. We hall treat of the parts by themelves. And here by way of Caution as touching our future herein required, we are to conider how much of the part we are to take up to titch with the Needle, for if here we take up but a mall part, the thread will cut it through, if too great a part, we hall occaion pain. Secondly, that we make convenient paces between our titches for a better exition of the matter. And then that we conider the depth of placing our Needles, and that our thread or Silk be of a good
ize. Here alo are we to note that the titches are not to be cut off the fourth day, but to remain on until the ninth or longer, for wounds here are not uddenly conolidated. Over the titches may be applied ome of the agglutinative Medicines which I have already propoed, being made of Turpentine, Frankincene, Bolarmenick, Dragons-blood, or the like. If to this wound inflammation be adjoined, the wound not being neglected, the inflammation is to be minded, the which does ufficiently declare it elf by its colour, touch, and ene of the affected part. And this is to be peedily abated and all other ymptoms, as pain, intemperiety, and the like. To conclude this.

Hitory. A very worthy Gentleman of our country falling down upon his ide, the point of his Knife being put into his pocket upwards, by the fall truck into his lower parts and left ide of his body, the which being examined it was found both very large and deep, whence iued a great quantity of blood. The bloody flux being topt, and the concreet blood cleaned, the wound was titcht up with convenient paces for the dicharge of the matter. The matter being digeted, the wound was healed, and he perfectly recovered, and was with me when I writ this.

div.head: CHAP. LXII.
Of the Abdomen wounded with Exition of the Intetines or Omentum.
div.p:
IF the cae be, that the Intetines or Omentum do come out of the wound, thee with all peed are to be retored. But if they have been out long, and the orifice of the wound be mall, and by reaon of the cold air thee parts are filled with flatuoity, o as that they cannot be reduced, you are in this cae according to Celus's advice firt to make an incarnative fomentation to dipere this wind, and then to try the repoition of the parts. The fomentation may be made of Camomile, Spicknard, Squinanth, Melilot, Dill, Pennyroyal, Wormwood, Mints, Balm, Lavender, and all the carminative eeds and berries boyled in Wine, in which is to be dipt a punge, and o to apply it warm to the affected part. Rhais for this purpoe doth apply the Lungs of Animals hot hereto. The flations being thus diipated, the Intetines are to be reduced with your fingers. If the Omentum do come forth at the wound, and by reaon of cold it hath got a trange colour, and purchaed an unnatural hardnes in it, o far as the part is corrupt, this is to be cut away: but if it carries its native colour, and no change do appear in it, this are we to repoe into its proper place; and if the wound be o mall as we cannot get it in with our fingers, we are advied by a earching candle to repoe it, this being dipt in ome Traumatick decoction. Some there are who for this ue do ue a Golden wire, and hereby do cut away all the putrefied part. The next intention after this is to titch the
wound up by Gatroraphia. By Aquapendens there are et down 3 forts of thee titches: the firt performed by thruting the needle through the skin and the Mucles, even to the Peritonaeum not touching it; then from within outwards the Peritonaeum is to be thrut through and the Mucles of the oppoite ide by the needle; then within the ditance of an inch the needle is to be thrut through the Mucles of the ame ide, leaving the Peritonaeum: and thus are you to proceed until you have titcht up the wound. The econd is done by titching the Mucles together and the ides of the Peritonaeum together. The third differeth not from the titch which is ued in other parts of the body. Thee being done, the next Intention is to apply agglutinative emplaters or powders, of which I have already directed ufficiently; over which may be applied Empl. Diapalma, de Betonica, Barbarum Stipticum, or the like. Galen propoeth the fourth cope is to prevent the hurting of any noble parts; and this may be occaioned either by pain, or a collection of matter or blood in the cavity of the Abdomen. Gal. for the firt, 6. Meth. cap. 4. advieth to embrocate all the parts from the Arm-pits to the Inguens with Olive-oyl warmed; or oyl of Camomile, Dialthaea or Roes for this ue is better. And as to the econd accident, matter and blood may well fall from the lips of the wound into the Abdomen, and may not only offend the Guts but alo all the other contained parts, for hereby ometimes a Tumour is caued, ometimes a Dropie generated. And thee igns do certifie their being inwardly contained; as firt, the weight hews the ame with pain and tenion of the part; 2. if upon depreion of the belly you find the matter make its paage from one part to another: hence are we by Galen directed to order uch medicines as may rarifie the parts, both diipate and draw forth the matter.

To conclude this, I hall preent you with ome remarkable
Hitory. hitories worthy our obervation as touching this Chapter. Albucais lib. 2. cap. 58. Meth. Med. writes of a wound happening in the belly which was made by a mall Knife, it was the breadth of a hand lacerated, and the Intetines came out the breadth of two hands, the Intetines were retored, and the wound in 24. hours conolidated, and the wound in the pace of 15. days was recovered, upon which wound was put old wooll, wahing it twice a day with Aqua Mellis until it was healed.

Another. Another hall be of the Omentum, the which falling out of a wound, the Abdomen being cut and wounded, the Patient recovered, and this is of Galen de uu part. lib. 4. cap. 9. That the Omentum was framed for warmths ake is ufficiently evident, although in thoe who have been wounded in their Abdomen, in which wounds this hath fallen out, being hereby made livid, this compells the Chirurgeon to cut off the hurt part. All uch therefore do find their tomachs cold, and do not well diget their victuals, and do furnih themelves with many outward coverings, epecially when a great part of this is taken away, as it happened once to a Fencer where we were forced to cut it almot all quite off, yet this man recovered, yet he the remainder of his life was ever hurt by any outward cold, and was not able to endure a naked belly, but ever did wear a quilt well thickned with Cotton over his belly.

div.head: CHAP. LXIII.
Of Wounds of the Omentum.
div.p:
THE Kell by the Greeks is called < in non-Latin alphabet > of < in non-Latin alphabet > to wim, in Latine Omentum, this wimming upon the bottom of the Stomach and the uppermot Guts. The Arabians do call it Zirbus, being as the mop of the belly weeping up its uperfluities. It is a large membrane, cituated upon the bottom of the Stomach, and downwards over the Guts unto the Navel. It's fatned to the Stomach, Spleen, and Colon. Its form is like a pure-net or Faulkners-bag, coniting of a double membrane knit together at the bottom. Its membranes are two lying one upon the top of another. It hath many Veins ariing from the Port-vein. It hath its Arteries from the Celiacal and Meenterical branches. The fat is very plentiful about thee Veels. Its ues are to keep the guts moit, and it warms and comforts the Stomach, and in time of Famine it upplies a kind of ubidiary nourihment to the natural heat. Having given you the abtract of the Anatomy of the Kell, whereas I have already hown in ome meaure how it is to be dealt with if it comes out the Abdomen being wounded; here hall we briefly hew how to cure any part thereof which is either cut, or hanging a long while out of the wound, eaily cauing it to putrify and gangrenate. If any part therefore of the Omentum comes out, and by reaon of cold or the air is too much cooled, which you may dicern by its unnatural hardnes, or if it be black or livid, then is this to be bound up near to the warm and ound part, and the corrupt part mut be cut away, letting the thread hang out of the wound until the corrupt part doth eparate
from the whole, then draw the thread wholly out of the wound. If the Omentum be nothing altered in its colour, let it be retored and reduced into its proper place, and be ordered as I have already directed in the foregoing Chapter. In thee kind of wounds becaue the flehy parts are generally hurt, digetives, mundificatives, incarnatives and cicatrizing medicines are required. All which I will how you in this enuing dicoure. Of a wound of the Omentum not being well handled whence did arie a gangrene, Glandorp hath it in Ob. 29. lib. pec. Chirurg. the which I hall et down here for thy better management if occaion doth or may Hitory.require. The Hitory is of a Nobleman who challenged a Scholar into the field to fight, the which being met, the Scholar wounded the Nobleman a little under the Navel the length of 6 fingers, out of which came forth part of the Omentum, with ome of the Guts, yet unhurt. The Chirurgeon which was imployed neglects this wound of the Omentum, and doth repoe the cold parts, and titcheth up the wound, whence in the eventh day when the putrified matter could not obtain an evacuation, a Fever did hereupon arie, with frequent perturbations of the mind. Glandorps Father being conulted, eeing the wound o trictly titcht up, preently did cut them open, hence followed out at the wound a great plenty of matter; and having more diligently examined the wound, and cleaned it with Wooll or Lint, he ees the Omentum turning black, as you ee in the beginning of a gangrene; the part of the Omentum was drawn forth, and tied in the upper part, and part thereof was taken off, which was the quantity of three tranvere fingers, and having precribed him a good order of diet epecially in repect of his Fever which was Clyter.very hot and afflicting, he had afterwards this Clyter adminitred. fol. malv. alth. violar. an. M. i. cord. hyperic. an. M. s. fl. Cham. Melilot. an. p. iij. em. ani.
faenicul. an. iij. Lin. Foenugraec. an. vi. Caricar. ping. ij. coquantur in q. . aqu. font. ad ix. his adde Benedict. laxat. vi. Ol. Amygdal. dulc. is. Ol. violar. vi. Sacchar. rubr. colat. i. mice. Afterwards was ordered this Cordial. Aqu. Theriacal. Cinamom. an. s. Borag. Cordial. buglo. Cardu. an. s. Roar. vj. Sacchar. Perlat. iij. Conf. Alkerm. i. mice; of which let him take a poonful now and then. The Tents were armed with this Digetive, over which was applyed Empl. Diapalma. Terebinth. lot. in aqu. Veronic. i. Ol. Roar. Lumbricor. Digetive. an. iij. Cort. Thur. Matich. an. s. Mel. Roar. s. vitell. Ov. n. j. mice. The circumjacent parts were anointed with Ol. Cham. Viol. Roar. and Lumbricor. and becaue pain much grieved the parts, over thee were applied this Catapl. fol. violar. M. s. Scord. pug. iij. Catapl. ummit. Abynth. Abrotan. Roar. rubr. an. pug. ij. fl. Cham. Mclilot. an. pug. j. farin. Hord. Fabar. an is. Lupinor. i. cum Lact. vacc. q. . fiat Cataplama, fine addendo Ol. Roar. i. violar. s. vitell. Ovor. n. j. mioe. Hence was generated good and laudable matter. In the interim he complained of pain of his Stomach, for which in ome mornings he took Caia for looening his belly, and for his weaknes of the Stomach was this ordered. Con. Roar. rubr. i. Abynth. Roman. vi. spec. Diarrhod. Abbat. ii. Rad. Enul. camp. cond. is. Ol. Cinamom. gut. iij. mice. By thee means the inflammation, and a flux of humours to the affected part, and the Fever with the other ymptomes, did within few days vanih. To the wound were applied mundifiers, incarnatives and agglutinatives, with a fair cicatrice, that the man recovered to his pritine health.

div.head: CHAP. LXIV.
Of Wounds of the Guts.
div.p:
THE Intetines are called by the Greeke < in non-Latin alphabet > , in Latine Intetina, being placed in the inmot part of the body; thee are wrapt up into many folds, they are knit together by the benefit of the Meentery, they are long bodies, hollow but not of a like bore; they are continued with the Stomach at the Pylorus, but their ubtance is thinner than that of the Stomach, and they have almot innumerable Veins. The mall Guts are in number three, Duodenum, Jejunum, Ilion, the which although they have almot one capacity, yet they are eaily ditinguihed by their ite, length, and by the Meeraick Veins. The great or thick Guts are of the ame number, called Caecum, Colon, and Rectum, all differing in ite, Figure, and Magnitude. You may find in all Authors of Anatomy their true inertion, ite and length, we hall therefore pas to the three coats, one of which is common to them all, having its origination from the Peritonaeum, this is made as a guard for their defence. They have alo two proper coats, partly as Galen heweth, that their expelling faculty might be trong, and partly alo for ecurity. They have all kinds of fibres, the inward being oblique that they might retain, the middle tranvere more proper for expulion, the right being in the mall Guts fewer than in the great. They have their Veels from the Port Vein, Arteries from the Coeliacal & Meenterical Branches, they have Nerves from the ixth pair. The ue of the mall Guts is as the proper conveighing intruments of nutriment, ditributing the ame, and for this reaon hath Nature drawn the Guts out to a length, o as he may in
each of them lodge a little quantity, fit to be uckt up by the Meeraicks. The ue of the great Guts is to contain the excrements in them, with choler which is afforded them from the bladder of gall having a paage which enters the Duodenum.

We come now to the dicoure of thee being wounded, and here are we well to conider whether the mall or great Guts be thus wounded. If the mall be wounded, Signs of the mall and great Guts being wounded.the Chyle is een to pas through the Orifice, the Hipps do tumify and grow hard, or Choler is een to come this way, epecially if the Duodenum or Jejunum be wounded, ometimes meat and drink do pas through the wound. There's little hopes of cure if the Jejunum be wounded, becaue it is exanguial, and does receive a great Quantity of veels, its coats being very thin and nervous: beides, the choler which decends from the bladder of gall on one ide, and the pancreatick juice which paeth into thee Guts on the other does much hinder Conolidation. And although thee reaons are true, yet that thee being wounded have been cured, Example and Hitory makes good; and therefore in thee caes by Hippocrates order we are not to leave the Patient in miery without help. Wounds of the great Guts are more flehy, and therefore may be allowed more readily and with les trouble and difficulty to be cured. If thee be wounded, the excrement does pas out by the wound; yet if a great and tranvere wound does happen here, it ofttimes does threaten death: but if the wound be mall and made directly, it may be cured, and yet mut not be allowed void of danger, becaue the external part of the Abdomen is divided. If inflammation adjoins with this wound, and caueth a fever, and this encreaeth, the Patient mut necearily die.

In curing of thee wounds five Intentions are required. Firt therefore the lips of the wound are to be brought
5 Intentions required as to the cure. together; econdly the Gut is to be reduced into its proper place; thirdly convenient Medicines are to be applied; fourthly to prevent any excrements coming to the affected part; and latly the penetrating wound of the Abdomen is to be cured.

1 Intention. The firt intention is performed by future: but here may we note that there are everal ways et down by Authors about this future. Some of which do take an Elder pith, and through this they put the needle into the cavity of the Guts, and then they ow the Abdomen and Intetine together; but this way in common ene is out of the way: others there are who do take a dry Gut of another animal, and this being extended do put it about the wound; but this alo is not to be followed, becaue this dryed Gut will oon fall from the moit, and therefore necearily it mut be improper. Another ort there are who apply to thee wounds the wings and bodies of Ants, and with their fingers do compres them in, but this way is alo idle. The bet and mot afe way therefore is to ow up thee wounds as women do ow cloath, or to titch up the brims of the wound with the Glovers titch.

2 Intention. The quantity of the Gut which is to be taken up hould neither be too great nor too mall, but in a moderate quantity, for the intetines are extended in their proper motions, and therefore if a greater part be taken up than what is neceary, the Intetine is eaily obtructed, and its Cavity rendred too trict, and hence come great pains, and the Gut is made ubject to the Iliaca paio. The future being made, the remaining part of the thread is to be left hanging out of the wound; here adviing before we begin any future, that we ought to apply ome agglutinative Medicine into the inward part of the Intetine, and for this ue the powder of Myrrh, Aloes and Frankincene is very
good: but here we mut note that thee powders are to be applied before the uppreion of the blood; but if you in this cae may fear the harpnes of Aloes, you may add the powder of Comfry root, and then to take one part of Aloes, two of Frankincene, and one of Comfrey, and thee to be prinkled both upon and into the wound. Some for this ue do much commend the Juice of Piloella, Pentaphyl. and Tormentil. others do ue the Juice of Elme, and do account this as an excellent Medicine. They do take the bladders out of the Tree which grow in the month of May, and out of thoe they take a liquour contained in them, and this they ue as a mot admirable Remedy. Fallopius writes that he aw an Empirick who old this Oyl for agglutinations of wounds, and this being applied to the deepet tabs, within the pace of twenty four hours it cures infallibly.

3 Intention. Thus have we hown the firt two Intentions, the third is to reduce the Gut into its proper place, and a future to be made in the Abdomen, it being firt Fomented with ome warm retringent Wine, over which alo may be applied of the former retringent powder.

4 Intention. Fourthly, no excrements are to be uffered to pas to the wounded part. Hence a repect is to be had to the order of diet, and well regulating of the whole body. In this cae alo may you precribe the Patient emollient Clyters with ome of the aforeaid Powders: inwardly by the Mouth may he take ome vulnerary decoctions, uch as I have precribed in wounds of the Thorax.
5 Intention. And the lat Intention is to cloe up the lips of the wounded Abdomen, as I have already hown.

Hitory. To conclude all with ome Hitorical Obervations. Glandorp ob. 32. writes of a Woman who being deperately tempted by the Devil, wounded her elf a little
under her Navel, and alo wounded the Ilion, both Chyle and Choler which did formerly flow out of the wounds of the thin Guts were purged out, the wound titcht up, and wahed, and over thee was applied a retrictive and agglutinative Powder, but all in vain, for inflammation, and gangreen eized the parts, and the fourth day he died.

Hollerius, ob. 17. libello proprio writes of one whoe venter being perforated with a harp Sword, the mall Guts were hereby wounded with a part of the great, both Guts and excrement paed through the wound, yet after a long time the Patient was recovered.

Another. Jacotius Com. 2. ad. Aphor. 17. lib. 1. ect. 3. Coac. Hipp. pag. 1002. writes that the Jejunum being the thinnet of all the Guts is held to be incurable being wounded, in repect of the largenes of its Veels, thinnes of its coat, and nervous nature, bordering upon the Liver; yet this hath been een cured, and is agglutinated with a more eay agglutination.

Hitories of wounds of the great Guts. Paraeus l. 9. c. 33. writes that he hath cured many who have been wounded with tranvere wounds in the belly, the which have recovered, the firt of which he mentioneth of a Portugal who being wounded with a Sword, cutting the whole body tranverely, o as the Intetines being wounded, a great plenty of excrements fell out of the wound, yet he recovered. The econd is of Aegidius a Noble-man, who being wounded in the middle of his body o as that for many days the blood came out by his Mouth and Anus, whence might be collected that the Guts were wounded, yet in twenty three days he was cured.

Another. To end this, Glandorp. cap. 36. writes of a young man of eighteen years of age, of a good habit of body, who received a wound above his navel three fingers long, out of which did hang part of the Omentum
with part of the Colon, the Colon was alo een wounded, for excrements came from it by the wound: this Intetine was preently titched up with the Glovers titch, afterwards was waht with warm harp retringent Wine, then was prinkled this Powder. Powder. Bol. armen. iij. ang. Dracon. Myrrh. Matich. an j. far. volatil. ij. Rad. Tormentil. Pentaphyll. an. ij. mice. The wound was handled as that it might be covered with fleh, the circumjacent parts were anointed with Oyls, and an anodyne Cataplam precribed for eaing of pains, he being well defended from cold and air, beyond all expectation of many he recovered.

div.head: CHAP. LXV.
Of Wounds of the Liver.
div.p:
WE come next to dicoure of the Liver, being in Latine called Jecur, quai Juxta Cor, being a large bowel eated in the right Hypochondry under the Diaphragma, round and mooth in its convex part, and in its lower part concave. Its ubtance is oft and red, much reembling concrete blood. Malpighius who by Microcopes hath mot accurately viewed its ubtance and inwards parts, hath herein oberved many things unknown to former ages. As firt, the ubtance hereof in Man is contexed of Lobes, and thee framed out of the Glandules, the which affording a heap of mall Ramifications, are inveted with a proper circumcribing membrane. And that the whole mas of the Liver doth conit of rough Glandules, and divere Ramifications of Veels, and hence is it, that they hould work together, Nature hath necearily interceded a commerce between thee Veels and thoe Glandules. Thirdly that the Veels of the Port, hollow, and biliary ductus, do run through all the branches into thee little Lobes in an equal number, and that the branches of the Gate Vein do carry the power of the Arteries, and that there is uch a commerce and ociety between the Gate-vein and biliary ductus, that both their ramifications are trongly knit by one and the ame knot. The ramifications of thee Veels are not joined together by Anatomois, but thee rough Glandules contitute the chief part of the Liver, and o they order ome of thee for conveying others for receiving into the ame. Hence may be conjectured that the Liver is a conglomerated glandule, training the Bilis.
And hence may we well contradict the opinion of the Antients, who did acribe to the Liver the principal faculty of anguification; for we evidently ee that it is but as a colature for the Bilis. It's covered with a mall membrane adhering to its Parenchyma, and from this do many mall watery bladders arie, from whence cometh the Dropie hereof, as Platerus oberveth. It's tied by three ligaments, to the Abdomen by the umbilical Vein; econdly to the Diaphragma upwards from the right part, by a large thin membranous ligament taken from the Peritonaeum called Supenorium; the third upwards alo to the Diaphragma. It's made of a Parenchymatous ubtance, much reembling the ubtance of a Bullocks Liver; the ues of which Parenchyma are very coniderable, howing it elf to be the principal part of the Liver, the other parts being but as ubervients to it, for the ligaments do trengthen its ite, a coat covers it, the Gate-vein brings it blood, the common Capula adminitreth to it, the Artery and Hepatick Nerve do pay their ervice partly to the Port-vein, partly to the common Capula and biliary pore, the mall branches of the Vena Cava and Hepatick Ductus do take hence their blood, it eparates the Bilis from the blood, and is as a colature here ordained by Nature for performing this office. But not to dwell too long here, we pas to its colour, and this is omewhat reddih, in ickly people it is een to look pale. The Veels in the Liver are the roots of the two great Veins the Cava and Porta. The Veels in the Liver are accounted even in number, as the branches of the Porta, of the Cava, of the bladder of Gall, the Capule of the great vein, the Hepatick Artery, Hepatick Nerve, and Hepatick Lympheducts. To which alo may be added the Umbilical Veins. Having thus given you an account of the Liver, its paages, ues, ite, connexion, and Veels, we come now to its Wounds. And here they happen either uperficially, or penetrating even its Trunks.

Signs. Celus lib. 5. cap. 26. gives us thee as Signs of a wounded Liver, viz. a great flux of blood in the right ide, the ides all drawn up towards the pine, the Patient doth delight to lie upon his Belly, ometimes vomiting of Choler doth happen, the blood which iueth out is thick, the Pule is hereby depreed, the Patient looketh of a white and ahey colour, accompanied with Cough and Fever, their water is bloody, and by their iege they are een to dicharge both bloody and purulent matter. The wound happens in the right ide, and under the purious ribs in that ide, at the hurt hereof the Heart is much concerned.

Preages. Superficial wounds here happening may admit cure, but large and deep wounds (Hipp. Abh. 18. lib. 6.) admit no cure. If cold weats attend the Patient, and he is very ubject to faint, if the extreme parts grow chilly, thee declare death near. If inflammation econds the wound, hence certainly follows Fever and Syncope, a troubled urine, and corrupt excrements, all which are Harbingers of death.

Cure. If the wound be deep and large, penetrating the ubtance of the Liver and dividing ome of its great branches, this cure is rather to be committed to the Miniter than to the Chirurgeon: but where any hopes may offer of cure, where no great flux of blood doth follow the wound, nor any Ichor floweth hence, when the Liver is lightly wounded, here may we attempt its cure, by precribing a cooling diet, and uch as is of an agglutinative quality; and for this purpoe, Rice and Barleywater are good, adding hereto Borage-leaves, Plantain, or Panadoes, or Milk, all thee to be ued until all danger of inflammation be over. For this ue alo Phlebotomy is very proper, or he may drink Wine mixt and allayed with water, wherein may be boiled Jujubes and Cichory. And if herein evacuation be required, here may be afely precribed Caia, Manna, Diacatholicon, Lenitivum,
or Rhubarb, all which are very good medicines to be taken in a morning. Keep the Body o open that the Patient may have the benefit of nature every or every other day. In thee wounds the flux of blood is to be topped, then apply Turpentine to the wound, adding the fourth day thereto Bol. Armen. and Mummy, and latly, Matick, Frankincene, and Tragacanth, anointing all its circumjacent parts with oyl of Roes. Outwardly may be injected of this into the wound, both for trengthning the diected Fibres, and alo for their agglutination. Succ. Equiet. Pentaphyl. Piloell. Polygon. Decoction. Thur. Mum. Rhabarb. opt. Rad. Centaur. major. Sang. Dracon. in gutt. an. q. . fiat mixtura. This to be injected into the wound two or three times in a day. A large wound here received is to be titched up, leaving an Orifice in its bottom for the dicharge of the matter and all other uperfluities; over which is to be applied Diapalma or any other agglutinative Empl. not leaving any patient which is deeply wounded without help, for a doubtful hope is better than a reolved depair, as Hipp. writes.

To conclude, Glandorp. ob. 33. fol. 166. writes of a young man who being of a good habit of body received a wound in his right ide at the end of the three batard Ribs, in which a great part of the Liver was wounded alo. The wound was eight fingers broad, and yet not penetrating all over the Abdomen. Hence followed a great quantity of blood. The Liver Vein of the right Arm was breathed, from whence was drawn four ounces of blood. The lips of the wound in the places where it had not penetrated were own up, and to the Liver was applied this following Powder. Terr. Lemn. Powder. Bol. Armen. an. j. Troch. de Carab. Terr. igillat. an. ij. Lap. Haematit. is. farin. volatil. iij. mice fiat pulvis ubtiliimus. To the wound was applied unguent. alb. Camphorat. for awaging of pain and Inflammation, and
Liniment. this Liniment with the following Cataplam. Ol. Ro. s Violar. iij. unguent. Santal. ij. mice. Herb. Violar. Catapl. Cichor. Endiv. recent. an. pug. iij. um. Aneth. Scord. Hyporic. Centaur. n. p. ij. Flor. Cham. Melil. Roar. an. pug. j. Farin. Hord. Fabar. an. is. Orob. j. cum Vini rubri q. . fiat Catapl. fine addendo ol. violar. is. Axung. Gallin. s. Vitell. Ov. n. j. To the lips of the wounds were put Tents and doills armed with a digetive. For his drink he was ordered this following. Medicate Barley water. Hord. bene mundat. M. j. coque in f. q. aqu. pluvial. ad lbiiij. colaturae adde Fol. Taraxac. Endiv. an. M. s. em. ani. iij. Cinamomi s. var. paular. ablut. j. colaturam erva ad uum. Ofttimes did he drink whey. Sometimes in a morning was given him an ounce of Syrup of Cichory with Rhubarb. And that which was very trange, he had no feaver till the twenty firt day. The which then happened with watchings and great pain, for which was precribed this Clyter. Rad. Alth. recent. Conolid. major. an. s. Herb. Malv. Alth. violar. an. Clyter. M. j. Taraxac. Sonch. Cichor. an. p. iij. fl. Cham. Meliot. Scord. Hyperic. an. pug. ij. em. Ani. Foenicul. an. iij. Lin. oenngraec. an. s coquantur in . q. aq ad ix. colaturae adde Electuar. de Bacc. Laur. vj. Ol. Sanicul. Lilior. alb. an. j. Succ. Epatic. s Butyr. recent. vj. Vitell. Ovor. n. j. mice. With this he was omewhat refrehed. After which was precribed an Emulion, and to the Region Epitheme.of the heart was applied this Epitheme. R. Aqu. Nymph. Lactuc. Borag. Roar. an. vj. Spec. tr. Santal. j. Cordial. temperat. j. mice. His pirits beginning to renew beyond hopes or expectation, he was ordered thee Troches.comfortable Troches. R. Spec. Aromatic. Roat. Dialacc. an. s de Gemm. Diacorall. an. j. Margarit. praecript. s. Sacchar. albiim. q. . olut. in aqu. Cichor. ij. fiant Tabelli, fine addendo Ol. Ani. gutt. iiij. The wound of the Liver began to conolidate, and incarne, and at length was produced a fair Cicatrice, and with admiration
of all he was retored to his former health.

Another. Foretus, Ob. 3. lib. 6. Ob. Chirurg. writes of one who who being wounded in the Liver, out of the orifice of which would did hang a piece of the Liver, Carpus in his firt viit repoed it, the which part Nature afterwards eparated. The day following in the morning was this precribed. Rhabarb. opt. j. Mum. gr. 10. Rub. Tinct. j. Potion. cumpauco vini rubri fiat potio. His diet was bread dipt in water, afterwards was ordered him bread put into chalybeated water, in which was boyled a bagg which contained thee things in powder. R. Matich. Tragac. Gum Arabic. Thur. em. Plantag. an. s. and this boiled bread he eat of until the flux of blood was topt. The third day and alo the fourth, fifth, ixth and eventh day he took of this following Syrup. R. Syr. Myrtin. j. Endiv. s. Syrup. Aqu. Endiv. Plantag. an js. Mice. The eighth day was precribed him this following. R. Rhubarb. elect. iiij. Potion. Scoenanth. gr. vij. Mann. elect. ij. cum. Aqu. Endiv. Chamomel. q. . fiat potio. His wound was thus dealt with in the econd viit, the blood being cleaned a Tent was armed with this compoition and applied. R. Sang. Dracon. in gutt. Myrtill. Bol. Armen. an. ij. Roar. rubr. M. ij. powder them all finely, and with adding hereto the white of an egg make a mixture. The circumjacent parts were anointed with Ol. Roar. and powder of Dragons blood was prinkled upon the part, over which was applied a bowlter or tuph dipt in vinegar and o pret out, over which was comprehended the rowler; and the part being thus bound up o remained for four days. The dreings being removed, a new Tent armed with Oyl of Turpentine and Roes was put into the wound, prinkling upon it of the former powder. Afterwards was applied this Sarcotick or Incarnative. R. Ol. Abietin. Myrtin. an. ij. Cer. j. Thur. Unguent. Sang. Dracon. an. s. mice, fiat nguentum. Afterwards with Bailicon and other convenient Medicines he was oon healed and cured.

div.head: CHAP. LXVI.
Of Wounds of the Ventricle.
div.p:
HAving drawn all the other parts out by Anatomy, we come next to the Ventricle which is accounted Natures Workhoue, the Kitchin of the body, wherein are hown the Organs and Intruments that both maintain the family of the body, and its pirits. And eeing the life-tide of every creature is incontant, and doth quickly pote away, Nature doth endeavour by reaon of the continual expene of his threefold ubtance whereof he coniteth, to conclude the breach by repiration and nutriment. This Ventricle is an Organick part placed in the lower Venter, and is the Intrument of chylfication. It lies under the Diaphragma as it were hanging in the middle of the body; its left part is larget and more round towards the bottom, and is placed in the left Hypochondry, giving way to the Liver in its right. It hath two Orifices, and both in its upper part, the left of which is generally called the upper mouth of the Stomach. It hath allowed it circular Fibres that it may hut its Orifice. It's by this Orifice that we let down our meat and drink, it's placed in the Epigatrical Region. Its right Orifice commonly called its lower part, doth much differ from the other, for it is narrow, and doth remain hut until an abolute concoction be made of the meat. The Chyle paeth by this Pylorus or Janitor. This Pylorus by Helmontius is held to be the moderator of digetion. It hath three orts of Fibres allowed it, right, oblique and tranvere, and to thee ome grant thee three operations, retention, attraction, and expulion. It hath three orts of coats or membranes,
the firt ariing from the Peritonaeum and is the thicket, the econd more flehy, the third nervous, into which the veels and coats of the Oeophagus, Mouth, and Lips are terminated. And hence is it that we perceive when there is any choler in our Stomachs that we do find a bitternes in our mouths. Its ubtance is membranous and cold, its figure is round and omewhat long, much reembling a Bagpipe, it's maller in Women than in Men, its veels it hath many from the Spleen. Conringius, Hortius and others do defend that it taketh its Veins from the Gate-vein, its Arteries it hath from the Coeliaca. Its Nerves arie from the ixth pair.

Signs and Preages. Now as touching its wounds. When the Ventricle is wounded there generally doth happen a Singultus, and a vomiting of choler doth ucceed, and whatever is taken in of meat or drink at the mouth doth make its quick paage hither. Here follows no great flux of blood, for the Veins belonging hereto are but mall, ave only in its bottom. It's uddenly tirred up with pains, and hence is peedily inflamed, the motions of its Veins do languih, thin weats do arie, and hence the extream parts do grow cold, ometimes both chyle and indigeted victuals do pas out of the wound, pitting of blood doth attend thee, and cruel pains of the Heart doth eem to be herewith concerned, at length this noble part doth grow hard, being deprived of its natural utenance. And the wound is made under the Sternon in the middle Region. This being cut, death oon follows. For it's the intrument of the firt concoction, and doth receive and elaborate what is received into it, and what it findeth unneceary or ueles it throws out by its Pylorus. Its outward part if only wounded may be cured having in it a flehy intertexture pun of tranvere Fibres, but its dometick or nervous part is either very rarely or never conolidated if wounded, being generally replenihed with humours and liquors, and hence follow Fevers,
Vertigo, Syncope, Singultus, vomitings, and other evil ymptoms, the which do pot away to the Heart, and make it hare and communicate of its direful accidents.

Cure. When the Ventricle is wounded, we are to enquire into thee its proper igns, and if poibly, to gain the true place of the wound; the which having once purchaed, we are to ee how far it penetrates. In thee wounds all fatty and oleaginous meats are to be hunned, and uch as are Euchymick and eaie of digetion are to be here elected. Let the Patient eat and drink very paringly. Outwardly may be applied a Decoction made of chalybeated water wherein have been boiled Comfrey roots, Sumach, Myrtills, Cicers, and Pimpinel. The common and general Intention of the inward parts is, that all uch things are here to be precribed which are mot familiar to the nature and contitution of the Patient, and uch as may mot properly be allowed for his nourihment, uch as are Partridge, Pheaant, Rabets, Blackbirds, Plover and the like. If the body be plethorique breath a Vein. If cacochymick dicharge the peccant humour with ome convenient Cathartick. Thee rather to be given Clyterwie than by the mouth. This he may take every morning by his mouth, as Syrup of Myrtills, of dried Roes mixt with the decoction of Centaury, Comfrey and Betony, to which may be added a little powder of the Troch. de Carabe or Spod. j. in thee caes alo Saccharum Roatum is good And becaue agglutination is the greatet intention in thee wounds, you may order your Patient to take every morning of Electuar. Diapermat. j. diolved in the decoction of Comfrey or Betony or Cinquefoil, and this to be taken every morning and at four in the afternoon. The wound if it be large is to be titcht up, which is very rarely done, or firt to be covered with Turpentine, anointing all its circumjacent parts with oyl of Roes, Camomile,
Matick, and the like, and fill up with Bailicon, and skin with Diapalma, leaving the ret to Nature to perform. If the wound be o large that it cannot be titcht up, then are we to dilate the wound of the Abdomen, and hereby enquire whether the Chyle doth pas out of the wounded Ventricle, and falleth into the cavity of the Abdomen; in this cae the wound is not to be titcht up, for the Chyle thus paing among the Guts doth corrupt them; and hence the wound is to be kept open, precribing inwardly uch medicines for the Patient as have both an atringent and agglutinative quality. In thee caes Troch. de Spod. de Terr. Lemn. de Carab. and Diapermat. as I have already hown are very good and proper. Outwardly may be injected into the wound two or three drops of this following medicine. R. Ol. Matich. j. Abietin. j. Thur. ij. pul. Tormentil. vel Chamomel. fl. hyperic. rad. Conolid. major. an. j. verm. Terretr. n. 5. Croe. j. vini nigr. ij. mice, coquantur ad vini conumpt. potea cola, and dip your Tents and pledgets herein and apply them to the wounded parts. And here in all wounds of the Abdomen are we to oberve that we defend them from pain and inflammation by anointing the circumjacent parts of the wound with oyl of Roes mixt with White-wine. Glandorp hath a remarkable Hitory, Hitory.which indeed ought to be communicated to poterity, of a Countryman of Prague thirty years of age, who wallowed a Knife which was nine tranvere fingers long, being contituted or brought hereby into an inexplicable narrownes, which no art could poibly be thought to remove or extract; yet by Gods mercy in this deperate cae it was conjectured that the Loadtone, and other attractive Intruments might work omewhat herein: hence attractive medicines are applied which made the end of the Knife to appear upwards above the upper mouth of the Stomach, where in uch a deperate cae, no more proper way could be found than Section
which was performed by Florianus Matthiius of Brandenburgh. Thus the Knife which was for even weeks and two days lodged in the upper part of the Ventricle, and had contracted a trange colour, was taken out by him, the wound being made by inciion, proper medicines being applied the Patient recovered, and by his Widom, Indutry and Art he was perfectly cured.

Another. Fallopius de vuln. cap. c. 12. writes that he cured both a Woman and a Man from whom both chyle and meat did pas. He cured a Woman, who being hot by a leaden bullet from the fore & back part, or quite through, perfectly recovered. But if a great wound do happen in the mouth of the Stomach, it brings peedy death with it becaue of the excellency of this part, and its conent it hath with the Heart.

Another. Jac. Orthaeus lib. Ob. prop. writes that in the City of Fuldana two indutrious and judicious Chirurgeons affirmed to him that they had a Souldier a trong man and one of a good courage in hand, who was wounded by a Countreyman about the left Hypochondry, the which wound when they had well examined, and inquired into its depth, it was found that the Stomach was wounded in its right ide, and o perforated, that the meat and drink which the Patient took in by his mouth threw it elf oon out by the Orifice of the wound, the finger being put over it, it did more evidently appear. The event hereof being conjectured to be ill both by thee Chirurgeons and uch as were pectators, it was conented that this wounded part of the Ventricle hould be brought outwards to the lips of the wound and that the wounded Stomach and the lips of the wounded Cutis hould be own together, although this operation was conjectured not to be void both of pain and danger; but the thing was done, o as the wound being conglutinated, no further danger enued, but the wounded man was retored to his pritine health.

div.head: CHAP. LXVII.
Of Wounds of the Spleen.
div.p:
THE Spleen is an Organick bowel eated in the left Hypochondry, between the Ventricle and Ribs. In man this is generally one, and very rarely exceeds this number. In its convex part it's tied to the Diaphragma uperficially, its Fibres do arie from the Peritonaeum. Its blunt part adheres to the Omentum and its neighbouring parts. Its magnitude is various in men, according to their variety of contitution and bodies. Spigelius doth oberve that thoe that have large Veins have alo a large Spleen. Its figure is long; its colour is ublivid or of a leady colour. It's covered with a double membrane, the outward ariing from the Peritonaeum, the other is its proper coat, between either of which is inerted a plenty of Lympheducts endowed with many valves. It hath innumerable thin and trong Fibres framed out of Filaments intertexed with admirable art. Beides thee Lymphatick veels, it receiveth other veels as Veins, Nerves, Arteries. Its Arteries ariing from the left branch of the Caeliaca, it ends forth the plenetick branch out of its blunt part. Its Nerves it doth receive from the ixth pair. Its office is to make a ubacid matter out of the arterious blood. We come now to its being wounded, where we may by thee igns collect its hurt. This part being well replenihed with Arteries, being of a pungy and looe ubtance, framed and nourihed as it were by a thick, black and melancholick blood, when this part is wounded there follows inflammation; yet when it is lightly wounded, thee wounds are of no great moment, for inward medicines may with eae reach this part.
thee wounds are collected from their ite alo happening in the left Hypochondry by the blood iuing thence. Thee wounds are to be cured as you do cure wounds of the Liver, and therefore I hall not here trouble you with repetitions.

Hitory. Foret. Ob. 2. writes of a Souldier being wounded in the Spleen, for which Carpus precribed this following Potion.Syrup. R. Syr. Roar. is. aqu. Cichor. caud. equin. Conolid. major. an. j. mice, and with Troch. de Carab. j. let it be aromatized. To the wound was applied mall Tents infued or dipt in oyl of Hypericon, Roar. and Abietin. of each equal parts, the which was thus followed for ome days; in the econd day over thee was applied Empl.this Empl. R. Vin. opt. iiij. Acet. j. & cum far. fabar. q. . fiat Empl. After this was applied an Incarnative Unguent, and then a cicatrizing medicine. In the beginning breathing of a Vein was precribed, and this Potion directed Potion.after the Syrup. R. Ca. novit. extr. vj. Diaprun. alutiv. j. Rhabarb. ij. Spic. gr. vj. cum decoct. commun. fiat potio, and after this method was he recovered.

div.head: CHAP. LXVIII.
Of Wounds of the Kidnies.
div.p: THee parts by the Greeks are called < in non-Latin alphabet > which ignifies to rain, or < in non-Latin alphabet > from a defluxion of humours. They are in number two, that the one coming to a michance the other may act for both. They are planted between the two Membranes of the Peritonaeum at the ides of the Cava and Aorta, the right being omewhat lower than the left. Their magnitude is much alike, their length is commonly three vertebres, ometimes four. Their figure does omewhat reemble an expanded Aarum leaf, outwardly gibbous and recurvated, inwardly omewhat concave. They are covered with two membranes, the outward of which is common and ariing from the Peritonaeum is called Adipoa, into this does pas Arteria adipoa. And out of this does pas Vena adipoa. This membrane does annex either Kidney to the Loyns and Diaphragma, the right alo to the Caecum, the left to the Spleen and Colon, its inward coat it gets from the outward coat of the veels. Either Kidney hath allowed it two large anguiferous veels, an Artery, and an emulgent Vein. In the inward part of the Kidney is framed a Pelvis or Infundibulum, being a membranous cavity, it appears of a fibrous ubtance. The ue or action is to eparate and dicharge the redundant eroe humidity from the blood, which is brought thither by the emulgent Arteries, of which blood in its tranition through the Kidneys glandules, venary fibres, and papillary caruncles, a good part of this erum is eparated and ditilled into this Pelvis, and thence being carried into the ureters is ent by them into the Bladder. As to its wounds

Signs. Cel. lib. 5. cap. 26. writes, if the Kidneys be wounded to the Pelvis, clots of blood will come forth with the urine, cauing a great pain in the wounded part, and this reaching the Groin and Teticle. Thee wounds are known by their ite and ymptomes, for hence do follow uppreion of Urine, or change of its colour, Preages.the patient does tumify. If the wound be made by the back and the Kidney penetrated this way, the patient cannot ecape, for in this cae the wound mut pierce the Poas. If the wound be made by the ide, and does but only penetrate the papillary Caruncles, it may be cured with difficulty. If the wound penetrates the Pelvis it mut necearily be lethal, in that the drain of the Serum from the Veins and Arteries is hindred. Then becaue its ubtance doth not without difficulty yield conolidation. If its Vein and Artery be wounded, here flatter not your elf with any hope of cure: beides they are always nourihed with waterih blood, and almot continually in motion, and being planted o near the Vena Cava, wounds here happening cannot be void of danger. You eeing this cure very dangerous to undertake, hould not be very forward to be concerned Cure.therewith, but according to Hipp. rule, becaue a doubtful hope is better than a reolved depair, you are here to ue the ame outward method which hath been already precribed in penetrating wounds of the Abdomen. Inwardly are you to begin here with a good order of diet, then an adequation of humours, the which ometimes is made by Phlebotomy, or by Solution of the thin humours, or by a peedy evacuation. If a great plenty of thin and crude humors do appear, vomiting in this cae is good, for it both does deterge, evacuate and revel fluxions. Let his diet be of good Juice, as Pheant, Partridge and the like, reer Eggs and Panado is good here, ordering him to drink but little, for this does both diturb and hinder the bet of Medicines from curing. And
ret here is a great advantage from thee. If much blood flow from the wounded Kidney breath a Vein in the Arm, and this repeat as oft as need requires. And then order uch Medicines as may top this flux. Into the wound may be injected a Traumatick decoction made of Comfrey roots, Tragacant. diolved in Wine, or Polygonum and Juice of Plantain with Poca. Over which may outwardly be applied a Cataplam made of Palmes, Acacia, Hypocitis boyled in red Wine. Such anative injections, and vulnerary potions as I have already et down in Wounds of the Liver and Thorax, may here with great advatage be made ue of.

Hitory. A Souldier being wounded, in which wound the right Kidney was alo wounded, was thus cured by taking every morning of Terr. igillat. j. Terebinth. Cupre. j. thee being mixt together. After which he took a little draught of white Wine, which Wine preently did come through the wound a little tinged. Outwardly was applied nguentum Sanctum, already hown you in Wounds of the Thorax, by which in a hort time he was recovered.
Fallop. lib. de vuln. cap. 12. writes that he aw the left Kidney pricked and wounded, becaue the Parenchyma, like thick blood concreted into fleh.
Dodonaeus in Schol. ad cap. 22. writes of a Woman which was by a Dagger wounded in the Loins, upon which he ejected bloody and purulent Urine, until both the wound and the Kidney was cured.

div.head: CHAP. LXIX.
Of Wounds of the Bladder.
div.p: THE urinary Bladder is a membranous part of the lower belly, the which receiving the Serum from the Kidneys doth retain it in it for a while. It is eated in the Hypogatrium between two coats of the Peritonaeum, in the cavity which is efformed by the bones of the Os Sacrum, Coxendix and Pubis. It coniteth of a threefold membrane. It hath a longih and globous or pyramidal figure. It hath one cavity perviated with three Foramens, two at its neck, and one at the end of the Ureter entring it. It receiveth its Arteries from the Hypogatrical Arteries paing into the ides of its neck, carrying blood to it for its nutriment. It admits Nerves from the ixth pair, and the marrow of the Spina Dori. It's divided into a neck and a bottom, its bottom lies upwards, its neck downwards, and is the lower and narrower part thereof. Its neck is contituted of many Fibres chiefly tranvere and orbicular encompaing the whole body of the bladder here contituting a Sphincter Mucle, contringing the neck of the bladder, o as the urine might not involuntarily fall out. Having given you this hort draught of the bladder by Anatomy, we are next to enquire into its wounds, where firt we are to enquire of the igns hereof.

Signs and Preages. Celus lib. 5. cap. 26. writes thee as Signs hereof, the urine doth come bloody and paringly. If the body of the bladder be wounded, the urine doth fall into the cavity of the Abdomen, and the pain will communicate it elf to the Teticles and Inguens. The Stomach is herewith affected, a vehement pain doth accompany the
Chet, and anxiety with cold Convulions and death follows. Wounds happening in the neck of the bladder are to be cured as we ee by daily experience in Lithotomy, or extraction of the Stone from thence. Wounds alo in the lateral parts thereof happening about the Groin are alo curable, in uch as are young and of a healthful contitution. Hipp. writes that wounds in the membranous parts of the bladder are incurable, Aphor. 18. ect. 6.

Cure. As to its cure. Things outwardly to be applied may properly be accounted thee. As, to three parts of Turpentine to add one of oyl of St. Johns-wort, and over this to apply Empl. Diapalm. Cyprus Turpentine with the yolk of an Egg mixt together with a little Vernih is alo good here. In uch wounds as happen o opportunely that we may come at them, falling upon the flehy part thereof, you may here proceed by injections put through the urinary paage, uch as are thee two Decoctions. . Hord. mundat. Roar. rubr. Centaur. min. an. M. s. vini Decoction. vigr. auter. q. . pro Decocto. To which add in the end Rhodomel. ij. And ue this. Or R. Cydonior. incior. n. A vulnerary potion. iiij. Equiet. Sumach. Bacc. Myrtill. an. iij. Roar. rubr. pug. ij. Balaut. ss. coquantur in aqu. pluvial. lb 16. ad 3. partis conumpt. coletur, colatur â¢ olv. Syr. Ã¨ Rois ic. Mel. Roar. an. vj. Syr. Myrtin. iij. Gum. Tragac. iij. of which let him drink and nothing ele for ten days. If you deire a more drying injection take this. Rad. Conolid. major. Centuar. fol. Oliv. Injection. Myrtillor. an. q. . Amyl. iss. aqu. chalybeat. q. . pro decocto, fine addendo Mell. Roar. ij. pro uu. If it be too harp add a little milk hereto, all thee to be applied warm, and o as they may beget no wind.

Hitory. Glandorp. Ob. 38. fol. 176. writes of a Souldier who having received a wound upon the Os Pubis, and being thrown backwards hereupon, the urine flew out copiouly. That night he was correpted with pain in his head.
Convenient things being ordered him, the third day he died, the body being opened the bladder was een wounded in that part in which the Urachus is inerted.

Another. Riverius Ob. 5. morbor. infrequentium fol. 75. writes of one who being hot by a bullet through the urinary paage, this wound penetrating the bladder, and the right ide of the Os acrum, o that he urined by the back part of his wound, the urinary paage being only hurt, yet he was retored to his former health, firt by applying a defenative, then with arming the Tents with Bailicon mixt with the yolk of an Egg, afterwards with nguent. de Reina, and latly with Sarcoticks and Epouloticks.

Another. Felix Wirtz Anno 1581. in the month of September, a Mariner, had a Knife truck into the right ide of his Abdomen four tranvere fingers above the Pudenda, o as the urine did wholly pas through the wound, the which afterwards was well cured, by precribing Clyters firt, then the wound was not dreed with Tents armed, but applying over it a conolidating medicine, over which was applied a gummy plater. Inwardly did he dayly twice in a day take a decoction of Orpine, which is excellent here in thee wounds, abtaining from hot meats, contenting himelf with little drink, and lying in his bed downwards. By which oberving he in three days had his urine flowed out by the Urethra, and was afterwards perfectly healed.

Another. Caparus Bauhinus in Append. ad Rouet. de Partn Caeareo writes of a Fiherman who had his urine peedily uppreed, the which would not by any remedies or by the Catheter be removed, hence did arie a great Tumour of his belly, and he was come even to the lat of danger: he being advied with, orders inciion hereof whereby might be found out the caue of this his uppreion. When therefore Inciion was firt made in the Inguen, as there it is their way of cutting, the Lithotomit
in eparating the carnoity which was the more protene by reaon of the bladder being thus ditended by the urine, did open it, and the wound was produced, and the urine pun out with a great force, whereby the Patient was oon at eae. The Teticle in the ame ide being takenout, the wound continued its paage by the wound. The wound being healed, a Fitula remained in the region of the Groin, through which a hort Catheter being ent, the which he generally carried about him, within a mall while his water paed without any detriment, and no longer did he urine through his yard. At this ection Platerus and Bauhinus were preent amongt the ret.

div.head: CHAP. LXX.
Of Wounds of the Teticles and Penis.
div.p:
WE come lat of all to the parts appointed for procreation, being the Genital parts, where we are to tay a while and view thee parts by Anatomy. And firt to begin with the Tetes or Teticles being proper parts hanging out beyond the Abdomen and planted in the Scrotum, they are called Tetes becaue they tetify a mans virility. They are in number two, partly that the eed may proceed more happily; partly that one of thee being taken away, it might be neceary for the other to perform the office of both. They are placed at the root of the Penis and hid up in a Scrotum. They much reemble a Pidgeons Egg. They have a peculiar ubtance the like of which is not to be een in the whole body, white and oft, being made of innumerable minute funicles of eminiferous veels. They are in a great errour who do account thee glandules, for they neither have in them the temper, ubtance or ue of glandules. They receivemall Arteries from the Spermaticks, and do end forth mall Veins to the Cava and left Emulgent. Its Nerves it receives from the ixth pair. The anguiferous Veels do enter the ubtance of the Teticles, and whether they do end in the albugineous coat, is a doubt not yet reolved. They are wrapt about with an albugineous and vaginal coat. They have two Mucles allowed them, called Cremateres or Supenorii. Outwardly they are covered with a Scrotum as with a Pure or Bag. To thee alo do belong, Vaa deferentia, Veiculae eminariae, Protatae, and the like, all which being at large dicoured of by Anatomits I hall peak no further hereof. Now come we to the Penis, where alo are we to ee
how this virile member is framed and contituted. The Seed being made ready in the former Veels, does require a peculiar Intrument for its injection, for the performance of which Nature hath ordained that part which we call Penis. This being an Organick part appointed for injection of the Sperm in terum, and alo for excretion of the Urin. It's placed at the root of the Os Pubis, it hath a long and almot round figure, not being alike in all people. It conits of a Cuticula, Cutis, Membrana Carnoa, and a proper ubtance, wanting fat. The rethra or Urinary paage is placed in its lower part, which inwardly is inveted with a thin and enible, outwardly with a fibrous and cavernous membrane, continued all along its neck. It hath a good large paage, ave only in its fore-part where the Glans is joyned to the nervous bodies. Its ue is to convey and conduct the eed through it, and alo to let the Urin pas through it, and hence Nature hath appointed two mall Cavities into it for the letting the eed into it. In the upper part of the rethra lie two nervous bodies, contituting the greatet part of the Yard. At the end of the Penis is planted a glans, or by ome called Caput Penis, in the which the two nervous bodies do end with the rethra: it hath a Turbinat Figure; its colour is omewhat ublivid, but tumefying it is red. It obtains a proper ubtance, being flehy, oft, pungious and of a quick ene inveted witha thin Membrane. Outwardly it is covered with a Praeputium which is framed of a Cuticula and Cutis, in its lower part it is tied to the Glans by a Fraenum or bridle. It takes its Arteries from the Hypogatricis prinkled through its nervous bodies running through its length, it ends forth Veins inwardly to the Hypogatricis, outwardly to the Pudendis. It's moved by four Mucles.

Thus have I given you an Anatomical decription of thee parts, we now proceed to them being wounded.
Signs. Where firt we are to inquire into the igns. And becaue thee parts are endowed with an exquiite ene, great care is to be had as touching their Cure that they may not be vexed with pain or Inflammation, thee parts being very plentifully tored with Veins and Arteries. For as Paracelus writes, wounds happening in thee parts are accompanied with great pain, and very ubject are they to inflammation. The whole body therefore being well ordered, and a good diet precribed, and Phlebotomy directed, we are next to come to the wounded parts, where we are both to provide againt pain and inflammation, for which ues thee are very proper Medicines. Againt pain may be ordered uch things as may mitigate it, and for this, R. Malv. Violar. Solan. an. M. j. Furfur. pug. ij. coquantur in Sapa, and apply it to the part. Oyl of Roes, Chamomile or Dill will do the ame, anointing the circumjacent parts therewith. And for Inflammation by Rondeletius we are advied to ue Repellers and breath a Vein, and for this ue alo may be applied a Cataplam made of Bean Meal, Wine and Vineger boiled together to be applied warm and renewed until the pain remit. If it ceae not by thee, you may add powder of Camomel flowers, Melilot flowers, Red Roes, and Elder flowers, and make it into a Catapl. to the wounded part. Oyl of S. Johns wort mixt with Turpentine is a good Medicine. If the wound be large titch it up, leaving an Orifice in its lower part for the dicharge of the matter, anointing the circumjacent parts with Oyl or Unguent of Roes and Oyl of Matich. Then the wound is to be deterged with honey of Roes, filled up with Bailicon, and incarned with Diapompholigos and skinned with Diapalma.

Hitory. We hall conclude this with ome Hitories. I begin with that of Foretus which he hath Ob. 6. de Pen. & Virg. vitiis fol. 39. where he writes of a Taylor who being vexed with an inflammation of his yard, which
inflammation he had contracted in the venerial embraces of a Woman, not much minding it at firt, having a Wife being a kind of a Doctres did acquaint her herewith, who ordered him a trong Purge made with Electuar. Ã¨ uc. Roar. This inflammation with inflation of his Penis, and tumour of his Scrotum and Teticles till encreaing, he required the help of another and better Chirurgeon, who by applying very hot medicines hereto within three days had made an Ethiomenus. The Chirurgeon having all his Intruments ready for taking off his yard, with medicines before the operation, the Patients friends called Foretus into conultation, and eeing that the Ethiomenus had not only poeed the whole Penis but had alo reached the Teticles, he conjectured that if the whole members hould be taken off the Patient would die under the Chirurgeons hands in the operation; and becaue in one part hereof the Penis did appear black and corrupted, and as if it were mortified and tinking, it was by general conent agreed to have all this removed becaue they were not to be brought to their former natural form. And this to be done with a hot Knife.
