Within a while the whole member grew corrupted, whoe corruption reached the Teticles, this Chirurgeon would alo have this amputated, but this was not agreed upon. Another Chirurgeon being advied with, contrary to the former opinion would by no means allow any further inciion, but doth order this following Catapl. Farin. Catapl. Hord. is. Far. Fabar. j. coquantur cum lact. viij. his adde succ. emperviv. coque ad conumpt. Succi, tunc adde pulv. Roar. rubr. fl. Cham. an. ij. mice pro Cataplamate, by which Cataplam both the inflammation and flation were allayed in the part, but the member eemed till to putrify, and hereupon a Fever to arie. Breathing of a Vein not being at firt precribed was not now to be attempted by reaon of his weaknes. Wherefore was precribed him this Julep. Aqu. Fumar. Borag. Julep.
Cichor. Endiv. Lupul. an. is. Syr. Aceto. Citr. de Fumar. Syr. Nenuphar. an. j. Spec. arom. Triaantal. Emulion. an. ij fiat Julap. And becaue he could not ret, was ordered this Emulion. Hord. mund. pug. j. Amygdal. dulc. depilat. ij. em. 4. frigid. major. em. Papaver. alb. an. j. fiat Hordeatum ad lbj. huic adde acchar. albi. q. . ad emulum. The remainer of the Ethiomenus was horrible in apect, o as the whole member eemed to be correpted with a black ulcer, paing into a gangrene, putrifying the parts, and with that ill mell that no man could come near him and this on a udden. While therefore the Chirurgeon was cutting away thee putrified parts, the mell o encreaed that one could carce remain in the room. Hence the Fever encreaed, and out of this ill mell did arie inflammation of his Throat, for which was ordered this Gargarim. Decoct. Hord. Gargarim. mundat. & Liquirit. lbj. Syr. violar. Ro. icc. an. j. mice pro Gargarimate. And for his drought was precribed him this following. Syr. violar. is. Syr. granator. j. and this he took frequently. After this the Fever began omewhat to abate, and the corrupt parts to be taken off by degrees. The aboveaid Cataplam was applied to the parts again. The putrifaction was of that largenes that it proceeded even to the Teticles. Over the Cataplam was applied a double linnen cloath dipt in Renih-wine. But at lat the Patient died. The Chirurgeon which only remained with Foretus applied only this Digetive to the putrified cut parts. R. Tereb. Digetive. elect. lbj. vitell. Ovor. n. 6. Mell. Roar. colat. ij. Ol. Ro. ij. Farin. Hord. iiij. fiat Degetivum. Afterwards he ued this incarnative powder with the Digetive. Powder.R. Sang. Drac. iiij. Matich. Thur. Myrrh an ij. Gum. Elem. Bol. Armen. Alumin. ut. an. iij. mice, fiat Pulvis ubt.

Another. Another Hitory we meet in Glandorp Ob. 37. fol. 179. who relates of a young man who being about to take
out his right Teticle, in his work he made the Teticle to well and encreae into a great mas, hence ucceeded a great delirating pain. The inward Vein of the Talus being opened, and a Clyter adminitred, the whole Scrotum with the Teticle and all its circumjacent parts were anointed with oyl of Roes, and above thee was applied a digetive and corroborating Cataplam, the Tent being armed with mel Roarum, over which was applied Empl. Diapal. by which he was happily cured. We had two in this our City of Norwich which endeavoured to catrate themelves upon the very thoughts of not marrying, mitruting that if ever they hould have any children, they could not maintain them: The firt of which had taken out and cut off both his Teticles, but hereby occaioning uch a flux of blood as was pat his skill to top, he endeth for a Chirurgeon of our Town who peedily tops this and heals up the wound, and cures the Patient. The econd not being o couragious, but entering upon his intended operation, could not with uch dexterity act his part; but upon undertaking to take the firt out, he occaions uch a flux of blood as he thought would peedily have rewarded his bold attempt with death. Hence was forced to end for a Chirurgeon, who after having topt the flux did agglutinate the wound, and the Patient remains in very good health.

Another. Benivenius cap. 68. de Abditis, writes of a Monk being cured, who by reaon of his zeal of chatity but yet indicreet and les rational obequiounes did cut off his Penis; from which iued a great flux of blood, which required a great care and indutry to top; For here it behoves every of the Veins to be taken up and to be bound up, that their mouths might be topt, the which being done, the remainder of the cure was not very difficult until the wound was almot quite cured, and he healed.

Another. I have alo read of a Baker who upecting his Wife
for Adultery, to be avenged of her, doth amputate his Teticles, who hould he conceive, he was reolved not to own it, making himelf detitute for any uch operation, by his amputation, whence he hould certainly know as he conjectured by this mad trick (than which urely could never be a greater) whether his Wife was honet or not. This tory Acakia reports, Com. ad Art. parv. Galen. Thus have I run through all the parts of the three Venters; if any more tudious, and a greater lover of Truth and Learning and Practice hath had greater experience than what herein is offered, I deire that he would pleae to lend ome of his light. But I proceed now to the extream parts, where I hall briefly dicoure of them, and o conclude this my whole Treatie of Wounds both in General and Particular.

div.head: CHAP. LXXI.
Of Wounds of the Shoulder.
div.p:
AMongt the Joints may be reckoned the Shoulders, Arms, Cubit, Writ, Fingers, Thigh, Leg, and Foot. We begin firt with the Scapula's, where we may ee the Scapula moved by four Mucles, Serratus minor ubtrated to the Pectoral Mucle from the four upper ribbs; Trapezius or Cucullaris, the which does carry the reemblance of a Monks-hood; Rhomboides, being a large, broad, and quare mucle, and Levator Patientiae. Having given you the brief Anatomy of this part, as to the cure of thee being wounded, by reaon of the many Tendons implanted, here mut necearily be ued care and indutry, for thee parts are cold, and hence cold being their greatet enemy you are to defend them from it. As to the Mucles being wounded, you are firt to provide againt all ill ymptomes by breathing of a Vein and a good order of diet, and by Catharticks. And as touching the wounded part, here are we firt to top the flux, then to bring the wound to a fair digetion by Turpentine, Bailicon, the Yolks of Eggs, Saffron, and the like, then mundefie with honey of Roes, Juice of Smallage, &c. Fill up with incarnatives, as Aureum, Fucum, Balam. Lucatell. Arcae. and skin either with Diapalma, or Deiccativum Rubrum. If titching be here required, you are here to take deep titches, and ow fat, let through the weight of the arm the wound may fly open again, hereby tudying the keeping of every Nerve or Tendon untouched; over this titched part may you apply ome of the former agglutinative powders. And if you think it neceary, put in a Tent at the bottom of the wound
for the dicharge of the matter; ever oberving to give every part its due motion, and therefore to place it in its right Orb.

Hitory. Foretus Ob. 24. fol. 109. lib. 6. writes of one being wounded from the upper part of the back in the Mucles of the Scapula with a deep and occult wound, not penetrating the inward parts, but lying hid under the Mucles, whence a cavity was made in its bottom towards the lower part, and matter was collected, and brought thence upwards. The Chirurgeon not being careful and diligent enough, the lower part of the wound towards the Cutis did begin to extend it elf, the which gave ome upicion to the by-tanders, which made them to deire further help; he being hereto called for aitance, he ordered the Chirurgeon to put a pipe into the wound, and into, that part to make an inciion; the which being done, the matter which was lodged was dicharged, and the wound being kept open by pledgets until this was wholly removed, it was afterwards with eae conolidated.

div.head: CHAP. LXXII.
Of Wounds of the Arm.
div.p: THE Arm hath allowed it eight Mucles, as Deltois uprapinatus lifting it up, Latiimus or Ani calptor, Rotundus major, thee bringing it down; Pectoralis, this bringing it forward, thence called the Boxing Mucle; Infra Spinatus, Subcapularis, and Rotundus, thee drawing it backwards. Wounds happening in the bough of the Cubit are dangerous becaue of the great Veins. Wounds of the Cubit are upicious alo in repect of Convulion and Inflammations. The German Chirurgeons are very crupulous in medling with wounds of the Biceps, for that it hath but a lender beginning and ending, but a thick flehy belly: but of this more in wounds of the Elbow. As to the Cure here, if either the Veins, Nerves or Arteries be wounded, you have already methods hown how to cure thee. If any of the Mucles be wounded, to prevent pain and inflammation, and top the flux of blood, keep the body oluble and other parts in good temper. If the wound happens according to the Fibres of the Mucles, a good ligature goes a great way in the cure. If the wound be tranvere, you are to titch this up, leaving a cavity in the bottom of the wound, into which you are to put a Tent armed with a digetive to cleane it inwardly. Outwardly may you apply ome retringent powder and uch as may agglutinate, then perform the ret of the intentions as I have already hown you.

Hitory. Alexander Benedictus de Curand. morb. lib. 1. cap. 47. writes that he aw a young Nobleman cured of a wound in his arm, to which, for the preent toppage
of the flux of blood his friends put into the wound ome mall linnen rags, the which preently fell out again, by applying his finger to the wound: he knew not what hould make thee to come off o, upon the endeavour of his friends to top this flux, in o much that he bled afreh, hereby the Patient was freed from a Spam, and the eighth day he walked through his Chamber.

div.head: CHAP. LXXIII.
Of Wounds of the Elbow or Cubit.
div.p: THIS part hath four Mucles allowed it, as Biceps, Brachiaeus, Longus, Brevis. Some ordained for its extenion, others for its flexure. Biceps if it be wounded is not to be concerned with without care and skill. The German Chirurgeons do eteem wounds of this Mucle, which with Brachiaeus doth bend the Elbow, to be lethal. Wounds happening in its beginning are mot dangerous, thee parts being Tendinous and o of an exquiite ene, being in its beginning double. If the middle body thereof be wounded it carries les danger becaue it is flehy, yet hence may follow a flux of blood and great pain. The cure hereof therefore doth chiefly conit in topping this flux of blood, eaing of pain, and in digeting, mundefying, incarning and cicatrizing the wound, all which I have already hown how they are to be performed.

Hitory. I hall conclude this with a Hitory out of Foret. Ob. 19. fol. 93. who there writes of a Student who being wounded about the Cubit of his left arm, o as its whole bone with its Nerves was cut, whence followed great upicion of Spam, Carpus being hitherto called, reduced the bone to its proper ite and place, and the wound being titcht up, and agglutinative medicines being applied over thee, a Vein in his arm was breathed. In the econd viit Tents dipt in Ol. Hyperic. were put into the wound, and then above the future was applied this powder. R. Thur. Mum. Sangu. Dracon. Bol. Armen. Matich. an. partes aequales: afterwards the whole arm was anointed with oyl of Roes, and let a pam might happen it
was anointed with Ol. Lumbricor. after thee was precribed this following Syrup. Syr. de Endiv. j. Syr. Roar. s. Aqu. Endiv Cichor. Buglo. an. j. mice. Every day he had adminitred the common Clyter, his diet was thin, the fourth day were the Tents armed with a Digetive made of oyl of Turpentine and the yolk of an Potion.Egg. The fifth day he took this medicine. Rhabarb. elect. is. pic. gr. vj. Ca. mundat. s. Diaprun. olut. s. Syr. violar. j. cum decoct. commun. fiat potio. He waht the wound with Malvatick-wine. The eventh day Digetive.he armed the Tents with this Digetive. Terebinth. iiij. Ol. Matich. Myrtin. an. is. Cer. j. Thur. Matich. Sandarach. an. vj. Sang. Dracon. j. mice. Afterwards were the dreings armed with this. Terebinth. Mell. Roat. an. ij. Myrrh. Sarcocoll. an. ij. farin. Hord. s. mice. The eighth day he began to eat ome part of a Chicken. The time of conolidation drawing near, this decoction was ordered wherein was dipt Scarlet cloaths, and thee were to be applied warm to the parts. This was the decoction. R. Salv. Beton. Abynth. an. M. J. nuc. Cupres. n. vj. Hyperic. M. js. Caryophyl. s. coquantur in vini nigr. xij. ad quartae partis conumpt. After the wound was conolidated, this Bath was ordered, with which for many days the arm was fomented both for the trengthening of it, and alo for its better motion. R. Beton. Hyperic. Salv. Ivae an. M. ij. Stoechad. Abynth. an. M. j. Aneth. M. iij. Medul. Rad. Ebul. M. j. s. Capit. Catrati n. ij. coquantur in . q. aqu. ad med. Conumpt. by which method this Nobleman was perfectly cured. Horatius Augenins lib. 5. Epit. 2. writes that Marcus Antonius died upon receiving a light wound of his Elbow.

div.head: CHAP. LXXIV.
Of Wounds of the Writ.
div.p: THE Writ is made of four Mucles, Cubitaei Interni, Radiaei Interni, Cubitaei externi, Radiaei externi. The firt two do contract the hand, the other two do extend it. If the Writ or joints of the fingers be wounded they mut be kept half hut moving a ball in the palm of the hand, for if they be kept extended, they when they are healed will be found incapable to grap any thing. In thee wounds you are to follow the ame Intentions as are already hown. If any of the bones of the Writ be broken or luxated, they are to be retored, and you are here to bring the parts to their ite and natural conformation.

div.head: CHAP. LXXV.
Of Wounds of the Hand and Fingers.
div.p: COnidering the admirable frame and tructure of the hand being as the Intrument of Intruments, and its proper action is apprehenion, and this made according to our will by its mucles, we here ought to enquire into its Mucles which are of two orts, ome guiding the motion of the whole hand, others only moving the fingers. In the whole, the Mucles which are allowed to belong to the whole hand are accounted forty in number, four of the Writ, four of the Radius, three of the Palm of the hand, and twenty nine of the fingers. Of thee there are nine inflecters, two bending the fore-fingers and even the thumb; the extenders being twenty, ixteen extending the four fingers, in which number are included Lumbricales, and Interoaei, the other four do extend the thumb. Having given thus a brief dicoure of the Mucles of the hand and its fingers, here we are to note, that if any of its Tendons or Ligaments be wounded, that you dres thee in the ame manner as I have already hown you to cure wounds of the Nerves and Tendons. If any of its Veins be cut top the flux and cure it as you do wounds of the Veins and Arteries; and if only ome of its Mucles be wounded cure thee wounds as I have directed you in wounds happening in the flehy parts.

Hitory. I hall conclude this with ome remarkable Hitories. The Firt is of Foret. fol. 176. cap. 37. where he writes of a young man who received a wound in the left hand tranverly made by a word by his Brother, which wound pat through the hollow of his hand even to
his little finger. Inomuch as that all the Nerves about that part and Tendons were tranverly incied. The wound was titcht up in three places, putting tents between every future dipt in the white of an Egg and Bol. Armeny for the topping the flux of blood. But this would not top it, wherefore by the command of Foretus, who afterwards was called into conultation, was Tinder or burnt rags mixt with the bole and the white of an Egg, after which the part being rowled up the flux was topped. Thee Topicks were left on for near three days. The third day the retrictive was removed, then was applied a digetive made of Turpentine, the yolk of an Egg and a little Saffron, with which the Tents and Doills were armed, they firt being dipt in Ol. Hyperic. Magitral. Thee being thus dret the wounds were bound up, and all the circumjacent parts were anointed with oyl of Roes for abating of pain and inflammation, and finding the fourth day a heat about his hand, intead of this digetive the whole hand was anointed with nguent. Populeon. The fourth day he was purged with Manna or Caia, the ixth day he took a decoction of Senna and Rhubarb. The eventh day being pat, when all ymptoms as Fever, Convulion, inflammation and the like were no further dreaded, he was not ordered uch a thin diet. The eleventh day becaue the wound did appear very ordid, and was not well purged, it was inwardly waht with a decoction made of Roemary flowers and Roes boiled in Rhenih-wine, the which being done the aboveaid medicines were applied. The thirteenth day was applied to the wound nguent. Bailicon for filling it up with fleh, ordering the Patient to keep a piece of wood in his hand; but becaue proud fleh did arie about his little finger, this was taken down by the powder of burnt Allome. The wound being filled with fleh it was skinned with Empl. Grieum and Deiccativum.

I will conclude this with that remarkable tory of the worthy Adrianus Spigelius, who by a piece of glas wounded the fingers of his left hand, hence followed inflammation, the which not only poeed his whole arm, but did alo occaion a large tumour under his arm-pit, the which was carce uppurated, but there flew out bloody and faetid matter; hereupon he omewhat amended: this ceaing a Diarrhoea upervening, every thing turns to the wort, and at length he dies Empyemated.

div.head: CHAP. LXXVI.
Of Wounds of the Thighes.
div.p: THE Thigh is moved by fourteen Mucles: Poas Iliacus, thee do bend it; Glutaeus major, Glutaeus minor, Glutaeus minimus, thee aid to extend it; Triceps taken for three, this doth adduce it; Quadrigemini taken for four; Obturatores thee for two, abducing it. If the Articulation of the Hip be wounded, the Thigh bone mut be kept in its Cavity, which may be done by laying the Patient on his back, and applying fit bolters and rowlers. If the wound be large and made directly, here are you to top the flux, and then diget your wound with Turpentine or the oyl of Eggs with a little Saffron. Mundifie it with nguentum ex Apio or Mel. Roarum, fill up with Aureum or Bailicon, and skin with Diapalma or Deiccativum Rubrum. If the wound be made tranverely and large, here are you to titch up the wound, leaving an Orifice at the bottom for the dicharge of the matter; then apply agglutinative Medicines, and proceed in this cure as I have already directed you in Wounds made in the fleh. If a wound happens here with a fracture, I hall here produce you an example of the like collected from Ambroe Parey, how you are here to deal, and another from Glandorpe in his Spec. Chirurg. Ob. 49.

Hitory. The firt of Parey is of a Noble man lib. 10. cap. 12. de vuln. Sclop. who kept his bed for even Months by reaon of a wound which he received three fingers above the Knee. With which he had thee ymptoms attending it. As Intolerable pains, continual Fever, cold Sweats, Watchings, Excoriations of his Coccyx, occaioned
by his o long lying in his bed. He oft times fell down like an Epileptick man with vomiting and a continual Trembling, o as that he could not bring his hand to his mouth without help. His thigh was fractured both lengthways and tranverely with many mall pieces of bones, of which ome came forth, and others kept within, adhering to the Mucles of the thigh and of the legg, which caued a very large cold pituitous and flatulent humour about the parts, that they eemed as it were extinguihed and robbed of their native heat. All which being conidered there was but little hopes left of any cure. Yet confiding omewhat in the Patients age and trength, he firt made two inciions to dicharge the matters, which did irrigate into the ubtance of the Mucles circumpoed to the bone. Which thing ucceeded happily, for hereby a great quantity of matter was dicharged. Here was injected into thee inciions by a Syringe a good part of Aegyptiacum mixt with Wine and a little Aqua vitae, whereby the matter was compreed and amended, and the oft, looe and pongey fleh corrected, the Oedematous Tumour he reolved, the pain abated, and the native heat which was oppreed by the weight of the excrementitious humours was corroborated. He fomented the affected parts with this following Decoction made of Sage, Roemary, Fomentation. Tyme, Lavender, Chamomile flowers, Melilot flowers, red Roe leaves, boiled in Wine and in a lye made of Oaken Ahes, to which was added a little Salt and Vinegar. This fomentation having in it an attenuating and exhaurient quality, it was ued for a long while. After this was made frictions with warm cloathes uch as might cover the part in every place. For a hort friction doth draw more of humour into the part, than it doth reolve. Thee being to be applied about the thigh, leg and foot, hot as they are taken from the fire and then dipt in Vinegar with a little of Aqua vitae, by which
the humours were tirred up, and many waterih humidities were een to run into weats. The Tumour abated, the native heat eemed omewhat hereby to be retored. After which were applied Stuphes dipt in the aforeaid lye, in the which was boiled Sage, Roemary, Lavender, Salt, Aqua vitae Cloves, and the like. Then were the parts o artificially rowled up, that they did occaion no pain, and that with good ucces. That if one day were herein neglected, the Tumour did arie into a great Bulk. Thick doubled Linnen bowlters were applied to the inuous Ulcers by which the matter which was inwardly lodged was expreed. For the reolution of the Tumour was applied this Cataplame. Far. Hord. Fab. Orob. an. vj. Mel. commun. Terebint. Catapl. Venet. an. ij. fl. Cham. Melilot. Roar. rub. an. s. Pulv. rad. Irid. fl. Cyper. Matich. an. iij. Oxymel. impl. q. . fiat Catapl. Vigo's Empl. ine . was alo applyed, by which the pain was wonderfully abated, and the Tumour yielded hereto. Yet thee were not applied untill the parts were made warm both by the bath and frictions; neither were Catagmatick powders omitted. For fifteen days he took of a vulnerary potion, and beides thee particular frictions, the whole body was precribed to be bathed, by which the blood was drawn with its pirit to the parts. At length the Fever being abated, and the pains leened, he taking meat of good Juice for retoring of his lot pirits, in a hort time he was made better, and by Gods goodnes was retored to his former health, ave only that he did not recover the perfect liberty of bending his Knee. The econd you may read in Matth. Gland. Ob. 49. of one being wounded with a bullet, whereby was made a penetrating wound with fracture of the thigh bone: but this being long I rather commit you thither, than to fill up my Book into a large Volume by Hitories.

div.head: CHAP. LXXVII.
Of Wounds of the Legs and Feet.
div.p:
BEfore I come to treat of thee, it will be neceary to bring in the parts of which they do conit, which is bet done by Anatomy. And here may we ee the Leg framed with eleven Mucles, thus called. The firt of which is Seminervous, 2. Gracilis, 3. Innominatus, 4. Biceps, thee aid to be made for its flection. 5. Rectus, 6. Vatus externus, 7. Vatus internus, 8. Crureus, thee appointed for its extenion. 9. Longus utorius, 10. Poplitaeus, thee adducing it, and the lat Membranous abducing it. The Mucles of the Foot are 6. Tibiaeus Anticus, Peronaeus thee bending it, Gemell. or Gatrochemii externi and Interni, Soleus, and Plantaris. The Toes have allowed them 14. Mucles. As thus, 1. Magnus or Profundus, 2. Sublimis, thee bending them, the 3. and 4. extending them, the 5, 6, 7, 8. called Lumbricales adducing them, 9, 10, 11, 12, 13, 14. Interoaei thee abducing them. The great Toe hath four allowed it. Having given you this brief urvey of the parts of the Leg, Foot and Toes by Anatomy, we proceed now to its wounds, where we may by advice learn, that if the Knee be wounded, it mut be kept extended, for otherwie before the Patient be cured of his hurt, he may chance to meet with a contraction. When the joints of the Toes are wounded they are to be kept in their natural poture. Wounds happening upon the Knee or Leg are very perillous, thee parts being accompanied with many Nerves, Tendons and Ligaments, and being planted by nature as the depending parts, they are the more ubject for reception of defluxions of humours. Prevent
in thee caes the impendent ymptomes by revulives, bloodletting, cupping, ligatures, and frictions, ordering your Patient a thin diet, keeping his body oluble and the like. Here are you, as touching the affected part, to take the ame directions as are precribed in wounds of the arm, making a repelling ligature to prevent any fluxion of humours. If any Nerve be here wounded thee you may know by the pain and inflammation, or if any Tendon or Ligament be hurt, addres your elf to my dicoure of wounds happening in the Nerves, where you will meet with ufficient directions and medicines, as may anwer your expectation here. If a large flux of blood ucceeds upon the wound, top it alo, as you are directed in wounds of the Veins. Keep your Patient in a good temper, and oberve to follow the former directions propoed, and with Gods bleing quetion not your way of proceeding. But to conclude thee parts, take thee following hitorical obervations, the which may add to thy skill if the like accidents might happen to thee in thy practice.

Hitory. The firt is of Gulielm. Placentin. Prac. cap. 5. who writes that he aw one who was wounded in the Leg upon the minor foile, by an Arrow, which Arrow reached to the uperficies of the bone, and did not hurt it. The Chirurgeon could not defend the place with all his intruments, but a tiffnes eized the part, and a Fever followed, and within les than a month the Patient died hereof.

Another. Another of the like examples Foretus brings in Ob. 49. lib. 6. fol. 255. of one John Roan of Delph who had hurt his Leg againt ome hard matter, the which did contue it and tranverely wounded it; this not being much regarded, he applies a Womans advice for eight days. But when his Foot was affected with cold, the Leg began to grow tupid, and hence followed a great pain and Spam, the which accidents could no ways
be removed; hence followed a Fever, no medicines taking place, although ix Chirurgeons were in conultation concerned herein with a Phyician. By this pain he became retles, the Fever encreaing upon him. In his Foot and whole Leg did a gangrene arie, the which not being to be cured, and he being o weak that amputation could not afely be made, died of this mall wound.

Another. He hath another alo of one who was wounded in his right Foot, o as the whole Foot was cut off about the Malleolus. To the cure of which Carpus being deputed, the blood he uppreed with the white of an Egg and a retrictive powder. And as for awaging the pain, which was vehement, and for the prohibiting the Spam, he anointed the whole Leg with hot oyl of Roes, and the Inguens with the ame. Upon his thigh was applied a a defenative. In the econd and third viits he applied two pledgets dipt in Saliva, and prinkled with his retrictive powder, which were applied to the cut Veins and Arteries. And above thee two other bowlters dipt in the oyl of Hyperic. cum gum. then he rowled up the part with convenient ligature, ordering the Patient a thin diet. And for his Fever was precribed this. Syrup. Potion. End. j. Mel. Roar. s. Aqu. Endiv. Betonic. Cichor. an. j. mice. The next dreing being the fifth day the pledgets were armed with nguent. ex Cera, Terebinth. ol. Roar. Matich. & Pulv. Lumbric. lot. in vino & praeparat. then was adminitred a Clyter. Then Digetive.was the wound dreed with this Digetive. Terebinth. s. Mel. Roar. iij. Farin. Hord. ij. Myrrh. Sarcocoll. an. s. cum vitello ovi fiat unguent. Afterwards he received a more thick diet. Then was the wound waht with Malvatick wine, and after its thus being wahed was it thus dreed with the pledgets armed with this Unguent.following. Terebinth. iiij. Ol. Myrtin ij. Cer. vernic. an. j. Sang. Dracon. vj. Thur. Matich. an. iij. fiat nguent. Upon the pledgets was pread Bailicon. And
thus he proceeded for ome days; the wound hereby being filled with fleh, this cicatrizing Unguent was ued. R. Ol. Ro. Sevi catrat. an lbj. Terebinth. V. Cer. Litharg. aur. an. ij. Cerus. iij. Thur. j. fiat unguentum. Then the wound was wahed with Allome wine, and there was ued unguent. de Calc. And above the wound was prinkled a little powder of burnt Allome, by which remedies he was perfectly cured.

Hitory of a wound in the ole of the foot. Ob. 50. Foret. lib. 6. we read of a man who after having wahed his Feet, with a Penknife tudied to crape off the callous on hard ubtance which grew under the ole of his Foot, with which Knife he cut the part, the wound not being great; but hereupon preently followed a Spam before proper medicines could be applied, whereof he preently died.

Another of the Toes. Dodonaeus cap. 71. Abdit. writes of a Citizen of Florence, and many others who having received any hurts here, within few days to have died: For upon here receiving a wound or ulcer epecially in old people, he found them to encreae and pread and grow of a livid colour, and the Cutis of the part to be filled with black Putules, and then loing its ene to grow livid and black, neither doth it leave its preading quality until it hath reached the bones themelves and infected them. And if any thing eem harp, and you cut to prevent its preading, it till creeps further, thee parts being far from the Fountain of heat, and the heat which is in them being weak, and the parts very well replenihed with Nerves, the which being herewith infected do eaily and peedily communicate of their hurts to otherparts, whence it happens that thee being touched they do end forth the ame o as until the whole member be hereby mierably infected. The ame accident happened to a Patient of mine here in Norwich, an old Gentleman, of above eventy years of age,
dwelling in Suffolk, who having a Corn cut in his Toe, and neglecting it did not eek for help very peedily, pains and inflammations eizing his Toe, did alo bring the whole Foot into conent; and hence caued an inflammation in that. Coming to Norwich committing himelf to my honoured Uncle Cropps, and my cure, although the bet of remedies were precribed, yet this turned into a gangrene; we uing the bet of medicines to eparate this, yet all availed nothing, for within eighteen or twenty days he had his Foot and Leg o far pread therewith, that it got upwards with that peed that it did in a very hort time occaion his death.

div.head: CHAP. LXXVIII.
Of Wounds of the Joints.
div.p:
WE are now arrived at the lat part of our dicoure, which doth treat of Wounds of the Joints, that part being o mot properly called which is framed for the etting together of the bones for the performing of free motion. Now wounds made here, are made either by puncture or inciion, and thee do reach either the upper parts, or ele do penetrate into the cavity thereof. All wounds here happening are dangerous, according to Galens aying, they being endowed with an exquiite ene by reaon of the Nerves, Tendons, and Ligaments wherewith they are covered, lined, and enwrapped. Hence therefore upon wounds here received do generally arie an afflux of humours, occaioned here by pain. Afterwards inflammations, watchings, thirt, convulions, weaknes, and ometimes death. Such wounds as do
penetrate the Joint, by Celus opinion mut of neceity be allowed dangerous, for hereby the moiture which kept between the joints is let out, the which being dipatched, an excrementitious humour doth fall thereinto, being a thin ichorous ubtance much reembling that of Meliceris according to his opinion.

Cure. As touching its cure, if it be punctured, dres this wound as I have already hown in puncture of the Nerves. Keep the parts from cold and defend them from pain, for cold hardneth the skin, hindereth uppuration, and doth extinguih the native heat as Hipp. writes. If the wound be made by inciion, and this be large, titch it up, hereby not touching any of the membranous or tendinous parts; leaving a mall orifice in the depending part thereof, for the better dicharge of the matter. If the wound penetrates not the cavity of the juncture, dres this with Linimentum Arcaei, adding hereto a little fine powder of Frankincene, Dragons-blood, Myrrh and Aloes; and to an ounce of the former Liniment add a dram of the aid powders; above which may be applied an anodyne Empl. or Cataplam made of fl. Cham. Melilot. Roar. rubr. Sambuci, farin. Fabar. Hord. and the like; to which may be added ome milk with a little Ol. Myrtin. Roar. & parum Croci, applying thee, and all your other medicines which are to be ued, actually hot. If the wound doth penetrate the Joint, you are by Aquapendens's advice to apply a very drying medicine: thee parts being naturally very dry, and therefore requiring drying medicines: they being alo void of ene and feeling, and a great plenty of matter falling herein, ought and do requet very drying medicines. And for this ue Balam. Peruvian. Liniment. Arcaei, Balam. notr. Balam. Lucatell. cum Spir. Terebinth. are very excellent medicines here; always oberving to keep every member in its due poition: and when you ee the wound doth begin to
unite, you may order your Patient to ue a moderate motion of the wounded part. To conclude, if you are to Unguent.diget, this is here very proper, R. Terebinth. lot. in aqu. alv. s. mel. opt. iij. farin. Hord. ij. Alo. Succotrin. iij. iat unguentum: or for the ame ue may this be applied. Catapl. Farin. em. Lin. Hord. Orob. an. partes aequal. mel. q. . ad Catapl. piitudinem, dein cum frigidum evaerit adde Pulv. Myrrh. Alo. an. s. mice pro uu.

Hitory. I'le hut up all with the Hitory of a man who being hot in the joint by a bullet, the hot penetrating the joint of his right arm, and although earching with my probe I oon found how it was lodged, yet by reaon of the narrownes of the orifice, and the many Tendons, branches of Veins and Arteries planted thereabouts, I at firt did not attempt the extraction of the ame, yet very peedily conjecturing how to prevent all pains, I dilated the wounded part and extracted the hot, the which being attended with a large flux of blood, this was peedily repreed by my retrictive powders, after which the wound was digeted with this following nguent. Digetive.R. Terebinth. Venet. lot. in aqu. Plantag. ij. Ol. Hyperic. magitral. j. vitel. Ovor. n. j. Croc. s. over which was applied a repelling Cataplam made of Bol. Armen. Sangu. Dracon. Myrrh. Matich. Ol. Myrtin. Roar. with a little Acetum and Aqua Roarum imul mixt. At the econd dreing for eae of pain, and allaying of inflammation, the circumjacent parts were embrocated with Ol. Roarum & Ol. Chamaemel. till continuing the former digetive until the part afforded a laudable matter; then was it deterged with this following injection which was injected into the wound by a Syringe, made of Sanicul. Hyperic. Centaur. Abynth. Agrimon. Betonic. Veronic. Salv. and the like, adding to the Decoction a piece of Roch Alome, in its boiling, and when colated annexing to it ome Mel. Roar. The wound being thus deterged it was afterwards filled
up with fleh by the benefit of nguent. Aurei, Bailic. & Liniment. Arcaei mixed all together, and by ordering the Patient a thin diet, keeping his body oluble, and a good temper in his parts, and by the benefit of deiccativum Rubrum his wound was cicatrized and the Patient perfectly recovered.

Thus have I ailed through the bloody Ocean of Wounds, wherein I have like a faithful Pilot hown how the young Chirurgeon may teer his coure in the wounded Main, and how he may keep both himelf and the veel of his Art from the Rocks and Shelves of ignominy and lander. To which alo have I added the variety of figures which how both his ueful intruments and potures, accompanying the dicoures with the authority of hitorical obervations. And if any more tudious, and a greater lover of Art, and mater of Learning hall be pleaed to end forth a better light, I will oon call in mine; in the interim accept with kindnes that which is here afforded, and be not diatisfied with my method which is good, and capable enough of teaching every young Artit, how to procure health to the wounded Patient, and to unite the parts which are disjoined.
